business.start.para: The SPEAKER (Mr Neil Andrew) took the chair at 9.00 a.m., and read prayers.

subdebate.1.para: Debate resumed from 4 December 2003, on motion by Mr Ross Cameron:

motion.para: That this bill be now read a second time.

talk.start.para: —Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 9) 2003 has eight schedules that implement a number of taxation measures: providing a GST exemption for certain lifesaving courses; transitional relief for the new value shifting regime; changes to the personal services income regime to deal with personal losses and fringe benefits tax; providing an income tax exemption for sugar industry exit grants, where the recipient agrees to not own or manage an agricultural business for five years; ensuring that the foreign resident withholding rules apply to alienated personal services income; taxation relief for friendly societies that demutualise; rollover relief for partnerships that are simplified tax system payers; and amendments to the consolidation regime transitional arrangements. While Labor will support all these measures, the provision of a tax exemption for sugar industry exit grants in certain circumstances does provide an opportunity to highlight the failings of this government with regard to the sugar industry. Labor will move a second reading amendment condemning the government's treatment of the sugar industry and its failure to provide effective adjustment assistance.

speech.para: Schedule 1 provides a GST exemption for certain lifesaving and first aid courses. Currently, all education courses must be certified by a state government body to be eligible for a GST exemption. However, many lifesaving and first aid courses are not certified by the state government but by lifesaving and first aid organisations. This amendment will ensure that such courses are no longer subject to the GST. Consistent with the Intergovernmental Agreement on the Reform of Commonwealth-State Financial Relations, all states and territories have agreed to this amendment. However, I understand that the government will also be moving another amendment which will give it the power to make regulations setting out which organisations will have the right to assess these courses as qualifying for the GST exemption and that the government has not, under the terms of the intergovernmental agreement on the GST, obtained the states' assent to that amendment and that regulating power. The opposition will not oppose that amendment in the House, but we will consult with the state treasurers before coming to a decision about how we will deal with it in the Senate.

Schedule 2 provides transitional relief from the new value shifting regime, which is an important integrity measure that will prevent companies manipulating the tax laws by shifting value between associated entities that are not part of the same consolidated group. Value shifts occur when a business—the losing business—provides goods or services to another business—the gaining business—in the same group of companies and the price paid for those goods or services is not the true market value. The effect of these transactions is to shift value between companies that are owned or controlled by the same entity. This is usually done for tax minimisation purposes. The new value shifting regime ensures that these value shifts cannot be used to minimise tax. However, the new consolidation regime effectively delivers the same outcome by treating groups of companies as one for tax purposes. As such, the new value shifting regime will not apply to consolidated groups.

Making groups of companies comply with the new value shifting regime during the transitional period for consolidation would impose an unfair and unnecessary compliance cost on groups that have entered consolidation. The amendments contained in schedule 2 will ensure that this does not occur, by excluding most indirect value shifts from the value shifting regime where value shifts occur before the beginning of the 2003-04 income year for the business providing the services or if the income year for the business providing the services ends before 30 June 2003—the beginning of the 2004-05 income year. These dates ensure that companies that have consolidated some time in the first year of consolidation—2002-03—do not have to comply with the new value shifting regime.

Schedule 3 amends the alienation of personal services income provisions. The schedule aims to ensure that, where a deduction is not allowed for a business related expense due to the personal services income provisions, fringe benefits tax is not applied. Currently, a personal services business would not be allowed a deduction for providing a car to an employee, but would have to pay fringe benefits tax on the provision of that car, effectively double taxing the provision of the car. In addition, the schedule ensures that, consistent with the treatment of individual taxpayers, tax losses can be used by the individual whose personal efforts or skill generated the income.

Schedule 4 provides an income tax exemption for payments made under the sugar industry reform program to taxpayers who agree to leave the agricultural industry altogether. While supporting this amendment, Labor considers that a more transparent way to provide additional compensation for this group of farmers would have been to increase the exit grant and to have it remain taxable. If that was the case it would not only be more transparent but also be consistent with the tax treatment of other grants that might otherwise be applied to business purposes which are deductible, effectively increasing the value of the concession that is being provided to them.

The sugar industry reform package is the third rescue package for the sugar industry introduced by this government—all have failed. The latest package, announced in September 2002, promised $120 million in assistance, but so far only $20 million has been spent. I wonder how much the sugar levy has raised over this time? It would be good if the parliamentary secretary to the Treasurer, who I expect to be handling this bill, could give us an estimate of that when he sums up in this debate. I can only wonder because the government will not tell the public how much it is getting from this tax. It is yet another example of the secrecy with which the Howard government veils its budget figures—so much for the transparency that was promised before Mr Howard's election eight years ago.

To add insult to injury over the government's claim that it cares about the sugar industry, we have seen the sugar industry abandoned by this government in the recent trade agreement with the United States. I draw the House's attention to an article by Christine Wallace that appeared on page two of the Australian on Wednesday of last week. The article `Lobbyists, negotiators stunned by Bush rebuff', states:

quote.para: JOHN Howard's last-minute free trade deal plea to US President George W. Bush pressed for more beef trade concessions and any concession at all on Australian sugar exports to the US.
The blanket rebuff earlier this month to the Prime Minister's modest requests shocked the negotiating team—which recommended against accepting the deal—as well as the business groups assisting them.
Mr Howard asked Mr Bush for market access for an extra 30,000 tonnes of beef in addition to the 70,000 tonnes already agreed on, pressing for total extra access of 100,000 tonnes.
He also asked for a quickening of the phase-in period from 18 to 15 years and any concession at all Mr Bush could offer on Australian sugar exports to the US.

“It would've made the difference between a good deal and a line-ball deal,” one source close to the talks said of Mr Howard's requests yesterday. “It caught all of us off-guard that the relationship wasn't worth 30,000 tonnes of beef.
“If the Yanks weren't prepared to do that, it really soured our view.”
Senior Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade officials, from the foreign policy rather than the trade side of the department, overrode the negotiators' recommendation that the deal not be signed.

Some negotiators considered resigning over the Government's agreeing to the deal, which includes unprecedented price mechanisms that will cut sharply into the extra US beef market access negotiated in it.
Australia has resisted accepting similar mechanisms from Japan, and they are considered a serious backward step by experienced trade negotiators.
“We've never agreed to this sort of stuff before,” one party to negotiations said last night.
Participants consider political over-optimism the key flaw in the process, as politicians expected good relationships would deliver benefits.
In the end it was a political call by Mr Howard that a deal should be done at any cost, participants say. Mr Vaile is understood to have left the final decision to Mr Howard.

talk.start.para: —The member for Kingston would understand if the chair is a little mystified about the relationship of this to the bill, given that the bill deals principally with indirect value shifts relating to services. But I am happy to be acquainted as to the link and invite him to make the link.

—The bill also deals with a tax exemption for sugar industry adjustment grants. I will be moving a second reading amendment which talks about the government's failure to provide effective assistance to the sugar industry.
—I thank the member for Kingston for the clarification. I hope he understands why I was mystified.
—I perhaps should have moved the second reading amendment first. This article was followed up in a line of questioning to the trade minister at a doorstop interview two days ago. A journalist asked:

quote.para: Mr Vaile, how hard of a sell is the FTA going to be, given that it's now emerging that in the final week, your technical advisers, your trade negotiators were telling you that you should walk away from the deal?

speech.para: The trade minister answered, `I don't recall such advice.' He certainly did not say that no such advice was given. He did not deny that such advice was given. He seems to have perhaps had a short attack of amnesia. He then sidestepped the question and said:

quote.para: I read stories in the media that were generated out of the Senate Estimates questioning, but on the ground in Washington at the time I don't recall getting any of that sort of advice from officials. Obviously the government had to assess the balance of what had been achieved, against the balance of what we were expected to defend, in terms of Australia's interests—

speech.para: So obviously there are some things in this trade deal that we can all feel uncomfortable about and which, in the trade minister's own words, we need to need to examine in the light of the benefits. He went on to say—

quote.para: and then make a decision. Whether we take that deal or whether we put it to one side and maybe wait for another 20 or 25 years to have an opportunity. We decided to go ahead with it because we believed the benefits that were on offer overwhelmingly balanced up the issues that we had to protect. And when you read the text you'll see that very clear guidance given by the Australian people in a couple of sensitive areas has certainly been delivered on.

speech.para: This seems to me to obfuscate rather neatly. It is pretty clear that the professional trade negotiators—at least those with a particular interest in agriculture—did not think that it was such an overwhelmingly good deal. The next question that Mr Vaile was asked was:

quote.para: Is it true that the chief negotiator considered resignation in the final stages of negotiation?

talk.start.para: —Mr Speaker, I rise on a point of order. I am very much interested in what my peer opposite is saying about the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill, but I fail to understand why this dissertation on the free trade agreement has anything to do with what is on the Speaker's list.

—I indicate to the minister that it was also a matter of concern to me. But the member for Kingston has pointed out to me that he is proposing to move an amendment, and I have the amendment in front of me. I would be happy if the member for Kingston were to acquaint the minister with the amendment. The member for Kingston has the call. Perhaps the member for Kingston can continue his speech and the Clerk can acquaint the minister with the amendment. I deem that the member for Kingston is in order.
—For the benefit of the minister at the table, the Minister for Children and Youth Affairs, I will move the amendment now to clear up the point of order finally. I move:

speech.para: That all words after “That” be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:
“the House:
(1) notes that the tax exemption for certain sugar industry exit grants is one aspect of a $120m package announced in September 2002, yet:

(a) so far only $20m has been spent although the industry is in deep crisis, having been hit by adverse weather conditions, destructive pests and diseas-es, a rising dollar, rising interest rates and a declining world price for sugar;
(b) the small hope offered by the FTA has been dashed when the Government failed to deliver increased access to the US market, and
accordingly, the House condemns the government for failing to:
(c) provide effective adjustment assistance to the industry in any of its three sugar industry packages; and
(d) secure any additional access for the sugar industry in the FTA with the United States; and
(2) also condemns the Government for failing to:
(a) deal with tax issues surrounding per-sonal services income; and
(b) provide effective incentives for private investment in research and develop-ment”.
So, in the context of providing a tax exemption for sugar industry exit grants, dealing with the government's other failures in relation to the sugar industry is certainly a relevant consideration.
As I said, the journalist had asked the trade minister:

quote.para: Is it true that the chief negotiator considered resignation in the final stages of negotiation?

speech.para: Mr Vaile answered:

quote.para: I'm certainly not aware of that.

speech.para: Again, not a denial or a rejection, just `I'm not aware'—a convenient absence of knowledge I think I would call it. He went on to say:

quote.para: And he was—he appeared before Senate estimates answering questions, he's appeared on a number of platforms with me selling the benefits of the FTA. And it certainly wasn't apparent in the hours and hours and hours that we all put in to achieve this outcome in Washington, so I just don't know where this story's coming from.

speech.para: Obviously the chief negotiator was a bit disappointed and was not overwhelmed by the political benefits that the government wished to derive from the trade agreement which seem to have entered into its considerations in accepting this deal.
The third question on the subject that was asked of the trade minister at this particular doorstop was:

quote.para: Is it true that twice in the last week in Washington Australia's trade negotiators, the technical people told you that you would damage Australia's long-term agriculture objectives, damage Australia's long-term stand in the WTO and your leadership of the Cairns Group?

speech.para: Mr Vaile answered:

quote.para: Oh, look, we had a whole range of discussions on a daily basis right throughout the fortnight that we were negotiating in Washington and, Graeme, I don't need to be told exactly the ramifications of some of the decisions that we take in Government.

speech.para: Clearly, the trade minister was not interested in the advice of the expert officials. He went on to say:

quote.para: I mean, that's a matter for the Government. But I certainly took the view that, given the global circumstances; given the way the multilateral system was operating, given the number of bilateral free-trade agreement negotiations that had been concluded—not just by WTO members but in fact by 14 out of the 17 Cairns Group members or members that were pursuing bilateral negotiations, in those discussions—and I'll be quite honest, we had a range of discussions on what are the implications of making this decision or that decision.

speech.para: So he admits that there are implications. He went on:

quote.para: We took the view that the way we have structured this agreement we were not going to damage our reputation as the leader of the Cairns Group or as a lead advocate in agricultural trade liberalisation across the world.

speech.para: These of course are the minister's views, not the professional trade negotiators' views. The minister also said:

quote.para: And I've just come back at the end of last week from the Cairns Group meeting in Costa Rica. And my view was certainly reflected in a number of the conversations I had with my ministerial colleagues at that meeting, who were obviously interested in the outcome of the negotiations, interested in the disposition of the United States vis-a-vis the multilateral negotiations on agri-culture. And certainly there was not any anxiety or animosity as far as being generated towards Australia's leadership of the Cairns Group. In fact, if you look at the transcript of some of the interviews that were done afterwards, most ministers said that this was one of the best meetings that they had attended, that there was absolute commitment to our pursuit of the three pillars on agriculture in the WTO.

speech.para: Of course, you would hope that members of the Cairns Group would continue to pursue multilateral liberalisation of access to agriculture. He went on to say:

quote.para: We agreed to lock in next year's meeting in Cartagena in Columbia, and in 2006 ... I've flagged our intention to hold the 2006 meeting, the twentieth anniversary of the Cairns Group, back in Cairns in North Queensland.

speech.para: How appropriate, when it is the sugar industry's future that is at stake.

We know that it is not a completely free trade agreement—it is just a trade agreement—and that many barriers remain for Australian businesses wanting access to American markets. Despite pleadings from the Prime Minister to President Bush for any concession on sugar at all, not one extra grain of sugar will reach the shores of the United States from Australia. In fact, judging by the way things seem to have proceeded, we are probably pretty lucky that Qantas has not been required to stock up on sugar sachets when it is in the US using US sugar.

In addition, we have degraded our standing in respect of the WTO. It is multilateral free trade agreements that will deliver real benefits to the Australian economy. I think this agreement is going to turn out to be one of the big disappointments. There will be a lot of debate when people finally get to see the full text and can start to make more rigorous assessments about what the benefits are and—as the trade minister said in his doorstop—what the costs have been, what the things that we had to defend were and what the disbenefits are for Australian business. My uncomfortable feeling is that when we finally get to see the detail of that deal we are going to come to the conclusion that the trade deal is more of a disappointment and a lost opportunity than the triumph that the Prime Minister, the trade minister, the foreign minister and the Treasurer have been trying to put to the Australian community over the last 10 days.

Returning to this bill, schedule 5 will ensure that foreign resident withholding rules apply to alienated personal services payments. Schedule 6 will ensure that mutual friendly societies that are life insurance companies are subject to the same taxation framework that applies to other mutual life insurance companies if they demutualise. This will give mutual friendly societies that are life insurance companies the following tax advantages: any capital gain or loss arising from members giving up their membership rights and receiving shares in the new demutualised company will be waived, no capital gains tax liability will arise until a subsequent event happens to the demutualisation shares, and members will receive an enhanced cost base for the demutualisation shares for capital gains tax purposes that broadly reflects the market value of the shares. These amendments will encourage mutual friendly societies that are insurance companies to demutualise without suffering any tax disadvantage.

Schedule 7 amends the simplified tax system provisions to provide, under certain conditions, optional rollover relief for partnerships similar to that provided under the unified capital allowance regime. The simplified taxation system was a recommendation of the Ralph Review of Business Taxation and allows small businesses to opt out of some of the more complex taxation rules and opt into simpler streamlined rules. For example, businesses can opt out of the UCA regime and opt into a simpler depreciation regime. However, the simpler depreciation regime does not currently provide the rollover relief that exists in the UCA regime. Therefore, when a partnership changes hands under the STS, a capital gains tax event occurs. This is acting as a deterrent to some taxpayers entering into the simplified tax system, as it reduces their flexibility.

Schedule 8 makes amendments to the consolidation regime. The consolidation regime allows groups of wholly owned companies to be treated as one for taxation purposes. Under the new regime, businesses must make irrevocable decisions which affect the tax costs of assets or the ability to deduct losses. The amendments will allow companies to alter their choices up to 1 July 2005, providing greater flexibility and allowing time for companies to assess the impact of the consolidation regime. In addition, schedule 8 will ensure that where a company joins or leaves a consolidated group part of the way through an income year the R&D tax offset applies appropriately. Labor will support the bill.

talk.start.para: —Is the amendment seconded?
—I second the amendment.

—The member for Kingston has gone through in detail the various schedules to the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 9) 2003. I do not intend to address each and every one of them in my response to the bill before the chamber. However, I would like to focus on several aspects of the bill. In particular, I am very interested in, and happy about, the fact that we are providing an extension of the GST exemption for lifesaving courses. As the member for Moncrieff and a resident of the Gold Coast, I can certainly say that the exemption provided by this bill and the extension of the exemption to the various entities that are registered for GST so that any lifesaving courses they provide to the public at large are GST exempt is something to be encouraged.

speech.para: This government made a commitment at the outset to ensuring that there was a GST exemption on lifesaving courses. The original legislation as it was passed missed the fact that there were number of registered entities that also provided the courses which fell outside of the exemption. As a consequence, the amendment that comes before the House today ensures that the net is cast wide to include all of those service providers that provide lifesaving courses so that those courses are GST exempt.

One of the primary service entities in this particular market is, of course, the Australian surf-lifesaving movement. I am very pleased that on the Gold Coast there is very strong community support for the surf-lifesaving movement. I am pleased, although they were captured by the primary piece of legislation, that this amendment will ensure that those other service providers in that same market will have the exemption. Having said that, we need to encourage as much as possible people to be fully aware of and fully trained to deal with the kinds of emergencies that can arise. The surf-lifesaving movement—and indeed many other service providers—provides a very important role in the community in ensuring that all Australians, and particularly young Australians, are best equipped when it comes to lifesaving, particularly with respect to water. In that regard, I am very pleased that this bill will see that there is no disincentive arising through the imposition of the GST on such courses.

The lifesaving movement does more than simply provide instruction on lifesaving. It also encourages an ethos in life that promotes the benefits that flow from being involved in the beach culture, and certainly that is something that I am very keen to promote on the Gold Coast. I know as a member of a surf-lifesaving club that there are many benefits that flow from being an active participant in surf-lifesaving. From my perspective I know for a fact that the more young people that are encouraged and involved in surf-lifesaving the better the chance that they will be able to respond appropriately and adequately in a situation where someone's life may be at risk, particularly when it comes to the risk of drowning.

Another aspect of the bill which I would now like to turn to deals with the amendment that was moved by the member for Kingston. I notice that, when it comes to the sugar industry exit grants, the member for Kingston's amendment contains a number of fairly outrageous and hypocritical positions that the Labor Party has put forward in the House today. The reality is that the free trade agreement that this government struck with the United States is a positive benefit to the Australian economy. This free trade agreement is one that could only have been brokered by this government and not one that could have been brokered by the opposition.

talk.start.para: —It'd be a different one if we did—we wouldn't be on our knees!
—Order! The member for Corio!
—It is quite ironic that the Leader of the Opposition—the gentleman who, I believe, used the very regrettable term `a conga line of suckholes'—
—Get off your knees!
—The member for Corio will find himself out of the chamber!

—would come into this chamber and challenge the benefits that flow from the free trade agreement. The entire focus of the opposition is on the fact that there was not enough additional access provided under the FTA for the sugar industry. I notice that when the Labor Party come into this chamber they do not talk about all the other industries in the economy; they do not talk about all the other service providers in the economy and the fact that each and every one of these will be better off as a consequence of the FTA—no. In an attempt to be politically opportunistic, they come in and focus just on the sugar cane industry.

speech.para: It has been lamented on this side of the chamber—we have regretted the fact—that we were unable to secure additional market access for our sugar cane farmers. It would have been an ideal world; it would have been much better to have been able to obtain additional market access. But the United States democracy is subject to the same types of political pressures as the Australian democracy. We see it on both sides of the Pacific Ocean. The reality—and I certainly recognise it—is that it would have been a nigh impossible task, had sugar been included, for the United States Congress to pass the FTA. I know, and certainly I have read some comments that a number of congressmen in the United States have made with respect to sugar, that had sugar been incorporated into the FTA the whole package would have gone down.

The choice this government had was a simple one: it was the choice between scuttling the whole deal off the back of the inability to obtain increased market access for sugar, and recognising that, whilst we would have liked to obtain additional market access, we are unable to. Nonetheless, there are significant benefits that will flow to the other 97 per cent of the Australian economy that will benefit as a consequence of the free trade agreement. Recognising the benefits that will flow to the Australian marketplace, because we now have virtually unfettered access to a market of some 300 million people, this government took the correct decision when it decided to push ahead with the FTA even though we were unable to secure additional market access for the sugar cane industry.

I know that there are a number of seats in which the sugar cane industry is a very potent political lobby group—likewise in the United States. I fundamentally believe, and I know from speaking with other members on this side of the chamber, that when we speak with participants in the sugar cane industry and explain the decision that this government had to make, there is a recognition that, yes, whilst it would have been nice to obtain additional market access, it would not have been possible. This government, as the Prime Minister has indicated, has already moved to ensure that we will provide additional assistance to members of the sugar cane industry who would like to exit the industry to be able to exit in a way that does not leave them worse off. In certain respects this bill and those aspects of it that deal with tax exemption for certain sugar industry exit grants are just another way that this government is demonstrating a real commitment to assisting those sugar cane growers who would like to exit the industry. Providing an income tax exemption, as outlined in this bill, is a very genuine way that we are doing that.

The opportunism of the Labor Party in this chamber reeks. The amendment moved by the opposition is a very clear example of why the Australian people know that the Labor Party lack credibility when it comes to the free trade agreement. What do we know at this stage? We know that the Labor Party are opposed to the free trade agreement. Senator Conroy and the Leader of the Opposition have both said that they would not support the free trade agreement when it comes before parliament. We now see a bit of movement away from that position: we have heard certain comments and certain phrases that the Labor Party would like to resile from the position that they took. They know that the original position the Labor Party took was unsustainable. The Labor Party know that, if they were out there talking to the Australian public trying to sell the fact that the free trade agreement is detrimental to the Australian economy, they would be pushing it uphill. They know that they had a losing hand when they adopted a half-cocked position at the very outset of the launch of the free trade agreement in Australia.

It is the Howard government, through its close and continuing relationship with the United States, that is able to secure an agreement like this. It is the Howard government that has been able to obtain virtually unfettered access to a market of some 300 million people through the free trade agreement—market access that will be of direct benefit to 97 per cent of the Australian economy. But it is the Labor Party that would like to scuttle the whole thing because they say that the other three per cent is so important that we should forget about the 97 per cent that will benefit. It is the Labor Party that are out there trying to sell the idea that this free trade agreement is so detrimental to the Australian economy that it ought to be scuttled. It is an absolute joke and it highlights the fact that the Labor Party are so concerned with being politically opportunistic that they will jump at each and every chance to score some cheap points, in particular with respect to the sugar cane industry. But the Australian people and the residents of the Gold Coast know the benefits that will flow from this free trade agreement, and I am very pleased that we were able to secure the kind of agreement that we did. Yes, it would have been better to obtain additional market access for sugar cane, but unfortunately it was not possible.

The decision that the people of Australia will need to make in the coming months is whether or not they are willing to listen to and adopt what the Labor Party put forward as their policy position when it comes to the free trade agreement. They will have a choice between what the Howard government has been able to deliver and what the opposition are proposing to put forward should they be elected to government. Let us deal with that for a moment.

If the Labor Party were to come to government, I would be very intrigued to see how they would deal with the free trade agreement in particular. We know that the Labor Party leader, Mark Latham, has made the comment in the past that President Bush is the most dangerous president in history. We know that the Labor Party and in particular the member for Werriwa have made absolutely scathing comments about the very strong relationship that Australia has and that the Howard government has fostered with the United States. Despite this past rhetoric, on the day that the opposition leader was elected opposition leader, he wrapped himself in the US flag, suddenly trying to win back some of that support that he had eroded in the past.

We see the Labor Party on the one hand desperate to attempt to be friends with the United States and, on the other hand, when they believe that there is some politically opportunistic point scoring to be done, attempt to put distance between this country and the United States. People out there are not fools; they see the hypocrisy of the Australian Labor Party. They recognise the hypocrisy of a leader of the Australian Labor Party who in one instance says that President Bush's regime is the most dangerous that the United States has ever seen, yet a matter of months later is standing in front of the United States flag attempting to portray himself and the Australian Labor Party as some kind of political alternative in this country—a political alternative that will be able to deliver the kind of agreement we have got in this free trade agreement.

The Labor Party will never be able to deliver the kinds of benefits we have under the free trade agreement, because they lack the credibility to deal with foreign governments, particularly a Republican-led United States. The reality is that Republicans in the United States would never trust the Australian Labor Party, because whatever position they might have on Monday, Wednesday and Friday is a different position from what they might have on Tuesday, Thursday and Saturday. The Australian people know the position of the Labor Party when it comes to these types of matters.

The bill before the House, the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 9) 2003, is a fairly mechanical bill that makes a number of adjustments. The amendment put forward by the Labor Party is laughable and certainly ought not to be supported. It is in fact nothing more than a politically opportunistic course of action by the Australian Labor Party. The bill in the main, though, is a good bill that encourages Australians of all persuasions—in particular, I hope it encourages young Australians—to become active in, for example, the surf-lifesaving movement, by removing any tax disincentives that might apply to lifesaving courses. I commend the bill to the House but I certainly reject the amendment.

talk.start.para: —The opposition will be supporting the legislation before the parliament today, and I rise to support the second reading amendment moved by the member for Kingston. Before I address the substance of the amendment, let me make some comments on the contribution to the debate just made by the member for Moncrieff. We now know that the member for Moncrieff has joined the conga line! He is dancing around like his leader and his deputy leader. He is dancing his way through the debates in this House, like many members of the backbench opposite—lemmings about to go to the electoral slaughter—and of course they have the temerity to get up and criticise the Australian Labor Party for moving a second reading amendment to the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 9) 2003 that we are debating here in the House.

speech.para: For the honourable member's—how do I put this?—education, let me outline some of the things that we now know about the trade agreement with the United States. It is not a free trade agreement. That was acknowledged by the National Farmers Federation, which has had something to say about the sugar industry being dropped off the table by the Prime Minister at the last minute. The Prime Minister is now known as the Judas of the sugar industry. He is now trawling his way through the sugar seats with his 30 pieces of silver, hoping he can claw back some electoral support. He is out there like an old drunken sailor, throwing money about and hoping that he can buy back some electoral support.

The whole Australian nation knows about this so-called free trade agreement, which the National Farmers Federation now refuses to talk about as a `free trade' agreement. It is not a free trade agreement, because it has significant exclusions. Of course, it has a major exclusion which is very important to the state of Queensland, whence the honourable member for Moncrieff comes. We know certain things about this so-called free trade agreement; for instance, we know that the government has not quantified the costs or benefits. The last time it did that was in 2002, and the gains are quite dubious indeed according to that analysis. When we quizzed the government on the floor of this parliament about the free trade agreement—and, indeed, about why sugar was left out, which is the subject of our second reading amendment—the government indicated to this House that it had no current assessment of whether the benefits in fact outweighed the costs in this particular agreement.

We all know—the Australian people know—why the sugar industry was excluded from the deal. It is not in Australia's national interest, I would submit to the House, to exclude a major rural industry, an industry that is important to regional Queensland and northern New South Wales. It just defies logic to argue that the free trade agreement is a comprehensive agreement when you have left out of the equation Australia's fourth largest rural export. But we know why the deal was done: it was not done in the national interest of Australia; it was done in the political interest of the American President. The Florida lobby—the sugar producers—blocked this, and the Prime Minister, in a wonderful gesture to his mate in the United States of America, dropped the sugar industry off.

talk.start.para: —Oh, wrap yourself in the Australian flag!

—I will tell you what, Minister: we would never negotiate on our knees like you lot have. We would not negotiate on our knees. Why don't you stand up when you negotiate? Do not negotiate a deal on your knees that drops off the table an industry that is important to the seat of Richmond and all the sugar seats in Queensland.

speech.para: Let me tell you, we are not going to let this slide. The member for Moncrieff wants to talk about rank opportunism. I saw it in the phone call on Sunday that stitched a deal up between the Prime Minister of Australia and the President of the United States. If that was not rank opportunism, I do not know what is. I will be circulating that speech by the citycentric Howard government, with its lawyers and merchant bankers who want to do the investment deals under this particular free trade agreement. We will make sure that that speech is circulated in the sugar seats so that the sugar growers of this country, and their families, understand where they stand in the priorities of the coalition government.

Today I want to address one aspect of this bill, and that is the arrangements that it will put in place to assist struggling cane farmers to exit the industry. The Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry, Mr Truss, announced on 29 October 2002 that farmers agreeing to leave the industry would be given an exit grant of up to $45,000. As a condition of the grant, the recipient must agree to either not become an owner or operator of any agricultural enterprise or not become an owner or operator of a sugar industry enterprise within five years.

The amendments we are considering tonight will exempt from income tax sugar industry exit grants that are paid to recipients who agree to leave the agricultural sector for five years. These amendments will include non-assessable income grants paid to recipients who agree to leave the sugar industry but not the agricultural sector.

These exit grants are just one part of what can reasonably be described as a failed industry package. Barely $20 million of a $120 million package has been spent. The reason for this is a very simple one, and it is a common thread in this government: the government and the agricultural minister in particular would rather pick a fight with the states than work cooperatively with them to achieve an outcome for this very important industry. The Howard government usually picks a fight over money. In relation to this particular package, it chose to pick a fight over the detail of much-needed regulatory reform. The loser, as always, was the very industry the federal government claims it is now seeking to help.

The sugar industry has been in decline for some years. Industry earnings have dropped from $1.84 billion in 1994 to an estimated income of around $975 million this year. These reduced earnings have been impacting not only on cane growers but on mill owners and the thousands of workers who have been employed in those mills. That means that whole communities in cane-growing areas have really suffered. Since 1993, the industry's share of world trade in raw sugar has slipped from 22 per cent to just 15 per cent in 2001. At various periods over the past five years the industry has also suffered from drought, cyclones and floods and the ravages of disease and pests.

The Howard government has put in place three sugar assistance packages since 1998, and now we have a fourth. The 1998 package consisted of additional funds for research and development, funding to help the New South Wales industry develop an export focus, the development of a national export plan, the preservation of single desk marketing arrangements and the strengthening of anti-dumping measures. Mr Anderson claimed this package would save the industry.

The 2000 package was introduced in September of that year to assist the industry to deal with low world prices, low sugar content, disease and rat plagues and a series of bad seasons climatically. The package consisted of income support, interest rate relief and financial counselling and had a budget of $83 million. Only $60 million was spent, with most of the funds going to the income support component of the package. The minister, Mr Truss, claimed that the package would help ensure that there was an economically viable and efficient industry in the longer term. Despite two rescue packages in two years, conditions in the industry continued to decline.

The minister was again forced to seek more assistance for the industry but only gained cabinet support for that assistance after agreeing to fund the package through a tax on sugar: the infamous Howard government sugar tax. He also commissioned Clive Hildebrand to review the state of the sugar industry in February 2002. Mr Hildebrand, who was the Chair of the Sugar Research and Development Corporation, was asked to examine the industry with particular reference to its economic, social and environmental drivers.

The report made a number of key recommendations, including rationalising the industry into larger holdings and adopting a mill area or mill region approach, as these represent the profit centres for the industry; implementing a systems approach to all operations, particularly the transporting and harvesting sectors; and encouraging product diversification and improving the business management skills of the industry at the local level.

The 2002 package that flowed from Hildebrand was built on income support, interest subsidies and a regional assistance package aimed at facilitating change and help for farmers wanting to leave the industry. The package was underpinned by a memorandum of understanding between the Commonwealth and the Queensland governments which went to the issue of regulatory reform. As I said, the package was funded by a sugar tax imposed by the Howard government on the food-processing sector to raise the $120 million, and there was also a contribution of $30 million from the Queensland government. As I noted earlier, negotiations on the nature and extent of reform to the regulatory regime for the industry have bogged down and, as a result, less than $20 million of a package worth $150 million has been spent.

The centrepiece of the third package was to be the $60 million regional adjustment plan to be driven by local communities and an overarching industry guidance group. None of these funds have been spent, and that is the reason we have moved this second reading amendment today: to give us the opportunity to highlight the policy shortcomings of the government in the three packages that we have had for this industry since 1998. The evidence for the failures can be found in figures from Centrelink that identify the number of cane farm families on income support. These figures also identify the number of farming families likely to be encouraged by the Howard government to exit the sugar industry. The figures show that 455 farm families in the Townsville region were forced to apply for financial help, and 556 families in the Mackay area and 166 families in Cairns were also in receipt of income support. The total number of recipients of income support is 1,465. This was the third assistance package provided by the federal government since 1998, and now the Prime Minister has announced the first instalment of package No. 4.

These numbers make it clear that the government has not delivered the reforms needed by the industry, and the number of farmers at risk has increased since the first Howard package was announced. The government's failure to gain any increase in access to the United States market through the so-called free trade agreement compounds the problem. Putting the Australian sugar industry on a long-term sustainable path is a major test which the Howard government has now failed on three occasions. Cane farmers and farming communities simply cannot afford failure No. 4.

There is, however, some light at the end of the tunnel—but not as a result of the efforts of this government. The recent agreement to a package of important regulatory reforms, between the Queensland government, cane growers and the Australian Sugar Milling Council, is most welcome. These regulatory changes, while not the entire answer to the industry's problems, are an important step forward, and the industry and the Queensland government should be commended. I commend Henry Palaszczuk, the Minister for Primary Industries and Fisheries, for his untiring efforts, along with Premier Beattie, for getting sensible reform on the ground in Queensland. It is reform that has been opposed by the National Party and by the Howard government every step of the way. It is now up to the federal government to put in place a package of assistance that addresses inefficiencies throughout the whole production process, including the milling sector. Efficiencies in transport infrastructure should also be pursued.

There is a need for a cooperative approach across all tiers of government in areas such as the facilitation of grower exits and the consolidation of blocks into large, more economic holdings. It is important that the House supports the second reading amendment moved by the member for Kingston. In that amendment, we have noted the Howard government's failure to secure access for sugar farmers to the market of the United States of America. The industry has faced very tough times in recent years. It has experienced a series of very difficult weather events, it has faced an appreciating local currency, it now faces rising local interest rates, it has faced a very low world price for sugar, and it has been forced to battle with Brazil on world markets—with the Brazilian currency having been devalued against the US dollar by around 40 per cent. But the industry also faces a minister who has failed to deliver the reforms which are required to put this key rural employer and major exporter on a sustainable footing.

The Prime Minister can fix this problem with the stroke of a pen—but not a pen that throws 30 pieces of silver at the industry to mitigate the deep sense of betrayal the industry feels over the government's actions in dropping it off the table in the so-called free trade negotiations with the United States. It must be a pen that asks for the resignation of the minister who has presided over this deepening crisis in the industry. I do not hold the minister responsible for the actions of Brazil or for drought, and I do not hold him responsible for cyclones, pests and diseases. But this parliament and the sugar industry hold the minister and the Howard government responsible for the abysmal failure of policy in responding to these issues. The government is responsible for the failure of its own policy response since 1998. It is responsible for dropping this industry off the so-called FTA negotiating table. It is responsible for its failure to cooperate with the Queensland state government in reforms it now acknowledges—and the industry acknowledges—are necessary for the long-term survival of this industry. And it stands condemned for playing politics in those sugar seats since 1998 to suit its own political purposes. In doing so, it has betrayed the interests of sugar producers and their families.

There is no greater betrayal for farmers and their families than to know that the national government of the day sold them out. It sold out their interests. It would not get off its knees and negotiate in an upright position with the United States, and it caved in to the sugar lobby in the United States—the sugar lobby that was so vociferous in its support for George Bush in the critical state of Florida at the last presidential election, the state that won George Bush the presidency of the United States. It is little wonder that in the sugar seats they call the Prime Minister `Bonsai John'. They call him `the little Bush'. Each and every sugar producer and their families feel that deep sense of betrayal. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —It is my pleasure to sum up what has been a spirited, at times informative, at times entertaining and, regrettably, at times malicious debate on the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 9) 2003. The previous speaker, the member for Corio, is basically a very good bloke, but he has a capacity to let himself down in these moments of debate. I will address in the first instance the reasons why the government will be opposing the member for Kingston's amendment in relation to the sugar industry.

speech.para: People ask me from time to time how I think the Leader of the Opposition is going. The factors in my mind are not what I regard as the peripheral or incidental ones. People may form judgments about his previous language or his apparent capacity to hold different positions at the same time, but it is the big issues that concern me—in particular, the free trade agreement, which is the subject of the opposition's amendment. There are big moments—for example, deciding whether or not we join the US in a coalition of the willing and whether or not we enter a negotiation with the US over a free trade agreement—that affect the direction of the nation. They go to the architecture of the Australian economy and of Australia's strategic relations and defence arrangements. At these moments, I think it is clear that the Leader of the Opposition has been found wanting. Often it is against his best instincts, but his party suffers, in this case, from a fundamental ambivalence about the United States, which I believe makes them unsuitable to govern Australia.

When we talk about the attack the member for Corio has made on the government for executing this historic agreement, we ought to bear in mind that this agreement gives Australia access to 300 million of the most prosperous individuals in the world. Whatever anyone thinks about the equity of the situation, the United States economy accounts for over 25 per cent of global consumption. The United States economy has provided over 80 per cent of all the growth in the world economy over the last decade. The United States economy accounts for almost 50 per cent of the world's equity markets. Here we have an opportunity for Australia, representing less than two per cent of the world economy, to negotiate privileged access to the largest and most prosperous economy in the world, and the opposition are ambivalent about it. The opposition cannot decide whether they are for it or against it. The opposition are somewhat embarrassed by their initial reaction of total opposition. On the basis that we did not get a perfect outcome for the sugar industry, they said we ought to trash the whole deal and rip up this once in a lifetime opportunity.

I think there is one thing about which we can be certain: if the Australian Labor Party had been on the Treasury benches over these last few years, we would not have this free trade agreement with the United States. We would not have the extraordinary opportunities for increased income for Australian exporters, increased profits for Australian industries with imported inputs and reduced prices for Australian consumers. That is the bottom line as far as this free trade agreement in concerned. Labor simply could not have executed it.

The government is committed to working in partnership with the sugar industry to facilitate a sustainable future. Yesterday the Prime Minister announced that the government will help those in most genuine need with immediate income support. As a first step to help ease their financial situation, up to $21 million in income support will be available to eligible sugar cane growers and harvesters. The government will be considering further assistance measures after we have further discussions with industry on the way ahead. This support is in addition to the $80 million in assistance provided over the past four years to thousands of cane farmers and harvesters and their families. Since October 2002 the Sugar Industry Reform Program has delivered over $20 million in assistance to over 2,500 people involved in the sugar industry. The Australian government will now undertake further discussions with the sugar industry about further assistance, and we have indicated we are prepared to go beyond the previously announced package to help position the industry for the future.

I have to ask: what has the Beattie government done to help its own sugar cane growers? In the last 18 months the Beattie government has spent virtually nothing on assistance to the industry. Earlier this week Premier Beattie reached agreement with the sugar industry on a model for regulatory reform, and I commend him for that. But it is now up to the Queensland government to commence delivery of its long promised, much anticipated but slow to arrive $30 million in industry assistance. The Australian government remains committed to working in partnership with industry to facilitate a viable future.

In terms of prices, sugar is essentially the most corrupt commodity market in the world. Sugar growers in Australia today and into the future will have virtually no control over the prices they are offered for their product. They face huge competition from other countries in the world, particularly from developing countries like Brazil, and massive subsidies from governments around the world who are determined to prop up the industry whatever its fundamental economics look like.

While the government has accepted its responsibility to help in this transition to viability, it is also incumbent on the industry to have a look at itself, be prepared to make changes, and accept the fact—I am speaking as the federal member for Parramatta rather than as the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer—that there are many individuals around Australia who face risks and uncertainties in their business environments and do not have control over all their variables. In some instances, individuals have to be prepared to look at other alternatives, such as moving capital into other sectors of the Australian economy, if they cannot secure the economic fundamentals of their business or industry.

The Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 9) 2003 gives effect to several wider taxation measures. Each of these measures will refine the operation of the current law, improving the fairness and equity of the system. Schedule 1 to the bill will ensure that a GST registered supplier of an eligible first aid or lifesaving course is able to treat the supply as GST free.

I foreshadow that the government intends to move an amendment to add greater flexibility to this exemption. The amendment to the bill will provide the necessary legislative flexibility to allow qualifying suppliers of a first aid or lifesaving course to be prescribed in the regulations. This will allow the government to recognise relevant training qualifications as and when appropriate.

Schedule 2 to the bill modifies the general value-shifting regime so that, as a transitional measure, the consequences arising from operating under the regime do not apply to most direct value shifts involving services. This measure will help to reduce compliance costs for businesses during the transition to consolidation. The consolidation measure is an important business tax reform initiative that allows wholly-owned corporate groups to elect to be treated as single entities for income tax purposes. The consolidation regime will promote business efficiency, improve the integrity of the Australian tax system and reduce ongoing income tax compliance costs for those wholly-owned groups that choose to consolidate.

The general value-shifting regime is an important integrity measure, designed to prevent the manipulation of tax rules by shifting value between assets by closely held entities that are not part of the same consolidated group. This new regime is complementary to the consolidation regime and reproduces the structural value-shifting integrity achieved by the consolidation regime to those groups outside consolidation.

The measures in this bill ensure that groups that consolidate during a transitional period do not incur compliance costs associated with setting up systems to identify service related indirect value shifts, when those systems will not be needed after consolidation. The measure will reduce compliance costs for business during the transition. The measure will allow groups that do not consolidate extra time to establish systems to track service related indirect value shifts that may require adjustments under the general value-shifting regime.

Schedule 3 will improve the operation of the alienation of personal services income provisions. The fringe benefits tax law will be amended to remove the potential for effective double taxation of payments that are made non-deductible by the personal service income provisions, and which may also be subject to fringe benefits tax. It was never intended that such double taxation would apply. This schedule will also make further amendments to the tax law to allow an individual working through a personal services entity to deduct a net personal services income loss. This change is consistent with the intent of the rules generally, which is to put the individual earning personal services income through an entity in the same situation, had the individual been deriving the income as an employee. These amendments were sought by tax professionals and will align the operation of the law with the original policy intent.

The amendments in schedule 4 will amend the income tax law to specify the taxation treatment of sugar industry exit grants made under the sugar industry reform program. One component of the sugar industry reform program is Commonwealth government assistance for cane growers who wish to leave the sugar industry. The assistance consists of a one-off payment, a sugar industry exit grant, of up to $45,000. Sugar industry exit grants that are paid to taxpayers who leave the agricultural industry altogether will be exempt from income tax. Grants that are paid to taxpayers who leave the sugar industry but continue to carry on another agricultural enterprise will be included in assessable income.

Schedule 5 will ensure that foreign resident withholding rules will apply where an alienated personal services payment is of a kind to be covered by the foreign resident withholding rules. This will facilitate the efficient collection of tax on the payments. The foreign resident withholding rules broadly require an entity to withhold an amount from a payment of a kind prescribed by regulations. The government has not yet prescribed any payments. An alienated personal services payment is a payment received by an entity that relates to an amount that is included in the assessable income of an individual. These payments may also be of a kind to be prescribed by the foreign resident withholding rules.

Under the existing law, where an entity receiving a payment of this kind is a foreign resident, the withholding rules will not apply and the entity may be liable to pay an amount under the alienation of personal services income rules. In these circumstances the tax relating to the payment may not be paid by the entity that is outside Australia. Recovery of the tax debt may then be difficult. The amendments will ensure the appropriate operation of the foreign resident withholding rules so that tax is collected on those payments before they leave Australia.

The amendments in schedule 6 will ensure that mutual friendly societies that are life insurance companies and that restructure by demutualising can benefit from the taxation framework that applies to other mutual life insurance companies that restructure by demutualising. Some friendly societies that qualify as life insurance companies have restructured by demutualising. However, due to technicalities in the existing law, the taxation framework that applies to other mutual life insurance companies that demutualise does not apply to those friendly societies. The amendments will remove this inconsistency.

Schedule 7 will amend the simplified tax system to provide an optional rollover relief when there are partial changes in the ownership of a partnership. This rollover relief will ensure that a taxable gain or loss will only arise when a partnership ultimately disposes of its depreciating assets. These amendments will remove a barrier that may be deterring some small businesses from entering the simplified tax regime.

Schedule 8 amends the consolidation regime under which wholly owned corporate groups are treated as a single entity for income tax purposes. The amendments will provide additional flexibility in the transition to consolidation by allowing certain choices made by a head company to be revoked or amended before 1 January 2005. The amendments in this schedule also ensure that the rules governing eligibility for the research and development tax offset apply appropriately in cases where companies join or leave a consolidated group part way through an income year. I commend this bill to the House.

talk.start.para: (Mr Jenkins)—The original question was that this bill be now read a second time. To this the honourable member for Kingston has moved as an amendment that all words after `That' be omitted with a view to substituting other words. The immediate question is that the words proposed to be omitted stand part of the question.

subdebate.1.para: Bill—by leave—taken as a whole.

talk.start.para: —by leave—I present a supplementary explanatory memorandum to the bill and move the government amendment as circulated:

quote.para: (1) Schedule 1, item 5, page 3 (after line 31), after subparagraph (v), insert:

speech.para: ; or (vi) that uses, as the instructor for the course, a person who holds a training qualification for that course that is a qualification (in life saving) specified in, or of a kind specified in, the regulations.

This amendment to the bill allows for the making of regulations to recognise additional instructor training qualifications for GST purposes. Instructors with the required qualifications would then be able to conduct lifesaving courses that are treated as GST-free supplies. Prior to this amendment, it was proposed that the supply of a lifesaving course was to be GST-free only if the course was conducted by an instructor that held a training qualification issued by Austswim, Royal Life Saving Society Australia or Surf Life Saving Australia. After the bill was introduced into the parliament, it was recognised that a number of other qualifications may be relevant to the conduct of lifesaving courses. The parliamentary amendment provides the necessary flexibility in the law to enable additional qualifications to be recognised as and when appropriate. I commend the amendment to the House.
Question agreed to.
Bill, as amended, agreed to.

debateinfo.title: INTERNATIONAL TRANSFER OF PRISONERS AMENDMENT BILL 2004

subdebate.1.para: Debate resumed from 19 February, on motion by Mr Ruddock:

motion.para: That this bill be now read a second time.

talk.start.para: —I rise today to speak on the International Transfer of Prisoners Amendment Bill 2004. This bill seeks to amend the International Transfer of Prisoners Act 1997 in two general ways, but its immediate purpose is to facilitate the return of Australian citizens David Hicks and Mamdouh Habib to Australia to serve any term of imprisonment if they are convicted by a US military commission. Let me say from the outset that the bill itself is sensible and grounded in compassion, but the circumstances creating the need for the bill are scandalous and one of the most outrageous indictments of Western society in recent history. The International Transfer of Prisoners Act sets up a regime for the transfer of convicted prisoners to their home country to serve out any sentence. It is based on an international convention allowing a country to transfer a prisoner following a conviction by a court or tribunal. This bill is necessary in order to ensure that a conviction by a military commission against a person held in Guantanamo Bay can still activate the beneficial provisions of this regime.

speech.para: The need for this bill comes about because a military commission is not a court or tribunal and Guantanamo Bay does not fit easily within the definition of a foreign country. The fact that we need this bill highlights the legal no-man's-land for prisoners at Guantanamo Bay, and it highlights the shameful fact that they will not be tried through any ordinary court process. Despite Labor's uneasiness about the circumstances in which this bill has become necessary, we intend to support it because of its humanitarian impact. Noone could argue that, if Mr Habib or Mr Hicks are convicted, they should stay in Cuba to serve out any sentence. Because of our commitment to support this beneficial legislation and also our longstanding objection to the process that is being proposed to try these men, I move the second reading amendment that has been circulated in my name. It reads:
That all words after “That” be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:
“whilst not declining to give the Bill a second reading, the House condemns the Government for:
(1) acquiescing in the use of US military commissions to try Australian citizens; and
(2) failing to explore all options for the two Australians currently being detained by US authorities in Guantanamo Bay, to be tried in Australia”.

Before dealing critically with the scandalous situation of Mr Hicks and Mr Habib, let me deal briefly with the transfer regime involved in the act and the proposed changes to it. Currently, as I have mentioned, the act allows for the transfer of convicted prisoners to Australia from a foreign country which is party to a multilateral convention, which includes the United States, or with whom Australia has a bilateral agreement for the transfer of prisoners, which currently includes countries such as Thailand. The current definition of `countries' is being amend-ed by this bill to acknowledge regions whose status might not clearly be one of a country.

This amendment will cover the situation in Guantanamo Bay, where the land is part of the sovereign territory of Cuba but which is `a region under the jurisdiction or control' of the US pursuant to a lease. New subsection 8(5)(d) ensures that a convicted prisoner held in these circumstances could still be the subject of a transfer back home. It is worth noting as an aside that, although those in Cuba are clearly in our sights now, it is possible that in the future this extended definition might apply to those convicted in Hong Kong or perhaps Taiwan or other countries or regions with unusual or irregular status—perhaps even in countries under the temporary administration of other countries like Iraq and perhaps in the foreseeable future Haiti.

The bill also extends the definition of `court or tribunal' to include a military commission of the United States of America for the purposes of this act. If it were not for the fact that this legislation is being introduced purely to ensure that convicted Australians can be returned to Australia to serve out their sentences, Labor might have very serious reservations about changing this definition. If the government were seeking to change the definition of a court or tribunal generally or for any other purpose, we would not be supporting this bill.

Labor does not support the US government's use of a military commission process to try our citizens. This process is not independent and it is not fair, and any decisions in any other context should not be given equal status to that of a court or tribunal. But Labor does accept that these definitions and amendments to the overall act are only on the basis that the bill is beneficial—and beneficial to those two citizens who might most immediately be affected. It is possible that this legislation is entirely premature and may be unnecessary, as no charges have yet been laid, let alone there having been any conviction against these two Australian citizens, but it is important that the mechanism be in place. We accept that the process, even though it has moved incredibly slowly so far, may move more quickly if and when charges are laid, and we would not want to stand in the way of supporting these beneficial provisions.

Certainly if prisoners convicted overseas are able to serve out their sentences here in Australia, it will be of great benefit not only to those individuals but particularly to their families and support networks that they would then be near. For Mr Hicks and Mr Habib, if they are convicted and returned to Australia under these new provisions, it could end what has been more than two years of isolation and disconnection from their families back here in Australia. In this context it would clearly be wrong for us to refuse to support the bill.

It should be noted, however, that this legislation on its own is not enough to secure the transfer of Mr Hicks and Mr Habib, if convicted, from Guantanamo Bay to Australia. I understand—and the broad scheme of the act makes this clear—that a separate agreement would still have to be entered into between the Australian and US governments to organise the final details, timing and conditions of any transfer and the terms of any ongoing sentence being served out in Australia. Any transfer under this act, if amended, still requires the consent of the prisoner, the transfer country and the receiving country—and, in Australia's case, the state or territory where the prisoner would be held to serve out their remaining sentence. We do not know whether the government has sought the consent of the US for such transfers in the event that either of these two men is convicted.

I have moved the second reading amendment in order to make two general points. One is that ongoing detention, without charge, of Australian citizens of a legally indeterminate nature is an outrageous position for this government to remain silent about. The Labor Party condemns the government for acquiescing in this process—for making no comments, for negotiating no improved conditions and for failing to explore all of the options for Mr Hicks and Mr Habib to be tried according to a fair process. Our amendment recognises the two fundamental aspects in which the government has failed its responsibilities in handling this matter. Neither the Prime Minister as the leader of this country nor the AttorneyGeneral as its first legal officer have taken any stand on this issue. Neither of them has challenged, queried or pushed the US government for holding two of our citizens in these legally questionable circumstances. Neither of them has effectively explored other options by which these two Australians could be tried in Australia.

Labor want to make it absolutely clear in this debate that we condemn the use of a military commission to try those detained in Guantanamo Bay. Labor has consistently argued that the US military commission process is seriously flawed and there are inadequate safeguards against an unfair trial. Our criticisms include the lack of independence of the commission from the US executive arm of government, the absence of any rules of evidence and the absence of an appeal mechanism to an ordinary court. Given that the Attorney is sitting here across the table, I might say that we are also extraordinarily concerned that the US Secretary of Defense, Donald Rumsfeld, has made the incredible comment in recent days that, even if people held in Guantanamo Bay are tried by a military commission and acquitted, the US may indeed continue to detain these people. That is an outrageous suggestion, and I would urge the Attorney to speak strongly to the US government to say that that would not be an adequate way of treating not just Australian citizens who might be part of this process but people of any other country who will be.

So while Labor is supporting this bill for the benefits that it brings primarily to the two people who are most likely to be immediately affected, we are doing this only on the grounds of the humanitarian impact. The obvious alternative—to leave them in the conditions in Guantanamo Bay—is one that cannot be justified. I would like to take this opportunity to also talk briefly about the current status of the people who are being held at Guantanamo Bay and, in particular, Mr Hicks and Mr Habib, as I think it is very much within the context of this legislation. The US has specified that the detainees will be tried by a military commission, the rules of which were set out in a military commission order on 21 March 2002. The first detainees—nationals from Yemen and the Sudan—were charged on 24 February 2004 and have been charged with conspiracy for having:

quote.para: ... willfully and knowingly joined an enterprise of persons who shared a common criminal purpose ... to commit the following offenses ... attacking civilians; attacking civilian objects; murder by an unprivileged belligerent; destruction of property by an unprivileged belligerent; and terrorism, said conduct being in the context of and associated with armed conflict.

speech.para: Both Mr Hicks and Mr Habib are yet to be charged, although Mr Hicks has been declared eligible for trial since July 2003. We are coming close to a year since that announcement and comments by the Australian government that charges were to be laid imminently. Mr Hicks now has a military and civilian lawyer representing him, and we understand both Mr Hicks and Mr Habib now have some limited consular access. The US government maintains its view that the detainees are not subject to the ordinary protections of US law, yet they are also not entitled to the status of prisoner of war. They are classed as enemy combatants, leaving them with this indeterminate legal status—or in a twilight zone, as it has been described elsewhere. The precise nature of the detention of all those held by the US in Cuba is being tested currently in the US Supreme Court, and we expect that the government will pay close attention to the outcome of this case to see in fact whether they should have been arguing about the status of Australian citizens well before this.

The US is satisfied that its military commissions are appropriate and, as I have already referred to, its most recent comments indicate that the US may continue to detain people even if they are acquitted by the military commission. It has not provided any information publicly that confirms whether its intention is to charge Mr Hicks or Mr Habib under US law, international law or some other combination of known or unknown laws. The Australian government's comments on these cases has been very inconsistent and misleading. The government says it does not know what evidence the US has against these two Australians, yet in the same breath it continues to assert that it knows that they cannot be tried under any offences in Australia. The government also appears to have taken little action advocating to the US that charges be laid quickly and a fair process be used. In fact, the government has taken an entirely handsoff approach, allowing the US to proceed in any way it sees fit, and has expressed no concerns about the process to be used in the military commission.

I was staggered by a press conference that the Attorney gave in Washington on a recent visit, where after dealing with a number of other issues, such as his negotiations over air marshals and others, he said at the end to the gathered press corps, `I had better raise this issue with you, because it seems to be of interest to you'—that is, the media. This is our Attorney, raising the status, interest or process that is about to be applied to two Australian citizens being held by the US in these extraordinary circumstances only because the media has some interest in it, not because as the first law officer of the Commonwealth he might actually take some interest in whether a fair process is being used or whether he, like his colleagues from other countries, should be arguing for a better process to apply to the detainees.

That is in great contrast to what the British government has argued successfully—for the return of at least five of its citizens and for assurances about the process for those remaining. The British government made public and constant comment about the concerns that it had that British citizens were not going to receive a fair trial before the US military commission, and the British government was prepared to take some responsibility for the way its citizens were going to be treated at the hands of a foreign power—and not just any foreign power, but a close ally. Australia, although similarly established under the Westminster system of government and with a commitment to the separation of powers between the executive and the judiciary—all the sorts of things that the Attorney would be well aware of—seems to have felt no such requirement to advocate that its citizens should be brought before its own justice system.
