The Howard government seems to be willing to allow the US executive arm of government to act as prosecutor, judge and jury for these alleged terrorists, removing any pretence of a separation of powers and, in fact, consolidating the powers in the hands of the government not only to set the rules for the military trials but also to decide whether those people will even be released from detention if acquitted by the military commission.

The military order that sets up these military commissions that would sentence Mr Hicks and Mr Habib if they are found guilty of any offences they are charged with is obviously going to be an exercise of executive power, not US judicial power. This does raise a further question as to whether any continued detention, if they were transferred back to Australia following a conviction, would in fact be challenged under our Australian Constitution. As the Attorney would know, under our Constitution there is no authority for executive detention by the Commonwealth government, except where it is connected with a head of legislative power and is reasonably necessary for the purpose of its exercise. The government has declined to share with the opposition its legal advice on the constitutionality of this bill, but we believe that the obligation is fairly and squarely on the government to satisfy itself that these limitations can be overcome. We would like to raise, for the purposes of seeking further advice on this, whether the government is satisfied that it would be constitutionally valid to continue to detain people in Australia if they were transferred here under the amended bill following sentencing by a military commission with this extraordinary use of executive power.

In the time remaining, I will outline what the Australian Labor Party believes would be a much fairer and more just way of dealing with this situation in general, and these two Australian citizens in particular. Firstly, Labor believes that alleged terrorists must be dealt with quickly. Once caught and detained, they must be charged and brought to trial to face justice. It is the responsibility of any democratic government to ensure that the process that they face is fair and that they are not left in a legal no-man's-land. Labor wants to be convinced that all options for an Australian prosecution have properly been considered, based on the evidence available to Australia and the US. Labor will continue to demand that the government actively look at all options that are available, including the use of existing domestic or international laws, the option of applying international laws in Australia—even if new enabling legislation would be required—and any other options that would deliver a quick and fair process.

Labor will pursue options with legal experts—international, criminal and constitutional lawyers. The government does not appear to have aggressively pursued any of these options. Despite the government's assertions that it cannot take any of these options, it has not addressed numerous options that have been raised by others in the community and by experts in the legal world and that could be pursued.

The bottom line, Mr Attorney, is if Mr Hicks and Mr Habib cannot be tried in Australia, Australia must demand from the US a quick and fair process there. If they are eventually tried and acquitted in the US, they must not continue to be detained after acquittal. If they are tried and convicted, they should be able to serve their sentences in Australia.

It is a disgrace that the Howard government has had more than two years to deal with this situation and still cannot answer any of the following basic questions: what they will be charged with in the US? Will they be charged under US or international law? Is there any international law that could be used to try them in Australia? Has Australia been given a brief of evidence by the US or has it even asked for it?

The government has neglected its basic obligations to citizens detained by other countries. The government does not know if their detention is lawful. It has left them in a legal no-man's-land. It has expressed no concerns about the military commission process. It has not actively advocated to the US, unlike the Brits and others, for a return, for a better process or for a speedy prosecution of Australian citizens. Most inconsistently, Australian citizens charged in other countries with offences like murder, drug trafficking or other criminal matters, have got more attention from the government than the two people being held in Guantanamo Bay.

What Labor wants is that terrorists should be brought to justice. Charges should be laid quickly and trials should be fair. The Australian government should chase all options and pursue a trial here for Australians involved in alleged terrorist activities, if that is legally possible.

In any case, the Australian government must urge the US to charge detained Australians quickly, and prosecute those charges using a using a fair process, not a dodgy military commission. Australians cannot and should not be able to be indefinitely held without charge and, if they are charged and acquitted, they must not continue to be detained.

In summary, Labor supports the bill that is before the House because of the beneficial impact it would have to those that it affects. It is certainly a humane approach to allow people to serve in Australia any sentence that they may have received in any jurisdiction overseas so that they are closer to their family. We support that in principle, and we understand why the government wants to change the provisions of this act to be able to allow Mr Hicks and Mr Habib, if they are convicted by a military commission, to be able to serve out any sentence here in Australia. But we strongly disagree, and register our disagreement, with the approach that the Australian government has taken in this matter more generally, with its acquiescence to US demands and its approach to use a military commission that will not achieve a fair outcome. We disagree with the government's ongoing acquiescence and failure to push the US to charge and bring to trial the two people who have been held for over two years in detention in Guantanamo Bay.

talk.start.para: (Mr Mossfield)—Is the amendment seconded?
—I second the amendment and reserve my right to speak.

—It gives me a great deal of pleasure to rise today and support the International Transfer of Prisoners Amendment Bill 2004 before the House. It is always a pleasure to speak after the member for Gellibrand because it the highlights the definite divergence of views of the Labor Party to the strong position adopted by the coalition on these very important issues.

speech.para: If, later this year, people ask themselves what it is that Labor has to offer and what it is in stark contrast that the coalition has to offer, then they need to look at contributions by people like the member for Gellibrand. Rational thinkers in this debate view the member for Gellibrand as even loopier than the current Leader of the Opposition, the member for Werriwa, who has a very confused contribution to make on this issue. It is not surprising when you look at some of his contributions made in various debates in past years.

The Labor Party cannot have the best of both worlds. Like many other issues, they have walked the centre of the road yet again. In one breath they said that they support the government in this bill but they put reservations and caveats on their support. Again, it is a demonstration to the Australian people that the Labor Party is weak on border protection and weak on national security issues, including terrorism.

This government has provided for certainty as best as possible for the Australian people. This government is about bringing terrorism under the best control that it possibly can, with all of the unknowns that are involved in the debate. It has been a government that has provided more definite legislation for strong and determined action to deal with the evil of terrorism we face. The Labor Party stands in stark contrast in this debate as it has in many of the debates on terrorism in this House over the last two years. It is something the people will take into consideration when they weigh their views about whom that they think will be able to lead this country prosperously and safely into the next decade.

This bill amends the International Transfer of Prisoners Act to facilitate the transfer to Australia of any Australian citizen detained at Guantanamo Bay who may subsequently be convicted and sentenced to a term of imprisonment by a military commission of the USA. It also applies the act to areas that may have an unusual status. Specifically, the bill amends the act to expand the definition of `transfer country' under subsection 4(1) to include a reference to `or a region'. It clarifies the meaning of a court or tribunal for the purposes of the act, particularly in terms of the definition of `sentence of imprisonment' contained in section 4(1) of the act. It also clarifies and expands the list of areas deemed part of a transfer country. In addition, it inserts a new subsection 8(6) to clarify that a region may be deemed a transfer country for the purposes of the act.

The amendments will increase the flexibility and application of the international transfer of prisoners scheme as it applies to Australia, allowing the scheme to apply to a broader range of areas. This will also allow the act to apply to a larger number of Australian citizens or persons with community links to Australia who are imprisoned in foreign countries. Conversely, the amendments will also allow for a larger number of foreign nationals imprisoned in Australia to return to their home countries, thereby providing an economic benefit to Australia.

The increased flexibility and application will also provide increased community benefits; reduce the impact on Australian families who have family members imprisoned in areas that the act currently does not apply to; and reduce the impact on Australian citizens imprisoned overseas who may suffer due to the cultural and language differences they experience in a foreign country. Returning such prisoners to Australia increases their chances of rehabilitation not only by enabling the prisoners to take part in prison programs and services that they may not have access to in a foreign country but also by enabling the prisoners to have more contact with their families. The amendments will result in the expansion of an established legislative scheme under which Mr David Hicks and Mr Habib could be transferred to Australia to serve a prison sentence imposed by a US military commission.

It is important as part of this debate to canvass some of the views that this government has more generally in relation to terrorism, and I alluded to some of those in my opening remarks. It is pertinent to put on the public record today that this government places a very high priority on combating the threat that terrorism poses to Australians and our interests not only at home but also abroad. We have made good progress, but we must not be complacent. The fight against terrorism will be long and difficult. There is no doubt about that.

Collectively, countries in the region have disrupted the Jemaah Islamiah network through the capture and detention of well over 200 JI members. The joint Australian-Indonesian investigation of the Bali bombings has resulted in 32 convictions to date and has yielded a great deal of useful intelligence about JI's operations in the region. But we have not disabled JI. Key operatives are still at large and the organisation remains highly resilient and committed to its cause.

Regrettably, South-East Asia remains a front line in the fight against terrorism. We assess that more attacks which threaten the safety and security of our citizens are inevitable. The Marriott Hotel bombing in Jakarta in August last year, the November 2003 bombings in Istanbul and the most recent horrific attacks in Karbala and Baghdad are tragic reminders that terrorist threats are not theoretical.

It is important to recognise the international nature of the threat. Terrorist groups are cooperating across regions, transiting borders and using one country to train in, another to raise funds in and another to seek refuge in. They are working together to maximise the impact of their activities. The government has been responding internationally. Australia has signed nine bilateral counter-terrorism MOUs with regional countries, supporting practical, operational level cooperation.

The Regional Ministerial Meeting on Counter-Terrorism that Mr Downer co-chaired with his Indonesian counterpart in Bali on 4 and 5 February identified ways of strengthening the region's counter-terrorism effort in the critical areas of law enforcement, information sharing and legal frameworks. At the Bali meeting, Australia and Indonesia also announced the establishment of the Indonesia Centre for Law Enforcement Cooperation. The centre, which will have both a capacity-building and operational support mandate, will be developed as a resource for the entire region in the fight against transnational crime, with a focus on counter-terrorism.

The threat we are facing cannot be negotiated away and its defeat will require resolve and commitment over the long term. In this debate it is plain for the Australian people to see that the only government with the determination to meet this serious threat head on is this government. This government has a proven track record in the fight against terrorism. We have a proven track record in putting forward legislation that is needed to enable our intelligence and law enforcement bodies to deal with the real threat that is posed, now on a daily basis, in this new world to every Australian.

But, as I say, it is important for the Australian people to consider alternatives. When you look at the alternative that is provided by the Australian Labor Party, you see that it stands in stark contrast to the position the government has taken not only in relation to the legislation before the House today but also in previous debates in this House. I want to refer specifically to some of the positions—and I say `positions' plural—that were taken by the Leader of the Opposition in this debate when it was discussed in the media only a week ago. Firstly, the Age of 21 February says:

quote.para: Labor leader Mark Latham says the Opposition would support retrospective counter-terrorism legislation to enable the Government to try Guantanamo Bay detainees David Hicks and Mamdouh Habib in Australia.

speech.para: That was the first report of what the member for Werriwa's actions would be. But we know that he has many positions on many issues, sometimes on the same day. We know that the Treasurer's assessment of the member for Werriwa is quite right—his mood can quite quickly change from Lateline to lunchtime. The member for Werriwa has this capacity to lead by Google search. He is the Google search leader. He has the Google style of leadership which sees new ideas discovered and rediscovered each day. The position that he takes on an issue on a particular day depends on the results of his Google search. An interesting article in the Weekend Australian on Saturday 21 February noted:

quote.para: MARK Latham was backing away last night from earlier suggestions that he would support retrospective legislation to have two Australians at Guantanamo Bay brought home for trial.
Yesterday morning, Mr Latham said terror suspects David Hicks and Mamdouh Habib should be tried in Australia and Labor would support any legislation to make it possible.
This would mean backdating legislation passed in 2002 to make terrorism an offence at the time the two men are alleged to have trained with al-Qa'ida in Afghanistan.
Mr Latham's office refused last night to confirm the Opposition would support backdating the legislation to allow the two men to face court in Australia.

speech.para: It went on to say:

quote.para: Left-wing Labor front-bencher and lawyer Daryl Melham told The Weekend Australian last month that retrospective legislation could be unconstitutional.

speech.para: There was a very interesting contribution in the Courier Mail on 23 February by Dennis Atkins, which said:

quote.para: MARK Latham blundered last Friday and it is telling on two levels.
The story of the day was that the British Government had negotiated the repatriation of five of its nationals held at Guantamo Bay camp ...

speech.para: It went on further to say:

quote.para: Latham was reported as saying he and Labor stood ready to back retrospective laws which would bring Hicks and Habib home. Now Labor is backtracking quickly.

speech.para: There is a familiar tone to all this. It goes on to say:

quote.para: Latham's spokeswoman says Latham said no such thing, rather he offered to talk to the Government about laws which could assist the pair's return.
On the general question of whether the Opposition Leader supports retrospectivity for criminal offences, his office says “no”.
And now shadow attorney-general Nicola Roxon says retrospectivity could be considered even though it would be “definitely unusual”.

speech.para: The article went on to say:

quote.para: This confusion raises a question about Latham. Either he was not thinking carefully enough or he was playing fast and loose politics.

Some of Latham's colleagues are worried about their new leader when it comes to attention to detail, claiming he is eloquent and interesting applying the broad brush strokes but disturbingly uncaring about the finer points of policy.

speech.para: The article went on to say:

quote.para: The problem we face is that new Labor under Latham is a hide-and-seek Labor. Federal politicians, especially leaders, allow basic accountability by releasing transcripts of media interviews—it always happened when Kim Beazley and Simon Crean led Labor.
But Latham is picking and choosing what is released. There are no transcripts available for last Friday, so we don't really know what the Opposition Leader was saying.

Apparently he criticised the Government for not having laws which could allow Hicks and Habib to be brought back to Australia, leaving the way open for his remarks to be interpreted as support for retrospective legislation.
The ABC, sensing a good story, sent a radio reporter out to quiz him further.
It is understood every question was framed in the context of retrospectivity and, while Latham did not use that word, he did not once repudiate the concept.

speech.para: This is the important part:

quote.para: Now that he's in hot water, his office is ducking and weaving. This is not new politics. It's just the same old song.

speech.para: I say not only to the people of Dickson but to all Australians that later this year they will face a very stark and distinct contrast. They will be faced with an opposition that is divided, weak and incapable of making decisions which are in the national interest in the long-term support of this country. On the other hand, they will be faced with a government that has a proven track record, not only in its ability to secure a safe and caring environment for Australians and to provide economic support for Australian families and small businesses, but also more generally in areas like protecting Australians from the very real terrorism threat that faces this country and, importantly, protecting our borders.

You only need to look at the Labor Party's track record and some of the hypocrites that sit on that front bench opposite to know what a Labor government would bring to this country. Make no mistake about it—the people in Dickson and right across this country face a very important decision. While some of the Labor Party's rhetoric and third-rate style may appeal to some people in our community, the reality is that when you look at the substance and the policies behind the rhetoric and the rubbish you soon realise that their promises are hollow and that a complete fraud is being delivered to the Australian people by the opposition leader and the Labor Party in general.

I take the opportunity today to commend this bill to the House. I commend the Attorney-General on his strong stance on behalf of this government in relation to terrorism legislation. I condemn not only the shadow Attorney-General but also the opposition leader for their perceived efforts to support the Australian people through their continually weak, pathetic, wishy-washy, flip-flop—however you want to describe it—stance on these bills. It is time to condemn the Australian Labor Party for their continually soft policy in relation to terrorism and border protection.

talk.start.para: —That was an interesting contribution. The member for Dickson brought everything to the chamber except a copy of the International Transfer of Prisoners Amendment Bill 2004, obviously. He forgot the bill. He decided to contribute to the debate, but he forgot to actually bring a copy of the bill that is being debated. The bill that we are discussing today, if I can remind the House, is about the capacity of the Commonwealth to transfer David Hicks and Mamdouh Habib back to Australia if convicted by a military tribunal of the United States.

speech.para: The member for Dickson should also understand that we support the International Transfer of Prisoners Amendment Bill 2004 but we move an amendment. We support the bill because it is beneficial, as the shadow Attorney-General indicated, but we also have to discuss the context in which we find this bill being introduced to the House. I will go to some of the specifics because they were absent from the last speaker's comments. The bill looks to provide the legal capacity to have two Australian citizens who are currently detained indefinitely without charge in Guantanamo Bay, Cuba, returned to Australia if ultimately charged. Therefore there have had to be amendments made to the International Transfer of Prisoners Act 1997, and we certainly support the amendment to the 1997 act to ensure that those prisoners can be returned.

Currently the act allows for convicted prisoners to be transferred to Australia from countries that are either a party to the multilateral convention, which also includes the United States, or with whom Australia has a bilateral agreement for the transfer of prisoners, such as Thailand. The definition of `countries' is presently restricted to colonies, territories or protectorates of those countries, as well as territories for whose international relations those countries are responsible. To be eligible for transfer under the act currently, a prisoner must have been sentenced by a court or tribunal—not a military court but a court or a tribunal—in the foreign country. The act also requires dual criminality—that is, actions being criminal both here and in the overseas jurisdiction. However, the Attorney-General does have the discretion to exempt such a requirement, as would be the case in the instances to which we refer today. Any transfer must be consented to by the prisoner, the transferring country and the receiving country.

That is the act we have in place today, and the bill before us seeks to amend it to ensure that the definition of `country', given the unique nature of the region of Guantanamo Bay—the fact that it is under United States control although in a foreign land—will provide for a new paragraph D at section 4: `a foreign country exercises jurisdiction or control over the region'. In other words, the definition of `country' will be broadened to apply to Guantanamo Bay under the 1997 act. Further to that, the bill also provides that `a military commission of the United States of America' is taken to be a court or tribunal for the purposes of the act.

We support this bill because it potentially benefits two Australian citizens, but it is certainly not an easy bill to support in its construction, because we have had to accede to a military commission of the United States being seen to be a court or tribunal. That is not a preferred position for the Labor Party to take in relation to this matter. We do so because of the potential beneficial consequences to Australian citizens abroad who are detained indefinitely. However, it is unfortunate that it has come to this, because, as the shadow Attorney-General indicated, there has really been no effort by this government to pursue the options raised by international lawyers of great expertise in the areas of international and criminal law to find ways to ensure that detainees, like those of Denmark, Great Britain and Russia, who have been released from Guantanamo Bay, are charged and tried in their own country. There has been no effort by this government to properly pursue an option which would allow for two Australian citizens to be tried and, if convicted, imprisoned in Australia and, if not convicted, released. That is not something that has in any way been vigorously pursued by this government.

Like the free trade agreement, unfortunately, when it comes to negotiating with the United States, this government does it on its knees. It bargains on its knees because, in effect, it defers to the President of the United States. John Howard's great mate George Bush calls the shots when it comes to the sugar industry in Australia and clearly he also calls the shots when it comes to Australians detained without charge in Cuba. I think it is a sad case when we see other countries finding arrangements with the United States to have their prisoners released to them, while Australia—part of the so-called coalition of the willing, as the Prime Minister likes to boast—cannot even get two detainees out of what is arguably an unlawful prison. The fact is that there is an arguable case—a probable likelihood—that the detention of those prisoners is illegal under international law. Indeed, it is not just the Labor Party who question the legality of the detention; it is questioned by many. I would like to quote a person who said:

quote.para: David Hicks cannot get a fair trial under the commission rules and procedures that have been established currently to try the detainees down in Guantanamo Bay.

speech.para: Who was that said by? It was not said by a member of the Labor Party and it was not said by an international jurist; it was said by a military officer of the United States: Major Michael Mori, the officer who has been charged with the responsibility of representing David Hicks. Clearly he is not there only to represent the interests of David Hicks; he has, I think quite rightly, pointed to the fact that the military tribunal is unfair because it does not provide for the basic rights of natural justice to apply.

One would argue that it is more likely that Saddam Hussein will receive a fairer trial under the Geneva convention than will David Hicks and Mamdouh Habib. That is the reality. For all that the government like to attack the evil former Iraqi regime and its leader Saddam Hussein—and they are quite right to do so; Saddam Hussein did preside over an autocratic, violent, repressive regime—the leader of that regime will in fact be treated more fairly, more justly and no doubt more expeditiously—given the fact that there is an election in the United States in November, I am sure there will be a show trial soon for us to watch—with recourse to more legal rights than the two Australian citizens who have been detained for two years without charge in a prison in Cuba. That is the situation we find ourselves in, and this government have not lifted a finger to concern themselves with this matter.

I know some are concerned; in fact, the member for Dickson did say, `This is all about the fact that we are against terrorists and the Labor Party are weak on terrorism.' I remind the member for Dickson that, while terrorism is certainly a threat to our citizens, it is also a threat to our tenets of democracy and we have to protect both. We have to protect our democracy and our citizens. It is not enough to argue that we can throw democratic principles and natural justice out the window because we are in a world combating terrorism. It is not enough to argue on that ground, because once we do that we have surrendered already to those who do not wish us to have a democratic and free society. So we have to be vigilant in our protection of both our citizens and the lifestyle and laws that they enjoy—which is not going to be helped, I would contend, by the government's failure to see that the detention of David Hicks and Mamdouh Habib is not fair.

As I have indicated, we do support the bill, because it provides for the possible transfer of prisoners upon conviction; but we have some serious concerns. The amendment moved by the shadow Attorney-General condemns the government's failure to pursue real options in order to find a better way to have two Australian citizens tried. It condemns the government for failing to negotiate on behalf of this country a proper process for our citizens when, in contrast, other sovereign states have already had their citizens released.

If the relationship that the Prime Minister says he has with the President of the United States is so cosy then why is it only one way? It may well be cosy but it is one-way traffic when it comes to looking after the interests of the two nations. In every circumstance, the United States wins hands down—for example, in the free trade agreement. We concede that the free trade agreement is not a free trade agreement; indeed it potentially damages many of our industries. We have not yet seen the actual agreement, of course, but we are waiting to see it; one day we will get to see it. We know the concerns of the sugar industry were raised. I know it is off the subject of the bill but it is a comparable, parallel point. The point the sugar industry had about the government not pursuing its economic interests—or indeed our interests as a nation in terms of employment and ensuring that our industries prosper—is parallel to the fact that this government fails also to protect its citizens from being held in detention without charge.

I think most Australians are really questioning this process, when neither of the detainees have even been charged with an offence after two years of detention. Whilst it has been some time—I think it was mid last year—since it was clear they were capable of going to trial, no trial date has been set. And when that trial date is set—let us hope it is soon—it is to be before a military tribunal, not before a judge and jury. Indeed, there is no judge. I return to Major Michael Mori, the US military officer assigned to David Hicks. He was interviewed recently by Judge Andrew Napolitano and the interview was aired on Fox News two weeks ago. When Mori said that the trial would not be fair, the interviewer asked:

quote.para: Why not? What is wrong with the procedures that have been established?

speech.para: Major Michael Mori responded:

quote.para: What is wrong with the procedures is basically the procedures have gutted the recognised criminal justice system either in the civilian process or under the uniform code of military justice.

speech.para: The interviewer pursued his interviewee and said:

quote.para: Well, let's start with the judges. Are the judges independent, or do they work for Donald Rumsfeld?

speech.para: Major Mori's reply was:

quote.para: Sir, there is no judge. The judge—independent judge has been removed from the system and been placed in the role of what they call the presiding officer on the actual jury panel themselves, so there is no independent judge to rule on issues, to control the process, to be an unbiased controller of the process to see that both sides get a fair access and fair presentation of the evidence without biasing the jury.

speech.para: That is what was said about the process by an officer of the United States armed forces. And in America it is not only he who is raising these concerns: former United States prisoners of war have raised concerns about the detention of people at Guantanamo Bay. They say it sets an absolutely outrageous precedent. It could allow US combatants—if found to be in this spurious category invented by the United States—to be detained in the future, with the Guantanamo Bay precedent being used as the way justice is to be applied.

This is turning the Geneva convention on its head. Indeed, we have former US POWs raising concerns about this matter, along with international jurists and many others and along with the Labor Party here today. As the shadow Attorney-General has said, there has been no vigilant effort to pursue the options that may be available to provide for those citizens to be tried here. If indeed they are convicted of those charges they must serve their sentence. They must indeed be sentenced according to the charges if convicted. But so far there has been no charge, no conviction, just detention. That is all that has happened in relation to this matter. No charge, no conviction, just detention—indefinite detention.

It has to be said that while the bill we are debating today might provide some relief down the track for the families of these two citizens, if indeed they are ultimately charged or are found not guilty and released—provided there is a further enabling process between the Commonwealth of Australia and the United States to allow them to return here—this bill is too limited in its application, too unimaginative in terms of its efforts to apply decent laws to our citizens. It lacks courage. Worst of all, it is not really intended to concern itself with two Australian citizens who have been treated so unfairly.

I say in conclusion that I support the bill. The Labor Party support the bill. We have quite rightly moved amendments condemning the conduct of this government in relation to this matter, condemning them for failing to fully pursue those options that I referred to earlier. The bill is certainly flawed and therefore we would ask the House to support the amendments and support the amended bill.

talk.start.para: —I welcome the opportunity to address the merits of the International Transfer of Prisoners Amendment Bill 2004. It is a bill I support but, as I will demonstrate, it should be renamed the `State Sponsored Kidnapping (Confirming Australian Government Indifference) Bill 2004' as that would at least be honest and accurate. According to the explanatory memorandum that accompanies the bill:

quote.para: This Bill amends the International Transfer of Prisoners Act 1997 to facilitate the transfer back to Australia of Australian citizens detained at Guantanamo Bay who may subsequently be convicted, found guilty and sentenced to a term of imprisonment by a military commission of the United States of America.

speech.para: This is because the current structure that imprisons Australian citizens in Camp Delta in Guantanamo Bay, Cuba cannot be reflected adequately in the current act. As everyone knows, because of a combination of legal holograms and transnational denial, prisoners at Guantanamo Bay cannot seek or obtain access to American courts or rely upon the American constitution to provide them with rights, certainty or even minimum standards of justice—standards that the poorest accused in Texas, New York and California would receive. As we can see, though, that is the way Bush, Rumsfeld and our very own cabinet would like it to stay.

Likewise, any sentence that is provided by a United States military commission to the prisoners of Guantanamo Bay cannot readily be described in the act as it stands. This is because the military commissions that will sit and supposedly dispense justice to the prisoners in Guantanamo Bay cannot be described as courts or tribunals. The previous speaker, the member for Burke, has reflected on some of the inadequacies of these military commissions. They cannot be described as courts or tribunals, because to do so would import a legitimate expectation that procedural conventions and rules that would be observed in courts and tribunals would be observed in these commissions as well. This would include conventions and rules like a right of appeal, the right to hear all evidence and the right to private discussions with a lawyer—rights that people charged with mass murder can expect to have provided for them objectively by the state in Australia, America, Canada and anywhere else you care to look that considers itself to be a civilised place, except of course in Camp Delta, Guantanamo Bay, Cuba. The New York Times columnist William Safire recently summed it up rather concisely. Each military commission, he wrote, would have the authority to:

quote.para: ... conceal evidence by citing national security, make up its own rules and find a defendant guilty even if a third of the officers disagree ...

speech.para: This is hardly the bulwark of liberty under anyone's measure. Despite these fundamental flaws, I draw this parliament's attention to section 45 of the existing International Transfer of Prisoners Act 1997, which reads as follows:

quote.para: On transfer of a prisoner to Australia under this Act no appeal or review lies in Australia against the sentence of imprisonment imposed by the court or tribunal of the transfer country or by the Tribunal.

speech.para: From that it seems clear that an Australian convicted of a crime by the Guantanamo Bay military commission will not be able to appeal the decision in their own country, despite the commission having lower standards of integrity than any Australian court. So anything more than a casual glance over this bill is cause for significant concern. The context surrounding this bill is plainly alarming and creates distress not just to many people in my electorate of Cunningham but also to people within the wider Australian community. And let us not forget the families of David Hicks and Mamdouh Habib, left to mourn the kidnapping of their family members by the United States government, because that is what Camp Delta is: an ongoing and unlawful deprivation of liberty. As I said, we have got to remember that these are Australian citizens. They have families. Mr Habib has a young son, a daughter and wife. Mr Hicks has his family as well. We really should be taking care of our Australian citizens. As well, the broader community is left to mourn the death of the Australian government's obligations to assist its citizens overseas when serious allegations are raised against them.

The wider concern though, as I see it, is just what Guantanamo Bay represents and just how safe a United States military commission conviction will be. To be blunt, I believe that Guantanamo Bay is an infection on the body of human rights law, which begins with the denial of habeas corpus writs and ends with the government's approval of indefinite detention without charge. Given that the chief lawyer at the Pentagon, General Counsel William J. Haynes II, said recently that the government of the United States might not even release people who are accused and then acquitted by a US military commission—that is right: those acquitted by the commission may never be released—this sore will get a whole lot bigger. Haynes said that indefinite detention of prisoners acquitted by a military tribunal might be necessary because the prisoners are `dangerous people' and because `When somebody's trying to kill you or your people, and you capture them, you can hold them.' If he meant that the Americans are entitled to hold prisoners captured in Afghanistan indefinitely without convicting them of any crime because they are prisoners of war, either he is wrong or human rights do not matter. If he meant to declare all the prisoners guilty of war crimes in advance, as Bush apparently did when he declared that the prisoners are `killers', then his remarks provide fresh reason to question the fairness and independence of the military tribunals that are so firmly under the Bush administration's control.

At the core of this issue is the fact that military commissions are, by their very nature and design, inherently unfair and, as a direct consequence of that, they are more likely to be responsible for a miscarriage of justice. First and foremost, they are likely to make mistakes because people will plead guilty under duress—the duress being that a prisoner in Camp Delta would be offered a plea of guilty on the one hand and the chilling spectre of indefinite detention on the other. What would your choice be to such an offer, Mr Deputy Speaker Mossfield? After having already served two, three, four or more years in detention without charge or trial, would it be any wonder or any surprise that people may prefer the certainty of a sentence to the horror of indefinite detention, regardless of guilt? It is a `Sophie's choice' of freedom—but it is not fiction, and this government rejoices in it in the name of the war on terror.

Where is the terror, though? It is certainly in the scenario I have just outlined; it just comes in a different, administrative, form from the violence of September 11. So from that, just how safe will a conviction from the military commission be? The answer is, plainly, `not very'. Do not take my word for it, though, Mr Deputy Speaker; listen to the few lawyers who have been assigned, belatedly, to defend some of the victims of United States sponsored kidnapping who are languishing in Camp Delta. I note in particular that Mr Habib has not yet been appointed a lawyer at all. Major Michael Mori—who, when it comes to these matters, appears to have more intestinal fortitude than the entire cabinet of the Australian government—is David Hick's military appointed lawyer. Recently he said, `The military commissions will not provide a full and fair trial,' and, `The commission process has been created and controlled by those with a vested interest only in convictions.' Major Mori has also echoed calls by Australians, most notably Senator Bob Brown during George W. Bush's recent visit to this place, to have David Hicks tried in Australia. Major Mori said:

quote.para: In fairness, if David Hicks has violated a law, an international law, there is no reason why it would not apply in Australia. That's universal jurisdiction, and so he should be tried in his country.

speech.para: When Major Mori said that, he echoed the sentiments of a significant proportion of Australians, and many members of this House would agree with that, I am sure. However, this government prefers to ignore these reasoned, well-researched and compelling arguments, and then has the gall to expect this parliament to be a party to this fraud, citing humanitarian benefits, including concern for the families of Mr Hicks and Mr Habib. The government's crocodile tears are flowing today.

So here we have it. First, these people are kidnapped by the United States government and thrown into Camp Delta at Guantanamo Bay. Then, according to the United States government, they have no right to challenge the legality of their detention. Next, they are held there indefinitely with no date being fixed for their release or trial. Next, the Australian public is expected to believe that any plea of guilty arising before the military commissions is given with free and informed consent. Next, the commissions' lawyers argue that the commissions are unfair and biased towards obtaining a conviction at the expense of basic principles of justice. Then, on top of all that, this government expects the parliament to support the transfer of Australian citizens to spend their lives in Australian jails because of proceedings that are not fair and which cultivate miscarriages of justice, while the American government is fighting, tooth and nail, to avoid the jurisdiction of its own American courts to oversee the government's actions. What a disgrace. Then, to reach commanding new heights of ridiculousness, there is no guarantee that these prisoners at Camp Delta will even be released upon acquittal.

As I have said, this bill should be renamed the `State Sponsored Kidnapping (Confirming Australian Government Indifference) Bill 2004'—that would at least be accurate. This bill represents the latest instalment of this government's policy to ignore, override and destroy the protection of long-established legal norms and basic human rights. This bill overrides, ignores, and destroys human rights by endorsing the legitimacy of the legal holograph that is Guantanamo Bay prison and cheerfully approves the Star-Spangled Banner production of show trials that are the US military commissions. In this way, by supporting the wholesale reduction in minimum standards of conduct in the criminal law, this bill holds the central tenets of justice in contempt.

Some may ask, in the shadow of these monumental obstacles to justice, why I would support this bill at all—particularly if it is so patently offensive to international and national standards. The answer lies in the interests of David Hicks and Mamdouh Habib and their families. These two Australian citizens—as we all know but some would rather forget—are detained in Camp Delta without charge or trial, without so much as a peep of advocacy from the Australian government, unlike other governments around the world who are, at least, trying to defend their citizens and to have some of them brought back to their own countries. Because of these two men, who are Australian citizens, and only because the interests of these two men and their families, will I support this bill. Under these disgraceful circumstances, I do not want to delay, by even one day, their eventual return to Australia to be reunited with their families. Given that the government has not and will not assist these two men in any way, despite all reasonable requests to do so, it is appropriate for the parliament to pave the way for their return to Australia—and that is the only reason why this bill should be supported. Once home, I look to the courts and to the protests by the people of Australia to ensure that David Hicks and Mamdouh Habib are released from any sentence imposed by the facade of justice that is dealt out by a US military commission.

I know many members on the other side have no sympathy for Hicks and Habib. Those people have made up their minds. They are judge and jury—but based on what? Media stories and reports? Briefings by our security services? We know the problems there. In this country we believe in the rule of law and the presumption of innocence. These two men are innocent until proven guilty, and we all must support that. Therefore, while I support this bill and the member for Gellibrand's amendment, I would like to inform the House that I was seeking to amend the bill so that the parliament had the opportunity to adequately describe its opposition to the Howard coalition government's overriding of basic human rights and long-established legal principles it would prefer to ignore. Accordingly, I was seeking to move the following amendment:
That all words after “That” be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:
“whilst not declining to give the Bill a second reading, the House:
(1) requests that the Government:
(a) immediately seek to obtain the release and repatriation of the two Australian citizens who are currently detained against their will in Camp Delta Guantanamo Bay;
(b) provide a report to the Parliament on the measures it has taken to achieve the release of the two detainees by 1 July 2004; and
(2) condemns:
(a) the use of Military Commissions in place of Courts as being inherently flawed and designed to secure convictions at the expense of justice;
(b) the United States Government's indefinite detention, without charge of over 600 people in Guantanamo Bay as an affront to human rights; and
(c) the Australian Government's complete lack of support for Australian citizens detained in Guantanamo Bay as an appalling failure to provide for the welfare of its citizens”.

talk.start.para: —The International Transfer of Prisoners Amendment Bill 2004 is before the House for debate and, although I support it, I stand to highlight the reason this bill has been framed, the events leading up to this bill and the government's failure to protect the very doctrine of law that makes this a nation of which we should be proud. I also stand because I am not a constitutional lawyer. Although I have studied law, I have no particular expertise in that field. There are many legal experts in this place, and no doubt they have helped frame this legislation and influence our concern about it. But this is legislation that needs to be assessed not just through a legal brain but also through a thinking heart. What is our role here if it is not to test all our actions against the values and mores that should guide a civilised Australia?

speech.para: The legislation is the government's reaction to having two Australian citizens, David Hicks and Mamdouh Habib, incarcerated in Guantanamo Bay for the past two years. It amends the International Transfer of Prisoners Act 1997 to facilitate their return to serve in Australia any term of imprisonment they receive if convicted by a US military commission. The legislation also overcomes the problem with the legal status of a place like Guantanamo Bay, which is part of the sovereign territory of Cuba but is under jurisdiction or control of the US under a lease arrangement with Cuba. Apparently the US have their very own separate `lawless' place to exercise their will in any way they see fit—not a good international precedent by a great nation. The legislation also covers similar regions with unusual status, such as Hong Kong and Taiwan. Although US laws may not apply in Guantanamo Bay, fortunately the US have not been able to escape the scrutiny of the international community. It is a pity, though, that they seem to escape the scrutiny of this government in their dealings with Australian citizens. The legislation also provides that a military commission of the USA will constitute, for the purpose of this bill, a recognised court or tribunal.

The bill, once enacted and applied, would not be sufficient to ensure that Mr Hicks and Mr Habib would be returned to Australia on conviction to serve their sentence here. A separate, formal agreement between the United States and Australia, detailing the terms and conditions of the transfer and sentence to be imposed, would also be required. If the government's track record in negotiating agreements with the United States is any guide, then it could be anticipated that any separate transfer of prisoner agreement would come with some major concessions by the Australian government.

Putting aside the cases of Hicks and Habib temporarily, the legislation would also allow any Australians convicted overseas in countries where agreements exist to serve their sentences in Australia, close to family and support networks, in return for Australia shouldering the cost implied in this strategy. Other countries, too, could have their convicted citizens returned to serve imprisonment in their own native country. In that way, the legislation is beneficial, particularly on humanitarian grounds and gains.

This legislation, however, is not an extradition regime to facilitate bringing back detainees from any place, but particularly from Guantanamo Bay, for trial. That is not central to this debate. But that the Australian government has done nothing to explore the application of Australian criminal law or international law to have these Australian citizens extradited to Australia is cause for condemnation and outrage. There may very well be other legislative options that could assist the extradition of Mr Hicks and Mr Habib for trial in Australia, but although the Howard government has had two years to explore better ways of dealing with these cases we have had nothing put forward for us to consider, other than the legislation we are debating today.

The legislation is worthy of support on humanitarian grounds, as it allows Australians convicted overseas to be returned to serve their sentences here. But I also support the second reading amendment put forward by the member of Gellibrand, in which we condemn the government for acquiescing in the use of US military commissions to try Australian citizens and for their failure to explore all options for the two Australians currently detained.

The cases of Hicks and Habib are complex or unusual in many ways. They are allegedly involved in terrorist related activities in a new global terrorism that has not really been experienced in the world before. Their cases are also complex and unusual because their alleged actions do not really fit the normal laws of military conflict or the usual application of the laws in this country.

Before expanding on these cases it is important to state that the innocence or guilt of Habib and Hicks is also not central to this debate. If they are guilty of a crime under US law, Australian criminal law or international law, they deserve the application of the full extent of that law. The real problem is that, if the system in place in Guantanamo Bay is allowed to run its course, we will never be able to be assured that, whatever the final outcome, our Australian detainees gained a fair trial or that their sentence was appropriate to any crime they may or may not have committed.

We need to have confidence in the legal system being applied to Australian citizens. In the case of Hicks and Habib we have no such confidence. Their cases are unusual: they were not engaged in a formally declared war against the US or Australia, they were apprehended but were not charged with any crime and they did not directly harm any US or Australian serviceman or citizen; however, they are detained by the US on the assumption that they are `enemy combatants' in the war against terrorism. Even though they are not members of any official defence forces of any nation, they are to be trialled by a US military commission, by a process acknowledged by the international legal community as being legally flawed—having inadequate safeguards against an unfair trial, lacking independence from the US executive government and lacking rules of evidence and any independent appeal mechanisms.

Why now, after allowing these two individuals—two Australians—to be held for two years, uncharged with any crime and facing the jurisdiction of a military commission rather than a recognised judicial body, are we debating today legislation that applies only to convicted prisoners held overseas? Well, the government has come under further pressure, now that two other countries—Britain and Denmark, both civilised nations like Australia—have succeeded in having their detainees in Guantanamo Bay returned for trial in their own country, yet the best we can do is pass legislation that allows the transfer of Australian citizens back to serve their sentences after conviction by the US military commission. It begs the question to the Prime Minister and the Attorney General: just how hard did you try?

Denmark and Britain both stood shoulder to shoulder in Iraq as members of the coalition of the willing and have been able to gain the return of their citizens. Perhaps it would be just for the Australian public to ask, `Wasn't our effort in that coalition good enough for us to be listened to when we wanted our citizens returned here for our legal processes to be applied?'

Incidentally, I do not see either of those countries—Britain or Denmark—busting to sell off their multilateral trading partner status in free trade agreements with the US either. In fact, when I checked today with an expert on trade matters, I was told that free trade agreements are usually done between a modern developed country and a less developed economy. I was amused to apply this rationale to our current free trade agreement with the United States. Just which nation is the less developed one? I digress.

But the Australian people must be wondering just how much special influence we do have with our good ally, the United States of America. The other pressure on the government to put this legislation to the House is the impending US Supreme Court decision after challenges by US lawyers to the legality of imposing a military regime on the prisoners held in Guantanamo Bay. So, to be seen to be doing something, the government puts this legislation forward.

Although supporting the legislation, it is not without some additional potential problems. I must register concern at the constitutionality of this legislation. The opposition has received no advice from the government on this matter but some legal inconsistencies do exist. If prisoners have been convicted by a military commission, then they are convicted under executive powers and not judicial powers. So it is not clear if, under our Constitution, they can rightfully be detained here at all. Our Constitution does not authorise executive detention, except when connected to legislative power, such as in the case of immigration detention. A High Court challenge to this legislation could be possible and the detention power challenged. Potentially, anyone brought back under this legislation would be unable to be detained, no matter what their conviction status. This inconsistency should be clarified by the Attorney General.

As suggested by a previous speaker, are we just opposing the United States? No, we certainly are not. The United States is a great nation and a great ally. It is one that we rightly should expect better of in our dealings. It is to the credit of the United States that the lawyers assigned by the Pentagon to defend the Guantanamo Bay detainees have condemned as unjust the system of military tribunals that will try the accused. The very people who have freely joined the US defence forces to defend their country's laws and freedoms, who are loyal servants of the military, have chosen to speak out against their own employer, the US government, to defend much nobler principles. Thank goodness! What a shame it took so long for the Pentagon to appoint these good men.
The US Department of Defense lawyer representing David Hicks, Major Michael Mori, stated:

quote.para: When you use an unfair system, all you do is risk convicting the innocent and providing somebody who is truly guilty with a valid complaint to attack his conviction. It doesn't help anybody.

speech.para: Major Mori has also stated, as the appointed lawyer of David Hicks, that he would rather see him tried in Australia. So would we, but this government has done nothing to bring this about within our laws and Constitution. The amendment moved by the previous speaker, the member for Cunningham, seeking that outcome has the right spirit but the wrong process. This legislation cannot bring that about, so we must do all we can to maintain pressure on the government to defend the principles of law and justice that protect our civil liberties.

Major Mori also stated that the US would not tolerate these rules for Americans, yet apparently our government sets no such standard for Australians. He also criticised the Australian government for agreeing too soon to concessions that include an agreement for Hicks to serve any prison term in Australia. We are debating this legislation today because this was the best deal our government could do, unlike Denmark and Britain. The Attorney General says:

quote.para: The government has been in continuous dialogue with the US since David Hicks and Mamdouh Habib were detained.

speech.para: That is a long time, a lot of talk but apparently not a lot of action. I quote two other appointed lawyers defending other detainees in Guantanamo Bay. US Navy Lieutenant Commander Philip Sundel stated:

quote.para: We are concerned with virtually every aspect of the military commission process and the impact it will have an our client's chances of getting a fair trial.

speech.para: So should we be. Major Bridges stated:

quote.para: The bottom line is it—

speech.para: the military commission—

quote.para: is an outdated system that was pulled off the shelf and dusted off from the WW2 era. The law has advanced a lot since then. The checks and balances we expect from a system today to make sure the process is fair and is not subjected to improper influences by any of the participants don't exist in the military commission system.

speech.para: How true. All the US lawyers appointed as `friends of the court' to defend prisoners have called for all prisoners to have the option of an appeal to US civilian courts. That is a decision we await and would welcome in applying further pressure on this government to appear to be asserting for and on behalf of Australian citizens.

Military commissions are not acceptable to us. They are very different from regular courts: there are no independent judges, the rules of evidence do not apply and detainees are at the mercy of the military, who have the power to keep them incarcerated even if they are acquitted. In registering our concerns today, it is not about whether our Australians are guilty or innocent; it is really about making sure that, no matter how extreme the situation our country faces, we remain guided by values and principles that protect our civility and integrity as a nation and distinguish us from the terrorists and anarchists who would tear civilisation down. It is our role, as a true friend to the American people, to support them to overcome the threat of terrorism, which saw the tragedies of September 11 and Bali wreak such human loss and tragedy on our peoples. But, in doing so, we must not assist the USA to undermine the due processes that set them and us apart as civilised nations. That is what this government should have been doing.

In this country, we are fortunate to have established and credible judicial and penal systems, so we should have faith that adherence to individual civil liberties will always be part of any legal process. The separation of powers and the rule of law exist in this country to protect the innocent but to be feared by the guilty; they do distinguish us from less civilised nations. Our shadow attorney-general, the member for Gellibrand, has rightly expressed Labor's concern that the Australian government is ignoring its responsibilities and wiping its hands of Australian citizens who have no chance at all of a fair trial. I also take the opportunity to congratulate the Australian Law Society and the Australian Law Council in their efforts to protect our legal system and its application.

In the particular cases of Hicks and Habib, and in applying this legislation to their cases, we need to look closely at one other area—the concept of `enemy combatant'. If the United States can detain and try people under the category of `enemy combatant', which is not recognised by any international law, does that mean that other countries in conflict with Australia can apply that precedent against Australian defence personnel who have been apprehended, and thus escape the international laws of engagement and any UN conventions that give protection to our military personnel when they are engaged in lawful combat activities? Would it mean that our intelligence and security personnel engaged in fighting terrorism could also be subjected to incarceration as `enemy combatants'? Apparently even we in the civilised nations spy on each other as well.

Any failure to adhere to proper legal processes, or to established international systems to establish new legal principles and conventions to deal with changing world circumstances, does put the civil liberties of all Australians at risk. Therefore, in conclusion, I support Labor's position, as outlined by the member for Gellibrand. The opposition would assert that it is a disgrace that the Howard government has had two years to deal with this situation and still cannot answer very basic questions about the rights and situation of our detainees in Guantanamo Bay. Labor's position is that we do want terrorists to be brought to justice and we do want charges to be laid quickly and trials to be fair. We want the Australian government to chase all the options and to pursue a trial here in Australia when people are involved in terrorist activities, if that is at all legally possible. In supporting this legislation, we are disappointed that this is the best deal that the Australian government was able to negotiate for two Australian citizens who at this time have not been charged with any crime and remain incarcerated in a very uncertain situation with a very uncertain future before them.

talk.start.para: —I thank the members for Gellibrand, Dickson, Cunningham, Burke and Newcastle for their contributions to this debate, and I thank the opposition for recognising the humanitarian nature and principal purpose of the International Transfer of Prisoners Amendment Bill 2004 and for their support for its passage. The government has developed this bill so that Mr Hicks and Mr Habib may benefit from the international transfer of prisoners scheme. The government has always said that it takes an interest in the welfare of these two men, and this bill demonstrates the government's commitment to assist Australian citizens detained overseas, but within context. Contrary to the opposition's assertions, the government has not simply acquiesced to the detention and possible military commission trial of Mr Hicks and Mr Habib. The government has taken an active role in ensuring that any military commission process is fair and transparent, and has also, obviously, undertaken a range of regular visits to be satisfied as to the circumstances in which Mr Hicks and Mr Habib are being held.

speech.para: I think what becomes very clear in listening to this debate is that there are fundamental differences of view between the government and the opposition in relation to the way in which terrorism should be handled. In the other place, the opposition will today take off the agenda a security related issue—that is, the issue of the proscription of terrorist organisations—because they are looking down the barrel of an election. But, when it comes to the question of what should happen to Mr Hicks and Mr Habib, it is not until we have heard the speeches today that it has become clear that the opposition is of the view that there is no requirement, in terms of dealing with the threat we face from terrorism, to respond in a way which will provide to our community the most effective protection possible.

I mentioned the other day in a speech I made in this House the difficult situation that we are in regarding our expectations as to what should happen in a civilised society and the extent to which those who are engaged in terrorist activities are prepared to use our commitment to those principles to their advantage. It is difficult to protect those principles when clearly terrorists have in mind the taking of the lives of innocent civilians.

talk.start.para: —If this were a wartime situation in which soldiers were adhering to the Geneva conventions and the rules of engagement, you would have no problem with military commissions. Military commissions have been used in Australia before; they were used after the last world war. They have been used internationally before. Here we are dealing with a situation far more heinous than that, where the combatants that we are ranged against clearly are not prepared to accept Geneva conventions; there are no rules of engagement and their targets are civilians.

speech.para: That is why people like the Attorney General of Canada, Irwin Cotler—a person who comes from what you would regard as a fraternal party, even though in Canada it has the name `Liberal', and who has been a significant advocate in relation to human rights issues over a long period of time—talk about some of the compromises you need to make. Irwin Cotler speaks very frankly about the fundamental human right that you never hear talked about: the expectation that citizens of a civilised society have that their government will be involved in and take all reasonable steps to secure their safety against terrorism.

That is the issue that we are dealing with here. We are dealing with an opposition that says that we are acquiescing in the use of US military commissions to try Australian citizens and that we are failing to explore all options to bring two Australians, currently being detained by US authorities in Guantanamo Bay, to Australia to be tried here. The United States has indicated already that it was prepared to free people who were marginally involved—those who may have made one casual visit to Afghanistan or Pakistan to engage in some training in conducting terrorist events and activities, participating in programs run by al-Qaeda or Lashkar-e-Taiba—because it had assessed that they would no longer pose a risk; in other words, they would not be likely to be engaged in continuing terrorist activity. That is an assessment that the United States has made. In fact, because we have received advice on these matters from the United States, we know that the charges that ultimately will be brought against these two people, where the allegations are clearly that they were not simply Taliban tourists, revolve around their training with al-Qaeda and Lashkar-e-Taiba and that their involvement with those organisations has been of a very significant order.

We all know that these organisations are vile and heinous in what they have been undertaking and the training that they are giving to people to engage in terrorist activities. We did undertake very extensive investigations here—let me make this very clear—to see whether or not it was possible to prosecute Mr Hicks and Mr Habib on the basis of the information that we have about their engagements abroad. We have legislated to create offences for people who train with terrorist organisations. Let me be very clear about this: we regard training with terrorist organisations and financing terrorist organisations to be of very real concern. We legislated in relation to those matters in 2002, but we did not legislate retrospectively. We looked at whether that was a desirable objective. We looked at all of the sorts of comments that you might expect people to make on these matters over time and we came to the view that, as heinous as training with organisations like this is, inevitably it would be highly problematic as to whether your laws would be successful. There are issues in relation to establishing mens rea for criminal offences and, when you are legislating retrospectively, it is very difficult to establish that as one of the elements. But you also have questions about the way in which the courts look at these matters—that, in strictly construing the laws, it is highly unlikely that they would survive challenge.

talk.start.para: —I will deal with the question of international law and with the question of existing laws. But the point I make is that in relation to these matters, on all the advice that we have received—and I have seen the views of footpath attorneys that there may be ways in which you could prosecute people in Australia; they have all been explored and they have all been looked at—we cannot prosecute Hicks and Habib in relation to Australia. I said initially that that was particularly in relation to their activities in Pakistan and Afghanistan. I have used those words advisedly, because we also wanted to look at what had happened in relation to Mr Hicks's training and activities when he was involved in Kosovo. There we wanted to look at whether or not the crimes (foreign incursions) legislation would apply, and the advice I have is that he could not be convicted under that act. I might say, if the honourable shadow attorney is interested in these matters, that is another area in terms of the adequacy of our Australian law where I have asked for work to be done to see why that law could not be used in relation to Mr Hicks's involvement in Kosovo and to ensure that that issue is addressed.

speech.para: But the fact is that the clear advice to us is that the international law did not apply in relation to the particular offences that had been established under Australian law before 2002. International law does apply now, because the amendments to our Crimes Act were to implement international law, and that was implemented in 2002. But the important point to understand about international law is that it only applies in relation to our domestic legal regime if it has been specifically implemented in Australia.

talk.start.para: —I do not want to get out of turn, because I was going to come to this. I notice that the shadow Attorney suggested we should legislate to enable the application of international law.
—I said you should explore it.
—Well, explore—that is fine. I do not mind whether you say we should legislate or whether we should explore it. But let me make the point that that is legislating retrospectively.
—For international law to exist—
—I am happy to hear you advocate that you want retrospective criminal law in Australia. I am happy to hear you advocate for that.
—You know that is not what—
—No, because they are the words you used. You seek to explore legislation to enable the application of international law.
—Mr Deputy Speaker Lindsay, I rise on a point of order. I ask the minister if he is going to verbal me.
(Mr Lindsay)—What is your point of order?
—My point of order is that he has misrepresented what I have said, as he well knows, and he should not do that.
—There is no point of order.
—I understand the shadow Attorney's sensitivity about this, because the opposition has been all over the place in relation to these matters.
—You should try to understand the argument!

—The argument is very clear: we are not intending to legislate retrospectively to create criminal offences, whether you want to dress it up in terms of enabling application of international law in Australia or not. If the international law did not apply in Australia at the relevant date, the mere fact that you legislate to enable it to apply now is legislating retrospectively. It cannot be anything but retrospective legislation. To just ignore the use of the word `retrospective' and to talk about enabling application to get you off the hook is an engagement in semantics, and it does not do you justice in relation to this matter. If you want to go out and argue for retrospective law, please do it, but do not say you want to have a situation where we do not legislate retrospectively and then argue that we should have an enabling of the application of international law achieved by legislation.

speech.para: I want to move on, because the time is limited. I want to make it very clear that the government has been very concerned to ensure that the issues in relation to Mr Habib and Mr Hicks are addressed in ways that will continue to protect their right to be tried, and tried fairly. That is why we have looked very closely at the commission arrangements. It is why we sought certain additional assurances from the United States in relation to those matters. It is why we sought an assurance from the United States that, if we legislated for the International Transfer of Prisoners Act to be amended, it might be possible for those who were found guilty and who do not pose a continuing security threat to be brought back to Australia to serve any sentence. That is the issue that is involved here, and it is the substantial question. The sorts of assurances that the United States gave us were that neither man would be subjected to a death penalty, that there would be access to Australian consultants, that they would be able to speak with their family members and that they would have two family members attend a trial. We have taken steps to ensure that we can continue to monitor the commission process, and to that end we insisted that government observers and an independent legal expert be allowed to attend the trials.

Let me just deal with the issue that the legal status of the detainees is questionable—an assertion that the shadow Attorney makes. This is not true. The United States has determined that the detainees are unlawful enemy combatants. The laws of war recognise that any combatants may be detained to prevent them from taking further part in armed conflict. The laws of war also recognise that a person may be prosecuted for his unlawful participation in an armed conflict. The member for Gellibrand has claimed that the status of the detainees is currently before the United States Supreme Court. In fact, the only current question before the Supreme Court is whether US courts have jurisdiction over persons detained at Guantanamo Bay. The member for Gellibrand suggested that the government should have made submissions to the Supreme Court. Given that Mr Hicks' defence team made a submission to the court, I do not think there was any requirement for the government to have done so. Mr Hicks' defence team is composed of an appointed military lawyer, an Australian legal consultant and a US civilian attorney with extensive experience in terrorism trials, and the team is certainly more than competent to adequately represent his interests.

However, I do welcome the opposition's support for this bill, despite its reservations about the Guantanamo Bay detainees. I welcome its support for extensive proscriptions, even though it has reservations about the lack of merits review. But what I would really welcome from the opposition is it taking security seriously and engaging in useful and productive discussions about initiatives that will work, such as the, I think, 100 initiatives introduced by the government since September 11.

This bill does provide a statutory basis for returning to Australia any Australian citizen detained at Guantanamo Bay who is convicted and sentenced to a term of imprisonment by a military commission, as well as expanding the application of the International Transfer of Prisoners Act 1997 to semiautonomous regions to enable such a region to be declared a transfer country with which Australia can enter into transfer agreements. In July, we did announce that as a result of our bilateral discussions we would work with the US in putting in place these arrangements for the purpose of prisoners serving any penal sentence in Australia in accordance with Australian and United States law. The government have developed this bill to meet this commitment. It is facilitative only. At this stage no Australian has been convicted. The bill is not specific to any person currently detained at Guantanamo Bay. It will allow for the transfer of any Australian citizen imprisoned at Guantanamo Bay who is convicted and sentenced to a term of imprisonment by a military commission. In addition, the bill will increase the flexibility and application of the international prisoner transfer scheme as it applies in Australia, allowing the scheme to apply to a broader range of areas. It will provide increased community benefits, and it will allow the act to apply to a greater number of Australian citizens or persons with community links to Australia who are imprisoned in foreign countries.

The amendments will also allow for a larger number of foreign nationals imprisoned in Australia to return to their home countries, thereby providing an economic benefit to Australia. It will reduce the impact on Australian families who have members imprisoned in areas to which the act does not currently apply.
