This is where the government is completely out of step with feeling out there in the wider community.

The Australian Greens are clearly opposed to mandatory detention. We support the closure of the desert prisons and the facility on Nauru. We support the release of people seeking asylum who are not a threat to the Australian way of life. They must be treated humanely and must not be used by the government as a tool in the campaign to deter people-smuggling. It is clearly unacceptable to maintain this pretence of border protection as the reason for the present harsh mandatory detention regime, a regime which is severely impacting upon the lives of those unfortunate people caught up in it.

I do not want to repeat my comments of last June, but I will say that they still stand and that, until this government adopts a more reasonable and humane approach to the treatment of asylum seekers, it will continue to be rightfully held in contempt by a significant proportion of the Australian and international community. Frankly, it is disgraceful that we sit here in the comfort of this chamber and pass legislation which will have such a savage impact upon our fellow human beings. It is sickening when the Minister for Foreign Affairs uses question time, as he did today, to tell us about how other nations, such as Great Britain, are following the Australian model and looking towards developing offshore processing centres. It is sickening to hear the government gloat about turning boats full of asylum seekers away from our shores. Answer me this: how can a reasonable and rational assessment of the legitimacy or otherwise of an asylum seeker's status be determined on the high seas?

The government will undoubtedly be judged harshly by future historians when they look back to this period and deal with issues of justice, human rights and the role we played on the international stage. The government would have us believe that we will be remembered as playing a part in getting rid of Saddam Hussein. That is true, but I would suggest that the scars of the present inhumane mandatory detention regime will remain. I know this because I have spoken with a number of school students on this issue. Believe me, if you think my comments are rather emotive, then you should listen to what some of those students have to say. What they have to say does not mirror what we hear from government ministers and spin doctors. These young students feel ashamed at the way in which we are treating asylum seekers, whether they be men, women or children—just as I feel ashamed.

My worst fears about how we are treating asylum seekers were realised when I visited Villawood detention centre near Sydney last year. There I met a man who had been in detention for six years. There I met a young boy who had been in detention since the age of 15. He was approaching 20 and had spent the best years of his youth behind the razor wire. Here was an innocent young man whose life in Australia had been made hell by this government. He was scarred for life.

This is what we are dealing with here: real people; men, women and children, just like us. On numerous occasions I have condemned the government's approach to asylum seekers, and I do so once again here today. I do so for good reason. This time, though, I want to make it a bit more personal, for perhaps that is the only way in which the government will wake up to itself. I can only hope that it will become harder, with time, for the government to continue to hide behind legalese, statistics and spin, rather than acknowledge the harm that is caused by the detention of over 1,000 people in Australia's immigration prisons. I hope it will become harder to talk of those people in alienating terms such as `illegal noncitizens', especially when we turn to the circumstances of individuals whose interests will be directly affected by the passage of this bill.

In a debate dealing with mandatory detention, so-called queue jumpers and people bringing about their own detention by coming to Australia without appropriate papers, it might be worth while to consider the plight of one real, flesh and blood victim of Australia's immigration detention system. I would like to speak about Baxter immigration detention facility detainee No. 340. His real name is Muhammad Qasim.

I spoke with Muhammad by phone today from Baxter. He told me that he had been in every detention centre in Australia, except Villawood, over the last five years and five months. I asked him how old he was. He replied that he was not sure, as time is interminable in detention and one day is like a year. I know he is 29, though he said he felt like he was 100. He told me that he just wants to get out of detention and had asked to be repatriated—somewhere, anywhere—some eight months ago. But still he remains in detention—in prison—thanks to this government.

How can anyone on the other side of the House condone such treatment? This young man has been held in detention in Australian for five years and five months, without any likelihood of release. The previous speaker, the member for Forrest, said that all these people will be released. But there are people such as Mr Qasim who do not have any likelihood of any release, because of their circumstances. And this is nothing less than criminal on the part of the government.

According to the latest ABS statistics, during 2003 there were seven people in Australia convicted of murder who received terms of five to 10 years. Likewise, there were 367 people convicted of assault and 818 convicted of sexual assault who received similar sentences of five to 10 years. Has Mr Qasim been found guilty of murder or rape? No; yet his sentence has been five years and five months. His crime was to come to Australia in search of asylum, an action which is not illegal under Australian or international law. Nevertheless, he is being treated by the government in the same manner as the aforementioned murderers and rapists.

This is nothing less than disgraceful. Nothing that any minister or member on the other side of the House says can change this. I would like to read a section from the letter Mr Qasim sent to me on 20 January this year. It may help honourable members to better understand the consequences of the bill now before us. It reads:

quote.para: Dear Mr Organ

My name is Muhammad Qasim ... As I write this letter, I have been held in immigration detention in Australia for five years and four months, and it seems I have no choice but to spend the rest of my life in detention. I am writing to you in the hope that you will listen to my story, understand my plight, and please, if you can, assist me to find some solution.

I was born in the disputed region of Kashmir in India on 14 May 1974. When I was a young child, my father was murdered by the security forces because of his peaceful political activities, and my mother died soon afterwards. As a young man, my own peaceful opposition to the government's brutal policies in our region led to me being detained and tortured by the security forces, and after some years in hiding and on the run, it became necessary for me to flee my country.
I passed through Singapore and Papua New Guinea on my way to Australia, but these were places where I had no legal right to remain and no way to have my claim for asylum heard.

I arrived in Australia on 9 September 1998. The delegate of the Minister for Immigration who assessed my claim accepted that I was an Indian citizen from Kashmir, and also accepted that I had been tortured, but she did not believe that I faced a risk of persecution. On 20 October 1998 my application for a protection visa was refused. I appealed to the Refugee Review Tribunal, but on 11 January 1999 my refusal was upheld by the single tribunal member who reviewed my case.

Since January 1999, 1 have pursued no further appeals, so I have been liable for removal from Australia. I believe that I would face the risk of arrest and torture if I returned to India, but I would prefer that possibility rather than dying in detention in Australia. However, for five years now, I have remained imprisoned here. Because I have no passport, birth certificate, or other official document from India, and because I was an orphan unable to afford any formal education, the Indian government has so far refused to accept the fact that I am a citizen of that country.

In January 1999, the Department of Immigration lodged an application for travel documents with the Indian High Commission in Canberra. However, it was not until August of 2003 that the Department conducted a language analysis test and an interview to collect background information, in order to provide more evidence of my Indian citizenship. I would have been happy to answer the questions that were put to me in this interview at any time, and I do not understand why it has taken the Department five years to do this.

In any case, I am afraid that the Indian authorities will continue to refuse to provide travel documents to me. The state government of Jammu and Kashmir is busy dealing with the ongoing conflict there, and might not have the resources to make time-consuming investigations to establish my identity. Also, because there are 20 million people living illegally in India who come from neighbouring countries such as Bangladesh, Nepal, Bhutan, Sri Lanka and Pakistan, it is difficult to persuade the Indian authorities to accept anyone as a citizen without definite proof.
I have applied to almost 80 countries, asking if they will accept me, but I have received no positive replies.

So far I have endured five years and four months in detention. Living without the freedoms that ordinary people take for granted is very difficult. The conditions of detention involve small humiliations every day, and at times we are subject to great injustice, but the worst thing is having no certainty about when my imprisonment will end. Even a criminal knows the length of his sentence, whether it is long or short, but I have no such comfort.

In April 2003, a Full Bench of the Federal Court ruled that it was not lawful to keep rejected asylum seekers detained if there is no real prospect of removing them from Australia. However, the Minister for Immigration has appealed that decision to the High Court. I do not know which way the High Court will decide this question, but the lawyer for the Minister argued before the Court that the government should have the power to keep people in immigration detention for the rest of their life.

What's more, even if the government does not succeed in its appeal, that would mean people who could not be removed from Australia would be released into the community with no visa, and no rights at all, obliged to live on charity. The courts might order our release, but they could not give us the right to work and support ourselves with dignity.

Therefore, I am writing to you to ask that you seek a real, practical solution to the problem faced by me, and by others who have spent many years in detention and whose countries will not accept them. We are human beings, and we need to live in freedom, and with dignity. To the nation that provides me with these things, I can only offer my hard work, my loyalty, and my lifelong esteem and gratitude.
If you require more information about my case, please contact me. Thank you for taking this matter into your consideration. I look forward to your reply.
Yours sincerely
Muhammad (Peter) Qasim
ID Number: BX 340

speech.para: What linguistic gymnastics will the government offer in defence of its policy that allows such a disgraceful set of circumstances as outlined by Mr Qasim to continue to occur? The government will prattle on about border protection while Mr Qasim and others waste away in a desert prison, with no solution from the government forthcoming, visa or not. Given the circumstances of Mr Qasim and the more than 1,000 individuals like him, I cannot in all conscience support this bill, for it is clear that it will further impact upon his few remaining rights and will leave him to perhaps rot forever in our immigration detention centres.

talk.start.para: —The amendments to the Migration Act are intended to deny interlocutory relief for unlawful noncitizens held in immigration detention. The Migration Amendment (Duration of Detention) Bill 2004 specifically seeks to amend section 196 of the act, which states:

quote.para: (1) An unlawful non-citizen detained under section 189 must be kept in immigration detention until he or she is:
(a) removed from Australia under section 198 or 199; or
(b) deported under section 200; or
(c) granted a visa.

speech.para: The provisions result from a line of authority flowing from the courts in which exceptions to the general rule permit interlocutory release of detainees, whilst the visa applicant's status as a lawful or unlawful noncitizen is determined.

This bill is opposed by all parties other than the coalition—that is, the Australian Labor Party, the Greens and the Australian Democrats are in opposition to this bill. Why are we in opposition to this bill? The government is responding properly to the directions of the courts in flagging legal issues that are in need of redress. In this case, a string of court-made decisions reflects gaps in the statutory intent of section 196 which continue to permit the courts from handing down interlocutory orders where a visa applicant's lawful or unlawful status is determined. These court cases are of note: Al Masri v. Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs [2002] FCA 1009; M276/2003; Woolley & Anor, Ex parte—Re (a High Court decision); and, Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs v. VFAD (FCA, 9 December 2002).

I now wish to briefly summarise the authority of these three judgments, which comprise two Federal Court decisions and one High Court decision. Al Masri is authority for the proposition that a failed asylum seeker may be released by court order where it is found that his or her detention has become unlawful, punitive detention. M276 is authority for the proposition that the present scheme of mandatory detention is unconstitutional insofar as the period of detention is indeterminate—specifically in relation to children—and, as the judgment says, `is not reasonably capable of being necessary'. VFAD is authority for the proposition that a visa applicant is entitled to interlocutory relief—that being release from immigration detention—where it is shown that the unlawfulness of a person's detention is in question.

These instances where interlocutory relief may be afforded are not closed. There is a string of powers under which a court may intervene. The existing bill is designed to address judicial review proceedings where interlocutory relief may be granted. However, these are not the only grounds. As was shown in case M276, release on grounds of unconstitutionality may also be raised. Equally, there are other grounds that may fall within the purview of the courts, including errors of law and the vast morass of existing subordinate immigration legislation, including the Migration Regulations, PAMS, ministerial series instructions, or MSIs—specifi-cally MSI 388, which deals with bridging visas—and ministerial directions and so forth.

I mention immigration by-laws because there is already a significant and very complex body of subordinate immigration legislation dealing with the release of unlawful noncitizens by the lawful application of bridging visa class E. The existing by-laws deal with the permissible release from detention of unlawful noncitizens who enter the migration zone. This raises a further complication to the existing proposed amendments to section 196 in that there are two groups of unlawful noncitizens to which this bill we are debating this evening may apply. These are the unlawful noncitizens who seek protection visas and other detainees who are unlawful for reasons other than protection visa applications.

I specifically refer to section 72 of the Migration Act, which relates to eligible noncitizens who have been immigration cleared. Subsection 72(2)(a) prescribes that the minister may make determinations under paragraph (1)(c) that a noncitizen is an eligible noncitizen if the noncitizen was an unlawful noncitizen when he or she entered the migration zone. The minister has issued directions and instructions relevant to this power. Migration Regulation 2.20 elaborates on the section 72 provision by further prescribing grounds upon which an eligible noncitizen may be entitled to a bridging visa. The bridging visa issued to eligible noncitizens who are protection visa applicants is a subclass 051 visa. This visa is prescribed in schedule 2 of the Migration Regulations 1994.

I question here in the House tonight whether the government has adequately reviewed the entirety of the migration law with respect to this bill. I note that the law already makes provision for the release of unlawful noncitizens who are mentally or physically sick, too young, too old, infirm or otherwise suffering harm from protracted detention. The bill anticipates closing the expansion of judge-made law in determinations that may further compromise the efficacy of section 196 on grounds of unconstitutionality, use of the provision for de jure punitive intent, or otherwise where the unlawfulness of the person is in question.

In response to this approach, I note, as I have done on previous occasions in this House, the draconian intent of this government in drafting legislation which takes a bloody-minded approach to dealing with immigration policy matters. When the government is challenged in terms of border protection, terrorism, other criminality or otherwise opportunistic conduct of prospective arrivals, the way it reacts is to attack the natural justice and procedural fairness rights of these people. I have also mentioned before in this House, when I have been speaking on migration bills, other amendments to the Migration Act which demonstrate a systematic disregard by the government for natural law and, with it, natural justice and procedural fairness. Regarding a previous bill, I referred to the provisions of subsection 501(3), which says that where a decision of the minister is made to refuse to grant a visa or cancel a visa that has been granted, subsection (5) prescribes that the rules of natural justice and the code of procedure set out in subdivision AB of division 3 of part 2 do not apply to a decision made under subsection (3).

Has it ever occurred to the government that the act of erasing natural justice is precisely what those who oppose freedom want to happen? The saying `The more you tighten the grip, the more a thing slips away' is appropriate here. Tightening the loopholes by restricting the equitable remedies that are available to the Federal Court and High Court fails to address the broader remedies already available at law. So it is clear that in this legislation the government is failing in its understanding of the problem. The problem is how to maintain the integrity of a detention regime in order to prevent persons escaping into the community, thus compromising Australia's border protection and other security, market, national and public interests.

The solution, I believe, is to be found in recognising the intrinsic wrongfulness of an action of a person who is otherwise not a bona fide applicant and who is in detention for reasons that were touched upon in the M276 case, which I spoke about earlier. In that case the visa applicant, an Afghani national, could not be compelled to return to Afghanistan because Australia had at that time no agreement with the Afghani government for the removal of Afghani citizens from Australia. I put to the government that the issues raised in M276 more properly raise matters going to immigration by-laws dealing with extraction procedures, including those dealing with preparation for removal, rather than depend on reciprocal arrangements with other governments on the return of their citizens. The current administrative procedures are that such persons who refuse to voluntarily leave Australia's immigration detention remain in detention for an indeterminate period. That is unacceptable.

Again there is a substantial body of by-laws that deals with the extraction of persons from Australia. I use the word `extraction' to distinguish between removal other than deportation, which deals with persons who otherwise have a criminal record, extradition or other prescribed arrangements with other governments. This matter in turn raises other ancillary but very important issues of issuance, travel documents and other preparatory documents necessary for the removal of unlawful noncitizens from Australia. As immigration detention team officers will tell you, as they have told me, this field of law is a science in itself. Uncooperative detainees who refuse to sign documents, refuse to obtain travel documents or simply refuse to cooperate find that these things all lead to protracted periods of detention. That is a fact.

Often the identity of a detainee cannot be determined. We read about those cases every day in the media. Often the country from which a detainee comes either does not recognise these people as citizens of their country or in some cases—as with Kosovo, Afghanistan or the former Soviet Union—the country does not exist or no longer exists. All these cases raise ancillary but related issues of statelessness and further blur the boundaries of migration law, cumulatively leading to protracted periods of detention. It would be a worthwhile exercise to draft law that clarifies the legal implications of people who will not or cannot obtain valid travel documents, which leads to a stalemate situation for extraction, rather than have this current government's limbic approach to extinguishing the judiciary's rightful and time-honoured recourse to equitable remedies in order to rectify impasses of the law.

I remind this House of a time-honoured maximum: where the common law fails, let equity prevail. The very reason why we are here debating this bill this evening is that the Federal Court and High Court of Australia have required recourse to the equitable remedies founded in our ecclesiastical courts which step into the common law and statutory law regime in situations where the statutory and common law have failed. It is the equitable jurisdiction which applies in the award of interlocutory relief in a system that is clearly not working. The remedy put by the government is to further extinguish the natural law in Australia, making the regime more punitive in the hope that this will gain public appeal. In reality, what this regime will do is create further festering distress for the many detainees and Australians who see the rising horror of protracted detention and, with it, the unnecessary suffering of people both inside and outside the detention centres.

In conclusion, it is legislation like this with its assault on natural law that will lead the Australian people when they vote—and that will be on either 18 September, if it is a double-dissolution election to get the media ownership law in place, or 30 October, if it is a general election. I notice that the member for North Sydney is laughing. I read Dennis Shanahan in the Australian, and there is no better grapevine of intelligence growing into the cabinet to inform us of what is the likely date of the next federal election. I believe that it will be 30 October.

talk.start.para: —You said the 18th.

—It will be 18 September if it is a double-dissolution election. Minister, if the Prime Minister decides to have an early election—that is the last card in the pack; and you would expect Australia's two biggest media moguls to back him, because they certainly will in relation to the Broadcasting Services Amendment (Media Ownership) Bill 2002 [No. 2], which you know all about—it will be on 18 September, because he cannot have it after that date. You know that the election has to be called before 12 August if there is to be a double-dissolution election, and the 18th would be the obvious date. But if it is an ordinary election and a half-Senate election it will be on 30 October, because Dennis Shanahan said so—and the member for Hotham knows that. When the political editor of the Australian gives intelligence on the cabinet, more often than not he is right on the money. I believe that, whatever the date of the election, whether it be 18 September or 30 October, the people of Australia—
—Do you back horses with the same logic?
—I would not be objecting if I were you.

—I would not, because they will lay the Prime Minister off on 18 September or 30 October. It is legislation like this. I have a copy of John Howard's report from 1996. You might remember I showed you another thing last week. I know this is getting away from the bill, but it is the Prime Minister talking about guaranteeing a second international airport regardless of the outcome of the EIS for Badgerys Creek. That is another example. But this legislation here before the House tonight, with its assault on the—
—Wait a second!
—You can have a look at it. I am very happy to let you have a look at it, because—
(Mr Hawker)—Order! Would the member come back to the bill.

—I remember the member for North Sydney very well. Like the member for Bradfield and Senator Coonan, he has chaired with distinction the Sydney Airport Community Forum. They have all done a great job and, look, they have all ended up on the frontbench. I am waiting for my opportunity to chair the Sydney Airport Community Forum, because that might provide an opportunity for the Labor Party.

—Mr Deputy Speaker, I rise on a point of order. I fail to see what the honourable member for Lowe is talking about. I believe we are here discussing a detention bill, and I ask you to bring him back to the bill.
—The member for Lowe will come back to the bill.
—The minister is very interested in this issue, because we are talking about Sydney airport now—and I know it is not related.
—I remind the member for Lowe that we have a migration bill—
—With great respect—and I do have respect for you, Mr Deputy Speaker, just as I have respect for the member for Petrie and my colleague and friend the member for North Sydney—
—What about me?
—and the former shadow minister for transport—he knows a lot about Sydney airport. I feel compelled to respond to the interjections. I realise we are a long way from—
—The interjections are out of order, and the member for Lowe will come back to the bill.

—I want to restate, particularly for the benefit of the member for Melbourne, who has just come into the chamber, that it is this bill, which is yet another example of the assault on the rights of people for a fair go in the country of a fair go, that will lead them on 18 September or 30 October—whenever the election is held—to lay off John Howard because they have had enough and they want a change. I can tell you that that is the mood of my electorate, and this is reflected in the so-called values in this bill that we are debating here tonight. People have had a gutful. They have had enough. They have said, `We want to have a change of government.' I have no doubt that when the gun goes off and we have the election—and you can see it here already, because the Prime Minister is clearly rattled; he is spending a lot of money at the moment in the anticipation that there is going to be an election this year; there could be an election at any time—it is bills like this that will influence people in my electorate to run to the ballot box on election day and grab the Labor how-to-vote card and chuck this government out. That is what should happen, and the member for North Sydney knows that. That will provide other opportunities for him and Mr Turnbull when he arrives. We will wait and see what develops, because this will be a very interesting period in Australia's political history. We look forward to seeing the new member for Wentworth when he arrives here on 30 October or 18 September. I hope that he as a lawyer, like the minister here at the table, understands that Australians do not like the fair go principle being assaulted, as it is in this bill. (Time expired)

—In speaking on the Migration Amendment (Duration of Detention) Bill 2004 and having listened to the honourable member for Lowe and his comments about a fair deal, I want to point out to him that when Labor were in government there were more children—hundreds of children—behind barbed wire than at any other time, yet he comes in here and lectures us about a sense of decency, what is fair and what is right. I want to refresh his memory, because he might not have been here at the time. Under the previous government, more children were behind that barbed wire that they talk about than at any other time in history. That government had no residential housing projects for women and children and no community options. They had the highest percentage of children in detention. In fact, 30 per cent of those people in detention in 1994 were children, compared to only seven per cent in 2004—and that includes the mainland and compliance cases.

speech.para: I also want to remind him that, while the Labor Party claim that 200 children are behind barbed wire in Australia, they are very loose and very free with their figures. Their figures are very misleading and very untruthful. In fact, they are more than untruthful—they are down right deceitful. There were 15 boat children in detention centres in mainland Australia as unauthorised arrivals with one or both parents as at 12 February 2004. All of them were failed asylum seekers. They had gone through the normal channels and had failed in their appeal for asylum. All have challenge decisions in courts or tribunals. Ten of them and their mothers were offered alternative accommodation in residential housing projects, but they declined those offers, and five of the children and their parents were ineligible due to difficulties in management processes, including some health issues and some behavioural problems.

There are other children in detention. There are 37 children with compliance cases—usually short term—and there are 15 children on Christmas Island and 83 children on Nauru. They are not in Australia, and they are certainly not behind barbed wire. It is also important for the member for Lowe's information to emphasise that these children do have access to education and recreation. I have visited, in my capacity as chair of the migration committee, a number of these detention centres. A number of the school children have external schooling, except for one who attends lessons within the centre. The children also have access to excursions such as movies, discos, swimming, picnics, camping, sightseeing and community events. I also emphasise—particularly when Labor talks about the Pacific solution—that there are hundreds more children who have access to these services.

One of the things that this government has had a very strong record in and has been very instrumental in is introducing the residential housing project. These residential housing projects exist in Woomera, Port Hedland and Port Augusta. They confirm the government's commitment to providing alternative detention arrangements for women and children. Everyone would agree that wherever possible women and children should not be in detention centres. I strongly agree with that. On 27 February 2004, there were 29 women and children in residential housing projects in Port Augusta and Port Hedland. I have been to those projects, and the people are very well accommodated in the community. They are able to do their own cooking and shopping, and they are able to live, as best as possible, in a very homelike environment.

But let us not underestimate this: they are in detention. The Labor Party would have us release anyone in a detention centre out into the community. Residential housing projects provide a more domestic environment. It is particularly important in many cultures for people to be able to prepare meals themselves and have the freedom to do their own cooking and shopping. They are also able to participate in community activities. Listening to some of the previous speakers, one would think that they were not free to engage in many of the community events that occur or in day-to-day activities like shopping et cetera.

Participation in the residential housing projects is voluntary; each individual family can decide whether they want to take up that option. Where there are concerns about the protection and welfare of a child, state agencies play a key role in the child's ongoing care and management. If a state child welfare agency recommends separation from parents, that advice is certainly accepted to the extent that it is possible within a legal framework.

Everyone in detention has different and special needs and, wherever possible, the accommodation of the residential housing program is appropriate. If the department finds that it is not appropriate they look at a number of detention options. When a child is in detention, some of the options that are available include foster care under the supervision of the state child welfare authorities or relatives. Also, there may be cases where alternative detention needs to be looked at under the auspices of a community organisation. But it is always in consultation with the Immigration Detention Advisory Group. The department provides discussions with community groups on alternative detention options and they are able to provide suitable care arrangements for detainees eligible for the granting of bridging visa E, subclass 051. As I mentioned earlier, while in detention women and children have access to a number of social, recreational and educational programs, and most children in immigration detention attend external schooling.

The reason these measures have been put in place is that there have been a number of unauthorised arrivals. In the year 2002-03 there were no boat arrivals on the Australian mainland, but there had been a significant number of boat arrivals previously, and the reduction has occurred as a result of the legislation that has been introduced. Some of the legislative changes have enabled certain parts of the Australian territory to be excised from the migration zone and those who arrive offshore without lawful authority are excluded from applying for any visa. The legislation provides the discretion to detain people in those offshore places or to move them to a declared safe country, such as Nauru, where their claims and their refugee status can be determined. From 26 August 2001 to 30 June 2002, there were 2,372 unauthorised boat arrivals at offshore excised places. This compares with 4,049 in Australia in the period from the year 2000 to the end of June 2001. From July 2001 to 15 September 2001, there were 1,277 unauthorised boat arrivals. This compares to 390 people in the period from July to September 2000.

It is important that the bill recognises and amends the Migration Act 1958 to put it beyond any doubt that an unlawful noncitizen must be kept in immigration detention unless a court makes a final determination that the detention is unlawful or that the person is an unlawful noncitizen. This bill adds a new subsection to section 196 of Migration Act 1958 that clarifies the parliament's intention that an unlawful noncitizen is only to be released from immigration detention in the circumstances as specified in section 196.

The bill is substantially the same as the Migration Amendment (Duration of Detention) Bill 2003. It ultimately was passed with amendments which limited its scope to stop courts ordering interlocutory release of persons of character concern. It is important that the bill cover broader concerns on the release of all persons from immigration detention centres before the final resolution of their court proceedings. The bill is an important measure in upholding the principles of mandatory detention for all unlawful noncitizens under the Migration Act. Subsection 196(1) of the act provides that an unlawful noncitizen who is detained under section 189 must be kept in immigration detention until he or she is removed from Australia, deported or granted a visa. Subsection 196(3) makes it clear that subsection 196(1) prevents a court from releasing an unlawful noncitizen from immigration detention unless the noncitizen has been granted a visa.

Despite the current provisions relating to immigration detention, there has been a series of cases in which the Federal Court has ordered interlocutory release of detainees prior to the resolution of their substantive court proceedings, and the amendments uphold division 7, part 2 of the act in relation to the mandatory detention of certain unlawful noncitizens. The bill also seeks to prevent the release of a detainee from immigration detention pending a court's final determination of the substantive matter as to the lawfulness of the person's detention—whether the person is an unlawful noncitizen. It does not affect the jurisdiction of any court to conclusively determine any application made to the court, including an application for review of a decision to refuse or grant or cancel a visa or make appropriate orders.

This is a very important bill. The residential housing programs have been working well. As of 27 February 2004, there were only 15 children in mainland immigration detention centres who arrived as unauthorised boat arrivals. From my experience of visiting these facilities, these children are very well cared for. It is an alternative to the detention centre, and I did note that many of the children and their mothers were quite happy in residential housing programs. They are free to come and go from the residential housing projects to the detention centre at any time. It is not compulsory; it is up to the family whether they decide that they want to take up that alternative accommodation. Currently 49 per cent of women and children are detained as a result of compliance action.

The government continues to develop and implement innovative approaches for women and children in detention. I believe that the residential housing programs will be developed even further and will be expanded. A lot of interstate cooperation is also required, particularly in foster care arrangements and areas of schooling. I know that arrangements with the states will continue to improve. There are also community care placements for people with special needs.

I feel that this bill addresses a very important issue—an issue of ensuring that we provide alternative arrangements for women and children. I have absolutely no hesitation in recommending what the bill proposes. It is a difficult area, as I mentioned earlier. It is absolutely and unmistakably an area that always arouses emotion in the community. But we do ensure that genuine refugees are given every possible form of assistance. Any visit to the Refugee Review Tribunal will reassure people that that is the case. I have visited the Refugee Review Tribunal on many occasions and seen exactly what is provided for people making applications. I have absolutely no hesitation in commending the bill to the House.

talk.start.para: —The Migration Amendment (Duration of Detention) Bill 2004 is designed to further inhibit the power of the courts to order the release from detention of noncitizens who are in Australia in an unauthorised way. It is designed to strengthen the government's mandatory detention regime with respect to asylum seekers and people who, in the eyes of the government, are unauthorised illegal migrants. It is further turning the screws on people in detention and further reducing the power of the courts to order interim release pending the determination of final legal proceedings with respect to the status of people who are in detention.

speech.para: The legislation is supposedly directed at those who are the subject of being returned pending a final decision. But there are apparently some legal experts who claim that it could even affect the situation which arose in the Al Masri case, where the court released a failed asylum seeker who simply was unable to return home to his country of origin because he was Palestinian. His detention was overturned by the court on the grounds that it had in effect become punitive detention and that it had become unlawful.

Regardless of the ambit of what the legislation is ultimately going to achieve, there is no question that what it is about is reinforcing the brutal and punitive nature of the government's mandatory detention regime and ensuring that people who arrive in Australia seeking asylum are faced with the prospect of indefinite detention in circumstances that are little different to the imprisonment that is imposed on serious criminals.

Under the regime that operates in this country, asylum seekers who arrive in Australia are put behind razor wire. They are put in detention centres that are, in some cases, out in the middle of nowhere and are designed in such a way that they are unable to see the outside world. In these detention centres there is a sense of being closed in and of being prevented from connecting with the outside world, even in some of the detention centres in the major cities—like Maribyrnong detention centre, which is very close to my electorate. When you are in that detention centre you have a very powerful sense of separation from the outside world. When you enter the detention centre there is a whole array of doors and electronic processes that are basically the same as a modern prison.

As is conceded by the member for Petrie, as part of the regime we still have significant numbers of children in detention, including children who were born in detention. We have poor accountability in the system. There has been an array of scandals over recent years associated with the management of the various detention centres by Australian Correctional Management. Due to the fact that that process has been privatised by the Howard government, you do not have direct government administration of detention centres and you therefore do not have the degree of accountability that inevitably is associated with direct government administration.

Most significant of all with the detention centres in which asylum seekers are held is the fact that you have the problem of effective indefinite sentence. You have the situation where people are held in detention—effectively imprisoned—with no indication of what the future holds for them, no idea of how long they will be in detention and no idea where they are going to end up. That is an enormously psychologically powerful and effective way of destroying people. The asylum seekers I have spoken to who have experienced detention or are in detention clearly indicate that that complete hopelessness—that lack of a sense of the future, possible release or when relief will come and they will be able to participate in any kind of normal life—has an enormously powerful psychological impact on people. That is why so many people in detention centres have engaged in acts of self-harm. That is why so many people in detention centres have done things that at one angle look relatively extreme. It is because of the psychological impact of not only being imprisoned but also having no idea how long that imprisonment will be for and when it will be terminated. On top of that is the fact that these people have committed no crime.

It is worth pausing for a moment to think about the people who are in detention centres in Australia, the people on whom this debate has focused—asylum seekers, predominantly boat people. Who are these people? Why are they here? What are their aspirations? Statistically, it has been found that they are mostly refugees, people who have been fleeing genuine threats of persecution, torture and death. They are people, in many cases, whose close family members have been murdered. They often flee their countries of origin with no idea of where their family is and with no capacity to discover what has happened to their loved ones. Obviously not all of those people are in that category, but the outcome of refugee applications certainly indicates that many of them are ultimately determined to be in that category.

Those people who are not determined to be in that category, failed asylum seekers, end up in detention for lengthy periods of time and in many cases are unable to return to their countries of origin. What crime have they committed? Why are they in Australia? The worst that can be said of these people, almost invariably, is that they are seeking a better life for themselves and their families. Even regarding those people who can be described only as economic refugees or economic migrants the worst that can be said is that they come from very poor countries with very limited opportunities and that by coming to Australia they hope to achieve a better life and better opportunities for themselves and their families. Those aspirations are nearly universal in our own society and I find it hard to condemn them on the part of anybody, be they Australians or people seeking to come to Australia.

Those are the kinds of people that we are dealing with. Yet when we hear both at first hand and second hand of the experiences of people in indefinite detention and the impact that it can have on young children—who can become withdrawn and suffer a whole range of physical and psychological illnesses and damage—we have to ask ourselves a very fundamental question: why do we treat in this way human beings whose sole aim is to improve their own lives and the lives of their families and who have committed no crime? Why does our society do this?

The Victorian Foundation for the Survivors of Torture, which has long been present in my electorate and is run by superb and very dedicated people like Paris Aristotle, is a good source of information about these issues. When you talk to the people who are directly involved in helping refugees who have come to this country fleeing the threat of persecution and torture, you get some sense of the life experiences that many of these refugees have had, of the threats that they have faced in their countries of origin and the reasons why they seek to come to a country like Australia. In many cases they have had life experiences that are so extreme and appalling that we can barely imagine them. In many of these cases, refugee status is achieved correctly, but not in all. There are plenty of people who fail to get refugee status for one reason or another. When you hear the stories of these failed asylum seekers and you understand what they have been through and what they faced in their home countries, it is very difficult to look them in the eye and say, `We have no place for you in our country.'

I understand that we as a nation cannot let everybody in. Clearly we cannot have an open door policy, nor should we. We have a range of fundamental national interest questions that have to be considered in determining how people come to this country—whether or not they are allowed to stay permanently and in what circumstances. But the vilification by this government of entire groups of people, such as asylum seekers and boat people, who are guilty of nothing worse than seeking a better life and better economic opportunities for themselves and their children is something that I have found extremely difficult to stomach over recent years. We do have issues to deal with and matters to debate regarding how to deal with people who enter Australia in an unauthorised way, people who overstay their visas and illegal migrants who work. These are legitimate issues. There are a range of matters that we all have to deal with, and they are a legitimate subject for debate. There are understandable differences of view as to how hard we as a society ought to be in seeking to regulate these matters.

But the one thing in these debates that in my opinion has been simply beyond the pale and beneath contempt is the persistent and vicious vilification of entire groups and classes of people on the basis of who they are, not what they have done. They are vilified not for any crimes or offences they may have committed, but simply for their aspirations. The bad behaviour of particular individuals has been by implication attributed to entire groups. In the eyes of the Howard government, all asylum seekers—all the so-called boat people—are tarred with the misdeeds of a small number of individuals who may fit that description. The acts of particular individuals have been attributed to entire groups of people in the public domain in order to vilify those people and condemn them as a group in the eyes of the Australian community.

We all remember phrases like `we don't want these sorts of people in Australia' and the scandal of the `children overboard'. But the point that I think has been missed by many commentators in the debate about the `children overboard' scandal is what happened immediately after it was exposed. What did the Howard government—in particular the Prime Minister and the then minister for immigration—do when it finally became clear that the `children overboard' story was simply a fiction? They came into the parliament and, instead of apologising and indicating clearly that they were mistaken and that it was wrong for them to vilify entire groups of people on the basis of what was subsequently demonstrated to be nonexistent evidence about the supposed acts of one or two, they immediately sought to vilify and condemn the same entire groups of people based on the other acts attributed to one or two individuals.

So the minister for immigration came into the parliament and started to regale us with a variety of stories about particular asylum seekers who had sought to sabotage boats, even to deliberately try and sink boats, in order to force the hand of the Australian government. Not only did the government not retreat from the appalling slander of the `children overboard' story and not only did they not apologise for the group vilification—the guilt by association—that they had pursued and imposed on hundreds of people based on the alleged acts of a couple of people that ultimately turned out not to have occurred, but as soon as that was exposed they then moved on to do exactly the same thing with respect to other alleged acts—the same thing. They attributed the misbehaviour of a handful of people, assuming that it might have happened, to all people in the same category.

If you are on a boat with 300 or 400 people and a couple of people seek to disable the engines for some tactical purpose, it is automatically assumed that you are equally guilty of that action and equally responsible for it. This from the party of individual responsibility. This from the Liberal party—the party that purports to uphold the rights and responsibilities of the individual in our society: vilifying whole groups of people based on the alleged acts of particular individuals.

Added to that has been a consistent pattern of seeking to ensure that the Australian people cannot connect with asylum seekers in any kind of natural or human way. There have been consistent efforts to ensure that the media cannot portray boat people as human beings, that no inconvenient pictures of young mothers with small children in their arms find their way into the media and that there is no way for ordinary Australian citizens to actually see asylum seekers for what they are: ordinary people from different countries and poor countries who seek nothing more than to escape the threats they have experienced and to get a better, safer life in Australia. All of this is in order to manipulate racist sentiments in the Australian community for political gain. That is the thing that I simply cannot accept.

I can accept that there is a legitimate debate about how to arrange our laws with respect to people who arrive in an unauthorised way. We do have to protect our borders. We do have to ensure that we know who is coming into Australia and in what way—that is all legitimate. There will be different views on that. I disagree with the government on many of them and the Labor Party disagrees with the government on many of them. What I cannot accept is the appalling vilification of innocent people for the purposes of political gain—for the purposes of arousing some of the darkest passions in the Australian community in order to achieve the political gain that would enable the Howard government to be re-elected.

It could be said, and I think it is probably correct, that to some extent this strategy is now breaking down. There are signs of quiet softening on the part of the government. In fact, some of comments of the member for Petrie indicate that the government is quietly trying to reduce the number of children in detention. That at least is an improvement. In circumstances where asylum seekers have been exposed to the Australian community—in the case of temporary protection visa holders, they are admitted refugees; they are just not given the same status as others who make successful refugee applications—it is good to see that, where those people have been in the community working in many parts of rural Australia, the response from those communities has been powerful and positive. From conservative communities—in many cases communities where there are not many people from a non-English-speaking background—the response has been powerful and positive: `These are good people. We would like them to stay. They work hard and contribute to our community.' To the great credit of one or two members of the government, such as the members for Mallee and Riverina, those views are starting to be reflected in the views being put in the parliament and in the party room.

There is a debate about Australia's population and about how we will grow as a nation and what role immigration will play. I am a high-immigration person. I think that immigration has been absolutely fundamental to the building of Australia. I think that, of all the decisions that have been made by politicians in this nation over the past 100 years or so, there have been few of greater significance than that taken by Arthur Calwell and Ben Chifley in the post-war era to open Australia to mass non-English-speaking immigration. It has fundamentally changed and improved our society. I think we need to stick to that approach and that means welcoming people who are refugees. It means welcoming those who are seeking the opportunity to make a better life, because, overwhelmingly, people who come to Australia with those objectives will contribute enormously to our community.

Labor believe that we should restrict the role of mandatory detention, that we should have a 90-day period for the purposes of health, security and identity checks and that, thereafter, any further detention in that regard should be subject to an automatic monthly review by an independent expert committee, so there is hope—there is a way out—for people who are detained. We believe the government, not dubious private companies, should administer the detention centres. Most of all, we will not engage in the kind of vilification that has been the hallmark of the Howard government's approach to these issues.

There will be a day of reckoning in Australia about the recent history of our treatment of asylum seekers. It will be similar to the cathartic experiences in the stories of the stolen generation. The time will come when huge numbers of Australians, many more than is currently the case, start asking: why did we treat innocent people and small children this way? There will be a day of reckoning. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I listened with great interest to the member for Melbourne and I commend him on the tone of his contribution. I also have some brief comments to make in my opposition to the Migration Amendment (Duration of Detention) Bill 2004. I believe it is no more than a cynical political exercise by the government designed to get asylum seekers branded illegal entrants and get the issue of border security back on the agenda for the election. How anyone describing their philosophy as liberal can countenance such legislation is a mystery to me. I have heard in recent weeks grave concern expressed by many people who support this government on other policy platforms; they feel abhorrence over this policy and its results in recent years. Notwithstanding the security issues that they are concerned about, they can separate—and quite easily separate—the issues of security and the treatment of people as human beings seeking a better way of life.

speech.para: In September last year the Migration Amendment (Duration of Detention) Bill 2003 was passed by this parliament, having been successfully and fairly amended by the Senate. The 2003 bill was the government's reaction to Federal Court decisions such as in the Al Masri case, where the court ordered that a TPV applicant who had agreed to return home be released from detention because at that time passage through three of six countries bordering his homeland had been denied, with the remaining three still under negotiation. The court found that this person could not be detained indefinitely until the repatriation process was sorted out and his return home could be ordered, and therefore his detention was unlawful. The court ordered his release. This was an interlocutory order, because his release was ordered before a final decision about his fate had been made.

The 2003 bill sought to prevent the Australian courts from ordering the interlocutory release from immigration detention of people determined to be unlawful noncitizens. This was to apply to all people in detention: those who had breached the conditions of their visas, those who were deemed to be of character concern and those detained while seeking asylum. The government's argument then was cloaked in terms of protecting the Australian community from criminal, undesirable and illegal immigrants, including asylum seekers—again paying no mind to the fact that it is not illegal to seek asylum.

The parliamentary process rightly saw the bill amended so that the exemption from interlocutory release orders could be applied only to those of character concern—for example, those who breached their visa conditions by overstaying or criminal activity—rather than all so-called unlawful noncitizens, people who in the vast number of cases arrived by plane and not by boat. This effectively meant that the court could still order the interim release of asylum seekers applying for temporary protection or other visas if the court decided this was appropriate under the circumstances of a particular case. The government's argument for the protection of the community meant that the minister backed himself into a corner and had to accept the Senate's amendments, and the parliamentary process thus delivered a fair piece of legislation.

This 2004 amendment to the Migration Act delivers on the minister's promise that he would introduce a new bill to ensure the exemption from interlocutory release was applied to all unlawful noncitizens. Never mind the fact that parliament has already thoroughly debated, and decided to exclude, this particular amendment to the Migration Act, and never mind the democratic principle of the separation of powers. The government do not trust the democratic parliamentary process, it seems, and they do not trust the courts. It is not the role of the parliament to unquestioningly support government policy, nor is it the role of the courts to unquestioningly implement it. The motivation for the 2003 bill was to stop the courts undermining the government's tough stance on border security and asylum seekers. The effect of the 2003 bill being passed with amendment was that our laws to deal with criminal and other illegal activity were improved, and our obligation under international law that refugees should not be treated as criminals was therefore preserved.

As the previous speaker, the member for Melbourne, said, the psychological damage done to women and children in our detention centres in recent years is a disgrace. Notwithstanding his comments about the moves that have been made after significant and overwhelming public pressure for a better process for women and children—for some to be placed outside those outback camps—our detention centre process in recent years has been a disgrace, a shame and a travesty of human rights.

Rather than debating an amendment that the parliament decided to reject five months ago, we should be looking at ways to improve our system of dealing with asylum seekers. A system that results in detention for periods of one, two or three years, or indefinitely—which was the potential outcome of the Al Masri case—is a flawed system, to put it mildly. We should be looking at separating asylum seekers from other immigration detainees and dealing with them in an entirely different system, recognising our international obligations. We should be thinking in terms of faster and more efficient processing, rather than indefinite or unacceptably lengthy detention, as the first step for those seeking asylum.

If the government is looking at current polling, it might note that many in the Australian electorate, while still concerned about security issues, are also concerned about the loss of our `fair go' reputation and are questioning both our asylum seeker policies after the debacle of the Pacific solution and our eagerness to get involved in a world police force. We can and should have a policy that treats asylum seekers as human beings, not one that demonises them and brands them potential terrorists. That only feeds ignorance and intolerance within our society.

Last Sunday evening I had dinner with two Kurdish refugees and their wives in Bathurst. Both men fled Iraq prior to 2001; one had been in the Iraqi army. They fled to Turkey, where they hid for two years in fear of recapture and their return and likely execution. These men have been granted residency and have found employment in Bathurst. One has completed a university degree, as has his wife, although they are looking to Sydney for greater employment opportunities; the other works for a local company—he is a permanent employee. All four love Bathurst and its people, who have made them so welcome.

They point out how natural it is for recent refugees to gather in communities and to speak their language with fellow countrymen. They have many friends in the suburbs of Sydney where Middle Eastern immigrants now live. They do their monthly shopping there. But they are quite happy to return to Bathurst, which they now regard as their home town. As they were telling me this story I remembered the years of the post-war immigration—and even recent immigration from Vietnam and other places—and how the first generation of settlers from whatever country gathered in communities to seek the security of their own cultures, cultures that in many cases are thousands of years old. Why wouldn't they? What is the culture to which they are supposed to suddenly transform themselves? What is the Australian culture? Surely it is but an amalgam of all of these influences from the post-war migration program and beyond. Whatever it is to be Australian, these Kurdish friends certainly understand what it is to be Australian now. They are people who have contributed in a far richer way than they ever dreamt they possibly could to this society, because they have been accepted.

What it means to be Australian now is different to what it meant 20 or 30 years ago and is perhaps a lot different to what it might be in another 30 years. That is the beauty of our ability to bring these people in and accept that the first generation might logically want to gather in their own cultural areas and share language and experiences with those of their own culture. But that is no reason to condemn them, as we are being in many cases encouraged to do by a very subtle use of policy, public statement, implication and innuendo. The media has played a role, too, in jumping to brand people with a tag often because of their country of origin.

As we have vilified whole groups of people in recent years—as the previous speaker, the member for Melbourne, said—on the basis of slur and innuendo and fearmongering, we have created fear and suspicion in our suburbs. We have exacerbated the sorts of incidents that do occur. I do not deny they occur, but they have been occurring for many years. We can look at the influence of some quite shady characters on the southern European migrants that came to this country in years past. We can look at the Riverina and the influence that certain individuals had on the Italian community, much to the dismay and horror of that community, who were 99.9 per cent hardworking contributors to the economic growth of this country post the Second World War.

talk.start.para: —We had a few Nazi war criminals as well.

—We may have had. But I think that they have settled into the democratic ways of this country and accepted that their past behaviour was unacceptable in this country. So too the vast majority of people coming to this country from the Middle East in recent times.

speech.para: In regard to the men and I spoke of—and their wives—whom I had dinner with last Sunday, the men have found employment in Bathurst, one permanent employment. They talked about how natural it was for recent refugees to gather in those communities. But in no way do they accept the branding of those communities as unlawful or indeed prone to the sorts of activities that have been alleged as common within those communities. That is stereotyping and the worst form of racial tagging, I would suggest.

While we seem to spurn and point fingers at certain sectors of the community, I wonder whether we are going to write off the whole of our National Rugby League on the basis of one group of people and certain allegations. I think not. I would suggest that we use the same sort of attitude when we come to judging our communities and those within them.

Had these two Kurdish gentlemen I speak of fled their country after 2001 they could have found their way to a country other than Turkey—perhaps Greece, where other Kurds have gone. They may have been able to purchase a passage to Indonesia. They may in their determination to reach Australia have bought passage on a people smuggler's boat. They may have ended up in Curtin, Port Hedland, Nauru or Woomera. They also may have been subsequently sent back to their homeland and they may have been unfairly branded. But fortunately they came prior to the hysteria that has created this stereotyping. They may have been temporary protection visa holders, but they may also have been rejected. Who knows?

They are little different from the several hundred who arrived on the Tampa in 2001, I would argue, or those who arrived after 2001 or the many hundreds who arrived before. They are not among the 60,000, mostly from countries of Anglo-Saxon origin, who are in this country illegally after arriving on a visa. These are the illegal non-Australian citizens, not the asylum seekers targeted by legislation such as this. Instead of exploiting these people for political gain, how much closer to our fair-go reputation might we be if we compulsorily detained asylum seekers for only the time—ideally a maximum of six to eight weeks; I think I heard the member for Melbourne say 90 days—it took for security and health issues to be ascertained?

We have the technology these days to release asylum seekers into the community under the care and supervision of church and charity organisations, not just to send mum and the kids off to suburban Woomera and give them a home while dad stays in the outback desert camp but to keep the families intact. Perhaps we have the ingenuity in this country for us to be a trendsetter. Why not a smart card to allow access to basic needs? Why not a finite and determined amount of social security that these people could access with their smart card? Then we would know where they were at any particular time. The computer technology is there. The decision on their application for temporary or more permanent protection would be delivered to them in person. They would be required to turn up for the decision and the interview.

talk.start.para: —What happens if they don't?

—I would suggest there would be very little temptation for the people I have spoken with on this issue to disappear into the woodwork like the 60,000 people who have arrived under other circumstances with a visa by aeroplane into this country. As I have suggested, they are the ones who want to disappear. Asylum seekers, by and large, are very genuine. They want to keep their families intact. They want to partake of the opportunities this country offers. I would suggest the smart card technology as a way of enabling them to be humanised and to be part of our society. Then, if it is determined that their country is safe enough to return to, so be it. As we have seen with the Hazaras in Young and Dubbo and with my Kurdish friends in Bathurst, these people want to work and contribute. They want to share their determination and their energy; they do not want to abuse the privilege they would be offered—and believe me, they regard the offer of even temporary protection as an absolute privilege. I am a fairly emotional person, but it does bring tears to your eyes when you see how determined these people are to make a go of it—and how they are making a go of it and seeing opportunities that many Australians never thought were there.

speech.para: It is a disgrace that we should attempt to tighten a noose around these people and perpetuate the dehumanisation of outback incarceration. This is something we did not do with the Kosovar refugees or, indeed, with those from eastern Europe after World War II. The shame of it all is that we do not take any responsibility for people once we do send them back, should their asylum status be denied. I have got a series of questions on the Notice Paper for the minister around this issue, and I do not believe the concerns of Hazara temporary protection visa holders about the safety and security of returnees to their country are in any way mollified by assurances from Afghan authorities. The same applies to asylum seekers from Iraq or Iran. I reject any legislation that could have the effect that a person is unlawfully kept in detention for a significant period of time because the court did not have the power to release them because of the operation of this amendment to the Migration Act. I therefore totally reject the bill.

talk.start.para: —The Migration Amendment (Duration of Detention) Bill 2004 essentially deals with the power of the Federal Court to make interim orders in relation to the continuing detention of a small number of asylum seekers—and I stress that it is a small number. One of the points that emerged from the contributions of the member for Petrie and the member for Forrest—when they tried to make a political point about the number of women and children in detention some decades ago and the limited number of people in detention now—was: what is the urgency of this legislation? The numbers involved are minimal, and they have established that point. The two other classes of people who were previously subject to detention have been dealt with, so we are indeed dealing with a very small number of people.

speech.para: This bill seeks to reopen a debate on legislative changes that were dealt with by the Senate last year. As is well known, the Migration Act provides for a system of mandatory detention for all unlawful noncitizens. An unlawful noncitizen is defined as someone who does not have legal authority to be in the Australian migration zone. The law provides that an unlawful noncitizen must be detained until one of two things happens: either they leave Australia or they are granted a substantive visa, such as a temporary protection visa. I have long been, and I remain, a strong supporter of mandatory detention. Fifteen years ago I was probably as naive as many of the speakers I have heard in this debate. I believed that everyone who came to my office was genuine, honest and sincere—that they were, as they claimed to be, asylum seekers. The reality, many years later, convinces me that we do need a form of mandatory detention.

I am not a person who would brand these people `terrorists'. I think that anyone who has half a brain would know that the last way by which a terrorist would try to come to this country would be to endanger themselves in a leaking boat and face detention. But in the real world, in the daily reality of my electorate, we do have to face up to the fact that we do need identity checks. We do need health checks. We have to look at security issues. Most crucially, we have to look at the fact—which, unfortunately, the member for Calare, whom I respect deeply on a wide variety of issues, does not seem to understand—that people will disappear. That is the international experience. For all the determination of people to work and contribute to this country, when people are faced with the glaring reality of losing their cases, they do not front up. They disappear. That has been the experience of all of the European countries. It has certainly been the experience of the United States.

It is up to those people who oppose mandatory detention to come up with a viable alternative. There are expressions thrown around about the possibilities of technology et cetera; there are dreams that groups out there are going to actually take responsibility for people whom they take into their care. It is not believable, quite frankly. These people will find it very difficult to detain people. They feel so compassionate about them that, at the end of the day, they will not take responsibility and these people will disappear.

There are currently three broad categories of people subject to mandatory detention. The first is criminal deportees, generally noncitizens whose permanent residence was revoked after serving a period of imprisonment following conviction for certain criminal offences. I note concerns on my part that perhaps the government has been exploring the option of actually taking citizenship away from people, and that is why there is an FOI in regard to that matter. In recent years, the minister of the day has become too inclined to deport people for criminal offences. I have seen instances of people in my electorate, like one person of Croatian extraction. He was 38 years old, and he had never committed a violent offence. His offences were related to fraud, social security cheating et cetera. He came to Australia when he was four years of age. This was a very different case from people like Vietnamese drug dealers, British drug dealers or whatever, who arrived a year ago and have not got citizenship. He was 38 years old, he had been here for 34 years with parents, brothers and sisters, he had no family in Croatia, and he was deported by this government. Can I say, while I am at it, that the government is going too far down that road. The second category of people subject to mandatory detention are those whose visas have been cancelled in response to character concerns, including security concerns. The third category is asylum seekers who arrive in our migration zone without a valid visa and whose claims are under consideration or have been rejected.

The member for Forrest spoke of a series of cases from the very limited number of people who are in the asylum seeker category. He was actually talking about two cases, and they are very narrow in their focus. The stated reason for the introduction of this bill is to constrain the courts, particularly the Federal Court, from interfering with the operation of mandatory detention by making interim or interlocutory orders for the release of applicants pending the final determination of their claims. The two cases referred to are very narrow. They set very little precedent for the other people in detention, and this is quite simply a political gambit.

The opposition would be concerned if there were evidence that the courts were increasingly and lightly releasing unlawful noncitizens in circumstances of mandatory detention. As I said earlier, I believe in the system. We have to have it. I would be concerned if I thought that, willy-nilly, the courts of this country were releasing people unnecessarily. No evidence has been produced in support of such a contention. In fact, it is notable that, while the Minister for Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs referred in his second reading speech to `a trend by the Federal Court to order the interlocutory release of persons in immigration detention', he made specific reference to just one case—and a quite exceptional one at that. This trend, as specified by him, is one case, one example.

I do not deny that there might have been several cases, but I remain unconvinced that there has been a sufficient trend to cause alarm, particularly given changes to the law that the opposition has already supported. I would emphasise that the opposition supported an earlier law change that prevents the interim release of criminal deportees and those who are subject to character concerns. So there is no dispute about those two categories of people and no evidence that the law change applying to them is in any way deficient or inoperative. We are thus left with the issue of a small number of cases involving asylum seekers.

While there may be others, there are two headline cases involving the Federal Court issuing interlocutory orders. The first case, the one referred to by the Minister for Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs in his second reading speech, is that of VFAD, an Afghan asylum seeker whose case was before both a single judge and then the full court of the Federal Court in 2002. While the minister made a reference to the order of the court, he made no reference to the circumstances involved. He did not tell this parliament the specific circumstances, which are extremely narrow and very rarely apply. The reality is that the notes for the case indicate that on 7 December 2001 a migration officer said:

quote.para: ... that he was satisfied that the respondent had a well-founded fear of persecution.

speech.para: That departmental officer departed overseas two days later, having said, basically, that the person would become a citizen if his security clearance was good. In the intervening time, there was an emphasis on changing circumstances in Afghanistan. But the situation was that a departmental officer essentially determined that that person had a valid refugee claim. This case was also accompanied by other peculiarities. The Hotham Mission gave guarantees with regard to housing, ongoing support, referral and material assistance. The court said at point 40:

quote.para: The position of the applicant in the present case is quite different in that, if his application succeeds, he will not be an unlawful non-citizen but, rather, will be a lawful non-citizen who is being unlawfully detained.

speech.para: Those were the specifics of the case. We are not talking about the kind of broad brush approach that is allegedly the basis for this legislation.
