This person had a very singular and unusual circumstance. An officer departed overseas soon after seemingly thinking the applicant had a valid refugee case. At point 50 of the case the judge said:

quote.para: The applicant has a strong prima facie documentary case as the decision record appears to be a decision to grant him a protection visa.

speech.para: That is the reason the court released him, not because the courts were saying, `We're going to let people out every five seconds; we want to overthrow the legislation; we want to destroy mandatory detention.' They let him out because of the peculiarities of the case. It was a specific, idiosyncratic, very individual case. Under FOI, the files for that case were obtained and perused, and the applicant argued that he was not, in fact, an unlawful noncitizen in the terms of the act. The court accepted that as an arguable proposition, based on the evidence before them, and ordered his release. It is clear that the circumstances of the case are extremely unusual and offer no comfort to others who are in detention.

The other case, the case of Al Masri, is interesting for two reasons. It shows those dreamers who believe that all the claimants are honest and that their words can always be taken as gospel that that is not so. Mr Al Masri said that he wanted to leave the country. He wished to get on a plane and leave, and at the early stage he was released. But the telling point here is that later on the court threw him back in detention. The same court that is under attack for being so loose and liberal, so easily persuaded to release people, said that in the intervening period the government had persuaded Israel, from recollection, to allow Mr Al Masri's movement so he could leave the country. Mr Al Masri, the man who had wanted to rush onto a plane and leave the country, decided at this stage that he did not want to leave the country, and he sought an injunction to restrain the government from releasing him.

The case is a narrow one. It received some publicity. The person was a failed asylum seeker who had, on the surface of it, agreed to depart Australia but was unable to do so, because a number of countries in the Middle East initially refused to allow him to transit through their territory. Eventually, the court ordered his continued detention, pending the finalisation of the necessary arrangements for his departure from Australia. And that is the point: the case which is cited as one of the examples of this trend, this tendency, this need for legislation, is actually extremely narrow and is not one that is going to be repeated every five minutes. It is clear that neither case has raised the probability of the courts ordering the interim release of masses of asylum seekers who are in detention.

As I said earlier, we need a detention system. We need to be able to check on people. We have a situation where vast numbers want to come here. Previous speakers have said that we should be pleased that we get aspirants, people who are keen to live in this country and who will work hard et cetera. Obviously, we would do the same thing. If we were in their circumstances, we would try to beat the system. But, equally, every society has the right to try to contain this problem. If we want to say that it is right that these people beat our refugee humanitarian intake rules because they are going to contribute to this country, we might as well go to Beijing or Nairobi and say that we have a new processing system for people who are aspiring to a better lifestyle. Let us be honest about it. The refugee humanitarian intake should not be utilised for people to come here with false claims and basically beat the system. That is part of this picture.

No-one else would dare to say this, including the government, but, contrary to the statements of some members on this side who come in here and say that most of these people are proven to be refugees and it is dreadful that anyone is impliedly detained, I have a belief that there is a covert policy in the department to approve as many of these onshore cases as possible. I do not believe it is intellectually viable to argue that, just because a person comes to this country on a boat, that person ipso facto should have greater proclivity to being a genuine refugee than people lining up in Islamabad and New Delhi.

To me it is interesting that a very high proportion of onshore claimants, despite all the refugee advocates' complaints, win their cases. It is not because they have better cases or because their struggle to pay the money and get on boats proves that they are more genuine; it is because, fundamentally, the politics of this country require that as many as possible are released as soon as possible. It is an embarrassment, a political difficulty, for whoever is in power if hundreds of people are detained for long periods.

Contrary to the view of some members on this side of the House, I do not see that as being related in any way to saying that mandatory detention is wrong, just because the vast majority pass through the system. The reason for that is, firstly, because there is a covert policy to pass them and, secondly, because they cannot be checked in the same manner as offshore claimants. We cannot, in these cases, go around to houses in Islamabad. Late last year, of the six women who claimed to be on their own, in four of the cases the immigration department found their spouses living in the same house. Male partners who were claimed to be dead were found to be present in Islamabad and Peshawar. In reality more people pass through the system in this country because the system cannot vet them probably. People throw away material and evidence and invent ethnicity and political histories that are not true. As I say, that is no argument against mandatory detention.

With regard to the government's genuineness in these matters, as I say I think this legislation is unnecessary. It is aimed at marginalising the opposition as having a pro-refugee, anti-detention policy. But the government's own record shows its total failure to deal with illegal workers. The government took a very strong stand recently: it provided a phone number, and you can apparently phone and dob people in. The immigration department says that this is the responsibility of the department of labour, but the department of labour then says that is the responsibility of the department of immigration. Labor has said that people should have a card that proves they have the right to work in this country; if they do not, they are illegal and their employers should be heavily fined.

I will not linger on this matter. Suffice it to say that we have a situation where 1,000 permanent visas were given to rejected applicants. The immigration department, which vets people, said that these people had no claims, that they should not be in the country and should not be given permanent residence. The minister, under ministerial discretion, allowed 1,000 to stay permanently. This matter has been canvassed very strongly over the past year. But people started complaining about boat people. I complained too over the latest case of the Kurds, who were determined to come here. They were generally found not to have valid refugee claims. It is worrying that these boat people attempted to come here. But, when 1,000 permanent visas were issued by the minister, after the applicants were rejected by the department, you have to wonder about the bona fides in this matter.

I strongly oppose the legislation. It is unnecessary, does not deal with the fundamental problem, the numbers that would be affected are minimal, there is no evidence of a trend that the government needs to counter and the court has not been out there in a cavalier fashion letting people out. The court has done so in two individual cases whose circumstances were very narrow. They are not precedents for a wide-ranging policy. The legislation is totally unnecessary.

talker.name: Hardgrave, Gary, MP
Mr HARDGRAVE
talker.role: Minister for Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

talk.start.para: —in reply—I am pleased to join this debate on the Migration Amendment (Duration of Detention) Bill 2004. I thank all the members who have made a contribution. The purpose of this bill is to restate and uphold the original intention behind the Migration Amendment Act 1992 and the Migration Reform Act 1992. These are the acts that introduced mandatory detention. The acts were introduced by the Australian Labor Party when they were in government. They have been maintained by the Howard government during our time in office and they are about sending a signal to those who would like to ply the trade of people-smuggling to try and bring people to this country by unlawful means that all unlawful arrivals will be detained to allow their status to be worked out, and to work out whether or not they qualify for entrance into Australia.

speech.para: This bill is not a departure from the Migration Act. It is a reinforcement of what was clearly the intention of the parliament back in 1992. The purpose of section 196 was to put beyond any doubt that an unlawful noncitizen must be detained until he or she is either removed from Australia, deported or granted a visa. Section 196 makes it clear that there is to be no discretion for any person or court to release an unlawful noncitizen from detention until one of these events occurs. Recently, however, there has been a trend for the Federal Court to make interlocutory orders for the release of persons from immigration detention, pending the final determination of that person's judicial review application. This has resulted in those who are unlawful noncitizens being released into the Australian community until their applications are finalised by the courts.

This process can often be a lengthy one and can often result in inconsistencies in the way the policy of mandatory detention is applied. This was never the intention of the parliament a dozen years ago, in 1992, when the mandatory detention regime was introduced. This bill ensures that parliament's original intention in relation to mandatory detention is absolutely clear. The bill amends section 196 to ensure that an unlawful noncitizen must be kept in immigration detention, except where he or she is removed from Australia, deported, granted a visa, or a court makes a final determination that the detention is unlawful or that the person is not an unlawful noncitizen.

As I mentioned when I introduced the bill, this bill does not prevent a court from making a final decision in relation to any application made to the court. The simple and clear intention of this bill is to uphold the government's mandatory detention policy, which was the policy of the previous government. Although those opposite can afford, as oppositions can, to have a variety of views, depending on the day of the week or the fora in which they happen to present them, we on this side are consistent in our determination to ensure the efficient and effective removal of unlawful noncitizens from Australia.

We on the side have been accused by the opposition of having some sort of obsession about this. But we are obsessed about consistency, we are obsessed about a sense of purpose, we are obsessed about the enforcement of that consistency and sense of purpose, we are obsessed about the rule of law and we are obsessed about ensuring that we decide who comes to Australia—in other words, about ensuring that our borders are protected from those who would attempt to breach them by bringing unlawful arrivals to this country in boats and by other means.

It is the very clear and simple intention of this bill to uphold the mandatory detention policy and to ensure that we send a strong signal to those who want to ply this trade that this country is very determined also to uphold the integrity of people who come to this country lawfully. But, yet again, the Australian Labor Party are sending a signal that they are soft on border protection. The Australian Labor Party are sending a signal that they have a variety of views in their own caucus—that there is torment in their caucus, as far as these matters are concerned. Now that the courts have demonstrated an increasing willingness to release persons from immigration detention pending final determination of their cases, we want to ensure that this matter is given the urgency that it deserves. It is absolutely crucial that this bill is passed.

The member for Reid, in his contribution, raised the case of VFAD in 2002, where the full Federal Court held that section 196(3) is silent as to the power of this court to grant interlocutory release in circumstances where a person in detention claims not to be an unlawful noncitizen. Further, the court did not accept that section 196(3), by implication, denied it power to order the interlocutory release. The member for Reid, in his contribution, suggested other reasons. But in the Federal Court's own opinions that have been offered in this particular case, the clear reason that needed to be addressed in this bill, and which is being addressed in this bill, is that `parliament has not made unmistakably clear its intention to abrogate the power of this court to protect a fundamental freedom by ordering the release, on an interlocutory basis, of persons in detention'. This bill is all about making that absolutely and completely clear.

I note that the member for Reid did admit that people do disappear—and this is the point. As people are released without a determination about their lawfulness being made, they can disappear into our community. That is the situation that occurs in the United States and Europe, where collectively there are millions and millions of people who are unlawful. There are millions of people in the United States alone, and across Europe, who are part of those societies without lawful reason to be there and who are making a mockery of the immigration processes of those places. This country is now becoming a template for other countries in that our approach and the range of measures we have in place have made a difference. This country is very much determined to make sure that a strong signal is sent to people smugglers and those in the legal profession here in Australia who hover nearby to try and deliver access into the Australian community, via court orders, without lawful visas having been issued.

The Labour Party in the United Kingdom are grabbing our approach; those opposite have the ghost of Gough Whitlam hovering over the policy-free zone. They have a policy on border protection of `let them in', and their policy on detention is `let them out'; it is the `let them in, let them out policy'. The member for Melbourne said that we vilify asylum seekers; no, but we vilify people smugglers. We believe their vile trade needs to stop. We do not apologise for this, whereas Labor seems to be very accommodating to people smugglers, sending them a message that, if they should be elected later this year, the people smugglers will be well and truly back in business and more and more people will be able to come to this country through that process.

The member for Melbourne even held up the late Arthur Calwell as a champion of non-English-speaking migration. What an absolute farce! The man was well known for his comments about `Wongs and whites'. At the end of the day, the Labor Party are trying to rewrite history yet again on these matters. While they may well have had, over the last 20 years, some 13 different ministers and shadow ministers covering the area of migration, it is a hot potato that those opposite seem never to want to hold. The latest shadow minister for immigration, the member for Perth, gave an eloquent listing of a variety of cases—but I think he was being totally bamboozled by the detail—distracting attention from the fact that those opposite are demonstrating complete ambivalence towards the concept of mandatory detention, a process that they themselves introduced.

In summary, the amendments contained in this bill will ensure the parliament's original intention—the intention that was stated in legislation introduced by the Labor Party in 1992—and will ensure that, in relation to migration detention, everyone around the world and everyone in our region understands very clearly what this government stands for and that the integrity of our Migration Act cannot be compromised. I commend the bill to the chamber.

talk.start.para: —In public life we come across people from all walks of life, many of whom in their own unique and particular way leave a lasting impression on us and on the community that they choose to serve. In my electorate of Calwell, one such individual was Petros Pantazopoulos, who passed away suddenly on New Year's Day this year. Petros was born on 1 April 1943 in a small town near Kalamata in the southern mainland of Greece. Like thousands of other Greek migrants, Petros arrived in Australia in the early 1960s seeking a better and secure future. Like many of his Greek compatriots, he settled in the high-rise flats in Collingwood in Melbourne's inner north before moving to the outer north-western suburbs of Melbourne and settling into the suburb of Coolaroo. It was here that he would settle with his wife—his childhood sweetheart, Antonia—and together they would raise two very bright, warm and thoughtful children, George and Helen.

speech.para: Petros was always motivated by the desire to help those who were often unable to help themselves. He donated himself to community life without reward but, rather, to simply offer support and advice to those who needed it. He spoke fluent English and had excellent knowledge of his community structures. It was no surprise therefore that those who were not as familiar with the English language would seek Petros's assistance, and he was always happy to help. But it was his involvement with the Upfield soccer club that gave him the greatest satisfaction. His other great passion was politics. Petros was dedicated to the Upfield soccer club, which he had been involved with since its inception in 1982. In his latter years, he would become an effective and successful secretary of that local soccer club, and in 2003 he took its seniors team to its first premiership in 10 years.

Petros was an almost daily visitor to my electorate office, and it was this premiership win that was arguably his favourite topic of conversation in the latter half of last year. To say that this brought Petros an incredible amount of joy would be quite the understatement, and it certainly brightened up what had been unfortunately a sad couple of years for Petros and his family. In 2002, Petros and Antonia tragically lost their much loved son George to cancer. This of course created a void in Petros's life—one that I am sure that, try as he might, he was unable to fill. As much as he adored his three delightful grandchildren, each of whom looked up to him as their big best friend, the emptiness associated with his son's loss remained. However, his role within the local community continued as always, and his commitment to the maxim of community spirit remained as strong as ever. He also remained a loyal comrade—if I may be permitted to call him that—working hard for the Labor Party locally. As I said earlier, politics was always his passion. In fact, it was in his role as an active and devoted activist that I first got to know Petros in the early 1990s. His work and passion for the Australian Labor Party were undying, and his assistance at all levels of campaigning will forever be appreciated.

Petros was one of those rare, street-wise political activists. You could always rely on him to tell you a few home truths, and that is what I admired most about him. He was up-front and almost always correct in his assessment and advice. His loss is one that has been felt by a large number of people, as was evidenced by the huge turnout at his funeral, with local, state and federal levels of government and a host of community based organisations represented. He was a constant source of advice and counsel, not only to me but also to my staff, who were always available for a chat on issues of the day. Petros will be widely missed, and I want to take this opportunity to once again pass on my sympathy to his wife, Antonia; his daughter, Helen, and her husband, Alfred; and his daughter-in-law, Mary. Petros Pantazopoulos was an individual who touched many people's lives, including mine and my husband's. He was our friend, and we will continue to be grateful for his support and commitment and will strive to do him proud.

talk.start.para: —The people of Western Sydney are decent, hardworking people. They set themselves high standards in everything they do. That is why, like so many in the electorate of Macarthur, I am becoming more distressed by the gradual loss of community standards we are seeing in everyday advertising. We have all heard the catchphrase `sex sells'. It is not easy to come up with a great advertising campaign, which is why many take the easy option of using scantily clad or naked women on their billboards and, as someone who drives regularly on Sydney roads, I am offended by them.

speech.para: What brought this to my attention was driving, with my two young children in the car, past billboards where a woman's backside is prominently displayed to try to sell an ice cream. What can you say when your own children turn to you and say, `Dad, that's rude, isn't it?' As a parent, I try my best to instil in my children morals, good values and respect for women. Sometimes it takes a fresh mind and the voice of a child to remind us how desensitised we have become.

Today we think nothing of seeing Kylie Minogue's scantily covered body splashed across billboards in Sydney. I blame the self-regulation of the advertising industry for this. The makers of the advertisements hide behind the decisions of the Advertising Standards Board. This is a board that is mostly made up of people from the advertising and media industries. I do not see a housewife, a mechanic or an ordinary Australian on this board. It is ordinary people who think these advertisements objectify women and that these advertisements are wrong. The board's membership clearly does not represent the values expected by ordinary Australians. The board is a toothless tiger.

I will give you an example. There was major controversy in 2000 when Windsor Smith unveiled billboards portraying a woman in her underwear apparently about to engage in an act of oral sex. The standards board did its job and requested that they be removed. Windsor Smith agreed to comply with the request, but only in its own time. The request occurred in the middle of March but it turned out that the hundreds of billboards, which had been strategically placed around the country, were to be taken down a few weeks later anyway. By the time the billboards were taken down, and with the increased publicity the case brought, you could hardly argue that there was any punishment for Windsor Smith or its advertising agency.

We need stronger penalties for agencies that breach the standards. In fact, the current system rewards them in the form of extra publicity. I cannot help but think that agencies deliberately take this approach to grab this type of publicity. We live in a society where crime and violence against women are becoming more prevalent. I do not need to remind anybody in this House of the alarming increase in violent attacks on women, including gang rapes and sexual assaults. While I do not directly blame this type of advertising it is part of the general decline in community standards that have led to an increase in violence and unacceptable behaviour.

Sport is another area in which I have noticed a real decline in standards. It is an important area to watch because it is such a vital part of our culture. Today, we regularly see violence and aggression on our sports fields. For instance, take the following quote:

quote.para: I can take you to any sports field any Saturday morning and show you parents getting stuck into it. Having a go at the ref, yelling abuse.

speech.para: This quote was made by the Leader of the Opposition, the Member for Werriwa, in the Bulletin magazine a few years ago. He identified a real problem. This type of behaviour is becoming more common. But where the member for Werriwa was wrong was the way in which he totally dismissed the problem in his next breath, with the misguided belief that this type of behaviour is acceptable. He told Maxine McKew:

quote.para: It's part of the Australian Way. We're not a namby-pamby nation that hides our feelings. I think were a nation that's willing to call a spade a spade and, if need be, to pick up the spade and whack someone over the head with it.

speech.para: I am yet to find a parent in my electorate of Macarthur who agrees that yelling at the referee, screaming abuse, venting aggression or hitting someone with a spade is part of the Australian way. Sport is the Australian way; it is the cement that holds us together as a nation. Hurling abuse at somebody and attacking them, whether verbally or physically, is not the Australian way.

This comment from the Leader of the Opposition, the member for Werriwa, goes to the heart of what is wrong with modern society. It goes to the heart of the decline in community standards and morals. As leaders of our communities, members of this House need to stand up and promote better standards in society. We should lead by example and not, as the Leader of the Labor Party would have us do, promote or condone violence, poor behaviour and a decline in community standards. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —Much has been said over the past few days about the concept of Australians working beyond the current retirement age, or `working till you drop' as it is being termed. Let us have a look at a recent attempt to encourage Australians to defer their entitlements. The pension bonus scheme is a voluntary scheme that supposedly rewards people who defer claiming the age or service pension. To benefit, you must register as a member of the scheme and then continue working for at least 12 months.

speech.para: I have a constituent who was one of the first to register for the scheme. He chose to continue working after he had attained the pension eligibility age, partly to provide himself with a focus after the death of his wife but mainly because he felt he could continue to make a contribution to society. He completed the five additional years in the work force required by the scheme. In addition, he acted as the principal afterschool carer for his grandchild for three hours each day. As a clerk, he never earned a big salary nor is he earning a big salary now. His capacity to expand his superannuation has been restricted by age. What is the net result for him for staying in the work force? The extra five years of work has had the effect of increasing his assets by just enough to make him ineligible for both the benefit under the pension bonus scheme and the pension itself—so much for an incentive to work longer.

It was not so long ago that politicians and commentators were talking about how Australians should be preparing for the time when we would all have more leisure time. We were encouraged to think about activities we might pursue and to think about our health so we would be in a position to take advantage of the new lifestyle. Now, seemingly instantly, we are going the other way, encouraging Australians to work longer into their older years. It might sound great in theory and on the surface it might seem a solution to Australia's demographic challenges.

It is fair to say that until now the largest proportion of Australians who have worked past the normal retirement age have been self-employed as well as professionals such as doctors, lawyers and accountants. They will continue to do so and it will not change anything. But how realistic and sensible is it for Australians who, for example, work in manual occupations to work beyond the current retirement age? The reality is that we all become physically weaker as we get older. It does not seem sensible to expose older Australians to unnecessary illness or injury, creating a heavier burden on our health system. Quite apart from that, after toiling for 40 or 50 years, hard working Australians are entitled to a retirement which they can enjoy.

A perfect example of a career with stringent physical and psychological demands is that undertaken by our police force. If officers believe that they can no longer meet the physical and psychological demands of policing after age 55, surely they should be allowed to retire with dignity and their entitlements. The flattening of organisational structures has impacted as much on police forces as on other groups in the community. Consequently, if those officers cannot meet the rigours of frontline policing, there is currently no role for them.

I would hate to think that these latest proposals would lead to a situation where Australians were expected to work beyond the current retirement age or in a manner that placed them at a greater health risk. One shudders to think of older Australians receiving white feathers or the like in the mail because they are no longer in the work force. I have no problem with good, well thought out incentives which encourage those older Australians who wish to remain in the work force to do so, but the expectation cannot and should not be universal.

Earlier this year the government expressed surprise that so few Australians had accessed the pension bonus scheme. If my constituent is any example, the answer is simple: after opting to work longer, they are no longer eligible to access it. Rhetoric and theory is fine; messing with people's lives and the retirements to which they have looked forward to—or leading them up the garden path—is not fine.

Let us not also forget the critical role which retired Australians play in our community. They provide a very substantial proportion of our volunteer work force. Volunteers save Australia millions of dollars every year. But, in order to give their skills in community service, they have to have not only the inclination but also the time. Older Australians, tired, ill or injured through working beyond a reasonable age, will be less inclined or able to volunteer as community workers. Any system which encourages, expects or obligates Australians to work beyond retirement age must be carefully thought out. There must be safeguards to ensure that those who opt in are not disadvantaged at some later stage as a result.

talk.start.para: —As the House is aware, in New South Wales we are rapidly approaching local government elections, including for Sutherland Shire Council, which covers my electorate and part of the electorate of Hughes. These elections are due to be held on 27 March.

speech.para: Every second Saturday I hold community consultations and meet with shire residents to talk to them about the issues that confront them in terms of their own living and interaction with the council. During many of these community consultations, local council matters dominate the discussions. One would think that they may come down to congratulate the government on our strong economic performance and our strong stand in terms of security matters and a whole range of things where the government has taken initiatives, but very often they come down to complain about the council.

The Sutherland Shire Council is made up of some very fine people, and the general manager, John Rayner, does an excellent job. But local constituents are very much concerned about issues such as footpaths and kerbs and guttering. Residents and local small business people have approached me with regard to shopping centre upgrades, which have been promised for the last four years. The council has budgeted for these upgrades but it has underspent on this important work by almost $3.7 million since 1999. Drainage is also a matter of great concern, with much of the existing infrastructure either broken down or in a state of disrepair.

Only yesterday a story regarding a constituent of mine was carried in the local newspaper. The article reported on a home in Loch Lomond Crescent in Cronulla, which is in the eastern part of my electorate. The owners of the home, Mr and Mrs Bakker, have for four years been suffering from flooding from a council drain which is adjacent to their home. According to Mr Bakker, during heavy rain, stormwater—which is often contaminated by raw sewerage—floods their property, washing much of the hillside on the lower portion of their property into Port Hacking. Their swimming pool is unusable due to contamination from this flooding. Mr Bakker has been in discussions with council for more than four years to have the problem addressed. He was led to believe that the council would agree to fund the approximate $140,000 which was required to fix the problem, but he was informed last week that the council had deemed the drain operational, despite overwhelming evidence to the contrary. The problem has reduced the value of the family home by more than $700,000.

A further concern of residents of the shire is the extremely high council rates which we are forced to pay. Sutherland Shire Council is one of the highest taxing councils in New South Wales. To compare the council's rates to other areas in Sydney: for a block of land valued at $400,000, a resident in Blakehurst, in the Barton electorate, would pay $779; a resident in Neutral Bay, in the electorate of North Sydney, would pay only $752; and a resident in Vaucluse, one of the richest areas in Australia, would pay just $794. In the mean time, an average young family in Cook with a block of land of the same value pays a staggering $1,531—twice what residents in the richest postcode in Australia have to pay. These rates give the Sutherland Shire Council a turnover of more than $184 million per annum—a magnificent budget by any standard—and yet many residents of the shire do not even have some of the most basic services, such as bus shelters, kerbs and guttering and properly maintained parks.

The council's debt has soared in the last four years to more than $38 million in internal and external debt. This has increased from $13 million under the last shire council. We now have a coalition of Shire Watch and Labor. Despite the efforts of Shire Watch to show that they are independent, they move as one with the Labor council. And of course there is expenditure. According to the council's own budget paper, it spent $12,000 sending a member of the council staff on an all expenses paid trip to Greece, Switzerland, England, Wales, Ireland, Northern Ireland and Singapore. There has been expenditure of $4.51 million since 1999 on private sector consultants—an increase of 143 per cent in consultants' fees compared with the previous council.

Then there is the campaign against ANSTO—the local nuclear processing station, which provides medical isotopes. The council spent $279,000 on the campaign and a further $6,500 flying in specialists from overseas. They allocated $20,000 to the Al-Zahra Muslim Women's Association in Arncliffe, which is outside the Sutherland Shire. Legal payments to the previous mayor amounted to some $56,000. So we have a political campaign and expenditure which goes on and on. The council needs to get its priorities right. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —In answer to question on notice No. 2672, the Minister for Education, Science and Training informed me on 3 November 2003 that, in the postcode areas wholly or partly covered by the electorate of Scullin, some 15,000 people have an outstanding or accumulated HECS debt of over $93 million. To put this into perspective, in the areas with postcodes 3074 and 3075—the suburbs of Lalor and Thomastown, which are wholly contained in the electorate of Scullin—some 2,700 people have a combined outstanding or accumulated HECS debt of over $20 million.

speech.para: I chose those two postcodes to illustrate the problem in disadvantaged areas. Those two postcode areas, under any reckoning or analysis, are disadvantaged areas of great need. These HECS decisions have already affected local areas. We must indicate our regret at a local level that, because of the government's changes to university HECS fees, the La Trobe University on Monday night decided to increase its HECS fees by 25 per cent for the year 2005. This additional impost will be a further disincentive to those in the electorate that I represent who are contemplating university education.

Fifteen or 16 years ago, arising from the RAN report, the then Labor government decided to institute a HEC scheme. Often Scullin was given as an example, because of the low number of tertiary qualified people in the boundaries of the electorate, to illustrate that HECS, in leading to additional places, would be an equity issue. It is time that we had an analysis to see if that is correct. Unless that is so, why should we continue to increase the obligation under the HEC scheme to future taxpayers? That obligation has risen from 20 per cent of university operating grants in the early 1990s to 33 per cent in 2003. There was a reduction in Commonwealth funding to universities from 77.1 per cent of university revenue in 1989 to 40.1 per cent in the year 2002.

Another example of the reduction in Commonwealth grants for higher education is that in 1975, Commonwealth expenditure on higher education as a percentage of GDP was 1.36 per cent, in 1988 it was reduced to 0.99 per cent, and in the year 2002-03 it was 0.53 per cent. Let us put to rest the idea that the Commonwealth is in any way protecting its input into higher education. This is part of this government's move towards ensuring that there is privatisation of a whole host of services, including education and health. It is consistent with the way in which in many areas of public policy we see a greater loading on putting private resources into the provision of services.

I believe that we do not value the effect of higher education, not only on the individual but on the community and the nation. That is the most important thing that seems to be missing from the current debate. There has not been a proper study. The government has said, `Why should other taxpayers be paying for a benefit that accrues to an individual?' This is nonsense in equity terms, when we look at individuals that are prevented from tapping their skills and talents by not going into tertiary education. I understand that tertiary education is not the be-all and end-all. But, if people are dissuaded from undertaking higher education because of the disincentive of a looming, burgeoning and increasing HECS debt, can we say that that is fair public policy? Are we actually tapping that unskilled talent that abounds in disadvantaged areas?

talk.start.para: —I wish to touch on another issue that I annually get a chance to speak about, which is to do with women's sport. Last week was the grand final of the WNBL, which the Dandenong Rangers won. I congratulate the Dandenong Rangers. Over the past two years I have indicated my concern about the media coverage of the event, which has been an example of the bad media coverage of women's sport. On this occasion, I congratulate the ABC, which showed the grand final direct, at least to the Melbourne market, which was a great improvement on the previous year, when they had a delayed telecast at about one o'clock in the morning. I congratulate the ABC for that.

speech.para: But I express my concern—along with others who have expressed concern, including the Prime Minister—that the ABC has regionalised its coverage of sport in general on TV and that the Melbourne market will be subjected to a sporting package within the news coming out of Sydney. I believe that the ABC, as the national broadcaster, should not only do things nationally. It should understand that it has a responsibility to ensure that the regional differences that abound in Australia are protected and catered for. I hope that it is able to reconsider its decision not to have a Melbourne based TV sporting program in the general news. I think that it is important in its role as the national broadcaster to cater for those regional differences.
Question agreed to.

business.start.para: The DEPUTY SPEAKER (Hon. I.R. Causley) took the chair at 9.40 a.m.

talk.start.para: —It has been nearly four years since the release of the government's Blandford report into MRI services. Despite the very high public health needs and relatively low income in my local area, there is still no access to local bulk-billing magnetic resonance imaging services in the entire western metropolitan region. By comparison, there are 13 bulk-billing MRIs in central Melbourne and the eastern suburbs. To access a local MRI service, patients must pay out of their own pockets, and this can cost $200 for a single procedure. Indicators of public health and income in the area show that the need for a publicly funded MRI service is clear. According to analysis that has been done by Western Health, the primary local hospital services over half a million people, in 1,335 square kilometres, to be precise. The population in the west is predicted to increase by 100,000 over the next five years. So the need for us to have this service is increasing.

speech.para: The population of those aged over 70 is predicted to increase by 11 per cent by 2011 compared with an increase in the Melbourne metropolitan area of only seven per cent. It is important for members to know that the life expectancy in this catchment area, which includes my electorate, is lower than the Victorian average. There are higher than average rates of cancer, cardiovascular disease and infectious disease. The Maribyrnong local government area, which is entirely included within my electorate, has the highest rate of cardiovascular disease in all of Victoria. The local rate of diabetes is significantly higher than the Victorian average for men and women. In parts of my electorate, men suffer from chronic respiratory disease at a higher rate than the Victorian population at large. Parts of Western Health's catchment area also include areas of very low income, where payment up front for MRI procedures is something people simply cannot afford.

It is extremely important that the government consider making an eligible MRI available in the area. It is a serious problem that links to our general health issues and the declining bulk-billing rates. But to have not a single rebatable MRI machine in such a large section of Melbourne which has the highest need is simply unsustainable and unfair. This situation must be addressed immediately. An MRI machine that people can afford to use is now becoming a central part of many treatment processes in the medical profession. I went through the different rates of cancer and cardiovascular disease in my electorate. Many of the symptoms that people will suffer and the diseases that people will need to have treated do rely on MRI services to be detected early and treated properly. The history and health concerns of my electorate relate to an ageing population who worked in very heavy industrial areas. It is important that they are able to access local services that can be covered by Medicare and that they are not faced with a $200 up-front fee or with simply not having a choice to get this service because they cannot afford it. I urge the chamber and the government to address this situation immediately and to provide a rebatable machine in the western suburbs of Melbourne. (Time expired)

talker.name: Bailey, Fran, MP
FRAN BAILEY
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Defence

talk.start.para: —When I travel across the 15,000 square kilometres and 185 communities that make up my electorate of McEwen, in my mobile office or when holding town meetings in any of those communities, I am frequently told what my local constituents expect of government, and the federal government in particular. There are three key themes that constantly come through. What people in my electorate expect, firstly, is that they will have opportunities to succeed. They want to be able to operate in an economic environment where they are rewarded for their efforts and where they get those opportunities. Secondly, they expect the federal government to maintain our national security. Thirdly, they expect the provision of services.

speech.para: When we came into government in 1996, throughout the 15,000 square kilometres of my electorate there was not one Centrelink office—not one. It took a lot of work to get that established. Initially, we got it established in a small shop in an arcade in Seymour. Today we have not only a purpose-built building but we have outreach services going into towns, plus, most importantly, we have the Murrindindi Cyberbus, which provides direct electronic access to Centrelink. It is the only one of its kind in the entire nation. Bob, the bus driver, is the secret to the success of the Murrindindi Cyberbus.

The services that constituents in McEwen expect include access to Medicare. In every pharmacy across the 15,000 square kilometres, we have Medicare Easyclaim machines. Occasionally, my constituents want access to something like a post office box from Australia Post. After 12 months of battle, we have finally got a post office box in Mill Park Lakes—a new suburb which is fast-growing and demanding. The residents are now telling me that they want access to an ATM and public toilets. This is not directly the responsibility of federal government, but we have already started the campaign to make sure that the local council—the Whittlesea council—honours its obligations to providing services and delivers on the public toilets, and we are going to pressure the major banks to provide an ATM service.

talk.start.para: —My local newspaper, the Advocate, recently said of Jim Bacon:

quote.para: Jim Bacon will leave his role as Premier with the State's economy in its best shape for decades, perhaps ever.

speech.para: Yet Jim Bacon's reply to this was that he was happy from the bottom of his heart, but what made him happiest was:

quote.para: ... to see the Tasmanian people now optimistic, happy, really confident about the future compared with what we inherited when we came to office in 1998, which I've often described as being virtually a clinical state of depression of the whole community in Tasmania.

speech.para: Jim Bacon personified this optimism. He shared this with Honey, his loving wife, and his Labor colleagues in government. Tasmania has been very lucky to have Jim Bacon head its government since 1998. He would be the first to acknowledge that he led a professional team, one of whom has sadly announced his retirement on the grounds of ill health—and I speak of the highly respected Dr David Crean, the former Treasurer of Tasmania. Jim has deserved the spontaneous, genuine and universal accolades paid to him since news of his serious illness became public. He is greatly respected as a man of substance and a genuine leader. Everyone hopes and prays that Jim's great determination and sense of optimism will see him through these tough times.

Sometimes known as `Good News Jim', Jim Bacon, a devout convert to Tasmania in 1980, was one of the key architects of what he accurately called `the new Tasmania', and nobody can deny the substance he gave to this reality. Personally, I cannot remember a more optimistic time in the beautiful isle for decades: the lowest unemployment in 20-plus years, record investment levels, a real estate boom, unrivalled air and sea access for tourists and travellers across Bass Strait, record tourism, massive energy infrastructure investment, a vibrant arts community and a progressive social justice program, just to name a few things.
As political analyst and associate professor at the University of Tasmania, Richard Herr, said in his tribute to Jim Bacon:

quote.para: Although we sometimes take the mickey out of him for being the `Good News Premier', by and large the Government has managed to get the State out of the doldrums ... It has improved and people feel that it has improved.

speech.para: I know that Richard joins with me and every Tasmanian in hoping for a role reversal for Jim—that he can become the Good News Premier in terms of his health and that the optimism and improved life opportunities so many Tasmanians have felt under Jim's premiership can be reciprocated in spades for this popular, substantive and courageous man. Jim, good luck to you and Honey, and every Tasmanian offers you both their best wishes and sincere thoughts.

talk.start.para: —How often and how regularly do we see on A Current Affair,Today Tonight or whatever stories relating to something that has happened in Centrelink? Of course they are always stories that are extraordinarily negative. How often do we see the good news stories on these programs? I am very fortunate and privileged in my job to be able to visit many of the Commonwealth government departments, particularly Centrelink in Townsville. I took that opportunity some three weeks ago. It is a totally different story when you are there on the ground, when you see the staff working and the dedication and hard work that they put into looking after their customers. We have seen a sea change occur from the old Department of Social Security and the CES to the modern Centrelink operation.

speech.para: When I visited the two Centrelink shopfronts in Aitkenvale and at the Willows, I was very impressed with the way that the staff went about their job and how they were concerned if anyone was waiting. I stood in line with their customers and talked to them and asked, `How is the service?' To a person, they said to me, `We couldn't ask for better.' That has to be remembered when we see these stories week after week on the current affairs shows; it has to be remembered that Centrelink does a fantastic job. It has a huge responsibility, but it carries it out extraordinarily well. I pay a tribute to Peter Doutre and all of his people in Centrelink in Townsville and thank them for the wonderful work that they do.

I also want to recognise some of the other leaders in Commonwealth agencies in Townsville and Thuringowa. We have Kevin Bycroft at DVA, who does an extraordinary job; Judy Paton at FaCS; Patimah Malone at DIMIA, a great person who is always there to help; Brigadier David Morrison, at the 3rd Brigade; and Mar Hube at Austrade. They are all extraordinarily focused on providing government services in a timely, appropriate and sensitive manner to the people of Townsville and Thuringowa. We really do appreciate the professionalism of the Commonwealth Public Service. If anyone tries to take these people on and say something bad about them, I will be the first to defend them, because they are magnificent people.

talk.start.para: —I rise today to bring to the attention of my colleagues the visit yesterday of Minister Dimitrij Rupel, the foreign minister for the Republic of Slovenia. This is the first visit of a serving Slovenian foreign minister to Australia. It comes at a very important time for Slovenia and for relationships between our two countries. Slovenia will be joining the European Union on 1 May—one of a number of countries to be acceding to the union on 1 May. That will be a very interesting and important time for Slovenia. Slovenia has been a trading partner of Australia's for many decades now. In fact, Australia is Slovenia's largest export destination in the Asia-Pacific region. Mostly, we import tyres from Slovenia. We also export a number of goods to Slovenia, and it is interesting to note that Harvey Norman recently—last year, I believe—opened their first store in Slovenia. They see it, as I think a number of other Australian businesses see it, as a country that will be a gateway to what was formerly known as the Eastern Bloc countries as well as to Eastern Europe. The port of Koper will link goods coming by sea to Slovenia with a number of other countries beyond Slovenia's borders. It is an excellent opportunity for Australian businesses to have access to markets that are not well known to them at this time.

speech.para: It is also worth saying that Slovenia, in slightly over 10 years since it declared independence from the former Yugoslav federation, has had enormous growth in its economic prosperity. The unemployment rate is low and inflation, which used to be one of the major problems with the Yugoslav economy, has certainly been brought under control. With all of that said, it disappoints me greatly to note that when a colleague of mine tried to exchange his Slovenian tolars after a very successful trip to Slovenia some time ago he was not able to exchange them at any Australian bank. He went first of all to the ANZ and was told that they would not change his tolars for Australian dollars, and on contacting other banks it became apparent that no bank would change tolars for dollars. The money of a country like this, which is about to join the European Union and has a strong economy and low inflation, should certainly be able to be exchanged in Australia. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —As honourable members would be aware, the other day in parliament I raised my concerns about the fact that if the American 911 emergency number were dialled in Australia it should not be diverted anywhere. I put forward a proposal that if 911 were dialled in Australia it should be immediately diverted to 000. I still maintain that that is an option, although I have since been told by Telstra that it would cause difficulties for phone numbers that already start with the prefix 911. But nothing is impossible, and I can see no reason why those prefixes should not be changed by adding another digit or some other procedure should not be put in place so that at least if children have heard the 911 number on American TV shows and they dial that number in an emergency some action is taken to assist them.

speech.para: In raising this issue, another concern has come to light. The concern is that 000, our Australian emergency number, is not known by many Australians. In fact, a survey recently conducted in Queensland showed that 50,000 Queenslanders were not aware that the Australian emergency number is 000. That is of great concern and I am sure that that figure is reflected in similar numbers throughout other states in Australia. This issue was raised when I was on a talkback radio show last night, with Stan Zemanek. I certainly agree with him that this is a concern that should be addressed, not only by Telstra but also by the Australian government. I can see no reason why the Australian government should not put more resources into a publicity campaign so that all Australians—young and old, and people from other countries—as well as visitors to this country, are fully aware that the emergency number in Australia is 000 and not 911 or any other number.

Recently, Telstra introduced a four-second recorded message on 000, which will hopefully alleviate a number of incorrect calls. Also, there are people who believe that 000 is an information service—that if they want to know something they can ring 000. Of course, it is not designed for that; it is designed for life-threatening situations, where immediate help from fire, ambulance or police services is required. Again, a publicity campaign should not only highlight the fact that the number to dial is 000 but also highlight the reasons why you dial 000—that it should be dialled only in a life-threatening situation. I use the short time I have in the parliament today to highlight my concerns about that and hopefully the government will address those concerns. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: (Hon. I.R. Causley)—Order! In accordance with standing order 275A the time for members' statements has concluded.

debateinfo.title: EXTENSION OF SUNSET OF PARLIAMENTARY JOINT COMMITTEE ON NATIVE TITLE BILL 2004

subdebate.1.para: Debate resumed from 19 February, on motion by Mr Ruddock:

motion.para: That this bill be now read a second time.

talk.start.para: —I support the Extension of Sunset of Parliamentary Joint Committee on Native Title Bill 2004 and I welcome its introduction. I am at this stage, as I have been previously, a member of the Joint Committee on Native Title and the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Land Fund. Members of the committee had discussion on and bipartisan support for the idea that the work of the committee had not concluded, notwithstanding that the 10-year sunset clause in the legislation had expired. We were of the view that there was still work to be done and that we should approach the government—particularly the Attorney-General, and secondarily the minister responsible for Indigenous affairs—to seek agreement to an extension. It was the unanimous view of the committee that that was the best way of extending the ongoing parliamentary scrutiny of this important and evolving piece of national legislation and of the public agencies which apply and administer that important act.

speech.para: When we in the committee agreed to take that approach, I was not optimistic that we would get agreement from the government to such a proposition. We discussed alternative possibilities, including the possibility that we might—by way of resolution of each house of the parliament—establish the committee with a parliamentary authorisation rather than a legislative authorisation. But in my view the government made a quick and prompt response to the committee's representations and has introduced this legislation to extend the committee's term. I welcome that; I think it is the preferred course of action. It is not the only course of action but it is the better of those options available to us. I welcome it and I support it.

The committee has done important work, but there is more work to do. In recent times the committee has looked at the development of the idea of Indigenous land use agreements. I think it did useful work in assessing how that initiative was evolving and it reported accordingly to the parliament. It has also regularly looked at the work of the National Native Title Tribunal. Only last night it met to examine and consider the work of the Indigenous Land Corporation and the associated land fund for which it is responsible. While those things are important and they have been done, there are ongoing elements of that work and there is more work to do. I would like to come to that in a moment.

Let us have a look at the context of this situation. The native title legislation arises from the High Court's decision in Mabo. That was a controversial decision because it made a major change to the nature of land use law—property law—in Australia. There is, in my view, a misconception that it created a new right. What it did was recognise an historic right that had gone unrecognised for 200 years. It corrected an historic anomaly and injustice in our history. It disposed of the myth of terra nullius forever. Terra nullius was a flawed concept. It had perpetuated an injustice and it had flowed through our legal system and into our historic analysis and our contemporary perceptions of race relations in this country.

It has not been an easy decision for people to accommodate themselves to. While I disagree with some of the colourful things that were said at the time of the decision—some of them I thought were more than colourful; they were repugnant—many of those things were said by people of goodwill grappling to come to terms with a major change that affected them and their lives and their businesses. They have not found the adjustment easy, and I am not critical of those people for that. Some who sought to exploit their unease I am very critical of: I think they have done the nation a disservice. But many people of goodwill have found native title a difficult concept to accommodate themselves to, and I understand that. That is a legitimate position, because it is a major change and people will not easily and comfortably come to terms with such major changes.

But it is overwhelmingly a positive initiative in the Australian historical context. It is playing, and will continue to play, a positive role in the evolution of race relations, property matters and the proper application of the law in Australia. I regret some of the narrow interpretations that have been made of native title post Mabo. Some of the decisions I think are flawed; nevertheless we all live in a country with the rule of law and when courts make decisions with which we disagree we have to work with them, just as we do when they make decisions with which we agree. I will continue to speak out on this issue over the years to come. This is not the place for a generalised discussion about native title, only to say that that is the context.

The magnitude of the change means that we should not be surprised or disappointed as a parliament that we are in the process of coming to the view reflected in this legislation—that after 10 years the work of this joint committee is not finished. We envisaged initially that perhaps five years would be insufficient. We extended it to 10; now we are extending it to 12. In my view, it will probably extend beyond that—not that I am critical of the two-year extension; that is a matter of judgment for the government. A two-year extension of the role of the committee is not long, but it does take us past the next election and will enable a considered judgment to be made by the new government.

I will not take all the time available on a matter that is agreed—the parliament does not need half-hour speeches to outline why we all agree about something—but I do want to take a few moments to talk about what I think is one of the important tasks still before this committee and which I hope will be its next priority activity. That relates to the circumstance confronting the native title representative bodies—the bodies that are tasked under the act with representing the interests of applicants in native title matters and which act as very important linchpins both in the efficient operation of the act and in the just outcomes of matters proceeding under the act.

The native title representative bodies are caught in a very difficult pincer movement, and I think, with respect to colleagues of all political persuasions on the committee, it is a shared view that this is a matter we should look at—perhaps not a shared view about what the outcome of looking at it will be but a shared view that this is a matter we should examine. The native title representative bodies deal with a budget that is externally fixed by the federal government and that has not been increasing rapidly. At the moment I am not talking about the magnitude of the funding. The funding is fixed, but the tasks that they have to perform are generated externally. The government does not say, `This is the job you have to do and here is an amount of money to do it.' The government gives them an amount of money, but the courts set workload, respondents bring matters forward and people with legitimate interests saying, `I would like to make some development on a property that is the subject of native title,' can initiate a matter. The native title bodies have a necessary obligation to respond to those matters, but they do not have the capacity to control the work flow, whereas the respondents' funding is met in a more normal manner for court matters through the Attorney-General's Department to participate in native title matters.

There is a structural problem there. It is not an easy one to resolve. I do not pretend that somehow or other a magic wand will solve that problem, but one of the tasks properly before the committee, in my view, is to look at the question of how we set a proper framework for the operation of native title representative bodies. It is not only a financial matter. It is to do in some instances with their structure and in others with their area of responsibility, their relationship with applicants, their proper role and function, and funding.

But they are matters that are causing problems not just for the representative bodies—although that is where the problems are most obvious, because they are the people who have to deal with the budgetary circumstances—but sometimes for respondents and sometimes for miners, pastoralists and others who seek an outcome in relation to a land matter and find that the representative body is not able to respond as quickly as they would wish, because of other priorities and funding crises. While on the face of it this is a problem for applicants and for the native title representative bodies—and it is—it is also a problem for respondents and for those seeking agreement from representative bodies about land use matters. So I hope this will be the next issue the committee takes up—not the last one, but it is of itself sufficient to warrant this legislation.

Mr Deputy Speaker Scott, I said I would speak for 15 minutes. In order to honour that commitment, let me simply say: I support the legislation. I welcome the government's prompt response to the representations from the committee chair, Senator Johnston. I congratulated him last night on the success of his representations in this matter. The two-year extension is not long, but it will take the committee past an election, and I hope that the new government will give ongoing responsibility to this committee to oversight and report to the parliament on the ongoing operations of the Native Title Act and the land fund.

talk.start.para: —Naturally, I too support the extension proposed in the Extension of Sunset of Parliamentary Joint Committee on Native Title Bill 2004 of the operations of the Joint Statutory Committee on Native Title and the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Land Fund. Clearly, the parliament has a distinct responsibility to oversight this important legislation in a bipartisan fashion. But it also therefore gives me an opportunity to comment on the operation of this legislation, and hopefully some of my remarks will be taken account of by the committee, if not by the government of Australia—or governments, given that the act requires both state and federal governments to legislate. Let me say that the failure of state governments—and, in fact, the absolute rejection of their responsibility, in the case of the Gallop government in Western Australia—to take up their responsibility to give native title, particularly in the context of pastoral leases, a substance which allowed for its resumption as it would apply in other circumstances, with appropriate compensation of which the Commonwealth promised the states it would pay 75 per cent primarily as a means of overcoming the logjam that exists in dealing with native title, was very foolish.

speech.para: I thought it was very foolish, because it accepted a principle that the High Court has virtually not designated. There could be a more appropriate or formal property right than native title. Where it might exist state governments could make even a prospective decision to resume it to allow for other development, but, where there was a proven loss arising from that native title, compensation would be paid. That is a fundamental principle of land ownership within Australia, and I think it was a major contribution to the system that was offered in the Howard government's 10- or 12-point plan that passed the parliament many years ago. I had a significant interest as the backbench chair of the committee that made those suggestions.

It was not something designed to take away from the Aboriginal people; it created an opportunity where people could get on with business that was in the national interest, if that was the view of the state. It might be a mineral claim or it might be the business of development, as I have found in my own electorate. The time taken to resolve native title issues—which sometimes, it is eventually agreed, do not exist—in order to add a small industrial estate to the boundaries of a town in one of my electoral areas is just outrageous.

Opportunities are lost. Someone comes along and says that they want to create jobs in a particular town and that a piece of land is required. They might be transferring business activity out of the city. They go down to DOLA, as the Department of Land Administration in Western Australia is known, who say, `We will now have to research all the native title issues.' By the time that research has passed through all its processes, the entrepreneur who wanted to move into the town has gone and rebuilt in the city or somewhere those issues do not apply, so the opportunities for decentralisation, jobs in rural and regional areas and economic diversity are lost. To me, that is very foolish and would have been overcome by the government simply saying: `We will resume native title rights in this area. We are not really sure what they are, but we the Commonwealth will compensate the appropriate interest groups in due course.' That still stands in the Commonwealth statute book but, of course, it has not been taken up by a single state government. As I said, it was taken up by the Court government in Western Australia, but it was overturned by the Gallop government.

In my view, the operation of native title—not the principles—is quite debilitating to the process of development, and that frequently reflects on even advantage to the local landowners, the Aboriginal people that may have native title rights. Nevertheless, it is worth putting on the record that the High Court in its Mabo judgment—and the member for Fraser gave that a fleeting remark—said that native title was not an estate in land; it was a form of access to land for certain historic and cultural purposes—for instance, the conduct of ceremonies or hunting and gathering. Of course, it is very hard to put a value on those things.

The Keating legislation, which still survives, said that, where a native title claim might be made, the participants with the exception of the claimant—that is, the prospective Aboriginal native title holders—would negotiate in good faith. For reasons I cannot understand, because it should be a universal requirement, the Aboriginal people are not required to negotiate in good faith. History proves that that has unfortunately become the right not to negotiate. The act has some provisions that allow claims and anything else to be arbitrarily taken after quite a lengthy period to the Native Title Tribunal. Other parties have to turn up to meetings to discuss issues related to that. I do not object to that but Aboriginal people frequently do not turn up, so there can be no negotiations. That is their right under the legislation.

I think that, if ever the committee wanted to uphold the good Aussie principle of a fair go, it would make it a requirement that all parties negotiate in good faith—if only to progress the matter. The great benefit that so frequently arises for claimants, whose rights to a claim are probably very shaky, is the extension of the negotiating period to a point where someone who, for instance, has a highly prospective mineral area and wants to get on with the business of development to the benefit of all asks: `Just how much do you want? How much should I pay to get you out of the road?' There may be no legitimate claim at all, but if you have spent $1 million on exploration, you have a prospective title and you want to get on with it, maybe $10,000 or $20,000 is cheap. That is fine in my mind, if there is a genuine inherent right in the claim. But, if there is not, why should people be forced to pay just to clear the decks?

A constituent of mine informed me the other day that he had eventually obtained a right to drill for oil. I would think that that is pretty important for Australia. But he has been telling me for at least three years of the battles that he has had over claims which have eventually come to nothing. There was no claim in the end because none could be substantiated, but the delays to that project might be quite expensive if he discovers oil—oil that might have been assisting Australia in its balance of payments.

I think all of us the other day got a bit of lobbying from APPEA, the petroleum export association, who told us of the great opportunities for our national economy arising from their gas reserves and how they might be better encouraged to progress those businesses. They raised the issue—which other sectors of the minerals industry are raising with government—of flowthrough shares. Flowthrough shares virtually mean that, if you invest in a company that is in exploration, the losses that that company incurs in its processes of exploration can flow back to the shareholder, who can then of course reduce their personal income in that process. However it is described, it is virtually a tax incentive to encourage people to invest in exploration. Prior to the Native Title Act, no such incentive was needed. I am not sure that flowthrough shares will overcome the problems that people experience through the delays to their right to explore and develop that arise from the failings of the Native Title Act or the failure of state governments, who are the land administrators, to take up the options that are inherent in the Commonwealth act as it was amended.

None of this is designed to take anything away from genuine applications for native title. It is all about speeding things so that both parties can come out of it with a better arrangement. That is very important. I think, consequently, that this committee in its extended life should be coming back to the parliament with some clear recommendations as to how we can get the situation moving. If an Aboriginal group has a legitimate claim that can be resolved, it might be resolved if all parties were obliged to turn up to the negotiation session. But one party turns up and the other does not and it drags on and on until it becomes a tribunal issue and then the tribunal has a backlog. It may then extend to a court somewhere and the court will have a backlog too. Who wins from that? Nobody. In fact there could be a unique situation where a native title right could be resumed on a pastoral property, which is mostly where these developments occur, and it could be paid out in due course in compensation. That is something that would benefit all parties.

On the matter of native title, I think the Kimberley Land Council were complaining the other day that they were short of funds to proceed with certain legal cases. This is another issue. We have all this litigation associated with these matters, and huge expense. Unfortunately in some cases the defendants—those who consider they are the titleholders under the laws of Australia—find themselves entering into huge legal costs with no assistance financially, whilst the applicant has been virtually 100 per cent funded by the government. But we find today that, for certain land councils, the funding they have under the current methods of distribution is insufficient.

As you would be aware, Mr Deputy Speaker Scott, a group of members of parliament made a submission to the Hatton inquiry, which was looking into the financing and funding associated with ATSIC. They made a suggestion, which I stand by very strongly, about the current tops-down funding process, as I refer to it, where a very large amount of money is transferred to ATSIC—now ATSIS, because the government has decided to take back the chequebook from ATSIC, for reasons that have been well publicised. There are funding decisions made in Canberra that eventually filter down through a series of Aboriginal organisations and a fraction of the money eventually arrives in the areas where it is needed most. We proposed to that inquiry that we should reverse the funding—that we should take up the local government model, where the Commonwealth government allocates an amount of money and it is distributed immediately and in full to the 727 local authorities.

If one looks at the language borders that have been laid out by the Institute of Aboriginal Affairs—I think it was them; I have certainly seen a map in their building—there are just over 300 acknowledged language areas. I am of the belief that they would probably come up as the appropriate boundaries for a series of Aboriginal local authorities. I choose to call them boards of trust, and I do that because I openly admit, from my own long experience in dealing with Aboriginal people, that they are under huge family pressures if they are the keepers of money. There needs to be a process to protect them from those pressures. They are not dishonest but they can get trapped into doing things that are not compatible with the administration of public moneys. So I call them boards of trust. I see a process were all that money is identified in the budget, similar to the local government funding, and the Commonwealth Grants Commission would decide how much each of those boards of trusts receive on a weighted per capita basis.

We know how to do that. They are experts in that field. There is no politics in it—we are not running around buying votes or anything like that. We make a commitment—it is quite a huge amount of money—and then that body sit there and make judgments as to where they want that money to go. They might make judgments about contributions to their local hospital to get better amenities. For instance, I would hope that, rather than funding Aboriginal health, which frequently puts another GP in a town that desperately needs specialist services and does not need two GPs—it is just not big enough—those people sitting in judgment with their own money would make better expenditure decisions.

I propose that the trustee of those funds might be the nearest local government authority, which in some cases would be an Aboriginal council but one subject to the laws of the state in terms of prudential arrangements. They would be there to countersign cheques and give some protection to the boards if they were asked to make financial commitments that were not within the guidelines. I would like to think that the parliament and the government were prepared to further discuss that.

I was very impressed with the support my submission got. Some 12 or 15 MPs wrote letters of support for those fundamentals. The Australian started to try and say, `Tuckey is saying that Aboriginals cannot manage money'. That was not what I was saying. Some of them can do it very well. As an example, I used to cash tens of thousands of dollars worth of cheques in my hotel for hardworking Aboriginal people who had jobs on the main roads and so on, and they always wanted $5 or $10 in single dollar notes to settle with the rellies, who knew it was payday and were waiting outside. They knew they had to take the bulk of that money home to their wife and family, but they were also under pressure to share what they had with others who might have been worse off. Unfortunately, that situation progresses right up to someone who has to manage money that the Commonwealth has provided. I think there needs to be a process.
