Some might have a different idea of how to do it, but the fundamental of our proposal was that the money should go out on the ground where the real need is and that people living there should make decisions within guidelines as to how it would be expended. The management of that money, we thought, was important and we did not leave that out of our submission.

I just add that to the day because, to the extent to which the community would want to fund native title issues, I would like to think that the process did not put pressure financially on people and that there were simpler and better arrangements. That is why I raise that matter also. I note that I am running out of time, so I will close my remarks. It is an important issue and it is important that Australia continues to have economic growth, if only to make sure that it has funds available through the taxation system, the royalty system and other proposals to help people in need, whatever their ethnic background. I think we have had too many delays. I think the mining industry has a false hope that they can extend their exploration activities by taxation incentives unless the administrative processes they must deal with today with native title are made more effective.

talk.start.para: —I welcome the opportunity to speak on the Extension of Sunset of Parliamentary Joint Committee on Native Title Bill 2004 because it gives me the opportunity to raise some issues which I think are extremely important in the way this parliament operates and communicates its deliberations to the people of Australia and the sad state of affairs concerning native title in this country at the moment. I would like to say at the outset that I support the extension of the sunset clause contained in section 207 of the Native Title Act. This would allow for a further two years sitting, to 2006, of the Parliamentary Joint Committee on Native Title and the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Land Fund.

speech.para: Having briefly looked at some of the committee's work over the years, including the minutes of the most recent meeting of 12 February 2004, it is obvious that there is a real need for such a committee. I would perhaps go further and suggest that a standing committee on native title be put in place such is the importance, to my mind, of this issue and the operation of the Native Title Act. As Richard Ah Mat, Executive Director of the Cape York Land Council, stated last November in a paper on public administration and governance on CapeYork Peninsula, `family, kinship and traditional ownership could be used as a model of good governance' in this country. Traditional ownership, land rights, native title or whatever you want call it, this goes to the heart of Aboriginal culture and heritage in this country. Aboriginal people know this, but whitefellas like to ignore it.

As the speech of the member for O'Connor reflected just now, native title is more and more being seen as a process to facilitate development rather than to redress traditional ownership issues. Money is running the agenda, not cultural heritage issues and Aboriginal sovereignty. Therefore, if this parliament claims to truly represent the people of Australia, it must ensure that traditional ownership and native title is dealt with in an appropriate manner. This is not happening at the moment. The joint committee, I feel, has a role to play here. I note the House does have a standing committee on Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander affairs and I would assume that it works closely with the joint committee on native title.

Unfortunately, my brief reading of the work of the joint committee as it currently stands and my many discussions with Aboriginal people in the Illawarra and my own electorate of Cunningham in New South Wales would suggest that there is a lot wrong with the native title system as it operates in this country in 2004. There are obviously many reasons for this, not least of which are the recent High Court decisions, especially Members of the Yorta Yorta Aboriginal Community v. State of Victoria & Ors, which has stripped away the ability of ordinary members of Australia's Indigenous community to obtain access to native title rights and other traditional rights.

The access of the native peoples of this country to native title is now so much more difficult than the promise that was held out when the Mabo decision came down over a decade ago. Native title for the Aboriginal people of my electorate of Cunningham, a metropolitan, semi-urban area located south of Sydney, is now just a dream. It is a dream that they have been pursuing with vigour since the mid-1990s, but it is one which has failed to bring forward any real, positive outcomes. I wonder whether the members of the joint committee truly understand the feeling out there in the Indigenous community with regard to this issue and how whitefella law and politicians have let them down.

I would also suggest that few people in Australia are aware of the work of the joint committee or of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs. But, as I believe native title is such an important issue and one which goes to the very heart of empowering the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people of this country, I am nevertheless supportive of their work.

In preparing to speak to this bill I cast my mind back to 1988, the year of the bicentennial, when there was a real flourish of interest in the true history of this country. Around that time landmark publications such as Henry Reynolds's Frontier and Eric Wilmot's Pemulwuy appeared to show whitefella historians like me that we had been lied to, that our history had been distorted and that Aborigines had been excised from the historical accounts of the development of the nation of Australia since the white invasion of 1788. Perhaps the book that most influenced me was a smallish one by Peter Turbet, entitled The Aborigines of the Sydney District Before 1788. This little book reinforced to me the simple fact that in the Illawarra, an area where my family has resided since 1839, the Aboriginal people actually lived for thousands of years. This might seem like an obvious statement, but it was one that was not really understood by a lot of Australians prior to the time of the bicentennial.

Growing up in the northern Illawarra, surrounded by housing estates, I saw no obvious evidence of Aboriginal occupation. This is a rather sad indictment of our history. I was not told about the Aboriginal history of Australia and the Illawarra by any of my teachers at school. I knew about Aborigines out in the Australian deserts, but I did not know about Aboriginal people in society, living in urban areas such as the Illawarra. I was not told the truth. The bicentennial opened the eyes of hundreds of thousands of Australians to the fact that we whitefellas were recent arrivals only and that the more than 40,000 years of Aboriginal occupation prior to that was real, meant something and needed to be accepted and recognised. We as a nation have been trying to do that ever since—though government, the law and vested interests both within and without the Aboriginal community have been getting in the way.

The call for land rights throughout the sixties, seventies and eighties gave rise to the Mabo decision in the early nineties. We also saw a realisation that assimilation did not work; it was abhorrent. Under the mantle of reconciliation, Australians hoped to solve some of the core issues facing our ongoing relationship with Aboriginal society. It seemed as though all the problems would be solved in the short term, as there was obviously a lot of goodwill in the general community. The mistakes of the past were now out there, exposed for everyone to see. But, no; we have not progressed nearly far enough. Today the picture is perhaps grimmer than it was back in 1988.

I can only comment on what I know. I can only comment on what I have gathered from talking with Aboriginal people in my electorate of Cunningham and the Illawarra and the South Coast in general. I was fortunate in that in 1988-89, as a local historian, I was able to publish a work which reproduced historical accounts of the Illawarra and South Coast Aboriginal people, dating back to Captain Cook sailing by the area in April of 1770. My book has been widely dispersed among the local community, both black and white. Just like the work of Henry Reynolds, it has revealed to our community some of the tragic events which occurred when white people invaded this country, took away the land from the local people and—make no mistake about it—engaged in atrocities such as poisoning, murder and rape. Dispossession was as real in my home town of Bulli and in Wollongong as it was in every other part of Australia. Native title was real. Charles Throsby Smith, the first white settler in Wollongong in 1818, later wrote when reminiscing in the 1860s:

quote.para: The Aborigines owned the authority of Chiefs, in a certain degree. Old Bundle was the name of the chief who claimed Wollongong, and no end of tribute have I paid to his Majesty, in the shape of tea, sugar, flour, meat, &c ... Timbery, however, claimed Berkeley.

speech.para: There we have clear evidence that the local Aboriginal people claimed ownership of the land—clear evidence that they did not hand over or sell their land to the British invaders and clear evidence that they were basically ignored, belittled by the British legal system. The local Aboriginal people owned the land, but this was never recognised. The Native Title Act does not redress this basic injustice. When we look at the minutes of the 12 February 2004 meeting of the joint committee and we read the statements by the Director of Service Delivery, the Registrar and the President of the Native Title Tribunal, we must unfortunately take their comments with a grain of salt.

While I am sure the members of the National Native Title Tribunal are doing their best under the circumstances and the legislative framework that is forced upon them, I believe that the whole system is flawed. There is ample comment within the Aboriginal community that the native title system is not working. There is lots of talk that this government is especially keen on making sure it does not work in the best interests of the native peoples of this country. Why is that? I believe it is because it is all about land. In this country, land, land ownership, the rights to the resources under or above that land and the profits to be made therein, drive the whole land rights and native title debate. And this is where my experiences come in with regard to the Illawarra. When looking at the work of the joint committee over the last decade, I note that it has travelled widely throughout Australia, but, in my opinion, it seems that most of its work has focused on remote areas. This is reasonable, I suppose, considering that large numbers of Aboriginal communities are located in these areas and there is a lot of mining and exploration in these areas which require the quick settlement of native title issues for the development to proceed. The previous speech, by the member for O'Connor, pointed out some of those issues. But it seems that native title is not hitting the ground in urban and metropolitan areas of Australia. The fact is that it should be. These areas contain large Aboriginal communities, usually composed of traditional owners and others who have come to the cities from regional and outback areas. That is right: in areas such as Sydney, Melbourne and Wollongong there are traditional owners—owners who have rights to native title—but this often not considered or recognised. Sure, a lot of the land in these metropolitan and urban areas has been alienated—that is, it is no longer classified as crown land. But the fact remains that, in areas such as the Illawarra, we still have the Timbery family and others like them, who were dispossessed by white settlers such as Charles Throsby Smith back in the 1810s and 1820s and who have never been compensated. This is a basic injustice which needs to be redressed.

Just two weeks ago, I facilitated a meeting between some local Illawarra elders and senior management of ATSIS and the office of the minister. During that meeting, which lasted for just on an hour, we tried to talk about all those native title and land ownership issues as they affect the Aboriginal community in the Illawarra. We spoke about how native title claims have been submitted by local elders from about 1994 onwards. We spoke about how the vast majority of those claims have been expunged, ticked off, removed, deleted or whatever by the New South Wales Native Title Service without any real consultation with the people who put in the claims. We spoke about how local councils such as Wollongong City Council and Shellharbour Council have been able to proceed with inappropriate, environmentally destructive developments—developments which destroyed known Aboriginal heritage sites such as at Sandon Point—and how those councils have been able to tick off any so-called native title issues because of the action of the New South Wales Native Title Service in facilitating this process. It is clearly believed by the local people—and I agree—that the New South Wales Native Title Service operated in the interests of shire local councils and developers, and against the interests of the local Aboriginal community, in these matters.

This has been going on for almost a decade now. It is obvious that native title is not working for the Aboriginal people of the Illawarra. The fact is it should work; it should work for the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people of this nation. It should work because, as I said earlier, native title and traditional land ownership lies at the heart of Aboriginal culture and society. We know about the recent problems at Redfern, which are mere symptoms of the general malaise. We know about the poor health of Aboriginal people in this country, about their high levels of incarceration, about their poverty, low rates of employment and difficulties in accessing education. We know that, as an invading community, we have failed the Indigenous people of this nation. Since day one, we have imposed our so-called civilisation upon theirs—we have treated them inhumanely and with an arrogance which shames us all. We have refused to empower the native peoples of this land. Where are their representatives in this House? Where is the recognition of their traditional law and customs within white law? As the latest issue of the National Indigenous Times proclaims: `The great divide continues: Yearbook's black figures'. That is the headline and it goes on to show various graphs and tables revealing the shocking state of Aboriginal disadvantage within this country.

There is, of course, a way out of this. It is a relatively simple way. It is to recognise the legitimacy of Aboriginal culture, heritage, society and relationship to the land. As Richard Ah Mat points out, the Aboriginal people of Australia `demand the right to take responsibility'. Alongside responsibility must come power, and this is something which whitefella society obviously does not want to relinquish. Whilst ever millions of dollars of taxpayers' funds meant to assist Aboriginal communities are wasted by bureaucracy and never actually hit the ground or get to those communities, nothing much will change. This is where I must say I agree with the member for O'Connor on the fact that we have to make sure that a lot of those millions of dollars do get down to the local communities, the local Aboriginal people, who need that money—rather than it being frittered away before it reaches them.

Whilst ever governments—whether they be local, state or federal—in this country refuse to give Aboriginal leaders power and responsibility or to allow Aboriginal communities to manage themselves, instead clinging to the old missionary `we know best' attitude, then nothing much will change. As long as governance mechanisms undermine Aboriginal traditional culture then nothing much will change. As Richard Ah Mat points out, `Native title is both a positive and negative for the Aboriginal community.' In the paper he delivered last November he stated:

quote.para: Native title on its own has thrown up new relationships and questions that we in the Indigenous community have never considered before. For example, many of our people have lived for over a hundred years or more outside their traditional lands. Many call home the lands of their neighbouring clans. What is their decision making role in the development of these Indigenous lands? The actual granting of native title creates for the first time in our history the possibility of a feudal hierarchy of decision making based on family ties to traditional lands. But our traditional society never admitted the possibility of a landowner being a law maker as in the kind of ownership exercised by an English baron or earl over his country estate and all of the peoples on it. So what is the role of traditional landownership that we want to develop?

speech.para: In summary, it is issues such as this which the joint committee needs to address. I hope it can do this over the next two years. I hope it can address some of the major problems facing native title in this country.

talk.start.para: —I am pleased to be able to speak today to the Extension of Sunset of Parliamentary Joint Committee on Native Title Bill 2004 to extend the life of the Parliamentary Joint Committee on Native Title and the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Land Fund, as established by part 12 of the Native Title Act 1993. I am an enthusiastic supporter of this legislation and, for many of the same reasons that have been articulated by the previous speaker, I would question whether or not it is now time to look to have a permanent standing committee on native title.

speech.para: I come to this debate probably with more experience than most other members of the parliament in relation to native title. I say that because at the time the native title bill was first passed I held the seat of the Northern Territory and I now hold the seat of Lingiari, where around 48 per cent of my constituents are Indigenous Australians. That obviously means that I have got the highest concentration of Indigenous Australians of any electorate—far higher than Kalgoorlie—

talk.start.para: —Sturt.

—and much higher than Sturt, Grey, Maranoa or any others around Australia that you might name. Prior to entering parliament I was an employee of the Central Land Council in Alice Springs. I was involved in that capacity in many debates with the then Hawke Labor government over the issue of national land rights. I will come to that issue a little later on. Having been engaged and involved—proudly, I might say—with the discussions about and the development of the first piece of native title legislation, I was then in 1996 unfortunately shown the door by my voters. But that was an opportunity—and they sensibly changed their minds 2½ years later.

speech.para: During a substantial period of that 2½ years I worked as a policy adviser for the National Indigenous Working Group on Native Title, at a time when native title legislation was facing amendments in this parliament. I well recall those days, because of the frustration that was experienced by many Indigenous Australians about the way in which native title legislation was proceeding, the way in which the law was changing as a result of various High Court decisions and the way in which certain conservative elements of the Australian community were seeking to limit native title. We saw that in the way in which the amendments that were passed in 1998 effectively provided a capacity for mass extinguishment of native title around Australia and changed the basis under which native title could be pursued by many who would otherwise have been entitled to think they were legitimate native title holders.

That raises significant questions, and I think we need to understand that this is a matter of great interest but also an intellectual challenge, because it is around the issue of how Indigenous title has been superseded by the Crown and then how the Crown has dealt with land and its impact upon that title. As I have said, we have seen mechanisms set up so that native title rights can be extinguished—by the Crown alienating from itself title by saying that if land is used for particular purposes that means that that land has been alienated and therefore native title has been extinguished. In 1998 we saw huge lists—I recall them well—of what areas of land in every state and territory in Australia would now no longer be available for native title claims. As a result, the proportion of Indigenous Australians who actually have access to native title is very limited indeed.

But it is nevertheless extremely important for those who do, and there are structures that have been put in place for them. One is the National Native Title Tribunal, which the Parliamentary Joint Committee on Native Title and the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Land Fund has the responsibility of reviewing, particularly in relation to its annual reports. I was not present, although I am a member of the committee, but last night in this house that committee sat and perused and examined the board of the Indigenous Land Corporation, or at least its executive officer and chair, Shirley McPherson.

I am sure you know, Mr Deputy Speaker Scott, that the creation of the ILC was part of a negotiated arrangement with Indigenous Australians in 1993. It was part of a package of arrangements. There would be an Indigenous Land Fund, which the Indigenous Land Corporation would administer; there would be native title legislation, for which the National Native Title Tribunal is fundamental; and there would be a social justice package. Of course, the Keating government was defeated in 1996 and, although it was progressing towards a social justice package, that social justice package has never been put in place. That is a significant issue because when we look at native title we need to understand that it was recognised by government at the time that native title was not a possibility for some Indigenous Australians, given the nature, as I said earlier, of the law and the way in which the High Court then interpreted and has successively interpreted native title. So it was therefore seen as important that the Indigenous Land Fund be created, to provide the possibility at least that Indigenous Australians who did not have access to land rights under state jurisdictions or under federal law would be able to have access to some lands.

Then there was to be the social justice package. It is important that we understand that the deal has not been completed and that the social justice package has never been provided. As a parliament, despite the fact that governments change, we need to comprehend and accept responsibility for the fact that an arrangement—which was agreed to by a previous government and which led to the development of the Indigenous Land Corporation and the passing of the native title legislation—was part of a deal which had a third leg. Governments have a responsibility, in my view, to live up to that deal, and we need to understand that it is extremely important that we do.

I note that the previous speaker spoke about the inadequacies of the Native Title Act in terms of the ability for Indigenous people in his own electorate to access land under the native title legislation. As I said earlier, we need to comprehend that, as a result of the way in which the law has developed, it is unlikely that will change. We need to also understand that state and territory governments have a responsibility to look at other ways of dealing with land issues through land rights legislation.

We should understand that native title legislation and land rights legislation are very different: native title legislation is the evolution through the common law, and land rights legislation is statutory law. The strongest piece of legislation, in terms of either native title or land rights law, is a piece of statutory legislation passed by this parliament in 1976: the Northern Territory land rights legislation. It provides people with rights as a result of this parliament giving due consideration to a report of a royal commission; it gives people rights which are far stronger in many ways than they could otherwise achieve under native title legislation. That is why, as I said earlier, there was an engagement with the Hawke Labor government in the mid-eighties over land rights. No doubt, Mr Deputy Speaker, you will recall—although the member for Sturt was probably too young—

talk.start.para: —What year are we talking about?

—About the time you were in grade 3, I suspect. Mr Deputy Speaker, you will recall that there was a push by the then Labor government, with Minister Clyde Holding and Prime Minister Hawke, to introduce national land rights legislation. It was effectively stymied because what was planned was to weaken the Aboriginal Land Rights Act so that it would conform with what the Western Australian government in particular, under Premier Brian Burke, was prepared to accept, along with the mining industry. I am happy to say that I was part of the organisation of the Central Land Council, under the then leadership of Pat Dodson, and the National Federation of Land Councils that took on the responsibility to make sure that legislation was not passed in that form, and we succeeded. We maintained the strength of the Northern Territory land rights act and it has been maintained ever since.

speech.para: When we think about the development of law in this country, we need to understand that we have the responsibility and the power in this place to make laws which will benefit Indigenous Australians. In this particular case the parliament chose to do it in a way which gives strong powers to Indigenous Australians. In the native title legislation, however, as a result of the way in which the native title law is being changed, both through this parliament and as a result of the High Court determinations, we have taken a step backwards. What has happened as a result is that many Aboriginal people, Indigenous Australians, have seen what they thought were their native title rights being extinguished, and that is a matter of grave concern.

In relation to the development of native title and, in particular, the way in which it has been dealt with by the respective state and territory governments, prior to the election of the Martin Labor government in the Northern Territory 2½ years ago now the former CLP government in the Northern Territory refused to deal with native title. Indeed, it froze applications for development on pastoral leases in the Northern Territory for an extensive period because it was not prepared to allow the Native Title Act to impose a regime upon the Northern Territory for the deliberation of native title. That was, of course, an act of lunacy, but the decisions were taken and this was done for base political purposes—for the same reasons that over time successive CLP governments in the Northern Territory chose to use race, racism, the land rights act and Aboriginal rights as a wedge in the community for political purposes. That was not much better—in fact, it was probably a lot worse in many respects—than the Hansonite movement in the last decade.

It is important to understand that when the new Labor government were elected in the Northern Territory they decided that they would adopt a different approach. In the previous 27 years of conservative government in the Northern Territory, every time there was a conflict it was taken off to the courts. The most litigious government in Australia in relation to Indigenous interests was the conservative Northern Territory government—the one which should have been the most responsible. It perennially took these matters to the courts. The new Labor government under Clare Martin adopted an entirely different approach. They took the view that the way to settle issues over native title and land rights, where there was a conflict of views or a difference of opinion, was to sit down and negotiate—to end the litigation. And, whilst there are still test cases which have been put to test the limits of the law on native title, what has happened since has been groundbreaking—indeed, breathtaking—in that there has been discussion, negotiation and compromise between the Northern Territory government and their agents, and the native title applicants, native title holders and the Northern Territory land councils acting as the representative bodies in the Northern Territory. Historically speaking, it is unprecedented.

This parliament could do a lot worse than to look at the way in which the Northern Territory government have operated in relation to native title as a blueprint for what other governments and jurisdictions should be doing. I say that with all sincerity. Things are not perfect by any stretch of the imagination, but the improvements are palpable. We need to know that the outcomes are obvious to all concerned. Particularly, by treating Indigenous Australians as equals, sitting opposite them at the table and negotiating deals and arrangements, you know you can benefit all sides and the whole community, and there is no conflict. To me, that is the way to proceed. Yet, historically—and I have to say this—it is not the way in which conservative governments in this country have chosen to operate, because they have not been able to. They have chosen to use issues of race, land rights and native title as a wedge for base political purposes.

It is incumbent upon the government to ensure that the representative bodies which are set up under the Native Title Act are properly resourced. We know—and we only need to look at the submissions which have been made to this committee, the life of which we are extending today—that those native title representative bodies have been significantly underresourced. Whilst the National Native Title Tribunal has money almost dripping out of its pockets, the organisations which are there to represent the interests of the native title holders—those who were given that responsibility by the government—are underresourced. We have seen only in recent weeks how the Kimberley Land Council, which is the native title representative body for the Kimberley in north-western Western Australia, has had to withdraw from native title hearings because of a lack of resources. It did not have the funds.

That is what produces the injustice about this process. If the representative bodies do not have the resources to represent properly the interests of the native title holders in hearings over native title, whose rights are going to be extinguished further? It will be those of the native title holders and native title applicants. It is extremely important that this government and the next government, which will be a Latham Labor government, understand that they have a responsibility to ensure that these organisations are properly resourced. Whilst periodically we hear stories of these representative bodies going off the rails, the fact is that they are crucial and vital if we are to actually achieve any measure of justice under the native title legislation.

I know that the two representative bodies which work in the Northern Territory—the Northern Land Council and the Central Land Council—are responsible and well managed organisations. They both do their jobs properly and represent adequately—indeed, I think very successfully—the interests of native title applicants and native title holders, whom they also represent. The land councils were set up under the Northern Territory land rights act in the first instance, but they represent the interests of those people who claim land under the land rights act and, subsequently, manage their affairs.

As a previous member said, if we are to provide a measure of justice to Indigenous Australians, we have to accept our responsibilities in this place to be wise about what we do. I am sorry to say that the amendments passed in this place in 1998 were in many ways not wise. The mass extinguishment of native title does us no good at all. It might have relieved the interests of those in the community who were scared after Mr Howard put a map on TV—you all recall that—saying that all this part of Australia would have its land extinguished in terms of native title, you would not be able to live on it, backyards would go and all this sort of nonsense. As a nation we are better than that. We need to accept that we have a responsibility to show the world community that we are better than that. We should not be concerned when the United Nations want to look at our record, unlike this government, which chose to refuse a United Nations committee the right to come and look at what we were doing in relation to native title and Indigenous issues. That is not right; it is inappropriate. We need to understand that we have responsibilities which we must carry out in a way which meets the needs of the whole Australian community.

talker.name: Pyne, Chris, MP
Mr PYNE
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Family and Community Services

talk.start.para: —It gives me great pleasure to be summing up for the Attorney-General today the debate on the Extension of Sunset of Parliamentary Joint Committee on Native Title Bill 2004. He could not be in two places at once, so I am glad to be here.
—He couldn't split?

—He could not split, so I am happy to be here to represent the Attorney-General in the Main Committee today. I do not have the long history or the huge number of Indigenous constituents that the honourable member for Lingiari has, but I am sure that he would recognise that I was actively involved in the debates about native title in 1994 and spoke in those in the House on numerous occasions. I was one of the coalition MPs who at the time, in my first term in this place, argued for a measured and moderate response to the native title issue that was on the agenda. Now, 10 years later, I am sure we can say with some confidence that the hype that existed at that time from either the enormous expectations or the fear that some people had of native title has not been fulfilled. In fact, native title has been appropriately managed in those 10 years by both Labor and Liberal governments.

speech.para: The member for Lingiari's speech was yet again an impassioned one about Indigenous issues in his electorate, but it did not touch very much on the extension of the sunset clause for the Joint Committee on Native Title and the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Land Fund. I will not argue with him about mass extinguishment of native title, about which Deputy Speaker Causley knows a great deal more than I do, or the point that he was desperately trying to get in—a new issue about United Nations committees visiting Aboriginal settlements in the Northern Territory—at the last minute there. The member for Lingiari has a history of ranging over many subjects when he gets the chance to do so. He did so again today.

He did make a couple of points which are worth responding to. He did say that he thought we should have a permanent standing committee on native title and the Aboriginal land fund. I do not agree with him about that. I think the parliament has it right. The native title committee was always to be a temporary committee. It had a five-year life then a five-year extension. We have now suggested—and Labor are supporting—a two-year extension for that committee. And there are good reasons for that. It is good that the parliament is flexible about its committee system. There is no point in enshrining in the standing orders or in the parliament committees that become irrelevant and building up a foundation that makes it very hard to remove them for one reason or another. There is no point in having a proliferation of committees focusing on subjects that will not need to be dealt with in the future. Sunset clauses are entirely appropriate.

The member for Lingiari also talked about the intellectual challenge that native title presented to people in the 1990s. I agree with him about that. Some of the best legal minds in the country were working on native title, both when the Keating government introduced the native title bill and when the Howard government had to deal with issues following the judgment on Mabo in the High Court. The minister at the time, Nick Minchin, from the Senate, was responsible for making changes and ensuring that it was a workable system, and he did that. It was a very interesting and intellectual challenge for all of us in this parliament to deal with native title over that time.

The member for Lingiari also said that the land available for native title is limited but important. I agree that it is limited and it is important, but it is also appropriate. The Howard government achieved the right balance not to please but to deal with all of the various stakeholders that were involved in the debate at the time. Many people would have liked to have seen native title disappear off the radar screen in its entirety; others wanted to extend it much further than either the High Court or the parliament had ever intended. A balance was struck by the Howard government, and an outcome was achieved.

The member for Cunningham made an unusual contribution to the debate. He did not comment on the sunset clause at all but ranged widely over a whole lot of statements that failed in being backed up by any facts. One of the more extraordinary remarks that he made was that he thought native title should be extended into metropolitan areas. I think the member for Cunningham needs to understand the system of native title. Perhaps he needs to work out the meanings of extinguishment and alienation of land. Obviously it is not possible under the decisions of the High Court or the parliament to have native title where land has already been alienated. The member for Cunningham should perhaps find that out for himself by doing some more research.

I commend the matter to the Main Committee. It is an appropriate sunset clause. I note that the Labor Party are supporting the government's position, and I thank them for that. I think it indicates the continual renewal of the committee system of which we have all been part. I thank the member for Fraser, the member for Lingiari, the member for Cunningham and, of course, the member for O'Connor—who made an erudite and useful contribution to the debate—for their contributions and commend the bill to the chamber.
Question agreed to.
Bill read a second time.
Ordered that the bill be reported to the House without amendment.

subdebate.1.para: Debate resumed from 2 March, on motion by Mr Slipper:

motion.para: That this bill be now read a second time.

subdebate.1.para: upon which Mr McMullan moved by way of amendment:
That all words after “That” be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:
“whilst not declining to give the Bill a second reading, the House condemns the Government for its budget waste and mismanagement, and wrong priorities which have resulted in:
(1) a costly Medicare `safety net' which does not protect families from increasing health costs and declining levels of bulk billing;
(2) inadequate funding and higher fees for students seeking access to higher education;
(3) a growing number of families who are financially squeezed and trying to balance work and family; and
(4) 500,000 Australians waiting up to five years to get their teeth fixed”.

talk.start.para: —We are debating the additional estimates of 2003-04 through Appropriation Bill (No. 3) 2003-2004, Appropriation Bill (No. 4) 2003-2004 and Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Bill (No. 2) 2003-2004. These are relatively straightforward bills which, as supply bills, we all know will pass without opposition. However, many members and senators may oppose the policies which these bills reflect. It has become obvious in the last couple of weeks that problems are hidden in the delivery of programs around Australia. We have heard about the difficulties many students have had in accessing appropriate and affordable education and training. University places have been cut back or have been priced out of the local market, and many students have been guided towards TAFE education. They have replaced many of the young people who were seeking a TAFE course as a first preference and who are now unlikely to be able to find a place in their chosen course.

speech.para: It is very sad that our children are not getting the opportunities they need to gain qualifications. We know that literacy is very important in the early years, but, as one travels through the schooling system, once literacy has been mastered there are many other courses that are important in the development of a job-ready person. It worries me as I watch what is happening to our young people—mainly the teenage boys who are constantly finding themselves in trouble with the law and the community. They have lost their way through the education system and now have nothing to fall back on. I watch our teenagers and compare them with teenagers and young men in other countries. There are striking similarities—and I talk of suicide bombers in the Middle East and the ethnic problems we have in our cities. They are young, energetic men who have little hope, who are totally disaffected by the current world and who are ripe for brainwashing by whatever cult happens along at the time. We have had the Eastern and Western religious cults, and now we have the Middle East varieties tied up with the Muslim fundamentalists. These cults come and go, but they run their course. They take with them the flower of our youth—in particular, teenage boys. We cannot as a nation afford to have that happen.

This means our society is failing them. It means that there are few programs in place to help young people make the transition from school to work. Having a home and a training course is becoming only a dream for many of our young people. Centrelink is making so many errors that young people are being breached for problems beyond their control. It is making them hopeless and angry. How can you explain 1.3 million mistakes affecting 700,000 Centrelink clients over a four-month period? No wonder people are disillusioned about the sort of help they might look forward to—help that they do not get. If you read the Centrelink manuals, you can understand why these mistakes are made. Whoever wrote them must be held to blame—not the employees at the coalface of Centrelink. The manuals are muddled, confused and sometimes downright contradictory. Government changes the guidelines as it goes along, usually in some centralised computer system, and every time there is a change the procedures become more and more complex. The old customer officer struggles to keep up. No wonder there are mistakes. This is what the government is doing to us.

Then look at what has happened at the other end of the scale with regard to our old people. Access to nursing homes is becoming critical. Our pensioners are queueing up to get a place and still more wait hopelessly for the type of care that they actually want. Couples are being split up as there are no spaces available. After spending their lives together, we are not giving them the option to be able to spend the last years of their lives together. Some people are hovering at home without the necessary backup and care. Now we have the government trying to seek funds from the elderly to prop up commercial nursing homes. We are seeing another try by this government to bring in nursing-home bonds because they have been so tardy in sorting out the management problems facing nursing homes. The charitable groups are giving up trying to make ends meet with their homes and they are selling them off.

The program that really needs more funds, of course, is Medicare. It has been stripped and threatened for years, and it is sadly in need of renewal. It should be more than a safety net; it should be a universal care provider. Instead, this government is just increasing dollars to doctors without looking at the overall need to improve hospital funding and access to doctors, and without actually looking at programs that would encourage doctors to practise in regional areas. Add to this the obstructions put in the path of overseas-trained doctors who come to Australia and try to help the chronic shortage of doctors in regional Australia, and one gets the picture of a rather sick country, with people too scared to go to the doctor in case they cannot afford to pay the bill.

This has also been happening for ages with dental care. Labor's dental programs have been totally abolished. We have a policy to bring them back. This government knocked all those programs out. There are people who have been waiting for months with a toothache. Nothing is more debilitating than a constant toothache, yet many older people cannot get near a dentist unless they pay up front. It is a national disgrace. People do not want to hear about how Australia can get a budget surplus; they want to know how and when they can get their teeth fixed. They want to see some of that budget surplus not being wasted on getting the government re-elected but actually being spent on practical things like fixing their teeth. They do not want to hear about tenders and deals; they want to hear about jobs and the assistance to get them.

It is enormously disappointing to hear nothing about the things that really matter to people in these bills that are being considered. In fact, the bills seem to be about saving money to create a surplus to spend at elections, rather than about spending it on the people who really need it. Evidence of this has come out in the papers today, as the government is trying to sweeten a budget deemed to be aimed at winning over sectional interests that might have been turning to Labor. The government is throwing money at the different groups it has broken promises to in the past. Why has it waited so long? The veterans have finally managed to win some concessions but this is only in part honouring the promises that were given to them. There is nothing new; it is just honouring the promises that were given to them.

There are still niggling discrimination problems within that system so that some veterans are getting payments while others miss out. Veteran groups are very strong on the fact that the special rate is still being eroded: instead of losing $78 per fortnight over seven years, veterans are likely to lose approximately $30 a fortnight over the next seven years—hardly keeping up with inflation. It reminds me of the Malaysia-Borneo veterans—people who fought for so long to be recognised as having been in combat and then missed out on the many privileges because they were in the wrong place at the wrong time. I wonder now what will happen to those who served in the gulf and in Iran and all the peacekeeping missions in recent years. Are they to be eligible for some decent assistance when they suffer illness or suffer as a result of the service that they have given our great country? We are always getting cases that fall between the guidelines of assistance because of technicalities. The government needs to sort this out once and for all.

The government have also been throwing money at private education instead of singling out those schools that have been living on nothing for decades. They have been tossing funds into the private school pot without any developmental work going on at all. They are just giving it to their old mates—that is, to the schools that they went to.

In trying to get the Medicare package through, the Minister for Health and Ageing is trying to bribe the Democrats into supporting a safety net threshold at a flat $500. Many families would not be able to find the money to pass that threshold and are therefore likely to forgo doctors appointments and treatment because of the cost. I am not talking about those who are on some sort of benefit; I am talking about families on low wages—and there are a lot of them in Australia today. They are the working poor who have been created by this government. They get no benefits from the government. They are struggling to pay their rent and feed their children, and now the government is talking about a $500 threshold.

Family payments have become so complicated and scary to access that many risk going hungry rather than go to Centrelink, because Centrelink will demand back some of the dollars that they have given them if they happen to make a few extra dollars in a month. People are now scared of Centrelink. They are scared of the organisation that was put there by government to assist people. That is what this government has done: it has made people frightened of an organisation which should be assisting people.

I listened with amusement to the member for Warringah's vicious attacks on the Labor Party regarding the lease of Centenary House, which is merely a business deal set up by the party's executive some years ago as part of extensive property investments to try and hedge against low interest rates. Some of the investments have performed better than others and have been good business practice—something that those on the other side seem to not want to understand. Maybe they are just very jealous that the ALP have been able to do this so well. They are jealous that the ALP have such good businesspeople and can hold and organise their finances in such a good way. That is what this ranting and raving is all about. The member for Warringah has green eyes. The government go crook at the opposition for wanting to ensure that all Australians have equal access to the services of government and for not being good businesspeople. And yet they cannot hack Labor being very prudent with money and being good money managers.

These appropriation bills give us little comfort that funds are being allocated properly and that Australians are going to be better off under this Howard government. Each year under the Liberals money has less value. Not only are ordinary Australians smarting, but business and industry sectors are being routed by the government's obsession with getting trade deals with the US at any cost—including in particular the sacrifice of the Tasmanian apple and pear industry. Australia and Australians are losing out all around.

talk.start.para: —Today I want to limit my comments on the Appropriation Bill (No. 3) 2003-2004, the Appropriation Bill (No. 4) 2003-2004, and the Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Bill (No. 2) 2003-2004 to the fiasco that has become Job Network mark 3. This system was meant to assist the unemployed in getting off welfare and into work, but it is struggling to work itself. The roll-out of Job Network mark 3—the third significant overhaul of employment services in just eight years—has been a litany of government mismanagement, government incompetence and delusional denials from the Minister for Employment Services.

speech.para: The transition to Job Network 3 has been a failed experiment in social policy, implemented not with the welfare of job seekers foremost in mind but to satisfy the ideological agenda of the Howard government at a cost to taxpayers of $2.85 billion over the coming three years. Just nine months into the Job Network's latest three-year contract, known as Employment Services Contract 3 or ESC3, its longer term financial viability is still far from certain. Only this week both the Australian and the Australian Financial Review reported on a confidential document written by the National Employment Services Association, the peak body representing private as well as not-for-profit Job Network providers, which warned that, unless providers receive an immediate cash injection from taxpayers, many will have to close their doors. One can only lament the crisis now besetting the Job Network, particularly given the fanfare and great promises made by the government at the time of its development.

Let us cast our memories back to the months leading up to the start of ESC3 on 1 July 2003. We can recall the confident claims being made by the Minister for Employment Services, the member for Longman, Mal Brough. There was the press release on 27 March 2003 in which the minister said:

quote.para: ... from July, Job Network members will deliver even better services to Australia's unemployed ... They will have greater access to jobs, more flexible assistance through a Job Seeker Account and a Service Guarantee ... The state-of-the-art job matching service will compare every job seeker's resume with every listed job, every night and the result can be accessed the next day for quicker access to work opportunities.

speech.para: On 28 March in the Courier-Mail, the minister said that ESC3 `will be delivering a very personalised, visualised service'. In the parliament on 27 May, the minister said that ESC3 `builds on what has been a very successful transition from the old CES to the Job Network'. Also on that day, he said:

quote.para: ... there will in fact be more Job Network personnel working in the [system] delivering quality services to Australians in country towns and in suburbs where the service is needed. Furthermore, it will be backed up with the world's best IT.

speech.para: In a press release on 19 June 2003, the minister said:

quote.para: We'll have the same Australia-wide coverage as in previous Job Network but the services will be more relevant and better tailored to the needs of local communities.

speech.para: On 19 June in the parliament, he said:

quote.para: An unemployed person needs to be treated as an individual. We need to take them, build them up personally and provide them with the skills and the connections for the jobs. To do that, we have provided what we call the job seeker account.

speech.para: Unfortunately, the reality has simply not matched the government's earlier rhetoric. We know this from talking to the unemployed and to Job Network providers. We also know this from freedom of information documents provided by the government's own department which show the contrast between what the minister was saying publicly, what the government and the minister were being told privately and what was actually occurring on the ground.

The transition to ESC3 resulted in the closure of some 1,100 offices around the country. This is a government that closed more offices than it left open—53 per cent. Most of those office closures occurred in rural and regional Australia. Some 58 per cent of the offices there—691 Job Network offices—closed as a result of that transition. As a result of that, many towns have been left without any Job Network office, forcing job seekers to travel further to get the help, assistance and training that they need to find a job.

While Labor first exposed the cut to regional Job Network services more than eight months ago, the FOI documents obtained from the government show that the government itself was being told by its departments that the level of service available to regional and rural job seekers would be lower. The FOI documents state:

quote.para: Job Network membership coverage is not available in some remote and rural areas (and appears to have been reduced with the third Job Network contract) and [the Department of Employment and Workplace Relations] has not yet provided a service strategy for these jobseekers.

speech.para: What an outrage! The FOI documents clearly show that this government was alerted to what the problems were but was not alarmed enough to take action. The closure of these offices was part of the shutdown of any public sector provision role. This is a government that wound up Employment National, resulting in the loss of more than 400 jobs across 165 localities. When the government moved to the Job Network it argued that we needed a public sector provider as a safety net; yet it moved away from that commitment.

On top of that, the size of the Job Network pool meant that the whole basis of the contracts for Job Network 3 was simply not what providers were told. Providers were told that there would be 720,000 or 780,000 people in the system. We know that that simply is not the case. What the minister purported to say was: `That's because unemployment has fallen.' But we know that that is not true, because the data shows that at the time that the tender documents went out, September 2002, there were 644,722 people receiving benefits. In July 2003, when the Job Network contract started, there were 633,259 people receiving benefits—a reduction of only 11,463. The latest figures from January 2004 show a further reduction of just 3,036, down to 630,223 people.

We know that the government confused those people who were activity tested, and therefore compelled to participate in the Job Network, with volunteers—people who could certainly go along to a Job Network office but who had no compulsion because of the nature of their benefit or because they were involved in some other program. That meant that the pool was more like 500,000. The government initially, in some circumstances, talked about a pool of 900,000. That meant that, even if you took their lowest figure of 720,000 to 780,000 people, when the real figure was 500,000, the size of the market was some one-third less. So, if you established your business under ESC3, expecting a revenue base of, say, $300,000 a month to be coming in, and all of a sudden you are getting only $200,000, then no wonder you are in strife. That is the basis of the fundamental flaw in the model from 1 July. And the minister knew, because on 25 July 2003 a minute from Centrelink to FaCS stated:

quote.para: I think we need to bring out the fact that there are only perhaps 500,000 customers who can be compelled to come in.

speech.para: So, in spite of spending $11.3 million on preparing, developing and implementing Job Network 3, the minister simply got his numbers wrong. The combination of increased costs and reduced revenues has already claimed one provider. Options Community Enterprises was a provider that specialised in helping people with disabilities to find work and was a top performer under Job Network 2. However, under Job Network 3 this 27-year-old organisation has been forced out of business.

Then we go to the IT debacle. On top of diminished service coverage, the operation of the Job Network has been further impaired by ongoing so-called technical difficulties with the IT system. Honourable members will recall that earlier in my speech I referred to the minister calling this `the world's best IT'. A briefing note to the Minister for Family and Community Services dated 11 June 2003 stated:

quote.para: It is now 11 weeks since ESC3 was introduced. There have been only two or three days where there has not been a system outage.

speech.para: For only two or three days out of the first 77 days when the system was supposed to be operating was it actually up and running. No wonder one provider has labelled the system a dog. A major component of this IT system is of course the Australian Job Search database. This system seeks to automatch job seekers with job vacancies. The vacancy information sent via various electronic means is supposed to be tailored to the job seeker's skills, work experience and areas of employment interests. But what have we seen? We have seen Joanna, a 53-year-old Tasmanian woman and former art gallery worker, matched with a job requiring a chainsaw licence. We have seen Rosa, a 56-year-old woman from Daylesford, who suffers from severe blood pressure and severe arthritis, matched with a job in the Army Reserve as a combat medic. We have also seen a young Tasmanian man matched with a job in an escort agency and a Western Australian matched with a job seeking someone to launder money. This is on the government's web site. The government is critical of the old operation of the CES. I say this to Minister Brough: the CES did not send people who were unemployed to jobs in escort agencies, while the government system has done that.

I now want to move to the job seeker account. This was the flexible part of the system. There was $900 available to Job Network providers. This fund had a total of $223 million allocated to it. It was there to be used to increase the employability of the unemployed. However, just last week we asked in Senate estimates hearings how much of the job seeker account had been accessed and we were told that, to date, a mere $31.4 million or 14 per cent of the money had actually been used by providers. Providers have been warning for some time that the overly bureaucratic nature of accessing the money in the job seeker account was discouraging its use. In one case study reported in the Australian on 1 March 2004, a rural provider calculated it had spent $75,408 on 3,240 job seeker account transactions without compensation. Unfortunately, when providers raise these issues the government simply ignores the problem. Therefore, the money sits unused in a government bank account rather than being used on the unemployed. The combination of the problem with the lack of numbers, the problems with the IT and the problems with the usage of the job seeker account means that many providers are under severe pressure. A February board report of a major Job Network provider stated:

quote.para: It is prudent to report to the board the general low ebb in morale that the organisation is experiencing at present—not too surprising, when you recall the historic graph. The situation hasn't happened overnight, but steadily, as our Job Network income has decreased and focus on performance has increased, the result is of course that people have departed either voluntarily or by termination of contract. This is unsettling, naturally.

speech.para: It goes on:

quote.para: It is sometimes difficult to appreciate the real wins we have actually made on the board when dealing with the seemingly constant run of problems.

speech.para: Then it goes on to say:

quote.para: They really need to see a few small successes very soon, in order to re-energise the morale and provide a light at the end of the tunnel (that hopefully is not a train).

speech.para: Indeed, I hope that the light at the end of the tunnel for the Job Network is not a train, because that train will run over Job Network providers—decent people, largely operating in not-for-profit organisations, who are not in it for the money but in it because they are committed to the satisfaction that comes from getting someone who is unemployed into work and making a fundamental difference in people's lives. But, more importantly, the unemployed at the moment simply are not the priority of the government. The priority of the government is defending the flawed system rather than acknowledging that the problems are there. Unless you acknowledge the problems that are there, you cannot take the steps to fix them, and that is what the minister needs to do. Just last week the head of a Dubbo job agency called for the service to be overhauled. The CEO of the OEC group, Rod Cooke, said a contract system that worked in the city was sending battling regional agencies broke. In the Daily Liberal, which is the local newspaper in Dubbo, he said:

quote.para: We're all hoping we can convince the Government to wake up to itself and give us the money we need to run their employment service.

speech.para: The article says:

quote.para: Mr Cooke said regional agencies were wearing the cost of trying to source jobs in areas where high unemployment meant few “outcomes” are achieved.
“A survey of rural providers showed they are operating at 80 per cent of expected income and 120 per cent of expected expenditure,” he said.

speech.para: That is not the Labor Party but the CEO of a Job Network provider in rural Australia saying that. I concur with Mr Cooke's comments and the comments that are being made by providers all around the nation that the government does have to wake up to itself. It does have to make changes, because it needs to back up the system that is only struggling to keep going because of the commitment of Job Network providers and Centrelink staff. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —It is like a poker game: the new player is keeping cool with a straight face; the more experienced player is looking uncertain and at times a little desperate. Every election year he puts a lot of money on the table and hopes that no-one will call his hand. Last year was not an election year. He made a few big bets, such as his tax cuts, but they did not come off. Now we are in an election year and John Howard is in serious danger of running out of chips.

speech.para: The Mid-Year Economic and Fiscal Outlook showed a surplus of $20.8 billion for the remainder of the 2003-04 financial year and the three forward estimate years. This followed a post-budget spend of $4.5 billion, taking the spend on net new policy decisions made in the 2003 calendar year to $23.1 billion. Spending decisions since the mid-year review have now added at least $3.5 billion. The government is continuing to eat into the surplus, announcing another $362 million in funding to Catholic schools last Sunday and in excess of $200 million for a veterans package only yesterday. Why is the government promising so much new spending? It is because it is getting uncomfortably close to an election.

The government is a classic flip-flopping, big taxing, big spending government which realises that it is in real electoral danger. We are about to see the characteristic behaviour of this poll-driven government, as we did in 2001, when Mr Howard responded to his party president's `mean and tricky' memo published in the Bulletin. The Howard government is now in a financial squeeze of its own making as it talks about delivering tax relief. The government's budget problem comes down to three sets of figures: (1) the Prime Minister's track record of buying the votes of interest groups in an election year; (2) the amount of bracket creep he must return to taxpayers to make them no worse off than they were when the GST was introduced; and (3) the size of the budget surplus. On present figures, over the budget and three-year forward estimates, the numbers do not fit. Mr Howard will have to choose what to sacrifice: the expectations he is building up amongst interest groups, the full return of bracket creep or the budget surplus. Alternatively—and more likely—he will compromise on all three.

First, let us look at Mr Howard's spending record. His government has been a classic adherent to what economists call the political business cycle. Before he went to the polls in 2001, the Prime Minister spent $25.6 billion buying interest group votes without promising even a dollar of personal income tax relief. This was poll-driven spending. It was not a case of the government having saved the good policy announcements for the election year; it was a case of the government's spending priorities being determined by the Liberal Party's private polling and directed on the single criterion of buying votes—government by Textor. The criteria that the Howard government uses to determine its spending have nothing to do with either what is fair or what is good policy. In fact, any connection between where this government directs its new spending and what is good policy is purely coincidental. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a table showing the net impact of policy decisions on the budget bottom line for each calendar year from 1996 to 2003.
Leave granted.

entry.para: NET IMPACT OF POLICY DECISIONS ON BUDGET BOTTOM LINE AS REPORTED IN THE BUDGET AND MID-YEAR ECONOMIC AND FISCAL OUTLOOK
Source: Budget papers and MYEF0 1996 to 2003

talk.start.para: —Over the last eight years, new policy commitments by the Howard government in election years have averaged $23.1 billion. By contrast, the Prime Minister's new policy commitments in non-election years have averaged only $3.9 billion. Last year was the only exception to that pattern. If you disregard the $23.1 billion spent in the 2003 calendar year, non-election-year policy commitments only average $124.6 million. This raises two questions: was Mr Howard seriously contemplating a poll in 2003, and will 2003 go down as the year Mr Howard lost the fiscal plot and the 2004 election? I should probably refrain from giving the Prime Minister gratuitous political advice after the event, but if he had not spent so much in 2003 he would be in a lot better financial shape to deal with his political problems now.

speech.para: The Treasurer, of course, was not too concerned about spending money last year. He would have done anything to make the Prime Minister feel as though he was at the pinnacle of his career in the hope that he would toddle off into the sunset. I think a better strategy for the Treasurer would have been to expose the Prime Minister to the very great concerns that the Secretary to the Treasury had in the middle of last year about the world economic outlook in the hope that the prospect of an economic downturn would have encouraged the Prime Minister to go, leaving any residual blame for the Treasurer to handle. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a table showing the Melbourne Institute's estimate of bracket creep, together with the government's own estimates of the surplus taken from the mid-year review.
Leave granted.

entry.para: BRACKET CREEP AND THE BUDGET BALANCE

talk.start.para: —The Melbourne Institute's estimates of the extra revenue taken through bracket creep total $13.3 billion over the four years from 2003-04. That means that, over those four financial years, 63.9 per cent of the budget surplus is attributable to bracket creep. If Mr Howard spends the entire $20.8 billion, as I fully expect him to, almost two-thirds of those dollars will be from the increase in taxation arising from bracket creep, so he is doing nothing more than handing back money that he is about to take from taxpayers.

speech.para: I would like to thank the Melbourne Institute for doing a couple of extra model runs for me to put these figures together. In particular, they gave me an estimate of the bracket creep that will accrue on current tax scales in 2007-08, which is one year beyond the forward estimates period, based on expected wages growth and inflation. That bracket creep estimate for the 2007-08 financial year is $6.2 billion. That means the cost of eliminating bracket creep in the 2004-05 budget year would be $17.8 billion over the next budget year and forward estimates period. We will not have the government's estimate of the projected surplus for 2007-08 until the budget is handed down, so we will not be able to estimate how much of that surplus is attributable to bracket creep or whether it is efficient to hand back the extra taxation that has been taken through bracket creep. Mr Howard's 2003 tax cut cost $10.7 billion and was ridiculed by a member of his cabinet, known for her frankness, as being equivalent to a milkshake and a sandwich. However he shapes his next tax cut, the Prime Minister will do almost anything to avoid that analogy being repeated as he approaches a federal election.

Finally, there is the surplus, which dwindled to $20.8 billion over four years, as measured in the mid-year review, after $4.5 billion of post-budget spending. As I said earlier, the government has made more commitments since the mid-year review, with the Prime Minister spending over $3.5 billion. Clearly Mr Howard cannot do both his usual election year $23 billion vote buy-up for interest groups and an almost $18 billion spend in eliminating bracket creep, using a surplus that is now less than $20.8 billion. In this year's budget, look out for smoke and mirrors and overcooked economic growth forecasts to boost revenue as the Prime Minister looks for the maximum amount of room to wriggle. We can expect to see money being pulled out of hollow logs.

Chris Richardson from Access Economics tells me the Reserve Bank may be one of those hollow logs. He has estimated that the Treasurer left perhaps a billion dollars of profit in the bank this year so that he can move it into his election year spend. According to Chris's back-of-the-envelope figuring, if the profit held up at the notional 2003-04 level then there would be an extra $2 billion to spend in 2004-05. The beauty of this sort of exercise, from the government's point of view, is that what is in the forward estimates for dividends from the Reserve Bank is whatever the Treasurer says that he will take. My response to this is that there may be a problem with the Treasurer's plan for raiding the bank, because the dollar has appreciated sharply over 2003-04. Reserve Bank profits actually increase when the dollar falls, because the bank sells foreign currency that it has bought when the dollar is high and is in its balance sheet at historic cost. Because it gets more Aussie dollars when it sells that foreign currency than it paid for it, Reserve Bank profits rise.

When the Aussie dollar appreciates, as it has done this year, the bank should be rebuilding its reserves by buying foreign currency. In these circumstances I would not expect the profit level that the bank had achieved when the dollar was falling to be maintained. On budget night, if there is a big increase in the revenue line marked `dividends', you can bet that the Treasurer has raided the bank at the expense of the governor being able to rebuild foreign exchange reserves. I would like to think that those considerations would prevail and the Treasurer would not make a raid on the bank in this election year, but that would be a triumph of hope over experience.

A couple of years ago the Treasurer took a special dividend out of Australia Post, and the price of a stamp went up by 5c. The problem with this sort of behaviour is that it is not sustainable. For eight years now the government has tried to base its economic credentials on tight budget policy and debt reduction. Eight years is long enough to judge any government. Since September 1991, Australia has enjoyed almost 13 years of almost continuous economic growth, interrupted only by the introduction of the GST. The government's stated fiscal policy is to balance the budget over the course of the economic cycle. However, the government's focus is on the political business cycle and not the economic cycle. Because the Howard government is prepared to spend all the surplus when the economy has been growing for a long period, it is a government whose spending is decidedly procyclical. It is easy to ignore that when the immediate economic outlook seems benign. However, with almost all the surplus being spent, unless the current period of growth goes on for a very long time the Howard government will not balance its budget over the course of the economic cycle: that is, if it lasts that long. In any significant downturn caused by a change in world economic conditions that sort of procyclical spending is likely to increase the size of the resulting river of red ink.

I am not predicting an economic downturn, but I also do not accept the Treasurer's presumption that his own economic management has been so brilliant that Australia is now no longer exposed to the international economic cycle. It is worth remembering that in the last half of last year the Secretary to the Treasury had sufficient concerns about the economic outlook to be arguing with the Governor of the Reserve Bank at board meetings that a further easing in interest rates should be considered. A careful reading of the governor's transcripts of evidence given to the House economics committee indicates that he too was not entirely sanguine at that time about the domestic implications of a world slowdown, given Australian households' exposure to debt. It is something you think about if you have been involved in managing the budget over the course of an international business cycle; the current Treasurer has not, having taken over the economy with the recovery already well established and the budget returning to balance.

The Howard government's first budget was tight, slashing $24 billion over the forward estimates, but since then the government has made new spending decisions worth $94 billion. By the time Australia goes to the polls that figure will far exceed $100 billion. Mr Howard's frame of reference might be the next poll, but Labor's will be Australia's future. I seek leave to have incorporated in Hansard a table showing the contribution of asset sales to debt reduction.
Leave granted.

entry.para: ASSET SALES AS A PROPORTION OF REDUCTION IN COMMONWEALTH NET DEBT 30th of June 1996 to 30th of June 2003
Source: ABS Government Financial Estimates 199912000 and 2000101 (Cat 5501.0) Budget Paper No.1 2003-04MYEFO 2003

talk.start.para: —Mr Costello may boast that he has reduced net debt by $72 billion, but that is much less impressive when you recognise that he has done it with $56 billion worth of asset sales. Most of his debt reduction is simply moving assets and liabilities around on the balance sheet, rather than any sustainable improvement in net assets. When we are talking about the Howard government's economic credentials we must not forget that many of those asset sales were made at low prices and some, like the sale of major public buildings, have significant long-term costs for the budget.

speech.para: The problem the Howard government must face now is that families are paying more and getting less. This is the highest taxing government in Australia's history. The tax to GDP ratio has increased 2.4 per cent since the government came to office. In current money terms that is the equivalent of Australians paying an extra $19 billion in tax. While Australian taxpayers are paying more tax than ever before, the government says it cannot afford to invest in the education of the next generation and it cannot afford a universal health system—only an inadequate safety net. The truth is the money is there for these priorities; it is just that the Howard government is wasting and mismanaging it. Australians deserve a government with priorities that reflect the best interests of all Australians. They deserve policies that provide opportunities for all.

talk.start.para: —In commenting on the Appropriation Bill (No. 3) 2003-2004, the Appropriation Bill (No. 4) 2003-2004 and the Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Bill (No. 2) 2003-2004, I want to focus on the wrong priorities of this government insofar as the average Australian family is concerned. The government likes to talk a lot about its strong economic achievements, and there is no doubt that we have been, as a nation, through a lengthy period of good growth. But I want to argue that, at a time of good economic growth, the government has failed to ensure that the growing wealth and prosperity of our country are being fairly shared by all. It is clearly not the case, because every indicator points to growing inequality in our society and a retreat from principles of egalitarianism. In fact we are becoming a much more unequal society, even in comparison with other OECD countries.

speech.para: The tragedy is that the Howard government continues to turn a blind eye to this growing inequality.
