For all the talk that we hear from the Howard government about its commitment to the battlers and to such things as family friendly policies, the reverse is actually the case: the government is creating more battlers—more battling families just trying to survive and eke out an existence. As far as family friendly policies are concerned, I think the average family will tell you that they have never had it as hard as they have it today. They have been hit very hard by the highest taxing government of all time. It is these average families that are suffering under enormous financial pressures as a result of this government's wrong policies and priorities.

Under this government, Australians are paying more tax than ever before. The tax cuts that came with the GST, as some measure of compensation, have long since been eroded. But the GST lives on, day in, day out. Household debt and credit card debt have gone through the roof under this administration. The great tragedy for the average family and their children is that the Australian dream of home ownership will never be a reality for many young people.

Financial stress and pressure are at an all-time high, and combined with that there is a decline in services and a reduction in opportunities for the average family. While services are declining, the government is relying more and more on the user-pays philosophy, which is now rampant in areas like higher education and, increasingly, health. With the greater tax share that is coming to the government, one would have thought there would be no excuse for the government not providing the outlays that are necessary to ensure a universal health system, underpinned by bulk-billing, and no excuse for the government not making sure that merit, not money, opens the door for access to further education.

There is little joy in the government's policies for large numbers of families that I represent in my electorate. I think the government fails to recognise the pressures that the average family is under. Nearly 30 per cent of the families I represent survive on a family income of less than $500 per week. That is 8,642 families and their dependants struggling to survive on $26,000 gross, or less, each year. Can you imagine how tough it is for them? The median family income in Throsby is around $44,000 per year. I represent families that could generally be described as middle- and low-income families. These families, who have contributed so much to the nation's prosperity and are the glue in the community networks, are precisely the families that are missing out on much of the rewards of Australia's economic growth.

The government cannot have it both ways. It cannot take praise for the good economic outcomes while turning a blind eye to the fact that those outcomes and that prosperity are not being shared equitably in our community. It is the average families who are slowly but surely sinking under the weight of an unfair tax system.

para.inline: A division having been called in the House of Representatives—
Sitting suspended from 12.10 p.m. to 12.23 p.m.

talk.start.para: —As I was saying, the impact of the government's wrong policies and priorities on average families is making their situation very difficult. They are slowly but surely sinking under the weight of an unfair tax system. As my colleague the member for Kingston pointed out in his contribution, the insidious effects of bracket creep are pushing more and more working families into the next tax bracket. We know that there is a lot of unpaid or overtaxed overtime occurring. They are struggling under the introduction of a user-pays philosophy for basic services. They are struggling under a government-induced family payment debt system. All in all, it is a system which is robbing people of any incentive to earn extra and better themselves and their families.

speech.para: The Howard government is squeezing the very Australians who have made our economy strong and prosperous. One issue that I particularly want to draw attention to is the impact that the interaction between the tax and welfare systems is having on low- and middle-income families who are out there wanting to earn additional income or, in some cases, as we have in my electorate, on people wanting to move from welfare to work. I would like to quote from a letter that I received from one of my constituents, Margaret Geeves, because I think it is typical of the frustration that is being carried by families all over Australia. The Geeves are a single-income family of six. Her husband, Dennis, has been in his job for 32 years and she is a stay-at-home mum by choice. I will quote from her submission to me. She says:

quote.para: Dear Ms George,

I am writing to you in the hope that something can be done about the taxation system that the Government has in place. It is not a fair and just system for all Australian people. There is no incentive to better oneself as I am about to explain in our situation. I challenge you to find someone in Government to justify and clarify why my husband is only $207 ... better off after receiving a bonus of $1,000 ...

speech.para: She goes on to explain that her husband had done well at work and achieved this bonus payment, but the impact of the bonus payment was that 47 per cent was taken away in tax, that is minus $470, and then another 30 per cent was taken away, that is $300, because of the clawback of 30c in every dollar in family allowance. So for the extra effort that Dennis Geeves had put into getting the bonus at work, the family was left with $230. This, as she points out:

quote.para: ... when spent incurs 10% GST (another tax) leaving us just $207 extra money coming into our household not affected by tax.

speech.para: She goes on to say:

quote.para: Not much an incentive to work harder to earn more especially when this is all bonus money that was achieved through goal making. Not much of incentive for being a stay at home mum losing Family Allowances especially with teenage children who can't get part time jobs.

speech.para: The letter continues:

quote.para: We aren't extravagant. We drive old cars .... We rarely eat out. We don't wear designer or surf brand clothes. We don't have a holiday very often as it is too expensive to accommodate six people ... We haven't been away for three years and we were thrilled with the bonus and planned a holiday ... but looks like we will have to cancel, as there is not much of this money left to use.

I hope that there is someone in Government who knows what I'm talking about when it comes to family matters ... The question I ask is how as a family can we see past today if the Government wants to take most of our well earned money?

As a mother I feel I have contributed to society by being there for my children and I am very proud to say that they are genuinely very nice people. I will never regret being there for them but I will always regret that the government made it so damn hard to survive in a system that takes so much from middle income families on one wage who are unable to claim much tax relief. I know we are not the only ones going through this fate and would like the Government to realise that people like us with large families on single incomes do not fit into the rich category of paying the highest income tax and losing family allowances.

speech.para: Margaret Geeves's comments express the frustration, resentment and anger of the average low- to middle-income family. This government turns a blind eye to the problems and struggles they experience on a daily basis.

Why is it that this government hits low- and middle-income earners with higher rates of tax than millionaires? One million Australian workers today are paying 60c in every additional dollar they earn through the impact of tax and the withdrawal of benefits. The government's own recently released figures show that many families in the middle-income range of $31,000 to $85,000 are keeping as little as 21.5c of each extra dollar they earn through the impact of bracket creep and reduced family tax benefits. Why is it that a government that talks so much about family friendly policies provides no incentive for mothers to return to part-time work? For each dollar they earn on return to part-time work after the birth of a child they lose 30c in family tax benefit A, 30c in family tax benefit B, 17 per cent in tax and, on top of that, their Medicare levy. Again, I ask, as Margaret Geeves asked me: why is it that the government is not hearing and not listening to the pleas of the average family?

I have spoken on numerous occasions about the flawed family payment system and the terrible tragedy of innocent families who have done the right thing being treated as cheats. We now learn that, since the changes to the family tax benefit system back in July 2000, at least three million families have received incorrect payments. That comes as no surprise because the whole system is based on the absurdity of people trying to guess and predict their income in advance.

Some 1.6 million Australian families have been punished and treated like cheats in a flawed system that has slugged them with debts of some $1.4 billion. And still nothing is done by this government to rectify this obvious injustice. It is ironic that the government surpluses keep mounting. The war chest is certainly being built up, as we have seen just in the last couple of days. The war chest is out there for the government to try to buy its way back into power, but it refuses to act on this problem. That is despite the fact that its own interdepartmental committee told the government exactly what we have been saying for many years now—that the flawed family payments system is creating victims who have done nothing other than try to guess their income in advance as best they can and to notify Centrelink of any changes. I think it is absolutely scandalous.

In my electorate 2,506 families have been hurt for doing nothing wrong. They have been hurt with total debts in that period that have now accrued to over $6 million. The average debt carried by families, 30 per cent of whom bring in less than $500 a week, is $711. I think the government's inaction on this issue shows that it does not care. It does not understand the pressure that families are under because, if it did, it would not allow this scandalous situation to continue.

The last comment I want to make relates to the growing number of working poor in our community. In a country as affluent as ours it is a tragedy that, for increasing numbers of families, paid employment is no longer a protection against poverty. While wage inequality grows under this government, it does nothing of a positive nature to improve the plight of the very low paid workers who depend on the award system. Some 20 per cent of workers—that is, 1.6 million people—rely totally on their award for their protection and for their wages. The only increases in their award rates of pay come through the ACTU's annual living wage applications.

Yet since 1996 this government has opposed every increase sought on behalf of low-paid workers by the ACTU. These are workers currently earning $11.80 per hour. They are workers in industries like hospitality, retail and community services, many of whom are part-time and casual workers and about 60 per cent of whom are women. At the moment, the ACTU is seeking to lift their minimum wage to $24,700 a year. It is hardly an exorbitant increase that they are seeking. Yet again we have this government not having the goodwill to support the claim. In fact, had the government had its way these same workers, today on minimum wages, would have been almost $2,000 a year worse off than they currently are. Thank goodness, despite the intentions of the government, we still have an independent Industrial Relations Commission where some measure of justice can be achieved for the very low-paid workers.

I think it is an absolute disgrace that wages at the top end of town go through the roof and that we see, on a weekly basis, the kinds of golden handshakes that are paid out to CEOs of companies that have not performed well; yet people at the lower end of the income scale, struggling on less than $12 an hour, cannot get support from this government to ensure that at least their minimum wage lifts them out of the possibility of falling under the poverty line. I think it is disgraceful that the government talks about tax cuts for people paying top marginal tax rates but shows absolutely no concern for those on low incomes and the growing number of working poor. Despite all the evidence that low wages are pushing many working families into poverty, the Howard government has consistently opposed any efforts that have been made by the union movement to secure reasonable increases in the minimum wage. As all the indicators show, the workers in hospitality, tourism and community services are in industries that are recording good profit outcomes; productivity has improved and continues to improve. Yet these workers are condemned by this government to try to survive on wage levels lower than $12 an hour.

In conclusion, I want to reiterate my view that the government's policies and directions are creating a more unequal Australia, a land of the haves and the have-nots. We are retreating from the notions of a fair go and egalitarianism. Who is bearing the brunt of all this? It is the average, hardworking, honest, toiling low- and middle-income earners who have contributed to this nation's prosperity but who, at the end of the day, are being left behind by a government that is not ensuring that our prosperity is shared equally by all.

talk.start.para: —At the outset, I would like to associate myself with the comments of the previous speakers with regard to minimum wages and recognise the campaign of the Liquor, Hospitality and Miscellaneous Workers Union, under the leadership of Jeff Lawrence, whose organisation covers cleaners, hospitality and the security sector—sectors that particularly bear the brunt of this government's determination to drive down real wages. Appropriation Bill (No. 3) 2003-2004, Appropriation Bill (No. 4) 2003-2004 and Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Bill (No. 2) 2003-2004 provide for variations to appropriation in line with spending and revenue measures adopted by the government since the budget and changes resulting from revisions to portfolio budget estimates. Arising from these bills and the immigration portfolio additional estimates statements, there are a number of matters I wish to canvass with regard to my shadow portfolio.

speech.para: From the outset, I note that the additional estimates statements are almost entirely lacking in proper information about changes that this government is making to migrant settlement services. This is part of a continuing assault on transparency and accountability under the coalition. It is no wonder that the opposition has instigated measures to try to tackle the assault on freedom of information in this country—that is, the way in which this government is endeavouring to decrease the amount of transparency in government through restrictions on FOI.

The history of the matter of settlement services is clear. Suddenly, out of the blue, in 2002 Minister Hardgrave announced an in-house review of all settlement services for migrants and refugees. There was, understandably, considerable suspicion that the review was more or less pursuing a predetermined outcome on the part of the department and the minister. That is of course because it stayed in-house. It was unparalleled. Organisations outside of government had carriage of previous reviews of such a nature; this was a departmental inquiry. There was particular suspicion in relation to major changes proposed in the final report of the review regarding migrant resource centres and project funding under the Community Settlement Services Scheme, the CSSS. The department's report was, however, also quite critical of the coalition's approach to access and equity issues and of arrangements to provide on-arrival assistance to refugees under the Integrated Humanitarian Settlement Service, the IHSS.

We are witnessing a pattern of consultations upon consultations, where the number of meetings convened by DIMIA seems to be inversely related to the amount of real influence that service providers exercise over the process. I am constantly told by the sector that everyone is in the dark about what the future really holds and that funded services are being warned not to take their concerns to their elected parliamentary representatives. One of the other things that disturbed me initially in this portfolio as I went around the country was the view by some MRCs that they had to ring up the department to see whether the shadow minister was allowed to come to meetings of their organisation to canvass what they were doing, the kinds of communities they were serving et cetera. I am pleased to say that the paranoia the government has forced upon these MRCs seems to have decreased over time.

At the report's release, Minister Hardgrave said that a high-level task force, chaired by Prime Minister and Cabinet, would be set up to pursue the major changes. That is about all the minister has chosen to reveal. We do not know the membership of the task force or its exact terms of reference. We do not know what its riding instructions were in terms of budgetary matters. Thanks to the Senate additional estimates hearing we do know, however, that the task force has completed its job, having reported to the government more than two months ago. To date, nothing has been revealed about the findings of the task force or about what decisions the government has taken in response. This is just not good enough.

It is particularly pressing that the minister tells us what the government has planned for what we term `established migrant communities'. The departmental review, instigated by the minister himself, questioned whether such groups should continue to be eligible for funding for migrant welfare projects under CSSS. It specifically mentioned the Armenian, Greek, Italian, Jewish, Maltese, Polish, Portuguese, Russian and Ukrainian communities as groups targeted for change. There are no doubt others. They have questioned whether these groups that have been here many decades should continue to be essentially covered and assisted by DIMIA. I want to say on a personal note that, particularly in regard to the Ukrainians, the Maltese, the Greeks and the Italians, this affects my electorate in Western Sydney.

This recommendation was clearly a key matter before the high-level task force, so the government should be able to tell us what it has in mind. Will DIMIA continue to support such communities or not? Does the government think they are the responsibility of some other portfolio and, if so, which portfolio and what guarantee is there that existing migrant welfare projects will continue to be funded? Or does the government really believe that it is all someone else's problem, and will it try to pass responsibility to the states or local government—a practice that has become very prevalent in recent years? We deserve answers to these questions.

What the government has reluctantly revealed so far is not reassuring. Under questioning from the opposition, the head of settlement services in DIMIA, Jennifer Bryant, told the Senate hearing on 17 February that the issue is:

quote.para: ... still under consideration by the government and, in the interim—

speech.para: in the interim, I stress—

quote.para: there have been no changes to eligibility criteria for the 2004 CSSS funding round. Any established community applying for funding in that round—

speech.para: in that round, I stress—

quote.para: will have their application considered on its merits ...

speech.para: Reading between the lines, this is a short-term expedient measure to cover the government's backside until after the election. There is no long-term commitment there. In my media release of 18 February I noted that the clear implication of Ms Bryant's comments is that the government proposes to make major changes to the CSSS next year if it is re-elected. In the meantime, the vast majority of projects are on the shortest possible grant period, to give the department the greatest scope to make cuts down the track.

Minister Hardgrave's press release of 25 February has only dug a deeper hole for the government and himself. Nowhere does it say that the established ethnic communities will be eligible for DIMIA funding after this year. It merely repeats Ms Bryant's comments that there have been no changes to eligibility criteria for the 2004 CSSS grants round and that all organisations that currently receive funding are eligible to apply. Big deal. We knew that already. We wonder why he cannot say what happens after that, other than talking about yet more community consultations, with no commitment that the money will continue for a wide variety of long-established welfare organisations around this country.

Some of those organisations are ones in which various ministers flaunt themselves and make adulatory comments about how fantastic these groups are, what a great job they are doing and how close to the community they are. There is a real threat here that the government is essentially going to cut their funding under the pretext that they are not the government's problem, they are not DIMIA's problem, they have been here too long and they are not part of migration settlement.

A related issue is the position of migrant resource centres, or MRCs. Somewhat paradoxically, the MRC program is a legacy of Malcolm Fraser. Their establishment was a key recommendation of the Galbally report, commissioned by his government. I stress that that was an external review of how the system should operate. It was not, like the latest one, an in-house, departmental, ministerially driven analysis. The purpose of MRCs is to offer multilingual information, advice and referral services, provide a base for sessional ethno-specific services, and foster the development of new services to develop local needs.

I am a strong supporter of MRCs, on three grounds. Firstly, they are multicultural in nature, with their boards and services not dominated by particular ethnic groups. I have seen at various stages attempts in my own area by specific ethnic groups to take them over. Those attempts have failed, and these organisations generally around this country have a broad coverage of occupation, background, politics and experience as well as a wide diversity of communities. Secondly, they are large and visible enough to have a greater impact than most small scale organisations. Finally, they are community controlled and thus receptive to the needs and concerns of the region they serve. I think the previous minister, the member for Berowra, would certainly agree that the MRCs in my region, which he has visited on many occasions, are doing a tremendous job. It is pleasing that the previous government established them and that groups like Auburn and Parramatta are functioning so well.

For reasons that have never been clearly explained, the current government has been far from enthusiastic about MRCs on a general front. We have had a number of them close. Some of them have closed for good reason—I could not dispute the need to close them. But we do see a fundamental thrust by the government to perhaps move towards the replacement of community controlled organisations which have a lot of volunteers with a lot of commitment and purpose with religious and other groups that perhaps do not have the expertise, background, knowledge and grassroots connections that are necessary for these groups.

Concerns include the withdrawal of funding for several centres, as I mentioned, and the nature of the replacement services that were put in place, usually under the CSS Scheme; and, secondly, the settlement services review proposal to amalgamate the separate CSSS and migrant resource programs into a single program, with vague references to MRC funding being `more contestable'—in other words, more under attack and open to other bidders—and to DIMIA core funding not being used to provide infrastructure support for other Commonwealth or state funded projects run by MRCs. I note that the review itself provided no evidence whatsoever that DIMIA core funding was in any way subsidising those projects that they are supposedly trying to avoid funding in future. They do not establish a problem and they do not make an allegation or accusation but, somehow, part of the reason they are attacking MRCs is to do with avoiding this problem.

We are now told that yet more consultations will be held in April on the ground rules for the new combined funding program. The proposed new case recording system, which seems to be purely driven by DIMIA's statistical and IT requirements, is also under question. The outline of this system seems to have been developed without adequate regard for the wealth of case data that the migrant resource centres need for their own planning and service delivery purposes. It completely excludes client contacts of less than one hour's duration in the statistics that they want and raises privacy concerns for individuals about the requirement that client visa numbers be recorded and notified to DIMIA—in other words, the visa numbers of people who are helped and assisted have to be given to the department, for some unknown reason.

There was a long discussion about this matter at the recent Senate estimates hearing. DIMIA appeared to concede some deficiencies in the proposal they have developed by saying that centres were free to use a second case recording system if they needed more data than the DIMIA system can provide. Just why any centre would want to use two separate systems to record one set of client cases was never explained by these bureaucrats, nor was it indicated who would fund the development and upkeep of this second system.

On the subject of IHSS enhancements, we welcome the modest improvements that DIMIA has made to the IHSS, revealed in Minister Hardgrave's recent answer to my question on notice. These improvements do not, however, address all the funding deficiencies highlighted by the settlement services review or solve the structural problems with the contracts for the programs. I have to say that, when I have been visiting organisations around this country, I have seen the reality of large numbers of volunteers, whether they were based on church or religious groups or had other charitable interests or were from certain ethnic communities, who have given their time and wanted to help their fellow human beings. I have had the evidence from them about the fact that they have walked away from the system. They have found the bureaucracy, red tape and requirements too great to put up with.

I have spoken to organisations that talk about the peaks and troughs of the arrival of humanitarian entrants. They get very little notification of when people will arrive and how many et cetera and they are supposed to service them and cater for them. I have seen the reality of different contracts in some states, where too many contractors handle different parts of the schemes. By the way we are going at the moment, it will reach the stage where one group will be providing chairs and the other will be providing tables. It really is a mess. These structural problems need to be solved before the next IHSS tender round, which is due to commence later this year.

In relation to the citizenship campaign, $6.3 million was revealed by the government communication unit to Senator Faulkner at separate estimates hearings. There is no portfolio budget statement for this campaign. It is an implied admission that, despite all the posturing around the place by the minister, the government's performance in regard to citizenship levels is very disturbing. He can do all he wants—he can get into an aeroplane and have a ceremony giving people certificates there or he can run around sports centres, which is all very noble and all very interesting—but the truth is that the citizenship rates are of concern. As I say, the government seems to be about to do something about that with its $6.3 million, but what it is going to do is unspecified.

My fundamental concerns with waste and extravagance by DIMIA are the $600,000 annual contract with a media monitoring firm and a further annual contract of $140,000 with a separate firm, apparently to distribute departmental and ministerial media releases. That is $740,000 in that area. There is a travel contract with a private sector travel agency for the provision of international and domestic travel, presumably for DIMIA staff, costing $28 million over 2½ years. There are litigation contracts with private law firms totalling $24 million over 4½ years, in addition to three separate contracts worth almost $40 million with the Australian Government Solicitor.

There are fundamental concerns with this portfolio, one of which is the survival of migrant resource centres in this country—organisations established under the aegis of the Fraser government and continued under Labor. They have very grave concerns as to their future. In IHSS things are being contracted out just because of the ideological need to do so: `Contracting out sounds good, so let's just try it. Who cares if there is a mess afterwards? We'll come back in a few years time and try to rectify the structural problems.' Also, there is of course the issue of the overall settlement services review.

As I said, there is also the question of where long-term communities in this country are going to fit. Italians are still the largest group with non-English ancestry in this country. They are a typical example of a long-term community. Throughout this country they have established very fine, respected welfare organisations. Many of these receive DIMIA funding, for very good reason. There is a real question about whether that is going to continue if the government succeeds at the next election. Its commitments to fund these organisations are clearly only for this year, only for this round. One has to ask why the minister and the department are not answering questions and criticism and guaranteeing that they do not intend to attack this program, because their own review clearly signals an intention to attack the funding basis of these larger communities.

It is all right to say that it might not be appropriate, that the Eritreans, the Ethiopians, the Somalis, the Sudanese, the Sierra Leoneans—the more recent arrivals—may have more needs. Yes, they do have greater needs. We see that in the sharing out of time at SBS. We have to have those debates. But one does not take money from these old, established communities without ensuring the kinds of services that are provided will be picked up by another government department. One cannot attack their funding simply because one has to fund other organisations. Just because Eritreans have a need does not mean that this government should attack the Jewish community, the Italians and the Greeks. That is what the government are on about. That is what these policy changes are about. That is what the review is clearly signalling.

para.inline: Sitting suspended from 12.55 p.m. to 4.03 p.m.

talk.start.para: —Today's ACNielsen poll shows opposition leader Mark Latham to be the most popular opposition leader since Bob Hawke. It also shows that if an election were held today Labor would win easily. I believe this is because many Australians want to get on Mark's ladder of opportunity and because they grow increasingly tired of a government and a Prime Minister who have been in office for over eight years now and have nothing new to offer the country. Indeed the Prime Minister gives every indication of wanting to stay in office forever. What must Treasurer Costello be thinking?

speech.para: I believe it is time that the Liberal Party looked seriously at generational change—at getting rid of a tired, stale, old Prime Minister and stale old ministers and seeking to refresh and reinvigorate the Liberal Party with new blood and new challenges. But let us not forget that Treasurer Costello had his opportunity. Way back in 1995 when the then Leader of the Opposition, Alexander Downer, had lost it, the Treasurer could have fought the previous leader, John Howard, for the leadership. He chose not to. Do you know why? Because he looked at the next election and he thought to himself: `I might lose. Better to wait.' In a comparable situation, Mark Latham chose to fight Kim Beazley, the member for Brand, for the leadership because he looked ahead to the next election and he said to himself, `I might win.' That is the difference between Mark Latham and Peter Costello. They say no guts, no glory.

talk.start.para: (Mr Barresi)—The member for Wills will refer to members by their correct titles.

—Sorry, I mean the Leader of the Opposition and the Treasurer. They say: no guts, no glory. I make the prediction now that the Treasurer will never, ever be Prime Minister. This Prime Minister will suck the lemon dry. He will only discard the leadership when the government's time is well and truly up. The Treasurer might get to put in a couple of heartbreaking years in opposition, but if things start to get interesting he will be mown down by the present Minister for Health and Ageing or by Malcolm Turnbull.

speech.para: This government's eight years in office have been a disaster for health care in Australia. In my electorate of Wills and right throughout Australia, bulk-billing has declined every single year since the Howard government won office, and families have had to pay more for essential health care each year. Last week the Howard government approved a 7.5 per cent average premium increase for the private health insurers—that is triple the inflation rate—which will mean another cost impost on millions of Australian families. They will be forced to pay an average $150 a year extra for their health insurance. That is last year's tax cut gone in one fell swoop.

I have to say that I am disgusted at the cosy relationship between this government and the private health insurers. I do not know the detail of what private health insurers do for the Liberal and National parties or for individual coalition MPs and candidates, but it must be a heck of a lot because this government is prepared to give $2.4 billion of taxpayers' money directly to the private health funds rather than spend that money promoting bulk-billing or promoting direct hospital services, where it could do so much. They claim that the taxpayer subsidy keeps premiums down, but have a look at the evidence: premium rises of 6.9 per cent in 2002, 7.5 per cent last year and 7.5 per cent this year—way above the inflation rate.

talk.start.para: —Is the member for Boothby seeking to ask a question?
—Yes.
—Will the member for Wills allow a question?
—Yes.
—How would the member for Wills propose to spend the $2.4 billion that is currently spent on the 30 per cent private health insurance rebate?

—I have no doubt that much of the money has been spent in a wasteful way and that we would be far better off if we were to provide money directly for bulk-billing, directly for services and directly for hospitals. There is no doubt that we can do a great deal better than this government has done.

speech.para: Private health insurers are the one group of people in the health system who do not contribute anything to it—unlike doctors, nurses and hospitals, which provide real services. They do not contribute anything, yet they are the one group of people this government is in love with and will do anything for. When groups of workers ask for pay increases, the Liberal and National parties go spare. Have you heard the hysterical rhetoric from the Victorian Liberals about pay claims in Victoria? In Victoria, the Liberals simply cannot be satisfied. If the Victorian Labor government settles the pay claims, the Liberals say they are giving in to the unions. If they do not settle the pay claims, the Liberals say there is chaos and industrial anarchy and the government should do something about it. The message is that pay rises will lead to inflation and ruin us all—yet, when it comes to the private health insurers, money is no object. They do not care if ordinary families have to pay another $150 per year.

As shadow environment minister, I lament the way this government has been going up and down on one spot over action to tackle climate change. The need for action gets more urgent with every passing year. Back in August 2002, after the government announced that it would not be ratifying the Kyoto protocol on climate change, it announced the climate change forward strategy. It indicated that the strategy would be developed over the course of the next 12 months. We are still waiting for it. The Minister for the Environment and Heritage, the Treasurer and others took to cabinet a proposal they had developed for a greenhouse emissions trading regime. It was a very modest scheme. It talked about introducing emissions trading by 2013. But the Prime Minister simply knocked it on the head. The aluminium industry and the power industry had got to him. Those who had been working on the climate change forward strategy fell off their chairs. The government has not announced the climate change forward strategy, because it has nothing to announce. There is no climate change forward strategy. We are going up and down on the one spot, and all the while the effects of climate change get more serious.

Then there was the long-awaited national energy policy. I am told that the Energy Task Force is just confusing matters further. At the last budget the Treasurer said more than he was supposed to say about the government's intentions in taxing LPG. This threw the LPG industry into a tail spin and caused six months of utter confusion on excise arrangements. The government finally issued a statement on this late last year, but it does not know where to take energy policy from here. The fact is that taxing LPG will increase greenhouse gas emissions, and those working on the energy policy have no bright ideas as to how to offset this. So business, consumers, motorists and environmental groups are all in the dark. There is no national energy policy and no climate change forward strategy. It is a government which is clueless when it comes to greenhouse and energy policy.

This brings me to an article in the Canberra Times back in January by Simon Grose. This article contains many errors. It is a bit hard to know where to start, but I want to deal with one paragraph in particular. It says:

quote.para: Despite what Thomson may say in Opposition, there is little he would do differently on greenhouse emissions if he were in the minister's seat, and he would have inherited a country in a pretty strong position.

speech.para: Firstly, Australia is not in a pretty strong position. Projections of emissions to 2020, prepared by the Australian Greenhouse Office, show that greenhouse gases produced by the generation of energy will have shot up to 160 per cent on their 1990 levels. To the extent that we are on track to meet our Kyoto target—and in fact we are presently tracking for 110 per cent of 1990 emission levels, when our Kyoto target is 108 per cent—this is due to the impact of one-off changes to land-clearing arrangements. This cannot be done more than once.

The statement that there is little I would do differently as minister about greenhouse gas emissions is arrant nonsense. Had Mr Grose bothered to contact me before writing his article, I could have spared him the embarrassment of making a mistake by pointing out several things. Firstly, I would ratify the Kyoto protocol and have Australia play a constructive role in international negotiations, rather than try to scuttle and undermine them. Secondly, Labor would develop a system of emissions trading. The Kyoto protocol may not be happening in the absence of ratification from the US or Russia but the European Union is developing an emissions trading regime, which will come into effect from 1 January next year. We would develop a regime which would be recognised by and compatible with that, because to do otherwise would see Australian businesses frozen out of a huge market. Thirdly, Labor would increase the mandatory renewable energy target by an additional five per cent by 2010. In contrast to this government's do-nothing approach to renewable energy, to clean energy, we would promote it. Fourthly, we would introduce a greenhouse trigger into the Environment Protection and Biodiversity Conservation Act. So there is a great deal that I can and would do about greenhouse gas emissions.

And we do need to act. Climate change is hitting Australia already and will hit us harder in the future. I saw the tree decline in the midlands of Tasmania, where that area is drying out and trees are dying of thirst. Similarly, in south-west Western Australia there have been many years of reduced rainfall and we have seen a drier climate for that part of Australia. We face the prospect of losing our snowfields in Victoria, of coral bleaching in the Barrier Reef, of species diversity in the wet tropics declining by anything up to 50 per cent, of dengue fever spreading further southwards and even of malaria. We face the prospect of extreme weather events—droughts, floods and bushfires becoming more frequent and more severe.

All of this means that I was astonished to hear recently of the National Farmers Federation telling a Senate committee that they do not support ratification of the Kyoto protocol. This idea is absolutely in the teeth of the best interests of Australia's farmers. Farmers have much to lose from extreme weather events. The recent drought, for example, was the most severe in history. That was not only because the country was very dry but because our temperatures were of the order of two degrees Celsius higher than they had been during previous droughts. That led to more evaporation, less moisture availability and a more serious drought. So the position that the Farmers Federation are taking is astonishing.

Kyoto is about getting other countries to do the right thing. It is about addressing those 98 per cent of emissions that come from the rest of the world. How on earth can it make sense for a farmers organisation to say that while Australia is going to meet its Kyoto target—and that is what the government says—we are not interested in international action to make other countries meet their targets? It is like turkeys asking for an early Christmas. Beyond Kyoto, Australia's role as a spoiler in international environmental forums has become notorious. Indeed, at a recent conference on biological diversity in Malaysia, the environmental organisation Greenpeace thought Australia's performance so bad that we, together with Malaysia, were the joint winners of the 2004 `Champion Assassin of Life on Earth' award. Good grief!

We received that award for our insistence on introducing trade issues into the Convention on Biological Diversity, undermining the precautionary principle of the convention and questioning agreed targets. At one stage, the Australian delegation, presumably acting on the authority of the Minister for the Environment and Heritage, decided that if it did not get its way on the definition of the precautionary principle it would try to bring the conference to a dead end by random objections, objecting to already agreed texts and abusing the conference's rule of procedure, which requires all decisions to be taken by consensus. Australia proposed to delete a sentence as innocuous as, `Respect for land tenure, prior informed consent and Indigenous territorial rights were critical in this regard.' Australia argued against recognising a range of governance systems, including traditional knowledge and practices of Indigenous peoples. Australia argued against a proposal to have a thorough framework for assessing protected area system gaps. Australia pushed to have two of the targets previously agreed to in Montreal in November reconsidered. That was the kind of action which earned us such an unfortunate award.

Just today we have seen the government again show its hostility to environment protection by announcing that its land-clearing promise has been broken. Minister Truss in question time announced, in an embarrassing reversal for the environment minister, that the government does not intend to honour its promise to pay $75 million to Queensland farmers in compensation for a ban on land clearing of remnant vegetation in that state. I will just take the House through some of the history of this. On 16 May last year, the Queensland government introduced a moratorium on broadscale land clearing in Queensland. The federal Minister for the Environment and Heritage, David Kemp, said that the Howard government had acted to stop land clearing in Queensland. He said:

quote.para: We've worked with Queensland closely and today I'm delighted to announce that a moratorium has now been imposed on new applications and permits on land clearing in Queensland.

speech.para: He boasted:

quote.para: This was a result of the fact that the Howard Government has been working in close partnership with the Queensland Government to ensure that we can bring into place a proper framework to govern vegetation clearing in Queensland and to protect native remnant vegetation.

speech.para: A week later, on 22 May, he followed this up by announcing a joint Commonwealth and Queensland assistance package of up to $150 million, with $75 million to come from each level of government. During the remainder of 2003, the Commonwealth government failed to follow through on this commitment, and at the end of last year, after numerous unanswered letters, the Beattie government decided that the Howard government was not serious at all about a halt to land clearing. On 18 January this year, Premier Beattie announced that he would increase Queensland's contribution from $75 million to the full $150 million. Notwithstanding that, in a subsequent press release dated 30 January, the environment minister still claimed that the Howard government `has committed $75 million to achieve an end to broadscale land clearing in Queensland'. Today we find the Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry telling the parliament that the Howard government is no longer committed to paying the $75 million.

Action is urgently needed on land clearing. Land clearing has three strikes on it: it is the principal cause of salinity; it is the principal threat to endangered species of birds, plants and animals; and it is a major contributor to greenhouse gas emissions. Land clearing in Queensland kills around 100 million native mammals, birds and reptiles every year. Both Queensland land-holders, the farmers themselves, and those people who are concerned to protect the environment will be disgusted at the federal government's withdrawal of financial support for needed action there.

The other area I want to return to as a conspicuous example of government environmental failure is its handling of the defence land at Point Nepean. First, it said it was going to sell part of Point Nepean. The member for Flinders thought that was all right. He said, `I accept full responsibility for fighting for such an outcome.' He told the Mail newspaper that on 30 July. Later on the government decided that it was not going to sell it; it was going to lease the land to a group involving Queensland developer FKP. The member for Flinders thought that was all right too. He told Barry Cassidy on 3LO radio, `This is a fantastic outcome.' Later on he decided that he had been a saviour of Point Nepean. In fact, he is one of the executioners of Point Nepean, pretending to be its saviour. The result at Point Nepean has been achieved over the strenuous objections of the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Defence, the member for Flinders and, indeed, some personnel in Environment Victoria who sold this issue out a long time ago and who left it to the likes of Kate Bailleau, Chris Smythe and others to fight on and establish a community campaign of such strength that the federal government could simply not ignore it.

The government has said it is going to establish a trust when what it should really do is hand the land over to the Victorian government to be declared a national park. Why should the community have to wait five years before Point Nepean is handed over to the Victorian government? We also ask: will the trust be independent when its chairperson was the spokesman for the consortium that was looking to commercially develop the site—

para.inline: A division having been called in the House of Representatives—

talk.start.para: —In conclusion, I call on the federal government to hand Point Nepean over to the Victorian government so that it can be declared and managed as a national park, not in five years time but right now. I further call on the federal government to lift the veil of secrecy surrounding its Point Nepean decisions so that the community and particularly the residents of the Mornington Peninsula can have a greater involvement, a proper involvement, in its future.

—There are a number of matters that I want to raise today in the context of debate on the appropriation bills that are worrying people in my electorate. I have been told by constituents many times about the frustration of not being able to get dental treatment. People who cannot afford a private dentist are missing out on critical dental treatment. The elderly and the disabled are often vulnerable to deteriorating dental health, for a number of reasons. Many medicines, for instance, cause dry mouth syndrome, which can lead to gum disease. Loss of teeth, badly fitting dentures and/or painful gums impact on the diet and the overall health of the elderly, reducing many of them to unsatisfactory and unsatisfying mushy food. Physically or mentally disabled people are often unable to care properly for their teeth and therefore they too suffer from dental health problems.

speech.para: All this suffering has come about, at least in part, because the Howard government abolished the Commonwealth Dental Health Scheme in 1996. At the time the scheme was abolished there were about 380,000 Australians on the waiting list, which was about six months long. By May 2000 the waiting list had grown to 500,000 people, and these people were facing a wait of between eight months and five years. No figures are available for the period since, as the collection of national figures has been stopped—and I wonder why. Despite increasing expenditure by state governments on dental services for low-income people, there is now a big unmet demand for public dental services. A recent national survey found that one-third of Australians in the $30,000 to $50,000 household income bracket had not been to the dentist for over two years, because they could not afford to go.

For this reason, I am very pleased that the ALP have decided to make dental health one of our priorities when in government. Federal Labor, with the state governments, will establish the Australian dental care scheme. This will be separate from Medicare, which was never intended to cover dental services. $300 million will be provided in the forward estimates for provision of dental care for health care card holders and their dependants. Of this, $120 million per year will be allocated for Australian dental care and $13 million will be used for dental assessments of older Australians entering residential aged care. Every person entering a residential facility will receive an oral health assessment and a written action plan from a qualified dental professional spelling out the appropriate measures for oral health. The Australian dental care agreement between the Australian government and the state governments will ensure that all low-income Australians, no matter where they live, will have access to affordable dental care.

I would like to spend a couple of minutes debunking a few myths about dental services. The first myth is that the Commonwealth Dental Health Scheme was only ever a temporary one—a one-off program—so it was okay for the government to stop the scheme. The fact is that in 1996 funding, increasing from a base of $100 million per year, was built into the forward estimates up to 1999-2000. This means that the Commonwealth Dental Health Scheme was planned as an ongoing program. The second myth is that the states should have redirected hospital funding to public dental programs. The truth is that the states are actually forbidden by the Commonwealth health care agreements to spend Commonwealth hospital money on dental services. The states face heavy financial penalties if they do move this money to dental programs. The third myth is that the states have sole responsibility for dental care. The Constitution itself is the source for debunking this myth. The Constitution gives the Commonwealth responsibility for making laws for the provision of hospital benefits, medical and dental services. Labor used this power when it established the Commonwealth Dental Health Scheme, and Howard canned the scheme by removing its funding.

I would like to turn to the subject of aged care. I hear over and over again—and I see for myself—the crisis in our aged care sector. The crisis comes from three sources: one is the underfunding and, if you like, the overadministration of aged care; the second is the lack of places; and the third is the crisis in staffing. The underfunding and overadministration of aged care is a common tale across Australia. People from aged care facilities in my area tell me about the inadequate funding of various levels of patients and the need for funds for capital improvements. There is a growing number of facilities not meeting accreditation requirements, closing down or being put into receivership because of financial problems.

I am told that people going into residential care now are sicker and frailer than people were when entering an aged care facility a decade ago. This has implications for staffing and for the finances of the facility. I cannot forget the nurse who approached me some time ago and told me about the utter frustration and despondency she and her colleagues feel because they cannot give the residents the care they need. Staffing cutbacks because of a lack of funding mean that staff do not have the time to stop and spend a few minutes talking to a resident or calming a resident in tears, and feeding residents becomes a rushed job. The fact is that these professional people are forced to give care which is rushed and less than perfect. It is both undignified and totally unsatisfactory from the point of view of both the resident and the staff member. Nurses in aged care facilities are paid less than their colleagues in the acute care sector. This only adds to their frustration and to the growing difficulties aged care facilities have in recruiting staff.

If there is any doubt about this situation, one can look at the number of homes being sold off simply because the present owners cannot afford to continue owning them. The Salvation Army has recently put 15 of its 19 aged care facilities around the country—including some in Victoria—on the market. The Salvation Army has said that the matter of ongoing financial viability, the need to find capital in excess of $100 million to upgrade facilities and significant consolidated losses in the last three years are some of the reasons for its decision to sell its facilities.

Administrators in aged care facilities also frequently raise the problem of the increasing paperwork required for the accreditation system. They tell me about spending most of the day behind the desk writing reports instead of being out there with their residents and providing the care the residents deserve and need. This excessive time spent on paperwork is made even more wasteful when there is no clear evidence that this system actually leads to improved care. The Australian National Audit Office audited the accreditation agency last year. In its report, the National Audit Office noted that there is no way of knowing whether or not the accreditation system actually improves the quality of care for the residents. This is because the government has not undertaken an evaluation program to determine this vital information. The accreditation system is costly to the taxpayer—about $11.5 million a year. The service providers themselves are also asked to pay a fee for their accreditation review—a review that is time consuming and of no proven value.

Another issue in aged care that needs attention is the growing demand and need for aged care that is culturally appropriate. This is needed for our Indigenous people and the frail aged people who were not born here. I watched my Dutch born, well-educated, highly intelligent mother-in-law, who had an excellent command of the English language, grow old and frail before she died. She changed from a woman who used English as her preferred language for years to one who forgot her English and returned to her native Dutch language. Towards the end, she was unable to make herself understood to the staff looking after her and barely able to communicate with her own sons—one can imagine the frustration of that for all concerned.

We need aged care facilities which not only have staff who speak the language of the residents but which provide meals in surroundings suitable and comforting to the residents. An excellent example of this is the Dutch aged care facility in Carrum Downs in my electorate. We need all sorts of different languages and cultures in aged care, including many Asian languages. A Vietnamese constituent of mine told me about his friend with an elderly mother. The friend was unable to find a culturally appropriate nursing home for his Vietnamese-speaking mother anywhere in the south-east region of Melbourne. There are no facilities specifically for Indochinese people in the south-east. The city of Greater Dandenong has the largest number of Indochinese elderly people in Melbourne, yet there are no culturally appropriate low- or high-care facilities for these people.

I want now to talk about education. Late last year I received a petition from 458 people, mostly students, condemning the Howard government's higher education legislation. The petitioners were alarmed at the prospect of having to pay $150,000 for a university degree. They saw the changes as the end of tertiary education for many students from middle- and lower-income families. I have heard the argument that education, particularly university education, is not of interest to many people, particularly those on low incomes. This is not my experience, and it is not the opinion of the 458 petitioners. I have met many parents who themselves have not had the benefit of completing secondary school and certainly have not seen the inside of a university yet go to extraordinary lengths to ensure their children get a good education. These parents understand that education is the key to their child's material success and fulfilment as a person.

It is getting harder and harder to get into a university or even a TAFE course. There are now 20,000 fewer fully funded university places than there were in 1996. This means that this year about 20,000 people who have the qualifications for entry into a university course have missed out. About 15,000 people have missed out on a TAFE place. The government's response to this is to introduce increased HECS fee places and full fee-paying places for universities and to ignore the TAFE system completely. By increasing university fees, the government will continue to deny a university education to many young people. Andrew McCallum, the President of ACOSS, says that the participation in tertiary education of students from low-income families is already 50 per cent below that of medium- to high-income families. This government shows no care or concern for this fact. By increasing HECS and encouraging full fee undergraduate courses, the government is callously denying many young, capable people access to higher education.

Recent comments from the Prime Minister about valueless government schools is further evidence of the arrogant attitude this government has towards access to education. This government is actually encouraging division in our society between the well off and those not so well off. It is making sure that those with deep pockets get a good education while those without deep pockets, despite any talent or potential they might have, are in essence being thrown away. This is a waste of our resources from a community and economic point of view and is devastating to the young people involved.

The Labor Party's response is set out in the Aim Higher document. It states that the ALP in government will create 20,000 new full-time and part-time undergraduate places every year by 2008, create 20,000 new full- and part-time TAFE places every year by 2008, abolish full fees for Australian undergraduates, not increase HECS fees and increase the HECS repayment threshold to $35,000 from July 2004.

We keep on hearing about the Australian economy and how well it is doing. The problem is that this prosperity is not being shared by all or even most Australians. Over 100,000 Australians are homeless, and 2.4 million live below the poverty line. Poor Australians are struggling even if they have a job. One million households have some work, but not enough to give them a decent income. The divide between the well off and those struggling is getting wider. The top five per cent of income earners earn the same in total as the bottom 45 per cent. The incomes of the top 20 per cent have grown seven times faster than the incomes of the bottom 20 per cent and 50 times faster than the incomes of middle-income earners over the last four years.

We have an alarming number of people either unemployed or underemployed. Those with jobs are more likely than ever before to be employed on a casual basis. A person in a casual job gets trapped. They have no access to sick leave or holiday pay. Even those who have been with the same employer, working regular hours, for a very long time are denied these entitlements. As at June last year, the number of men in permanent, full-time jobs had grown by 3.5 per cent since 1996. For women, this figure was 7.5 per cent. In the same period, the number of men in casual jobs had increased by 21 per cent and the number of women by 14 per cent.

Quite apart from losing out on entitlements, a person on a casual wage lives a more insecure life. Often families relying on casual work cannot rely on there being enough income to cover the household bills or to pay for a school excursion for the kids. A person on a casual wage often cannot borrow money to buy a house or even a household item. They cannot borrow from reputable lenders anyway. The person stuck in casual employment often gets stuck in the poverty trap. Despite our economic growth, there are more long-term unemployed people now than when this government came into power in 1996. Despite the increase in the long-term unemployed, this government has halved its spending on labour market programs. The government accuses people of adopting welfare dependency, yet it cuts programs to assist people back into the work force.

Add to this the problem of those who are aged over 45 years and trying to get back into work, and a very dismal picture is painted of the Job Network system and also of this government's lack of commitment to getting people back into work. Almost one in three people over 45 who are unemployed say that they are unemployed because of the attitudes of employers—employers who consider that those over 45 are too old. This figure grows to 59 per cent of those over 55 years of age. We must get better at employing older workers. We have to change the culture that says that these people are too old to be useful and we have to stop the discrimination that exists against mature age workers. I hear too many stories of people who are basically tossed into the too-hard basket by Job Network agencies. People who have lifetime experience are invaluable in the work force. They have the technical skills required and they certainly have a different perspective on things than their younger colleagues. A sensible workplace will have a mix of men and women, young and old. We must work to establish a culture where older workers are valued.

This picture of older workers having trouble getting work is set against the background of the Treasurer recently urging us to work beyond normal retirement age—in fact, to work until we drop. Those who have worked hard all their lives and have reached a reasonable retirement age look forward to being able to retire. Usually people look forward to spending their retirement in good health and doing the things they have saved for all their lives. Maybe they look forward to taking a holiday—some people like to exchange bricks and mortar for a caravan. Most people look forward to a mix of spending time with family, including grandchildren, enjoying sport and social activities, doing some volunteer work and maybe undertaking some study. People heading for retirement do not want to be told now that all their plans should be tossed away and they should just stay at work.

Another issue that has been well rehearsed here is the issue of Medicare. Let me be very clear about this: people in Isaacs do not want Medicare to be destroyed. People want the option of being able to attend a doctor who will bulk-bill them. People are worried about not being able to afford to go and see the doctor. I was talking to a constituent recently who was very upset because she now has to ration her visits to her GP. This woman has cancer and should be seeing her doctor regularly. What sort of a society are we living in where a sick person has to ration her visits to her doctor?

The lack of bulk-billing is just one symptom of a health service in crisis. There is also a shortage of doctors in the outer urban areas. The combination of these two things means that people are turning in growing numbers to the public hospital system for attention when they should really be seeing their local GP—if only they could find one and if only they could find one that bulk-bills. Dandenong Hospital has reported that 38 per cent of all the presentations at its accident and emergency department are primary care type presentations—in other words, people who should be seeing their local GP. It is interesting that at the nearby Frankston Hospital there is a much lower percentage of primary care type presentations, and that is because Frankston Hospital has a bulk-billing GP clinic attached to it. I think the message is very clear.

In finishing, let me summarise my points. There is a need for affordable dental care for those on low incomes, and that need is becoming desperate. We need more aged care beds, and we need them to be properly funded. We need aged care facilities that are culturally appropriate for non-English-speaking people. We need to have higher education available to those who have the academic ability, regardless of how deep their pockets are. We need secure ongoing employment, to replace the de facto permanent jobs offered on a casual basis only. We need to change our attitudes to employing older people. We need to respect those who have reached retirement age and now want to enjoy their retirement and we should not force them to work until they drop. Finally, we must ensure that Medicare is saved.

talk.start.para: —It is with great pleasure that I join this debate this afternoon on the Appropriation Bill (No. 3) 2003-2004, Appropriation Bill (No. 4) 2003-2004 and the Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Bill (No. 2) 2003-2004. It is a very useful debate, because it provides the opportunity to talk about issues of importance to people in my electorate. These bills clearly illustrate what the government's approach to running this country is—and what it has been about since coming to office in 1996.

speech.para: The time has come when the Australian people clearly understand that this Howard government has in its arrogance forgotten to whom it is accountable. The government has failed to finance the basic services that Australians expect their government to provide. The Howard government has failed to provide adequate basic services like health and education. This is not a government for all Australians. The Howard government has created a situation where some communities are looked after lavishly while other communities are neglected. It has created an environment where some Australians are living in poverty and struggling to put food on their tables. In Australia today some families have to decide whether they will go to the doctor and buy medicine or buy food. They simply cannot afford to do both.

Nowhere is this failure of the present government more clear than in regional Australia, in electorates like mine, Capricornia in Central Queensland. This is not the Australian society that I or those of us on this side of the House wish to see, but it seems that this is the Howard government's vision which is being imposed on the Australian people. In the short time I have to address these bills today, I want to focus my remarks on some of the government's failures that are adversely affecting the people of Capricornia in Central Queensland. I also want to make the point that, with this Howard government, the pain for regional Australia is not over yet. The government has more to come, and I wish to take this opportunity to flag a couple of the new policies we all know the current government has in store for people in electorates like mine in regional Australia.

Many communities across Central Queensland are only just starting to learn to live with the closure of one or more of their local bank branches. Labor believes that banking is an essential service and there should be equality of access and costs for all Australians for such an important service. However, the recent report by the Joint Committee on Corporations and Financial Services on regional banking services and the foreign ATM fee structure has sent another shudder through rural and regional Australia.

Currently, banks charge their customers a foreign ATM fee when they use an ATM owned by another institution. This fee is the same whether you live in Sydney or Rockhampton, Longreach or Mount Morgan. However, under pressure from the banks, government members of parliament are proposing to allow banks to charge rural and regional customers higher fees to use an ATM. Some experts are suggesting that the cost of using a foreign ATM in rural Australia could rise to between $5 and $10 per transaction. Foreign ATM fees have already risen by 262 per cent since the government came to office. Clearly this government is not interested in the welfare of people living in regional Australia and it is becoming more and more obvious that this government does not understand the needs of people in rural and regional Australia.

Anyone travelling through rural Australia will see that small business is at the heart of all of these small towns. Nowhere will you see a Bunnings or a K-Mart but in every town you will find local families committed to their small business and their local community. It is these small businesses which the government has penalised $15 million for not complying with their BAS obligations in the past 12 months, while Australia's big businesses were only fined a total of $9,000.

Under the Howard government a third of small businesses spend one to two days on each of their BASs with a further 20 per cent of small businesses reporting that they spend more than two days on their BASs. Figures released by the Australian Taxation Office show that small businesses in regional and rural Australia are having trouble complying with their BAS obligations, with many finding the system too complicated to handle. Instead of helping these small rural businesses, the government rips another $15 million in penalties from that already overtaxed section of our economy. Only Labor has a simpler BAS option for small business operators, which will free up those people to run their businesses and spend more time with their families and their communities instead of filling out a mountain of paperwork for this government.

While talking about small business, one also has to look at employment in this country. Again we find that the Howard government has failed the most vulnerable in our society—I am speaking about our young people. Alarming new figures reveal that one in six teenagers in Central Queensland are unemployed. Figures based on recently released Australian Bureau of Statistics data show that, for the 12 months ending October 2003, youth unemployment was 18.9 per cent. This means that young people in places like Rockhampton and Yeppoon are being left behind by the Howard government. Instead of getting our young people into jobs or training, the Howard government is letting them fall through the cracks. These shocking results come at a time when the Job Network is failing to assist many young people to get into jobs.

Figures released by the Department of Employment and Workplace Relations show that the Job Network intensive assistance program placed only 19.9 per cent of young Australians in full-time jobs in the year ending March 2003. The department's figures also found that, on completion of the intensive assistance program, an alarming 57 per cent of young unemployed Australians either remained unemployed, were in further assistance or, tragically, were so discouraged from their experiences they left the labour market altogether. Young Australian adults and their families deserve opportunities that give them a strong start in life. Our young people should not be condemned to starting their adult lives on the unemployment queue.

We have heard from many members about the experiences of constituents in trying to access dental care under the current system. The member for Isaacs ran through that issue in quite some detail. I would like to add to the debate the experiences of people in my electorate. There are many examples I could give of individuals who have been badly affected by this government's failure in dental care, but I would like to bring to the attention of the House the plight of just one person as an example of the problems faced by so many. A constituent of mine from Yeppoon has been waiting over a year for her treatment. Two of her molars are causing extreme pain and are starting to crumble in places. Over a year ago she visited the public health system and explained her situation. It was not until she had suffered three weeks of excessive pain that she underwent an interim filling, which was really just a quick fix to stop the toothache so that she could join the waiting list to have her teeth properly filled and repaired.

She has been waiting over one year now and the temporary filling fell out seven months ago. She still experiences extreme tooth pain, which is now also affecting her jaw. She has been advised by the staff at the public hospital that the dental surgeon comes once a month for one day and that she is No. 90 on the list. She cannot be promised when she may receive her treatment. She has been told that she will just have to wait until her name eventually moves up the list. It is a simple piece of mathematics to work out that, if one surgeon comes once a month and sees on average five patients, this woman would have to wait another 18 months to have her two fillings attended to. This poor woman has tried over and over to explain to the nurses that her tooth problems are affecting her whole jaw area and she is being kept poor by having to buy pain-killers on a daily basis.

This Howard government owes this woman an explanation. More than that, this government should act immediately to ensure that this woman and the many like her around Australia receive treatment quickly. It should be understood that the crisis in public dental care was exacerbated by the heartless decision made by the Howard government in its first budget back in 1997 to scrap Labor's Commonwealth Dental Health Program. It was a decision that profoundly affected the poorest people in our community. The decision to axe that program cannot even be defended on financial grounds for, as we now know, investing in public dental services now will save money in the longer term. There is increasing evidence that poor oral health is associated with many illnesses including diabetes, cancer, cardiovascular disease and preterm or low birth weight babies. Yet this government has washed its hands of this national crisis. It does not even acknowledge that this crisis exists.

The then Minister for Health and Ageing said on television some 12 months ago that the Commonwealth and states have various responsibilities and public dental health services are the responsibility of the states and `we don't deliver direct dental health programs'. It is not good enough for this government to try to pass the buck to the states by saying it is a state and not a Commonwealth responsibility, when Labor's effective program showed that we could attend to people's basic dental needs, cut down on waiting lists and have as part of our program preventative dental treatment.

In the case of my own state government, I think we need to congratulate the Beattie government on the way in which it has tried to fill the void left by this heartless and mean Howard government. Queensland Health currently has the largest public dental service in Australia, providing free services to school students and eligible adults and their dependants state wide. This is now a fully funded state program following the cessation of the Commonwealth Dental Health Program in December 1996. The demand for public dental care is increasing in Queensland as the population increases and more people are eligible to access the service. Queensland, with the other states and the Australian Dental Association, has lobbied the Commonwealth government to once again fund the Commonwealth Dental Health Program. The Beattie government has advocated for the restoration of this important national program as well as participating in the development of a national oral health plan to gain oral health its deserved national priority status.

Queensland was and remains the only state to recurrently fund a supplement to replace the Commonwealth Dental Health Program. The evidence of the need to introduce a Commonwealth funded dental program is compelling. Again, only Labor has listened to the people and only Labor will respond with a $300 million Australian dental care policy and program. This commitment by Labor is in stark contrast to the Howard government's failure in the area of dental care. It is in this general area of ensuring access to basic care and of assisting families, particularly those under financial pressure, where this Howard government needs to be condemned. Australian families feel that this government has failed them and the facts support the sentiments of these hardworking Australian families.
