It is clear that we are in the grip of a national crisis as far as the provision of public dental health services is concerned. It is a crisis that this government will not acknowledge and will not take any action to remedy. It is a crisis because, as the Australian Council of Social Services has pointed out, there are 500,000 people across Australia currently on waiting lists for public dental treatment. It is a crisis because at least half a million of our fellow citizens cannot afford to pay for private treatment and are forgotten and left languishing on waiting lists in all states and territories. Hardest hit are low-income families and pensioners, including many people in rural and regional areas such as in my electorate of Capricornia. It is a crisis because people are waiting years to get basic treatment, such as having a tooth filled, and are often waiting between five and seven years for dentures. Again, it is the people living in rural and regional centres who are worst affected by this crisis. The staff in my electorate offices have a continuously open file on constituents in Capricornia whom this government has failed in that most critical area of dental care.

The examples that I have given this afternoon point to a government whose priorities are all wrong and a government that is out of touch with the needs of people in my electorate. This government is the highest taxing government in Australia's history, yet it cannot rein in its waste and mismanagement of public resources and refuses to take proper responsibility for the provision of basic services. There is a high price to pay for this government's careless attitude towards taxpayers' money, and it is the every day working families in my electorate who are paying that price. They are paying through higher fees for services that used to be regarded as the fundamental role of our national government—things like health and education. Those working families and those even worse off on pensions and benefits are paying for this government's neglect and mismanagement through the lack of access to vital services in my electorate. These include nursing home beds, bulk-billed GP visits, TAFE and university places and child care and outside school hours care. Right now the people in my electorate are paying the price for this government's neglect, and I believe that when the election is called later this year it is the Howard government that will pay the price—and quite rightly too.

talk.start.para: —In rising to speak on the Appropriation Bill (No. 3) 2003-2004 and the related bills, I want today to talk about sexual and domestic violence against women. These are particularly relevant crimes all of the time because of the vast number of victims of these crimes but, in a week in which we have been reading about the fallout of the allegations made against the Bulldogs Football Club members alleged to have assaulted a woman in Coffs Harbour, perhaps it is even more top-of-mind than it would normally be.

speech.para: Everyone would know that a number of members of the Bulldogs team have been accused by a 20-year-old woman in Coffs Harbour of sexually assaulting her. Of course, an allegation of such a crime is disturbing. The idea of the crime itself is disturbing. If it has occurred, it is a terrible thing for that woman, a shock for the whole community and a shock for many people who have read about it in the newspapers. An additional thing that I found incredibly disturbing is the language that is being used in the reports whereby you have players speaking about group sex using slang terms for it in a way that indicates that it is very often the topic of conversation. They have come up with a whole language for describing what happens in these situations. I think that that in itself is incredibly disturbing. That it is a matter for such common discussion that a language has developed around it with its own particular terminology is disturbing. Furthermore, it is disturbing that part of the discussion has occurred on rugby league web sites on which fans and others have been writing in a way that, in an absolutely classic fashion, blames the victim of this crime.

This speaks to us of a glaring problem in Australian culture. We know from research that has been done that up to 30 per cent of young men think it is okay to force a girl to have sex with them. We have a problem in this country with sexual assault, and the figures bear that out. In 2002 there were 17,850 victims of sexual assault who reported that they were victims of sexual assault. We know that this is the most underreported crime there is. There are varying estimates of the level of underreporting, but most experts would agree that there are probably 250 to 300 sexual assaults every day in New South Wales.

Sexual assault is a particularly violent and personal crime that leaves the victim in a highly traumatised state. Victims of this crime are often the most vulnerable people in our community—sometimes children, very young women, very old women, women with disabilities or mental health issues, or Aboriginal women. The thing that is particularly shocking about it as a crime is that in the vast majority of cases the women know their attackers. They are usually work colleagues, friends, family members or next-door neighbours, even partners.

The very illustrative point about the Bulldogs situation is that all of the things that the women are saying in the newspapers can be extrapolated to victims of sexual assault more generally. The things that are being said about these women are what women fear will be said about them if they report. They are things like: `She was asking for it', `It was the way she was dressed', `She was talking', `She was flirting'. It is extremely worthwhile to be having this debate now about how inappropriate, wrong and criminal these acts are. I am also shocked by the fact that the officials of the game are getting up and saying, `If they have broken our code of conduct we will deal very strictly with them.' If they have behaved in this way they have not broken a code of conduct: they have broken the law. I do not think we have heard a single one of football's supposed leaders out there saying, `If this has happened, these people have broken the law and they should go to jail.'

It reminds me of a couple of other recent cases. There is one case where the sentencing is happening at the moment. There are five young men involved and two girls. Four of the men were brothers, and it is alleged to have taken place in their home. The young men are saying that they did not realise that it was culturally inappropriate behaviour to gang rape two girls. We are so missing the point if we start talking about whether it is culturally appropriate behaviour or not. This is a criminal act. It is not just a criminal act in Australia; I imagine it is a criminal act in every single country in the world to force someone to have sex with you.

We have a problem with young men's attitudes to young women—and it is not just young men and young women; we have a problem with men's attitudes to women in that so many men seem to be able to convince themselves that somehow they are not culpable if they are involved in this behaviour and that somehow there is an excuse. Sometimes their families give them an excuse—we have seen court cases where the perpetrators' families have called the victims and their families names and accused the victims' families of somehow being complicit in what has happened to them.

What can be done? It is no good just saying that we have a terrible problem with attitudes in this country. We do, absolutely, and we need to police these crimes. We need to make sure that people who commit them are jailed and that the court system does not continue to make the life of the victim a living hell when it is protecting the lives of the perpetrators. We need to have good policing and good judicial structures, but we really need to be changing attitudes from a very early age. This is why I raised the point that 30 per cent of young boys in one survey said it is okay to force a girl to have sex. The only thing we can do is start teaching people from a very early age that violence is never okay and that relationships between human beings have to be based on respect and consent.

That was the purpose of the `No respect, no relationship' campaign that was being developed for this government. I was really very pleased when I saw a few years ago now that this government had made a commitment on this. I think it was at the time of the last re-election of this government. The Prime Minister said that domestic violence was going to be at the top of the list of priorities and dedicated $25 million, then a few years later another $25 million, to domestic violence and, at the same time, $16½ million for this campaign on changing attitudes towards sexual assault. I thought that was terrific. I do not often think that the Prime Minister is doing great things, but this was something that I was really very pleased to see. I think it is an incredibly important thing to do. That is why I was so very disappointed to hear about the decision to pull this advertising campaign.

This advertising campaign is not designed, as the Prime Minister has implied in his answers in parliament, to be a first port of call for information for someone who has been sexually assaulted. The campaign's communications strategy and the advertising agency brief, each approved by the Ministerial Committee on Government Communications, specified that the agency—Grey Worldwide—direct the target market to a specially created web site. That is what the Bulletin says about it. It was an advertising campaign that was aimed at raising awareness and providing a point for further information for people to look at. The fact that it does not behave like a piece of information that is designed for people as a first port of call in a crisis is exactly the brief that the advertising agency was given. For the Prime Minister to imply—though he has never said it as directly as this—that the reason the ads were pulled was that they did not provide that crisis information is disingenuous given the government's own brief on the issue. I had a little play with these ads myself and, if that was the barrier to running the campaign, you could add an extra line at the bottom of the print ad that says, `If you have been sexually assaulted, call the police or your nearest rape crisis centre.' You could very easily run a national ad with one additional sentence. You would not have to change the layout of the ad at all. If you wanted to do state based ads, you could go one extra step and insert a phone number. I am not an advertising genius, but it took me about 15 seconds to work out how you could address the Prime Minister's main stated problem with these ads.

The advertising campaign is not going to go ahead. We have been told that the group that pulled the ad, the Ministerial Committee on Government Communications—which interestingly had no women on it until Sussan Ley was apparently recently appointed—decided that it was not in line with the government's message on this issue. The Prime Minister said on 17 February, `My broad understanding is that there was an intervention because the campaign did not conform to the decisions of the government.' On 19 February he said, `Suggestions that the campaign has been cancelled and will not go ahead are completely wrong.'

If the only thing that is wrong with it is that, as he originally said, it is not appropriate to tell someone who has just been sexually assaulted to look at a web site, I agree with that and I have told you the solution to that. If the problem is that it does not agree with the government's program or message in this area, I really want to know what the program or message is. This advertising campaign basically says that relationships have to be based on mutual respect and that, if you want further information, here is where you go. There are specific messages in each of the advertisements. One young girl who has been assaulted says, `I reported him. It was so hard to do but such a relief.' The message is that she did the right thing. Another young woman says, `I said no, but he wouldn't stop. I didn't know what to do.' The message is that that was sexual assault. A young man says, `Well, she was flirting with a couple of mates, and I gave her a slap. She deserved it.' The message is that, no, she did not deserve it. Another young man says, `A mate said the way I treated my girlfriend was embarrassing. I just never saw it until he said it.' The message is that it is important to think about your behaviour.

I am absolutely perplexed to know what could possibly be inappropriate in those messages. If we acknowledge that we need to change behaviours from a very early age in young men and young woman, who are underreporting and taking the blame and the shame on themselves if something like this happens, these messages would seem to me to be incredibly appropriate. All of the experts in this area—all of the experts who deal with attitude change in the area of sexual violence—say that these are the best tested messages that they have seen and that they would set a new international benchmark for good campaigning in this area. Again, I am perplexed that the Ministerial Committee on Government Communications could find anything with these messages that is problematic. Triple J, which were going to be part of this consolidated campaign, have decided apparently to go ahead with their eight 10-minute sections promoting healthy relationships between young people. I congratulate them for doing that. I think that is very responsible of them to do it. It is a shame that they will not have the backup of the print media for their campaign.

I want to turn very briefly in the few minutes left to me to the area of domestic violence. As I said earlier, the Prime Minister said at the beginning of his first term that domestic violence was going to be a priority for this government. In 1997, he announced the Partnerships Against Domestic Violence program, which was due in 2002, and then there was a further roll-out of funds for this partnerships program. I could go over the history of underspending in this area—the most obvious and classic example, of course, being the $10 million underspend which was diverted to use for the terrorism fridge magnet—but I want to talk about the more substantive issue.

The area of domestic violence affects very many Australians. Last year more than 32,000 women with young children were given shelter in women's refuges around this country. The statistics vary about how many people are affected by this, but it is not unusual to hear a figure of one in three or one in four women who in their lifetime experience domestic violence. It is an incredibly high figure. The underspending in this area is a problem in itself; there is plenty to spend money on. Many of the programs that have been run eventually under the Partnerships Against Domestic Violence program have been really excellent programs. I am not afraid to say that, even though there has been underspending by this government, many community organisations have come up with and run really excellent programs. The problem with this model of funding—and I have grave concerns about it—is that the money is not given out until late in the funding cycle. By the time a program gets under way, there might only be a year or 18 months left before their money runs out. If there is one thing that we can be absolutely sure of, it is that this is not a problem that is going to be solved overnight; this is a problem that will take generations to finally solve in this country.

The message on domestic violence is that we need to work with young people to break the intergenerational cycle of violence and that we need to educate whole communities and whole groups of people about domestic violence—what it is, what people have a right to object to in the first place. This is still not clear in Australian society. We have a great deal of work to do with the victims of domestic violence. Of course, we have to do something about the perpetrators too. The tragic thing is that, when 40 per cent of homicides in this country take place within marriages—within domestic relationships—and are the result of domestic violence, we muck around with a program that runs for a year or 18 months and when that year is up the program coordinator has to spend the next six months worrying about whether they are going to have the funding to keep running their program at the end of the funding cycle. I think that that is a really disappointing public policy result. It is an enormous frustration to the amazing people who work in this area, who are confronted every day with situations that no-one should be confronted with. It is a real letting down of the victims. Whenever we spend money on domestic violence or sexual assault awareness raising, the emergency services required go through the roof. We have to make sure that we are not just raising awareness and letting people hang out to dry. We have to fund the after-care services, the follow-through services, appropriately.

talk.start.para: —These appropriation bills seek funding for the Department of Defence, the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade, AusAID and the Australian Federal Police for ongoing commitments and aid work in the Solomon Islands. They also cover funds for the New Guinea deployment of our Federal Police, the implementation of the MedicarePlus package and several other specified amounts for particular purposes. As well, the bills contain clauses that provide a mechanism for the Minister for Finance and Administration to lapse amounts not required by departments. This sensible provision seems designed to prevent agencies or departments from seeking ambit claim appropriations or from carrying forward unspent amounts. If that is the intention, it is obviously a sound budgetary move.

speech.para: The appropriation debate enables members, however, to make wide-ranging comments, and I want to discuss several matters that are highly pertinent to this election year. Telstra is one issue vital to this government's budgetary ambitions but at the same time vital to the Australian public's belief that continued public ownership of our major telco is non-negotiable. The latest twist in this debate is the Telstra-Fairfax furphy. As I said in a recent press release when the story hit the headlines:

quote.para: The political hand of the Prime Minister is up the shirt of the Telstra puppet in the latest act of the privatisation show ...

speech.para: I believe that the outrageous idea for Telstra to buy Fairfax emanated not from the Telstra senior management but from the cabinet and the Prime Minister to fuel the argument that a government should not be in a position to own a private media outlet.

The government desperately wants to get its hands on the $30 billion from a full Telstra sale. Indeed, its survival may well depend on it. No doubt many of the items on the government's wish list for the approaching campaign would depend on a full sale. Indeed, the Telstra-environment nexus could be further exploited by another heritage fund, as it was in 1996. But the public have consistently argued against the full sale of Telstra, and an overwhelming majority of rural constituents in particular are adamant that they will not countenance any sale under any circumstances. Telstra's inability to meet demand for new services in the bush makes a joke of the government's continued insistence that services are up to scratch. Only yesterday I was looking at recent figures of Telstra's response to the Estens inquiry, and it was pointed out that there is no separation of the city-country service figures in that and that the so-called 90 per cent or 95 per cent service rate that is being reached is highly coloured by the metropolitan outcomes.

This nebulous term `up to scratch' was invented on the run by a Queensland National Party senator at the end of his career who is more concerned about the survival of a political anachronism than about services to future generations of rural Australians. Despite the rhetoric of broadband Internet access, there is little hope of affordable access for people other than those close to a major centre or exchange. CDMA mobile services continue to disappoint and frustrate and are nowhere near the reliability once provided by the GSM-analog mix. Breakdowns and slowness of repair continue at a regular rate despite the best efforts of hard-working Telstra Country Wide staff in my area, who I suspect are totally frustrated by the inadequacy of their budget allocations.

Yet the Prime Minister, in response to pressure from the big end of town, stands in this place and defends not the people of rural Australia but the private shareholders of Telstra—these people holding shares without the permission of the wider Australian public. Indeed, the Prime Minister is arguing for the selfish interests of minority private shareholders at the expense of the majority public shareholding. How about the Prime Minister arguing on behalf of the majority of Australians, who do not want Telstra fully privatised—the 90-plus per cent of rural Australians who have answered surveys by me and the member for New England with a deafening `No!' when asked whether Telstra should be fully privatised? Of course, the continued public ownership of national assets is anathema not only to the corporate friends of the government and to the finance industry that stands to win—I would hardly say `earn'—a cool $600 million for the sale of the last tranche of Telstra. It is also anathema to the free market agenda, and no doubt there is already pressure for Australia to hand over its publicly owned telco to the market, as the Singaporean government has been required to do with its government owned SingTel under its FTA with the US.

Moving on to free trade, if you examine the trade fact site of the United States Trade Representative, you will read that under the FTA Australia will accord substantial access to US service suppliers, subject to very few exceptions, based on the so-called negative list approach. Australia's commitments apply across a wide range of sectors, including but not limited to telecommunications services and financial services, including banking, insurance and securities. Given that under the FTA all US investment in new businesses is exempted from screening under the foreign investment board regime and that thresholds for acquisitions are raised from $50 million to $800 million, one wonders: why is there a need for any limits on US ownership of Telstra; should it go to the market? Why is there a need for a foreign investment review process if, as the US trade site says, the higher $800 million threshold would exempt 90 per cent of US investment transactions from screening? I thought the Foreign Investment Review Board process was designed to ensure investments were in the best interests of Australian people. The average Australian would ask: `Why this lack of transparency?' Indeed, members in this place must be asking the same question if they are serious about their representative duties.

As for support for this free trade agreement from the so-called grassroots, I am battling to find it in much of my electorate. Most people seem to want an answer to the most basic question: if trade is supposed to be free, why has there been no increase in sugar exports and why is there such a long time frame for anything approaching free trade in beef and dairy products? There are also legitimate and deep concerns over the disadvantage that our manufacturing industry may face from the country of origin rules, and I suspect the car industry's enthusiasm may well be somewhat premature.

On top of this came last week's recommendations that pork, banana and apple imports be allowed. In the case of apples, growers are outraged that there has been no satisfactory explanation of how the fire blight bacteria can be kept out of this country if imports are allowed from New Zealand and, inevitably, from North America. We are being asked to concede that it is an acceptable risk for apples to be imported from fire blight infected New Zealand, whether it is from a currently active area or not. Apples that have had antibiotics not allowed in Australia sprayed on them during their flower to bud stage, supposedly to kill off any fire blight bacteria, have to be cool stored for six weeks. This replaces a previously discredited protocol, suggested several years ago, where a 50-metre buffer zone was to be created around export crops in New Zealand. That has now gone out the window and is substituted by this new regime.

This is protocol on the run. Whereas the New Zealand application for entry to Australia was rejected several years ago—as it has been since the 1940s when New Zealand growers first tried to access our markets—now, in the year of the free trade agreement, it seems that Biosecurity Australia has been forced to roll over for economic rather than quarantine reasons. Nothing has changed in this debate since 1997, 1998, 1999 and 2000—indeed, for the past 80 years—except for one thing: the free trade imperative, which is to rule over all other considerations. Non-tariff barriers are no longer acceptable in any form—that is the message—and tariff barriers are only okay if they are selectively applied by the United States and complemented by subsidies. That is the real situation, and apple growers and horticulturists in my electorate are ready to revolt. I would suggest that growers in other electorates that cover the Murray Valley, the Tumut-Batlow area, parts of southern Queensland and Tasmania are feeling likewise, and that is only apple and pear growers, not pig or banana producers, who are already making their feelings known.

The Australian editorial yesterday asks, `How come New Zealand is such a producer and exporter of applies if it's supposed to have this fire blight bacteria?' New Zealand has, like 39 other countries around the world which have been infected by legal and illegal imports, sustained its industry on the back of such infection. The disease can and does wipe out entire orchards and it destroys livelihoods. New Zealand growers have put up with the risk, just like they do with the Johne sheep-wasting disease. New Zealand's idea of a level playing field is one infected with every disease under the sun. Like America, with genetic modification, they believe that, unless they can contaminate the rest of the world's markets, they are not going to have the access that they require and, in many cases, the control of those markets by dint of their economies of scale. Is that any reason not to maintain every possible barrier to fire blight from entering Australia, especially when the Australian climate is said to be far more conducive to the spread of fire blight than the New Zealand climate? Just because New Zealand and North America's apple industries survive, with the ever present threat of fire blight and the ever present effects of it, is that any reason to risk infecting our orchards?

I asked the minister today whether he would consider an extension to the 60-day reply to the draft protocol and the recommendations that have been released. As I understood his answer, the minister said that the science has already been documented and we have been through this process many times in the past, but, yes, AQIS may consider an extension. But he seemed to be asking: why is it necessary? As I said, the last time around the protocol was rejected quite strongly because of the inherent risks. Now farmers are being asked, in the middle of harvesting, to come up with a science based response to a new protocol that has to deal with the antibiotics and the chlorine dip, which is supposed to obviate the risk of the fire blight bacteria getting into the calix and then into the core of the fruit. As I understand it, there is no guarantee that the antibiotics will do that job. It creates air pockets at the base of the apple. There is every risk—as I heard at a meeting in Orange last week, addressed by department of agriculture horticulturists and apple advisers—and real concerns that the very apples that have been treated in such a way could still be the carriers of this particular disease.

So we have the antibiotics; we have the chlorine dip, which is new to the protocol; we have the cool store, which is new to the protocol; and we no longer have any buffer zone. Yet the minister seems to be arguing that we have already covered the science. We have not. There is new science being put up as the answer to New Zealand's argument that they do not pose a risk, and it certainly requires more than 60 days for orchardists to get together the expertise that they need to respond in any substantial way to this recommendation. They are certainly very suspicious of the apparent speed with which AQIS, Biosecurity Australia and the government seem to be rushing this thing through. They wonder how coincidental it is that it is all happening at the same time as the free trade agreement is being put on the table.

Canada's National Union of Farmers has produced a startling report, showing how farmers in that country have fallen further and further behind the eight ball under the modern free trade model. The report is called The farm crisis: bigger farms and the myths of competition and efficiency. It maintains that the destruction of rural communities, growing environmental problems, declining farm numbers and the farm income crisis cast doubt on the sustainability of the current high input, export oriented expansionist model. The report puts it thus:

quote.para: As the system is currently structured, farmers are just the hamsters in the wheel that powers an expanding agribusiness empire. The Government's solution to the farm crisis is for the hamsters to run faster.

speech.para: The Canadian farm union's report further states:

quote.para: Globalisation and trade agreements have increased competition levels for farmers—driving down farmers' prices and profits—and the effects for the dominant agribusiness transnationals have been just the opposite—

speech.para: and not only for the transnationals, I would suggest. We saw the report released yesterday—and I think the minister was again talking about it in question time—that showed that Woolworths' and Coles' profit margins are only 4 per cent and so the growers have not got an argument when they say they are being squeezed by the supermarkets. How they are being squeezed, though, is by the increase in imports and the opportunities for other product, some of it produced with far cheaper labour than we have in this country, to come onto the market. That creates a surplus of supply and further drives down the prices that growers are getting. Even old season apples are being sold at about—or a little above—the cost of production.

We are risking our orchard industry, quite forgetting for the moment the risk of fireblight. We are increasing supply, and of course the supermarkets love that. They can force down prices. We seem always to be looking at the benefits to the consumer, but we are not going to have any producers if we continue down this route. We are only going to have supplies from those areas that can produce at the most minimal wage cost. That is what is happening. That is the danger that our agricultural industry—particularly the horticultural sector—is facing. Of course, it is not just a rip-off in the chain from grower to supermarkets; it is the fact that the supermarkets are able to screw down the prices they can deliver to local growers by importing masses of product from offshore.
Elsewhere in this report from the Canadian farm union, they say:

quote.para: Economists simply create the illusion of efficiency by refusing to factor in resource depletion, biodiversity loss, habitat destruction, water use, pollution, climate change, the degraded nutritional value of some foods and a host of other externalities.

speech.para: Madam Deputy Speaker Gambaro, mark those words. They could apply equally to much of Australian agriculture—and that is before the much vaunted free trade deal kicks in, with the American market enjoying a substantial advantage over ours for years ahead. Added to this is the quite deliberate agenda of contaminating our relatively clean green agriculture, land and products with genetically modified crops so that a few major transnational companies can control what our farmers plant and what chemicals they use and what products consumers eat, despite the growing rejection of GM-engineered foodstuffs by consumers in Europe and Asia. Producers in my area are asking why there is such a rush to introduce GM-engineered canola, when markets around the world are saying, `Hold off; we do not know the long-term health and environmental consequences.'

Indeed, a grower in my area, Lachie MacSmith, who recently went with an open mind to Canada to have a look at this as a canola producer, came back totally alarmed. The growers he met said, `Don't go down this route—we've basically become slaves to the GM industry and we can't segregate.' Once you go into it, the whole process means that you become captive to the technology.

This parliament was told by the AMA, in a committee inquiry I was party to about three or four years ago, that the jury is still out on the long-term environmental and health consequences. That was enough for me to hear alarm bells ringing. How, then, can the Monsanto spokesman, Mark Buckingham, say that GM crops have been accepted by Canadian farmers and have proved successful when the evidence is showing quite the contrary? From where do the Gene Technology Regulator and the GM industry acquire their superior wisdom when the AMA is not even prepared to proffer a projection on what the long-term consequences of this technology are?

What is the meaning of the New South Wales government's moratorium on the planting of commercial crops when we understand that they are about to buckle to requests to allow commercial trials? It makes an absolute nonsense of their promise, during the last state election campaign, to impose a meaningful moratorium. I call on the New South Wales minister to send a representative of his department to a meeting in Canowindra next week, to be attended by the deputy president of the Canadian farmers union, where she will spell out what she sees as the dangers of this technology to a country which should be prizing its clean green status and the buffer zone of the oceans around the continent.

talk.start.para: —In debating the Appropriation Bill (No. 3) 2003-2004, the Appropriation Bill (No. 4) 2003-2004 and the Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Bill (No. 2) 2003-2004 I would like to demonstrate how the government both ignores the needs and increases the burden on Australian families. I also wish to highlight how the distorted social spending of the government mirrors the extent to which it is out of touch with the reality of daily life in Australia.

speech.para: Despite claims of superior economic management, it is an indisputable fact that the Howard government is the highest taxing and highest spending government in Australian history. As these bills indicate, it is also indisputable that, despite massive tax windfalls resulting from the GST and the sale of Telstra, essential public services are being eroded and some might say even destroyed. It is a growing paradox. It is certainly a paradox for the people in my electorate when this government collects record high taxes whilst simultaneously professing an inability to fund its health, education and welfare responsibilities. This government's distorted funding priorities and disregard for the welfare of Australians is making life for my constituents more and more difficult. Their frustration, of course, is understandable because, despite contributing more of their household income to the public purse, the government is wrenching affordable education, health and aged care from their reach.

In the end, it is a choice between differing values and the value we place upon the backbone of Australian society, which is of course our families. Labor recognises the tremendous pressure that is burdening Australian families and, unlike the current government, we are actively working towards easing that pressure. Ignoring the needs of Australians only serves to augment social frustration and dysfunction. Unfortunately, the government does not understand the pressure on our families and, unlike Labor, does not consider support of struggling families with the same sense of urgency that it requires. One need look no further than the yellowing pages of the Prime Minister's report into families in 2002, which clearly identified the need for immediate social reform.

Unlike the Prime Minister, who chose to ignore this call for assistance and deal with the problems facing countless Australians, Labor has already formulated viable, affordable solutions to give our families the helping hand they deserve. Labor's prioritised social agenda for health, education and aged care is not a political white elephant. The funds to provide those services exist and we will fund these services by relocating government spending in line with societal need. Labor can potentially invest an extra $5 billion into public education and health—$5 billion that the Howard government is wasting through its misdirected priorities.

This commitment to reprioritise the agenda and redirect funds is being met with relief and approval by Australian families. I see evidence of this in my electorate office on a daily basis. Families are responding positively to Labor's agenda and are excited about the opposition's focus on opportunity for all. Our policies on early childhood learning, decent Medicare bulk-billing levels, the national dental health scheme, environmental progress and more places in our universities and TAFEs have indeed struck a chord with the people in my electorate.

Of course, there exist countless examples of the government's distorted and apathetic policy responses to Australians' needs and concerns. I would like to refer in particular to the government's axing of the essential and affordable national dental health scheme. How does refusing to fund access to dental services for needy Australians stack up against the $693 million blown by this government on advertising material? That material supposedly promotes Commonwealth initiatives, but in reality it is little more than shameless political advertising. How does spending an extra $2 billion on consultancies stack up against families being unable to access bulk-billing GPs—in particular, after hours? How does maintaining the Prime Minister's two lavishly appointed taxpayer funded households stack up against the thousands of Australians living in poverty—many of whom are in my electorate of Calwell—or the escalating number of young people unable to afford to buy a home of their own, despite the government's much flaunted but inflationary First Home Owner Grant Scheme? How does wasting $1 billion of taxpayers' money on failed currency swaps stack up against the critical shortage of nursing home beds for elderly Australians?

In my electorate I suspect that the government's distorted priorities have resulted in the rejection of an application to the Department of Health and Ageing by Kiwi Dale Pty Ltd for funding under the 2002-03 aged care approval round for the building of a 124-bed facility in Roxburgh Park. Needless to say, the people from Universal Care Management, acting on behalf of Kiwi Dale Pty Ltd, are shocked at the rejection, given that stage 1 of the development is due for completion in June-July of this year and stage 2 is expected to be completed two months after that. They are shocked because they have ventured into providing a service and facility that they know and we know is desperately needed. They—and I—are bewildered as to why the department would knock back such a proposal at a time when a major operator such as the Salvation Army is abandoning the field of nursing home care.

Who is going to fill the space that has been vacated by the Salvation Army? Surely it makes sense that universal care should be supported in its venture and not rejected. As this is a very important issue I want to make reference to some comments in a letter that I received from Universal Care Management, which I think are very important:

quote.para: The facility is also ideally located within a retirement living development at Bridgewater Lakes [Roxburgh Park]. People taking up residency are looking for care support services which were to be provided from the aged care facility. This may now not be possible.

Given that it is the clear policy objective of the Federal Government to have contemporary aged care accommodation on the ground and operational, and this was to be given high priority in the last and, I suspect, all future ACAR processes, I cannot understand why the Department of Health and Ageing would pass over a facility that will obviously be available mid 2004 for a new application which cannot be operational until late 2005 or early 2006.

In addition to the obvious delay to the community in accessing services, up to 100 employment positions and significant local consumption expenditure will be adversely impacted upon as a result of this decision.

speech.para: Obviously the result of this decision directly contradicts the government's professed commitment to easing the burden of elderly Australians, especially in the area of the provision of aged care facilities.

But I do want to talk about the national dental health program, which I made mention of earlier. The government's axing of the Commonwealth dental health program upon acquiring government in 1996 is probably best described as mean-spirited. When the program was axed, there were some 380,000 Australians waiting an average of six months for public dental care. Since then, these figures have skyrocketed. Today, in 2004, there are over 500,000 people waiting up to five years to get their teeth fixed or attended to. Many of those waiting for access to dental care are elderly Australians—the very people we have a duty to support and care for. But low-income families are also heavily affected. A national survey found that one-third of people in the $30,000 to $50,000 household annual income bracket had not been to see a dentist for over two years, because they simply could not afford to. Many of these people endure months and years of pain, diminished health, social embarrassment and discrimination as a result of not being able to go to the dentist or as a result of going to their local health service to be told that they have to wait. They have to wait and wait—for possibly up to 15 to 24 months.

This situation is reflected in my electorate, where the latest statistics indicate a staggering 2½ year wait for a dental appointment at the local Dianella health service. In fact, such is the depth of the crisis in my electorate that people are resorting to simply having their teeth extracted, because they can no longer wait for dental care. In comparison to other OECD nations, Australia's dental health record is not very good. We have to ask ourselves why. In my electorate, public demand for our local health centre is so great that the centre is forced to refer people to the very few private dentists that we have in the area. Regrettably, the numbers of such private clinics prepared or able to afford charging patients a reduced rate are small. They are very few and far between. In fact, it is unrealistic and unfair to burden private practices with the inaction of this government.

I want to make reference to a woman who recently came into my office seeking my assistance in helping her access desperately needed dental care. The health centre that she had gone to was unable to assist her and the local dentist could not afford to see her at a reduced fee. What struck me about this was that my eight-year-old daughter was actually in my office on that day, and she was listening to this woman's problems—and I presume that it would be quite fascinating for an eight-year-old child to see an adult actually become very distressed about the fact that they could not get access to a dentist. To my surprise, my daughter took it upon herself to put together a list of her friends and other people that she knew that she wanted to collect donations from in order to assist this woman. From my point of view, it was an admirable act on my daughter's part, and I am proud of her for it, but I think it is very pitiful that people are in many cases forced to forgo their dignity and come into our offices literally begging for assistance—an assistance that was once available to them. It is an assistance that has been ripped away with the election of the Howard government. Quite frankly, it is pretty disgusting that the government refuses to acknowledge that there is a crisis and refuses to reinstate the Commonwealth dental program.

Labor will not ignore the Australian people. Already we have pledged accessible dental care for all who need it. We will invest $300 million in Australian dental care over four years. We will provide for up to 1,300,000 extra dental procedures. This should be enough to clear the existing backlog and substantially reduce the enormous waiting list that currently exists. Under Labor's plan, concession card holders such as pensioners, healthcare cardholders and their dependants will have access to free check-ups when they need them, as well as subsidised dental treatment, restorations and dentures. Under Labor's plan, no Australian child will have to miss out on dental care because their parent's wallet is not big or deep enough.

Recently at a street stall in Sunbury, a newly acquired part of my electorate, I confirmed first-hand something that I have seen in other parts of the electorate—that is, the opinion of families on declining bulk-billing levels. Sunbury, which is a suburb with some 10,000 children under the age of 18, is a commuter town with a very young population, an elderly population and certainly a growing population of families. While we were asking local residents to sign a petition to save Medicare, I could not help but be aware of the beeline made by mothers and young women in particular to sign the petition. All were deeply concerned about the rising cost of health care at local general practitioners and the loss of local bulk-billing and after-hours services.

Since the Howard government came into office, bulk-billing rates have plummeted nationally by 13 per cent. In the electorate of Calwell, the percentage of Medicare bulk-billed consultations has slumped by 6.2 per cent to 81.5 per cent in the year from December 2002-03. At the same time, the out-of-pocket expenses of seeing a doctor have risen by 10 per cent. The number of bulk-billing practitioners sits at 81.5 per cent in Calwell. Some people might think that is very high, and that may be the case. However, we are talking about an area that has many lower socio-economic families who rely very much on the availability of bulk-billing GPs. Any loss of bulk-billing services hits my community, and it hits it very hard. One of the other major problems, in addition to the loss of bulk-billing GPs, is the fact that a lot of public hospital emergency and casualty wards are being swamped by patients who, unable to get access to GP services, in particular after-hours GP services, take themselves and their children—they are usually families—to the casualty wards and sit and wait in very long queues. This is an ongoing and growing problem, and it needs to be addressed. There is, of course, a way that we can address this, and we can do it by funding GP practices that are positioned adjacent to hospital emergency centres. The GPs in these practices will be available to deal with routine matters, leaving casualty and emergency wards to attend to the more difficult cases, which usually involve emergency and high medical care requirements. It is bizarre that the government appears to be adverse to such a solution.

The Northern Hospital, although not in my electorate of Calwell, certainly services a great number of the people who live in my electorate. The federal government left the Northern Hospital waiting for funding to begin operating a GP practice. It was set up and ready to go but it could not be operated for months because it was waiting for funds from the federal government. Eventually it did not get any funds from the federal government, and it was the state government that had to step in and provide the funds so that this GP practice could commence operation. This is not a permanent situation for the state government. The state government has only stepped in to provide the funding for a short period of time, and no doubt the Northern Hospital will be back lobbying—and perhaps even begging—the federal government to consider allowing this practice to continue. In fact, I have to say that, if it was not for the excellent local health care services provided by the Dianella Community Health Service—and in this case the Bracks government's dedication to affordable general practice access through a collaborative partnership and the funding of the on site general practice service at the Northern Hospital—the increasing demand of local residents for accessible and affordable health care would simply not be met.

Another critical issue facing my electorate is the lack of educational opportunities for young people. Calwell residents already suffer disproportionate rates of disadvantage and diminished educational access. Demands by the government that those who miss out on one of the highly competitive HECS places should sign themselves up for full fee places and burden themselves with debts that would be equivalent to house mortgages, ignore the economic realities of my constituents. Accumulated poverty and disadvantage already limit their access to tertiary education. Universities have now been given permission to increase their HECS fees and decisions to increase their HECS fees by up to 25 per cent will turn away prospective students from the northern suburbs who are unwilling to burden themselves with crushing debt and who will always have to consider the prospect of mounting student debt when determining their postsecondary choices.

La Trobe University's decision to increase fees by about 25 per cent, which I think was announced yesterday, is regrettable and will seriously affect my electorate as thousands of my young constituents study there. They rely on institutions like La Trobe University to help them progress and fulfil their ambitions and aspirations, so this is not going to be very good news for them. But we are lucky in Calwell to have an excellent TAFE college which provides further education and technical training and opportunities for kids, particularly kids from Broadmeadows and the surrounding areas. The Kangan Batman TAFE is one of those institutions that provide excellent education and training. The minister himself often proclaims the value of TAFE institutions and, in particular, promotes them as alternatives to universities. Despite this, the government's 2003-04 budget has denied TAFEs new funding—in fact, there is no funding. This government has wilfully ignored the pleas of these great institutions such as the Kangan Batman TAFE and simultaneously, by ignoring them, it disregards the concerns of the students and their families.

The Labor Party listen to and work for Australians. Our funding for an extra 10,000 TAFE places and an extra 10,000 university places will address the needs of Australian students. Rather than denying education to students and increasing the financial pressure on students and their families, we have pledged not to support increased HECS or upfront fees. The differing responses of Labor and Liberal to the higher education funding crisis draws a clear distinction between two visions for higher education: our vision of opportunity for all and the government's vision of a two-class education system. Where you end up depends very much on where you live, what the sizes of your parents' wallets are and what your opportunities are. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —Appropriation Bill (No. 3) 2003-2004, Appropriation Bill (No. 4) 2003-2004 and Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Bill (No. 2) 2003-2004 offer members on both sides of the House a very important opportunity to highlight key issues of concern to their electorates. Some of those issues have national connotations; others are quite local. In my case, there are some very important issues of real concern to my constituents. The first one is health. Previous members have contributed much in this debate to the issue of health. When looking at the health system in the Geelong region, it is fair to say that at the moment it is in crisis. That is not a reflection on Barwon Health or the workers who earn their living in this very important industry, but it is a reality.

speech.para: There are several elements to this crisis situation. The first is the shortage of GPs in the Geelong region. I have had representations from the General Practitioners Association of Geelong about this particular issue. Many of my constituents are not able to access a general practitioner and, of course, that is of real concern to them in meeting their primary health care needs. This factor and several others have put immense pressure on the casualty department at Geelong Hospital and also on waiting lists at the outpatients department of that hospital. Some of that pressure comes from the fact that in the region we have a shortage of aged care beds. People are being kept in the Geelong Hospital when they should be attended with care in specialised nursing home facilities. I will say this to the government: you can find $1 billion for a war in Iraq but you cannot find the resources and funds necessary to enable older people in Geelong to live out their days in dignity and receive appropriate standards of care.

When I talk about a crisis in Geelong's health system, I also refer to the impact of the government's policies on the pockets and the incomes of families in my constituency. We have seen a substantial increase in health costs for families in Geelong. Firstly, this has come from the rapid decline in bulk-billing in the Geelong region. I will provide to the chamber some statistics on that in a minute. The other particular pressure on health costs has come from the increase in private health insurance premiums. We have a rather high level of private health insurance usage in Geelong, with GMHBA based in the city. We have seen recently, as a direct result of government policy, some very substantial premium increases that are impacting on Geelong families to the tune of $150 a year.

When the bulk-billing rate declines in a community, low-income earners and families under economic pressure face real difficulties and pressures on their household budgets as a result. Bulk-billing was designed as an essential part of the universal health care system of Australia. It enables low- and middle-income Australians to gain access to a universal health care system—a quality one at that—at a reasonable cost. Bulk-billing delivers an economic advantage to people who use bulk-billing doctors. The last time Mr Howard released bulk-billing figures for each federal electorate was in the September quarter of 2003. At that time, the rate of bulk-billing in the electorate of Corio stood at 58.4 per cent. In the Liberal-held electorate of Corangamite, over the Barwon River, it stood at 41.8 per cent. The figure for both of these Geelong based federal electorates stood well below the national average of 67.4 per cent.

When you look at the national figures since the Howard government came to power, you can see that the rate of bulk-billing has generally fallen by around 13 per cent. At the same time, the average cost of seeing a GP has risen by 64 per cent. In September 2003 that increase stood at around $13.40 per visit. When you take the rising costs of seeing a GP and the economic disadvantage that flows to low- and middle-income families from reductions in bulk-billing and when you add to this the increased premiums for private health insurance, the economic pressure on Geelong households in this health area alone has been quite substantial.

Labor do have a plan for the health care system, as we did when we structured the great universal health care scheme in Medicare. We have a plan to restore bulk-billing. We will immediately lift the Medicare patient rebate for all bulk-billed consultations to 95 per cent of the schedule fee—an average increase of $3.35 per consultation. Labor will subsequently lift the Medicare patient rebate for all bulk-billed consultations to 100 per cent of the schedule fee. That will be an average of $5 per consultation. We will offer doctors an incentive of up to $22,500 to meet stipulated bulk-billing targets and we are going to provide more GPs and nurses in areas of critical need. This is a plan to address the damage that has been done to Australia's health care system by the Howard government. Members opposite can run but they cannot hide. The electorate are now poised with their baseball bats, ready to take them to this coalition government because of the broken promises and the burdens it has visited upon them.

The second important area of concern for Geelong families is that of educating their children. Australian families, and Geelong families in particular, do not ask much from their governments and their education system. They simply ask that a decent opportunity be provided to their children—that their children have the opportunity to develop their skills and personalities and become good contributors to Australia, to the ongoing development and greatness of this country. We know that at this particular point in time in our history that there are gross inequities in the opportunity that is available to students in this country to access a good education. These inequities are no more pronounced than they are in the Geelong area. We do have schools that are very well resourced. I cast no aspersions on the parents who choose to send their children to those schools—they make a sacrifice to send their children to those particular schools. But the economic reality is that many of the parents who do send their children to those schools have an economic capacity that far surpasses that of others in the Geelong area.

We have an extraordinary situation in Geelong where schools that exist within two to three kilometres of each other are like chalk and cheese when it comes to the level of resourcing and, of course, access to real opportunity. That is where it is the responsibility of government to make sure that educational institutions most in need have the first call on the resources and that every Australian child—including every child in Geelong—gets a fair crack of the whip at getting the education that will propel them along a road to new opportunity. That is not the case in Geelong, and that is a reality that the community in Geelong has to face.

We have the greatest deceiving government in Australia's history at it again in the electorate of Corio. I refer to the recent announcement in a press release by the Minister for Education, Science and Training of a number of places at Deakin University. It stated:

quote.para: ... the Geelong region will benefit from 164 new Commonwealth scholarships ...

speech.para: On the face of it, the electors of Corio might say, `That is the government doing its job and expanding opportunity.' But we find that the scholarships are spread across all Deakin campuses, including Burwood, Toorak and Warrnambool as well as Geelong. So the Geelong campus is one of four that will share in these 164 scholarships. I welcome the initiative. I am not going to turn my back on 164 scholarships for Deakin University, but the minister ought not come into my electorate and put out a press release claiming credit for addressing a need in the Geelong region when in fact some of those scholarships will go to Melbourne.

Under the Howard government, we have seen the recently announced slug on Geelong families of a 25 per cent Deakin University fee hike. This 25 per cent fee rise has also been announced by Griffith University, the Queensland University of Technology and La Trobe University and we understand that a number of other universities are about to follow suit. The minister has stood up in this parliament, day after day, week after week, claiming that his new policy for higher education would not lead to maximum fee hikes. We told him that it would. We told the minister that his policies would lead to these 25 per cent increases. What has happened? We now have 25 per cent fee increases, and they will impact quite heavily, for instance, on working families in Geelong who seek to send their children to Deakin University in their own community.

Labor will remedy this situation, and we are committed to removing that 25 per cent fee hike. We are going to provide an extra $300 million to universities over the next four years to make sure that they can deliver a quality education to their students not only at Deakin University but at universities right across the country. We will fully index grants to those universities to make sure that they have the capacity to deliver the quality education that we expect. We will also create 20,000 new places not only in the higher education sector, at universities like Deakin, but also at TAFE institutions, such as the Gordon Technical College in my electorate.

In the time remaining, let me talk very briefly about Geelong's transport network. We all know how important the transport network is to the economic wellbeing and growth of communities. When Labor was in power, the Keating government, in its great infrastructure spending, created the Western Ring Road around Melbourne. That particular public investment has altered the economic geography of the 13th largest city on the face of the earth. It has certainly made it a little easier for me to get to Melbourne airport, but now with the Jetstar announcement to fly out of Avalon I may not be using Melbourne airport as much as I have in the past.

The issue of real concern now is the Geelong ring-road or the Geelong bypass. It took the community of Geelong many years of very difficult and sustained lobbying to get the third lane on the Princes Highway between Melbourne and Geelong. That has proved to be a great advantage to commuters and has provided a great economic benefit to constituents in the Corio electorate. I do not doubt that. Unfortunately, that third lane on the Princes Highway ends at the northern suburbs of Geelong. The Bracks government has committed some $190 million to the ring-road and has requested that the federal government make a matching contribution under its Roads of National Importance program.

I think it is fair to say that, in discussions we have had with the minister and, indeed, the shadow minister, as would be expected at the first cut and call of these particular lobbying efforts, the community has not been successful. We will keep on trying because we think we have a very important economic and social case to make. That ring-road will certainly connect the Princes Highway from Melbourne with the Bacchus Marsh Road and the Ballarat Road—and I note the presence in the chamber tonight of the member for Ballarat, an excellent member who will hold the seat at the next election—and around to the Midland Highway. It will, of course, rejoin the Princes Highway going into the western district, into the heartland of the electorate of Corangamite, and it will also connect with the Surf Coast Highway. This is a very critical piece of road infrastructure which will alter the economic geography of the Geelong region.

I ask Minister Anderson, in a spirit of bipartisanship, to consider the representations that are being made. I ask the shadow minister, the member for Batman, to also consider carefully the arguments that are being advanced by the community. This piece of infrastructure will connect Melbourne with the Great Ocean Road, one of the premier tourism attractions in Australia as well as in the state of Victoria. Ayers Rock, the Great Barrier Reef and the Great Ocean Road all occupy a special place.

So the economic advantages of connecting this last piece of the puzzle are quite substantial. But there are also safety considerations, because at the moment that traffic goes through the middle of Geelong via Latrobe Terrace. We have traffic jams and degrees of congestion and environmental pollution in that stretch of road through Geelong that could be mitigated should this bypass be completed. As well as the safety aspect, there are enormous social benefits, because many of my constituents and the constituents of the member for Corangamite travel to Melbourne to work. They have seen the benefits of the great lifestyle in the Geelong region. I hope good sense will prevail and ministers and shadow ministers will open their minds to argument and that we can have a sensible debate and discussion on this very important piece of infrastructure for the region. Health, education and transport are the real issues for my constituents, and these are the issues that I bring to the attention of the House tonight.

talk.start.para: —I would like to speak about a number of issues in relation to the Appropriation Bill (No. 3) 2003-2004, the Appropriation Bill (No. 4) 2003-2004 and the Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Bill (No. 2) 2003-2004. The first issue that I have some concern about—probably the most recent event that has occurred in the parliament that could have significant impact on country Australia—is the ethanol debate, which has been before the parliament for quite some time. I was astonished last night to watch the Senate when it was debating the labelling issue in relation to ethanol. I was absolutely staggered to see that The Nationals in particular voted against the recommendations of the task force that was set up by the Deputy Prime Minister, John Anderson, to look at the labelling issue and to try and overcome some of the confidence problems that had been expressed in the community. Those confidence problems were basically started by the Labor Party with a bit of a scaremongering campaign that took place some months ago. But I found it astonishing after all the work that had gone in.

speech.para: I know that one of the proponents of the Gunnedah ethanol plant, Matthew Kelly, was involved with that committee and with putting together recommendations so that people when they pulled up at the bowser to get their fuel knew that they were buying up to 10 per cent ethanol and that they should check with their car manufacturers as to the impact of ethanol on their engines. The recommendations were a fairly positive indication that ethanol, after checking with the manufacturer, is okay to use. And that is known world wide. Everybody knows that that is the case. Ethanol has been used in the United States, parts of Europe and South America for many years. Any number of countries have used ethanol.

The recommendation—and I am told that it was done at the beck and call of the Minister for the Environment and Heritage, a member of the Liberal Party—was changed and a very negative spin was put on the label that will appear on the bowsers when motorists pull up. The label even has the absurd suggestion down the bottom: `Do not use in any aircraft.' I have not seen an aircraft pulling up at a road station for quite some time and I do not think I will again. There is a little place called William Creek out on the Oodnadatta Track where that sign might be appropriate, where aircraft use the main street. That label was not recommended by the committee. The committee was set up by the government itself—a lot of community members took time to be involved in that decision-making process—and it has come out with this absurd suggestion: `Do not use in any aircraft.' When you buy diesel to put in your car, you do not see: `Do not use diesel in aircraft.' You do not see that on LPG. You do not see on petrol browsers signs saying `Do not drink after dinner'. You do not see a sign on petrol bowsers that says: `There are cancer-causing agents within this fuel.' So why did the Senate endorse it?

The Nationals have supposedly been promoting this particular product. They say they are behind it, but everything they do seems to be negative. They did not support a disallowance motion that was put before the Senate last night by the Democrats—in particular, Lyn Allison. To her great credit and that of the Democrats, they have been stalwarts in this debate. There is an amendment in the Senate that would allow for a 10-year freedom of excise period so that the industry could get established. In the past there has not been a tax on ethanol. The government has decided that, through its cleaner fuels policy arrangements, it will impose an excise regime that is based on energy components. But I will not get into that.

What is required for the ethanol industry to take off is at least a seven-year excise exemption from the start of production, not the five-year program starting from last September that the government has endorsed and which is currently sitting in the Senate. Any new players who want to become involved in the ethanol industry—other than Dick Honan, the Prime Minister's friend, of course—would get probably only 2½ to three years of excise exemption. Anybody who knows anything about that industry knows that it will not start under that arrangement.

One has to wonder what the government's agenda is. It has a cleaner fuels policy. It wants 350,000 megalitres of fuel produced by, I think, the year 2010, which is laudable and I applaud that particular policy. A grants scheme has been put in place to encourage people into the industry. Then the government imposes a tax regime that it knows will not start the industry and will benefit only the existing players, the major one of which is Manildra and the Prime Minister's friend—or previous friend now, I am told—Dick Honan.

I was astonished to see this negative label endorsed by country members of the Senate last night. I was particularly disappointed to see the Tamworth based senator, Senator Sandy Macdonald, who has been wandering around the electorate of New England saying that he is a great supporter of ethanol, physically in the parliament but not saying anything and voting for it. I also note, having checked the Hansard, that the self-proclaimed champion of the bush, Ron Boswell, did not even turn up to vote and did not say anything about it. He is out in the country areas of Queensland suggesting what a great thing ethanol is and saying: `We're in there working for you—it's the filthy Labor Party that is opposing it, but we're there. We're the champions of ethanol. We're working on getting the sugar industry involved in the ethanol industry.' He did not even bother to go in and vote on this absolutely crucial issue.

I had some people in my office today who are prepared to finance a particular ethanol plant. Two years ago, I met with them in Sydney. They are still here now and no progress is being made. If the government is serious about cleaner, renewable fuels and import replacement and those sorts of issues, let us get on with it and give these people a period of grace to get established and create the jobs in the country that all country members are talking about. Let us get positive about this particular fuel—the rest of the world is and we should be as well. It is an ideal opportunity to make a significant change in terms of agriculture in Australia and do it to the benefit of those people who live in the country as well as others who reside in this nation.

Most people would know—and the fuel companies definitely know—that in 2006 there will be changes. Again, they will be government driven, and I applaud the government for making these particular changes. Certain additives will be taken out of petrol because of their carcinogenic nature. The nonbenefit in relation to the removal of those additives from the make-up of fuel is that there will be a reduction in the octane content of petrol. So what do we do about that? We have got engines designed to certain octane levels running around our roads at the moment, so what do we do to fix that? The easy fix—and I am told that the fuel industry is recognising this now—is to use a natural agent that naturally oxygenates the fuel and increases the octane level. That, strange as it may seem, is ethanol—this renewable product that can be grown every year on our farms throughout Australia and provide an important added product and import replacer for our nation.

We hear all this talk in this place about the free trade arrangements and how we have got to become global players, and here we have something that we could be producing for ourselves every year. It would have the environmental impacts that I spoke about earlier, and we have a government which seems almost afraid to embrace it. One has to ask the question why. Why are we denying these industries the right to be established? Why do we assume that if the farming community becomes involved in the ethanol industry, produces fuel for the nation and removes a number of the carcinogens from existing fuel processes it should be taxed?

We had the Deputy Prime Minister in the parliament today talking about agriculture and the farming community, almost gloating over the fact that the farming community earns on average a 1.8 per cent return on capital and drawing some absurd analogy with the Labor Party building—the rorts for rent or whatever it is that Tony Abbott speaks about. A 1.8 per cent return! We have an opportunity to help not only those farming families but also the farming communities around them, particularly in the Queensland area, where whole communities are involved. Peter Costello was heard saying today on one of the radio stations that there are only 6,700 sugar producers. That was almost saying to the Sydney radio market that that is not many people—it is not even half a suburb, what are we worried about?

There are whole communities involved. I am sure you, Mr Deputy Speaker Causley, would be fully aware of the reliance on sugar that those communities have. It is not just the farmers and it is not just the people in the mills; it is the extended multiplier effect in those communities and the way they have existed in the past. We are going to go around with another rash of handouts to an industry that is sitting there screaming for a positive way out of predicament it is in. We have been unable to achieve a free trade arrangement for sugar, so that is an issue that is having an impact as well.

Here, we have the possibility of assisting those communities into ethanol, and there are proponents of it who are quite happy to look at fifty-fifty grain-sugar arrangements for ethanol where the storage problems for sugar would be overcome. Half of the year they would be using sugar and the other half of the year they would be using grain. Those sorts of options are there. We have Ron Boswell running round Queensland saying, `We're going to look after you, the National Party is the only way out—it is the only one that will look after you.' What did they get yesterday but some sort of dole arrangement being doled out to them just to buy them off for a few more months.

We have private sector investors who are prepared to invest in these industries. Country Australia has been screaming out for city money that people want to invest. I had people in my office today who are keen to invest $80 million in the industry. The only thing that is standing in their way is the legislative arrangements in this parliament. The government have endorsed the principle of excise freedom. The government, in their policy, have said in the Senate, `We endorse the principle of excise freedom.' The policy says that any entrants into the ethanol industry will have five years excise freedom from September 2003. As I said earlier, any new entrants would probably gain only two to 2½ years of excise freedom. The government know that, but having accepted the general principle of excise freedom they should be of a mind to transfer the five years to seven years from start-up of production so that the economic viability of the industry will be established. During that period of time, the debt payback can be made. I have seen the business plans for a number of plants. It can be done. Then they can settle down to the new energy driven excise arrangements that the government have put in place already. I would urge the government to look closely at that, particularly coming up to the next budget. I think that some amazing changes could occur.

One of the other issues that I would like to speak about is national competition policy. One of the reasons I stood for federal parliament was that I was very concerned about the way in which national competition policy had very little regard, almost by definition, for country communities—remoteness, smallness and distance being factors in terms of the economic processes. I still see a lot of those warning signs out there. There is an absurd arrangement at the moment where the National Competition Council is threatening to impose a $50 million fine on the New South Wales government. The New South Wales government is playing a bit of a political game back with it. There is an absurd arrangement to do with the farm debt mediation bill that was put through the parliament—I think whilst you, Deputy Speaker Causley, were a resident of the New South Wales parliament. You may well have voted for it at that particular time. I know I moved 10 amendments to it because it was not in a very good form at the start. I am pleased to see the member for Parkes here, because I think he was involved with the farmers association at the time, prior to being president. That organisation was very pro the farm debt mediation legislation at the time.

We currently see the National Competition Council and the Treasurer, Peter Costello, threatening to fine New South Wales if it does not adhere to the recommendations of the council. But the farm debt mediation legislation in New South Wales has helped hundreds of farmers—not thousands of farmers, but hundreds. It has brought people together to mediate where there have been debt problems and it has done it very successfully. That is going to be taken out under the theory of national competition policy. It is an absurd suggestion. We see it also occurring in relation to the liquor industry.

talk.start.para: (Hon. I.R. Causley)—The member for Parkes has a question. Does the honourable member for New England accept the question?
—Yes.

—Is the member for New England aware that the Commonwealth government at no stage imposed a fine on the New South Wales government over farm debt mediation and that all the New South Wales government have to do is justify the use of farm debt mediation to continue with it?
—Questions have to be brief.
