—I am well aware of that. I did mention that the New South Wales government is playing its own game. But this is a federally initiated policy, through the various COAG arrangements that have been put in place. The federal government can stop the absurdity in relation to the way this is being applied. Even Fred Hilmer would turn in his grave if he saw what is happening here. In theory, at least, this could be provided by other private sector people, but to apply national competition policy to farm debt mediation is quite absurd. To apply national competition policy to the chicken meat industry in the northern part of New South Wales, in the name of competition, when there is only one processor is absolutely absurd and has the potential to wipe out much of the chicken industry.

speech.para: I would have thought that the member for Parkes, with his background in the farmers association, would at least have some sympathy towards that idea, but obviously he is not attempting to do anything to change it. We have seen some far from innocuous aspects of human social behaviour in recent weeks, and I listened to the member for Sydney earlier on talking about some of those aspects. We have an absurd arrangement in New South Wales at the moment where the Commonwealth is going to impose a fine on the New South Wales government if they do not open up every corner store and fuel station so that people can pick up cheap grog at these places. Thank God the aircraft will not be able to get into the fuel stations to get their ethanol! This is an absurd aspect and impact of national competition policy. If we apply that to chemists, for instance—and the theory is that we will—the first people to be impacted will be those in the country towns, because chemists will lose some of their trade to corner stores and other people in the community, and they will not be viable with the residual trade of the drugs that only they will be able to prescribe.

It is about time that people in this parliament, rather than moving ridiculous amendments in the Senate that impose restrictions and negatives on country communities, started to look at some more positive aspects—and at the way in which national competition policy is having a negative impact on the social fabric of our nation. It is absolutely absurd to apply this sort of policy to chicken meat, where there is one processor. There is no competition, so how can you apply the policy? It is all very well for the member for Parkes to say that Bob Carr can write back and suggest that these sorts of things are not good enough. That has been done. It is no good going back and saying, `It wasn't done well enough.' The Treasurer can stop it. There is this absurd arrangement in this place where no-one seems to know whether it is the National Competition Council that makes the decision or whether the Treasurer can overrule the council; they both hide behind each other. The member for Parkes has said that if the state wrote back and said it was not good enough the National Competition Council would change its mind. Let us see it happen, because the state has written back asking the Commonwealth to change its mind. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —This week during question time the Minister for Education, Science and Training, Dr Nelson, was good enough to draw the House's attention to the fact that my electorate contains a number of Jewish schools. Indeed it does. I have visited most of them, as I have visited most of the schools in my electorate, many times—as have successive Labor leaders, including the current Leader of the Opposition, Mark Latham, the member for Werriwa, who made an extremely positive impression on all those schools which they remember to this day. I am very proud to have many fine schools in my electorate—government, denominational, Catholic and independent—and also to represent the parents, teachers and students of these schools.

speech.para: The minister went on to imply that the opposition's education policy will result in government funds being taken away from these schools. I am sure that the minister knew that this insinuation was untrue but, in case he was genuinely mistaken, let me make a few points about Labor's policy on school funding and the history of this debate. In 1973 Kim Beazley senior, the most farsighted education minister this country has ever seen, introduced a policy of needs based funding for all schools, regardless of whether they were government, denominational or independent schools. He established the Commonwealth Schools Commission to assess all schools on the basis of their needs and to fund them accordingly. Naturally, in practice, the schools that benefited most from this policy were poorer government schools and, indeed, the poorer Catholic schools. That is why Archbishop James Carroll, then the Catholic spokesperson on education, welcomed the new policy so warmly. The wealthy independent schools benefited least, but no distinction was made in principle between schools of one type or another.

Although the Fraser government abolished the Commonwealth Schools Commission, they did not tamper with the principle of needs based funding. It took the Howard government and the former education minister, Dr Kemp, to try and undo the work of the Whitlam government. The new formula introduced by the Howard government ostensibly continued to fund non-government schools on a needs basis, but it adopted a new formula to calculate how federal government money should go to non-government schools.

The new formula was calculated by linking a student's home address with a socio-economic status, SES, of the census collection district, CDC, in which the student's family lived. But this funding formula ignored the fact that all of the families living in a single CDC do not have the same household income—some families have higher incomes, some have lower. It should be obvious that families who can send their children to the wealthiest private schools will be wealthier than the average of families from within the CDC where they live. This leads to the wealthiest schools receiving lower SES ratings than they would have received had the real income or wealth of the families who use those schools been measured directly.

This distortion is particularly striking in country areas, where disparities of income between the wealthy few and the less wealthy are more striking. In a given rural census district, there will be a handful of landowners and a large proportion of people on lower incomes. Therefore, many of the wealthy parents of students at say, Geelong Grammar, will live in census districts which are, on average, low income. This has the effect of lowering Geelong Grammar's SES score and allowing it to obtain more government funding than some would argue it deserves.

This distortion has been remarked on ever since the former education minister, Dr Kemp, the member for Goldstein, introduced the SES formula. Whatever the modellers intended, I cannot believe that they deliberately designed this system to divert higher levels of public funds to the wealthiest and best endowed private schools at the expense of not only government schools but also the less wealthy majority of non-government schools, particularly most of the Catholic school education system, which are poorer in capital, endowments and the ability to charge fees. Catholic parents make great efforts to send their children to Catholic schools and also raise funds for the schools. It is a disgrace that we have a funding formula which benefits category 1 schools, most favoured by members and supporters of the frontbench who send their children there, while disadvantaging the vast majority of independent schools, including the Catholic schools, such as the excellent Christian Brothers College in East St Kilda in my electorate.

Catholic schools are not the only schools which are disadvantaged by the funding scheme the Howard government has introduced. As the minister pointed out, there are several Jewish schools in my electorate, which has the highest Jewish population proportion in any federal electorate. These schools all have SES ratings of between 110 and 121, putting them at the upper end of the ratings ladder and thus placing them at the lowest level of assistance under the present system. By comparison, the three best-known former category 1 elite private schools in my electorate, Melbourne Grammar, Wesley College and Caulfield Grammar, have SES ratings of 121, 118 and 115 respectively. Frankly, it is farcical that a gravel covered college like Yeshiva College, which has an SES rating only 1 point higher than Caulfield Grammar School and a couple of points below Wesley College, is compared to those schools. If anyone ever visited these two schools the disparity in income, endowments, physical circumstances and their capital is astonishing, yet they receive the same level of assistance under this so-called needs based funding formula set up by Dr Kemp.

These schools in my electorate are excellent schools. They all have high levels of academic achievement and the best facilities that the parents and communities associated with them can afford. But they do not have the fantastic facilities of say, Melbourne Grammar, which has just opened a magnificent new sporting complex in Port Melbourne. For instance, Leibler Yavneh College in Elsternwick does not have a swimming pool. It has two tennis courts—and this for a school with nearly 600 students. Yet, according to the SES formula adopted by the current government, Melbourne Grammar and Leibler Yavneh College are placed on exactly the same level in terms of funding that they receive. Any reasonable person visiting both schools would conclude that either Melbourne Grammar is being overfunded or that Leibler Yavneh is being underfunded, or both. On Monday, the minister sought to suggest that the funding for Jewish schools in my electorate in particular—and I really thought his objection was very offensive—would somehow be put at risk under the policies of the opposition. In fact, under any reasonable funding formula, most of these schools would be better off not worse off. This has been repeatedly assured by the shadow education spokesman, who has visited all of these schools with me over the last few years. I will quote the education policy adopted at the ALP national conference earlier this year:

quote.para: Labor continues to respect the right of parents to choose a non-government school for their children and, on the basis of educational and financial need, for these schools to receive public funding consistent with the MCEETYA principles outlined above.

speech.para: The principles referred to are those of the Ministerial Council on Education, Employment, Training and Youth Affairs. They include, among other things, the principle that public funding across different schools and sectors should be distributed fairly and equitably and that public funding for schooling must support the right of families to choose non-government schooling and must support non-government schools on the basis of need. The policy continues:

quote.para: Labor rejects the Howard Government's unfair and divisive funding arrangements for schools, which have delivered the largest increases in Commonwealth funding to some of the best-resourced schools in Australia. Labor will adopt new funding arrangements for non-government schools that reflect the following principles:
—Commonwealth and state and Territory funding policies and arrangements will be aligned to provide a coherent national approach to funding conditions, mechanisms and accountabilities;
—the resources available to non-government schools, including income from private sources, will be considered when assessing financial need—

speech.para: This, of course, is one of the great faults in the current government's addressing of this issue, particularly in relation to the elite private schools. Not only does the government not take into consideration the huge fees these schools are able to charge—which, of course, the parents of today are often making great efforts to pay—but also it does not take into consideration the massive endowments and great capital that these schools already have. In my view, the huge increases in federal government funding that some of these elite private category 1 schools are getting are undermining public support for the level of funding that they and all independent schools should receive. Labor's policy continues:

quote.para: —public funding should be subject to non-government schools meeting quality standards for curriculum and teaching, planning arrangements that promote the economic use of public resources and accountability and reporting conditions that are consistent with those required by governments for schools in the public sector.

speech.para: I have no doubt that Catholic and Jewish schools in my electorate will meet these criteria and will be no worse off—and probably better off—than they are at present. I turn to another area of appropriations that I think has seen a serious abuse in my electorate. Very unusually for Melbourne Ports, it is the issue of the Australian defence budget—namely, the use of defence resources to promote commercial activities. As honourable members know, the Australian Grand Prix is held every year in Albert Park in my electorate. It will be held next week. There is widespread participation by Australians in this event and some enjoyment by Victorians right across the state. I do not denigrate that, but citizens in Middle Park, St Kilda, Elwood, South Melbourne, South Yarra, Albert Park and Port Melbourne constantly deluge me with complaints about the noise caused by the annual fly over of an F18 fighter bomber from the Royal Australian Air Force that coincides with the Grand Prix.

No-one who knows my record would ever accuse me of being against the defence establishment or anti-RAAF. It is absolutely appropriate that the Roulettes flying exhibition team participate in this event but, for reasons that I will outline, the participation of serious aircraft like the F18 is inappropriate. Every year since 1996 my constituents have objected to this fly over, which takes place over one day, at a low level over the most densely populated suburban areas in Australia. The F18's extremely loud boom frightens many people, particularly children and the elderly. It terrifies household pets. But the worst aspect of this Grand Prix fly over is the waste of defence resources and public funds. Last year I succeeded in getting the government to reveal the cost of this exercise. The assistant defence minister, Mrs Vale, informed me that the direct costs of the fly over amounted to $697,969, with $23,201 for fuel—a total of $721,170. No doubt it will cost more this year.

At a time when this country has major defence commitments in Iraq, East Timor, the Solomons and other places, and when the defence budget and our defence personnel are stretched to the limit, in my view it is a scandalous waste of money that $720,000 is used to fly an F18 over an inner suburban area to promote a commercial car race—a race that is highly profitable and is run by the billionaire Mr Bernie Ecclestone. The House should recall that the Grand Prix is a private commercial event operated for profit. I have no objection to people making a profit by staging public entertainment events, but it is outrageous that we should expect the taxpayer to provide Grand Prix entertainment in order to boost their profits.

When the Howard government came to power in 1996 and began this policy of subsidising the Grand Prix—no doubt as a favour to the then Premier of Victoria, Mr Kennett, and his business friends—the then Minister for Defence, John Moore, said the annual cost of the fly-over was about $200,000. It is striking that the cost of this exercise has more than trebled in eight years. I ask honourable members opposite: why is the Howard government, which has made such major commitments of our defence forces overseas, and which makes so much of its support for defence personnel, providing more and more expensive entertainment for the Grand Prix? What equipment or amenities are our service men and women on active service overseas being deprived of so that $720,000 can be wasted in this way for one fly over of Mr Ecclestone's Grand Prix?

Finally, I want to raise again the continuing crisis of administration in Centrelink. Recently, Windsor Centrelink, which is just outside my electorate but serves many of my constituents, held an open day. As usual, my staff went along to this open day—usually I go as well—and were impressed by the dedication and sincerity of the Centrelink staff, whom we know and work with. My office nearly always finds them to be cooperative and sympathetic when we raise particular problems that are being experienced by Centrelink clients. The fact remains, however, that Centrelink is structured in a way that makes it grossly inefficient and indifferent—indeed sometimes hostile—to the needs of its clients.

This is not the fault of Centrelink's staff or even Centrelink's management; it is the fault of the government and successive ministers for family and community services. At the bidding of the Prime Minister and Treasurer, they have deliberately designed a system which punishes Centrelink clients by pushing them out of the system for trivial reasons, without explaining those reasons adequately, and then makes it very difficult for them, even with the assistance of the office of a member of parliament, to regain access to the system. My office—like, no doubt, the offices of most other members and certainly the members on this side of the House—deals with a steady stream of Centrelink clients, many of them elderly and from non-English speaking backgrounds, who have received letters from Centrelink telling them that their benefits are being cut off or reduced for reasons which they do not understand. They tell us that they cannot get Centrelink to take their phone calls or answer their letters and they cannot get a straight answer to the most basic questions about their circumstances. As I hope I have outlined, there are a number of appropriations of this government that could be highly questioned.

talk.start.para: —I have made the point in this place before about the hard-nosed attitude that banks have in pursuit of profit and about their hard-nosed attitude to customers, whom they seem to see as a distraction from the real business of making money. Indeed, in the past I have noted that studies by the Labor Party have shown that (1) Australia's bank accounts are second only to Canada as being the most expensive in the world, (2) Australia is one of the most concentrated banking markets in the world and has one of the most concentrated markets for retail transaction accounts, and (3) banks have created a bank-fee poverty trap which poor customers are often unable to escape.

speech.para: It is as true today as when I first raised this issue to say that banks are the most profitable businesses in the Australian economy. One has to wonder then why we see the costs of banking services continuing to rise, why we see banking services continually being withdrawn and why services are made harder for customers to access on a face-to-face basis. All of the above, of course, form part of the reason that community banks in Australia have attracted the attention of a service-starved public seeking customer-friendly products delivered face to face.

I am very pleased to have had a close working relationship through my office with the launch of the Kingsway Community Bank as a branch of the Bendigo Bank. This bank launched its prospectus last November, and the realisation of many people's expectations came a step closer recently when plans for the new bank were lodged with the City of Wanneroo in Perth's northern suburbs. I want to compliment chairman Bill Meredith for the work he has done and for the work of the board. Bill has on his board: Rachel Dodge, as a hardworking and dedicated secretary; Joe Hawkins; Edith Slade; Alison Thomson; Patricia Tassell; Alan Green; Laurin Lang and John Halligan. In addition, associate members Stan and Elaine McEntee and Bernie Tynas continue to make a strong contribution to the Kingsway Community Bank. I know everyone involved is hoping that the building program will be finished in about three months. Indeed, on 28 March a groundbreaking ceremony will be conducted as another step in the determination of this community to have its own bank. I congratulate all involved and, like them, I look forward to the day that the bank opens its doors. I will be one of its customers.

The next issue I want to deal with relates to the Wanneroo cadet unit, which operates out of Wanneroo Senior High School. These cadets do a great job, not only on Anzac Day when they parade at the local Wanneroo Anzac service but also in attending the annual fete at Belgrade Village and in assisting the seniors there. They assist the community in other ways, but they particularly assist the seniors. It came as a shock recently for the cadets and their parents to learn that their unit was to be amalgamated with another unit in the neighbouring local authority of Joondalup. Taking something from Wanneroo and relocating it to Joondalup is simply not a popular thing to do up in the northern suburbs. Fortunately, I was able to make an approach to Fran Bailey, the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Defence. Fran kindly and quickly arranged a meeting for me with her office and senior officers in Canberra to discuss the matter. I thank the member for McEwen for her understanding and sympathetic response to this important issue. The result is that the Wanneroo cadets have been given a stay of execution and have been given time to recruit numbers and to show that they can sustain those numbers over a period of time. This is an important local issue, and I now urge the broader community to get behind this cadet unit and these young Australians. I know the parent group are keen to see this unit continue, and I trust that they will get the support they need. I know too that Dot Newton, as a local councillor and parent of a cadet, has the support of the City of Wanneroo. I wish them well in their endeavours to see that this important cadet unit continues.

Like a lot of others in this place, I have been a cadet. I know I had tremendous fun with my mates in the cadet unit of the day, and I know the tremendous benefit that I got out of being in cadets. I think today, when there are so many pressures on and so many diversions available to young people, it is important that we do keep these cadet units running, and it is important that we give these young people support through the community to enable them to be involved in cadets. I think it is a great thing for young men and young women to be involved in and they certainly have my support.

The third and last issue I want to deal with tonight relates to a bloke by the name of Mick O'Mallon. Mick is a TPI Australian SAS veteran of Borneo and 7RAR in Vietnam. Mick is living in Vietnam on his pension only and is unable to afford the cost of travel for himself, his wife—he married in Vietnam—and two children to come to Australia. Mick has had a run of bad times, and it is hoped that individuals and associations in the veteran community will get behind Mick and help to bring this Australian home. I am very grateful to a bloke by the name of Lex McAulay from Queensland who has put together a bit of a story about Mick, and I want to put it on the record. Lex McAulay wrote:

quote.para: Mick's next tour of duty was in Vietnam with 7RAR, as a forward scout. After RTA—

speech.para: that is, return to Australia—

quote.para: he spent the rest of the time when we were involved in that war as an instructor, and was about to take his discharge when he was interviewed about joining the military police. Mick's prior experience had been as one of those hunted by the provosts, and he thought it was a joke, but the provosts were undergoing a big change and Mick spent the rest of his Army service with the RACMP—

speech.para: that is, the Royal Australian Corps of the Military Police. I might say that, despite that, there are still a lot of veterans who are happy to help him. Lex McAulay continues:

quote.para: Mick tried various small business enterprises without success and spent some time in the NSW Department of Corrective Services as a guard in the Goulburn jail, and later as supervisor in the forestry section of the department. This ended in a dispute originated by Mick over workplace safety. He became a T&PI at this time and the department was able to send him on his way on the grounds that PTSD—

speech.para: that is, post-traumatic stress disorder—

quote.para: was a previously existing condition before he joined them.
Along the way, Mick had lost out in three marriages with property settlements leaving him with nothing. Yes, some blokes are a glutton for punishment.

About five years ago, Mick was in Melbourne for Anzac Day, wondering what to do with his life, when he literally tripped on a sign board outside a travel agency. They advertised visits to Vietnam. Mick walked up and down past the shop for three days before he went in to ask about the Vietnam tours. By this time, the shop staff were about to ring the police; Mick is not an oil painting, either.

During the visit to Vietnam, he met a local lady who is now his wife and the mother of their 4-year-old. Mick is also step-father to her son from a previous relationship. Mick has been living in Saigon/HCMC—

speech.para: that is, Ho Chi Minh City.

quote.para: Mick has been busy for almost four years as the voluntary and unpaid Secretary (Vietnam) of the Australian Vietnam Veterans Reconstruction Group who undertake charitable civil projects in those areas where we operated.
Prospects for the O'Mallon family are not good in Vietnam. Mick needs the health care available here and he and his wife want to give the boys the prospect of a better education and circumstances.

Mick's T&PI payment and a small army pension are barely enough for survival in Vietnam yet alone meet the financial burden of applying for visas—expensive—and the travel costs for four people plus resettlement costs. It is beyond Mick's ability to extricate himself and his family without our help. Therefore, some of us have decided to contact as many Vietnam veterans and veterans' associations as possible to inform them of Mick's situation, and ask that financial assistance ... be donated ...
In this way we can bring back to Australia an Aussie with two tours of frontline active service, who has had his share of hard knocks, and give two kids a better chance at life.
Please give this serious consideration. If the veterans do not help Mick, no one else will.

speech.para: That is the end of the story, which is very well put together by Lex McAulay.

Graham Smith, who is an ex-6RAR soldier and an existing committee member for the restoration of the Long Tan Cross, is one of those who is helping to coordinate the support that the veteran community is trying to put together to get Mick home. Mick O'Mallon has done a great job in Vietnam working with the Australian Vietnam Veterans Reconstruction Group, a group of which I have the pleasure to be patron, and I know that he has done an immense amount of work in helping to preserve and keep open the area where the Battle of Long Tan was fought. I approached the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs to find out whether there were any circumstances in which the application fee—which, from memory, is some $850—for the visa that Mick would have to apply for in Vietnam could be waived. The answer was that there are no circumstances in which that fee can be waived. Fortunately, the Vietnam Veterans Association in North Brisbane have decided that they will put up the money to cover the cost for this application.

I think it is a tremendous thing that the Vietnam veteran community is doing to try to get behind this bloke and get him and his family back here to Australia. The issue raised by Lex McAuley is that, once again, if the veterans do not help Mick, no-one else will. I think that is very true. It is very encouraging to see that people like Normie Rowe are prepared to put together a fundraising concert where all of the proceeds—apart from the administrative costs, of course—will go to this push to get Mick O'Mallon and his family back here to Australia.

I wish all of these people well in their endeavours to assist Mick. I know that the Minister for Veterans' Affairs and a group of other veterans who were recently in Vietnam—I think last year—had the opportunity to meet Mick. I am sure that they, as leaders of their associations—the Vietnam Veterans Federation, the Vietnam Veterans association and the RSL—could collectively pool their resources and networks and help this bloke come home. I wanted to put this issue on the record in Hansard. I hope that the community can get together the necessary support, enthusiasm and degree of mateship to ensure that one of their own is looked after. I thank the House for its attention.

talk.start.para: —In rising to speak on the Appropriation Bill (No. 3) 2003-2004 and cognate bills, I want to talk about issues that affect my electorate of Bendigo. I refer to the first outrage: a 25 per cent fee rip-off inflicted by the Howard government on the students at La Trobe University in Bendigo. The decision by La Trobe University to increase HECS fees by the full 25 per cent, because of the Howard government's user-pays principle of higher education funding, has dealt a bitter blow to regional Victorian families who are already struggling to provide higher education for their kids. On the government's own figures, students attending La Trobe University in Bendigo in 2002 incurred a total HECS debt of nearly $6 million for that year. The figures, which I believe are an underestimate, were provided by the education minister, Dr Nelson, in reply to a question from me on the Notice Paper. The answer showed that the debt incurred in just that year by students deferring payments of tertiary fees totalled $5,878. The Howard government has failed to reveal the total HECS debt incurred to date by La Trobe students, but I understand the total HECS debt accumulated by those students could be close to $50 million—little wonder that it will not come clean on the figure.

speech.para: The Howard government's fee rip-off has put one huge millstone around the neck of central Victorian students. They cannot afford to pay the heavily increased fees, and they have to go to new levels of debt for more years to pay the government back. The minister's answer shows that the Howard government, after taking office in 1996, dramatically jacked up tertiary fees at La Trobe University in Bendigo. They pushed them up from the existing flat rate of $2,442 per year for all courses, which they inherited under the Keating government, to three new big differential levels which are set in 2004 at $3,768 a year per course or one group of courses, $5,242 for another and $6,283 for another.

Under the 25 per cent fee increase imposed by the federal government policy on La Trobe University, these fees will murderously slam in one hit as follows: fees for band 1 courses, including arts, humanities and nursing, will rise in 2005 by $942 a year from $3,768 to $4,710. This is a massive $1,326 increase—a 54 per cent increase on the Keating government levels of 1996, when the rate was just $2,442. Fees for band 2 courses, including other health sciences, maths, computing, business and economics, will rise by $1,342 from $5,376 to $6,708. This is a Howard government increase of $4,266—a 175 per cent increase on the 1996 level. Fees for band 3 courses, including law at the La Trobe Bendigo campus, will rise by $1,572 from $6,283 to $7,854. This is an increase of $5,412 when compared with the 1996 levels, which represents an increase of some 221 per cent.

At present, the average HECS debt for students at La Trobe University in Bendigo, for all courses, is around $3,130 per year. This estimate is based on what I think are more accurate figures than the minister has quoted. So, on average, a three-year course for a student deferring fees at present costs around $9,390, a four-year course costs around $12,520 and a five-year course costs around $15,650. The impact of the devastating new 25 per cent increases is to jack up the average HECS cost of a course at Bendigo by $783 per year or by $2,346 for a three-year course and by $3,915 for a five-year course. In other words, a 25 per cent fee increase jacks up the average HECS cost of a course at La Trobe University by between $2,346 for a three-year course and $3,915 for a five-year course.

The Howard government is shifting the cost of education onto students and their families. They have turned Fawlty Towers—a familiar name for the La Trobe University at Bendigo—into a simple tax office. So what is the overall impact on the student population? On the education minister's figures, the total debt incurred for the whole population at La Trobe's Bendigo campus in 2002 was around $6 million. On those figures, students have now copped an extra $1.5 million in debt per year. Their total HECS debt for just one year will jump from $6 million to $7.5 million. Let us look at the likely impact on just one other group of students—those undertaking a computer course at La Trobe University's Bendigo campus. The 25 per cent hike in federal tertiary fees imposed on La Trobe University's Bendigo students will cost a computing student around $5,000 more in debt and take an extra two years to pay off. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

debate.para: The following answers to questions were circulated:

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 15 September 2003:

quote.para: What was the cost per aircraft of acquiring and installing ground to air missile counter measure capability on RAAF C130 Hercules aircraft.

talker.name: Brough, Mal, MP
Mr Brough
talker.role: Minister for Employment Services and Minister Assisting the Minister for Defence

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

answer.para: (1) The cost of acquiring and installing ground to air missile counter measure capability on RAAF C130 Hercules aircraft was A$4.3375 million per aircraft. Four aircraft were modified at a total cost of A$17.35 million.

talk.start.para: asked the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 18 September 2003:

question.para: (1) In which court and tribunal matters did he intervene or otherwise appear as a party in 2002-2003.
(2) In respect of each matter, what was the (a) name, (b) court or tribunal, (c) matter number, (d) date of his intervention or appearance, and (e) cost of his intervention or participation.
(3) In respect of each matter, did he make written or oral submissions or both.

talk.start.para: asked the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 18 September 2003:

quote.para: Further to the answers to questions Nos 1620 to 1635 and 1637 (Hansard, 12 August 2003, page 18168) what are the Chief Executive Officers of the Minister's departments and agencies doing to ensure that they do not retain the services of any barrister or solicitor who has previously been made bankrupt.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: The Attorney-General's Department and its portfolio agencies brief counsel in accordance with Appendix D to the Legal Services Directions issued by the Attorney-General under the Judiciary Act 1903, Directions on Engagement of Counsel.

The Government's policy in relation to briefing of counsel was set out in the letter of 21 March 2001 from the then Attorney-General to all Ministers, asking Departments and agencies to take steps to ensure that they did not brief counsel who used insolvency as a means of avoiding tax. The policy is not directed at preventing the briefing of all counsel who are, or have been, insolvent.
When the Department and its agencies need to brief counsel they rely on advice, in particular, from in-house and external solicitors to engage counsel in accordance with this policy.
Both the Office of Legal Services Coordination and the Australian Government Solicitor provide assistance to agencies to enable them to comply with the policy.

talk.start.para: asked the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 9 October 2003:

question.para: (1) Further to the answer to question No. 1552 (Hansard, 7 October 2003, page 20694), what are the changes to bankruptcy law aimed at preventing people using bankruptcy in an improper way.
(2) Why has it taken the Insolvency and Trustee Service Australia and the Attorney-General's Department since February 2003 to brief him on options to progress this matter.
(3) Will he introduce legislation to ensure that the individual who has been bankrupted on twelve occasions cannot ever be declared bankrupt again; if so, when; if not, why not.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) The Bankruptcy Legislation Amendment Act 2002:
(a) removed early discharge provisions that have permitted some people to be bankrupt for only six months
(b) increased the debt agreement income threshold by 50 per cent, to about $46,800 after tax, to encourage more use of debt agreements as an alternative to bankruptcy

(c) introduced a new discretion for Official Receivers to reject a debtor's petition where it appears that the debtor can afford to pay their debts and the petition is an abuse of the bankruptcy system
(d) strengthened trustee powers to object to the discharge from bankruptcy of uncooperative bankrupts after the standard three-year bankruptcy period; and
(e) confirmed the Court's power to annul a bankruptcy if the bankruptcy petition was an abuse of process, even if the debtor is insolvent.

I intend to introduce legislation to address the issue identified in the High Court decision in Cook v Benson, which will allow a trustee to claw back excessive personal superannuation contributions. I also intend to introduce legislation which will change the treatment of assets to prevent the use of family law and bankruptcy in shielding a bankrupt's assets from a trustee. I also intend to introduce legislation to improve confidence in arrangements under Part X of the Bankruptcy Act 1966.

(2) The recommendations made by the Joint Taskforce which examined these issues and the suggestions for change put forward in the issues paper released in November 2002 are complex and required sustained discussion with a wide range of stakeholders in order to provide informed advice to Government.
(3) I intend to introduce legislation aimed at preventing anyone using bankruptcy in an improper way.

subdebateinfo.title: Defence: Abrams M1 Main Battle Tanks
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 2724)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 5 November 2003:

question.para: (1) Is the Government considering the acquisition of Abrams M1 Main battle tanks (MBT) for the Australian Army; if so, (a) what version or versions of the Abrams tank is or are being considered, and (b) what role is envisaged for the Abrams tanks.
(2) Does consideration of the acquisition of Abrams MBTs reflect an increased priority for MBTs in the ADF's force structure; if so, what is the strategic basis for that increased priority.

(3) Does consideration of the Abrams tank reflect a decision to develop new types of capability in the land force not contemplated by the Government's current defence policy as set out in the Defence 2000 White Paper.

(4) Does consideration of the Abrams tank reflect a decision to develop heavy armoured forces suitable for contributions to coalition operations in high-intensity conflict; if so, what other additional equipment would be required to develop such new types of capabilities; if not, what factors would warrant the acquisition of a tank of this nature.

(5) Is consideration being given to acquisition of self-propelled artillery, self-propelled air defence, and the logistics capabilities required to constitute an independent armoured capability; if so, what would be the total cost of such new types of capabilities; if not, is it intended that these tanks would only be used as a contribution to allied forces and rely on allies for vital combat support.
(6) What do the versions being considered weigh and how does this compare with the weight of the Leopard tank.
(7) What implications would the weight of the Abrams tank have for the Australian Defence Force's (ADF) ability to deploy the tanks within Australia's region and beyond.
(8) Could the Abrams tank be transported in the ADF's current landing ships and troop lift ships.
(9) Would the landing ships and troop lift ships need to be modified to transport the Abrams; if so, what would that cost.
(10) Would the current tank-transport fleet need to be upgraded or replaced to transport the Abrams tanks; if so, what would that cost.
(11) Would the ADF's current bridging capability need to be upgraded to handle the Abrams tanks; if so, what would that cost.
(12) Would the ADF's servicing and support facilities need to be upgraded to accommodate the Abrams tanks; if so, what would that cost.
(13) Would the Abrams tanks be based in Darwin; if not, where would they be based.

(14) Would Abrams tanks acquired for the ADF be powered by gas turbine; if so, (a) what would be the logistical implications for this form of power for fuel supplies to ADF operations, and (b) would ADF fuel-handling capabilities need to be upgraded; if so, what would be the cost.
(15) How many tanks is the Government considering acquiring.
(16) What implications does any cut in tank numbers have for the ADF's capacity for training, deployment and concurrent operations.
(17) Taking into account all the issues raised in this question and any other costs arising consequent on a decision to acquire Abrams tanks, what would be the total cost of this acquisition.
(18) What are the deficiencies in the ADF's current tank capabilities which fall short of the Government's strategic requirements.
(19) What other approaches have been considered to address those deficiencies and what would those other approaches cost.

talker.name: Brough, Mal, MP
Mr Brough
talker.role: Minister for Employment Services and Minister Assisting the Minister for Defence

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

answer.para: (1) Yes, the updated version of the M1A1 Abrams is one of the options to be considered: (a) The versions of the Abrams being considered are the M1A1 AIM (D) and the M1A1 AIM (D) + ; (b) It will be employed as part of the manoeuvre element in our combined arms teams.
(2) No. The acquisition of a replacement tank reflects appropriate maintenance of balance within our combined arms force structure.
(3) No. The replacement of our tank fleet is entirely within the capability guidelines given in the Defence White Paper, Defence 2000: Our future Defence Force.

(4) No. The consideration of procuring a replacement tank is entirely consistent with the Government's policy position. Paragraph 6.39 of the Defence White Paper states that: “We aim to provide our forces with a clear margin of superiority against any credible adversary. We will plan to give our forces a high chance of success and survival”.

The types of tanks currently under consideration provide the level of crew protection and survivability that the Australian Defence Force requires. This improvement in the survivability of close combat elements will ensure that our land forces “have the combat weight they need to achieve their missions without undue risk”, (Defence White Paper, Defence 2000: Our future Defence Force, paragraph 8.12).

(5) Acquisition projects for the modernisation of many elements of the Army's combined arms capability are contained in the Defence Capability Plan. All projects are scoped and funded to provide a fully supportable capability not merely platform replacement.
(6) Tanks under consideration range from approximately 55 tonnes to approximately 64 tonnes. The current vehicle has a combat weight of 42.5 tonnes.
(7) The same issues which have to be considered for the deployment of the Leopard 1 Main Battle Tank.
(8) Yes.
(9) The tanks can be lifted on and off the current landing and troop lift ships.
(10) The current tank transporter fleet will be replaced in any case. The tank replacement program may fund the early introduction of those replacement vehicles.
(11) The in service Medium Girder Bridge and the Floating Support bridge are both MLC 70 capable.
(12) The servicing and support requirements for the tank fleet will change for any replacement fleet. The cost has been factored into the program estimates.
(13) There is no plan to change the disposition of the tank regiment.

(14) All baseline Abrams variants are equipped with a gas turbine motor. Australia would not intend to change the design.: (a) The Abrams would not impose additional types of fuel supplies on the ADF. (b) Additional tactical fuellers would be acquired for an Abrams tank.
(15) Tabling of exact numbers required for the acquisition at this stage may prejudice future negotiations with the relevant suppliers.
(16) Any replacement fleet will include sufficient quantities of vehicles and systems for training, deployment and concurrent operations.
(17) Exact program costs are commercially sensitive and tabling them would prejudice future negotiations with the relevant suppliers.

(18) The current tank fleet represents a superseded design which has marginal survivability and lethality capabilities. It has very limited potential for Network Enabled Operations and as an orphan fleet represents a high risk cost spiral in terms of through life support. These limitations will become greater over the next 10 - 15 years.
(19) Extensive platform upgrade and substitution with different capabilities options have been studied and discarded due to cost benefit, capability and schedule issues.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts, upon notice, on 5 November 2003:

question.para: (1) Has he seen the report by Tim Rutten titled “Producer tells of the politics of Fox” in the Sydney Morning Herald on 3 November 2003 in which Mr Charlie Reina alleged that “Editorially, the Fox News Channel newsroom is under the constant control and vigilance of management”.
(2) Is he able to say how interference in the editorial independence of an Australian newsroom by a media owner could be in the public interest or good for Australia's democracy; if not, why not.
(3) Can he explain whether the Broadcasting Services Amendment (Media Ownership) Bill 2002 would allow further concentration of media ownership in Australia; if not, why not.
(4) Will he now abandon this Bill; if not why not.

talker.name: Williams, Daryl, MP
Mr Williams
talker.role: Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) Yes.
(2) Reference is made to part (2) of the answer given to the honourable member's question on notice No. 2278 (Hansard 3 December 2003, page 23305).

(3) The Bill allows Australian companies to be competitive on an international stage by realising the benefits of scale and scope that cross-media mergers can provide. Well resourced media companies that do not have to rely solely on cost cutting for improving profitability are more likely to deliver the program diversity and high quality news and information services the public desire. The Bill also increases the competitiveness of small to medium-sized firms and new entrants, by allowing them to attain the necessary economies of scale and scope to compete effectively against the larger incumbents.

At the same time, amendments previously made to the Broadcasting Services Amendment (Media Ownership) Bill 2002 provide strong safeguards to protect diversity of news and media opinion, and prevent market dominance by any media group. These include:

an amendment stipulating that a cross-media merger cannot be approved unless five independently owned commercial media outlets (across radio, associated newspapers and television) in metropolitan markets, and four in regional markets, remain in the market after the cross-media acquisition occurs;
an extension of the `two out of three rule' to metropolitan markets;

a restriction on newspaper ownership to one newspaper per market where the person also holds a cross-media exemption certificate for that market (relevant newspapers are those included on the ABA's Associated Newspaper Register); and
a requirement to review the ownership and control provisions in three years time.

(4) No. The Government made an election commitment to reform Australia's media ownership laws. Without reform, the current media ownership laws will restrict the Australian media sector to an outdated structure with little or no capacity for new players, improved competition, or the ability to respond to a rapidly evolving and converging international media environment.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 6 November 2003:

question.para: (1) What representations did the then Member for Flinders, the Hon. Peter Reith, or his staff make in respect of the application by the Western Port Oberon Association for a Centenary of Federation grant.
(2) How did the relocation of the decommissioned Otama meet the criteria for a Centenary of Federation grant.
(3) When did the Western Port Oberon Association receive advice that its Centenary of Federation grant application was successful.
(4) Who were the office bearers of the Western Port Oberon Association, Hastings, in March 2001 and who signed its application for the Centenary of Federation grant.
(5) Is the Western Port Oberon Association an incorporated body.
(6) How does the project relate to the Federation of Australia 1901.

talker.name: Brough, Mal, MP
Mr Brough
talker.role: Minister for Employment Services and Minister Assisting the Minister for Defence

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question as follows:

answer.para: (1) To the best of my knowledge, the then Member for Flinders made three representations to the then Minister for Defence, the Hon John Moore MP, to acquire the vessel on behalf of the Western Port Oberon Association. However, no reference to a Centenary of Federation grant was made on any of these occasions.
(2) The Department of Defence did not administer the Centenary of Federation grants, and as such was not privy to the approval criteria.

(3) The granting of Centenary of Federation funds to the Western Port Oberon Association was announced in a media release on 3 October 2001 by the then Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Defence, the Hon Dr Brendan Nelson MP.
(4) Defence did not administer the Centenary of Federation grants, and as such was not privy to the signatories to the grant. The office bearers of the Western Port Association in March 2001 were:
Mr James (Max) Bryant - President;
Mr Bob Sheppard - Vice President;
Mr Phil Solomon - Secretary;
Mr Geoff Allman - Treasurer;
Mr Darryl Massie - Association Lawyer;
Mr Barry Wright - Project Technical Officer;
Mr Bob Roff - Community Liaison Officer;
Mr David Renouf - Local Government Liaison Officer; and,
Mr John Ord - RSL Liaison & Environment Officer.
(5) Yes, as at 2 March 2001.

(6) The project commemorates the Royal Australian Navy and, in particular, its submariners. The Victorian Colonial Navy was the largest component transferred to the new Australian Commonwealth Navy on 1 March 1901, and the region in which the project will stand has a strong naval heritage.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Health and Ageing, upon notice, on 27 November 2003:

question.para: (1) Is he aware that in Australia the rate of newly diagnosed cases of HIV has increased over the past year, particularly among indigenous Australians.
(2) What is the Government's current level of support for HIV prevention efforts within Australia.

(3) Can he confirm that the World Health Organisation and UNAIDS estimated that public sector spending on HIV vaccine research and development amounted to less than 1% of spending on all health and pharmaceutical related research and development in 2001.
(4) What is the Government's spending commitment to HIV vaccine research and development.
(5) Can he confirm that the Global Fund to Fight AIDS, Tuberculosis and Malaria recently announced that contributions to the fund are inadequate to meet its objectives.
(6) Can he confirm that Australia is the only western country that does not contribute to the Global Fund to Fight AIDS, Tuberculosis and Malaria; if so, can he explain the Government's position.
(7) Is the Government planning to contribute to the Global Fund to Fight AIDS, Tuberculosis and Malaria.
(8) Is he planning to attend the XV International AIDS Conference to be held in Bangkok in July 2004.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) I am aware of the increase in newly diagnosed cases of HIV over the past year. There has been an increase in the number of new diagnoses of HIV amongst Indigenous Australians, from 13 in 2001 to 23 in 2002. However, the overall number of infections in the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples remains small (180 new diagnoses since 1993) and fluctuates considerably from year to year.

(2) Australia's response to HIV/AIDS is considered to be among the best in the world, and has resulted in a sharp decline in deaths from AIDS since the mid-1990's. The Australian Government spends a total of approximately $48 million per year directly on HIV/AIDS initiatives. Of that $48 million, approximately $24 million per year is allocated through the Department of Health and Ageing for national HIV/AIDS education, prevention and promotion programs; HIV/AIDS research and surveillance; and Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander sexual health programs. Further funding is provided to States and Territories through the broadbanded Public Health Outcome Funding Agreements (PHOFAs) for the development and implementation of local State and Territory HIV strategies, including support for HIV testing. In 2002-03, States and Territories received a total of $124.2 million under the PHOFAs for national public health programs.

(3) The World Health Organisation and UNAIDS estimates that public sector spending on HIV vaccine research and development amounted to US$430-US$470 million in 2001. The International AIDS Vaccine Initiative reported in November 2002 that this expenditure accounts for less than 1% of global spending on health and pharmaceutical related research and development. According to the UNAIDS Progress Report on the Global Response to the HIV/AIDS Epidemic 2003, although definitive figures are not available, it is likely that spending on vaccine research and development in 2003 will significantly exceed 2001 levels.

(4) The majority of funding (around 70%) provided to the Australian Centre for Hepatitis and HIV Virology Research in 2003 was provided for HIV vaccine research and development. This constituted an amount of approximately $1.8 million. In addition, in 2003, the National Health and Medical Research Council funded 9 grants specifically for research into HIV/AIDS vaccines, totalling an amount of approximately $675,000. Funding for HIV vaccine research and development is only a small part of Australia's national research effort in HIV/AIDS and hepatitis C. The Australian Government currently provides approximately $14 million annually for this national research.

(5) The Global Fund to Fight AIDS, Tuberculosis and Malaria announced in July 2003, that without considerable increases in funding it will not have the resources to meet the anticipated cost of the next round of proposals it receives.

(6) On 18 February 2004, the Australian Government Minister for Foreign Affairs announced that Australia would contribute $25 million over the next three years to the Global Fund to Fight AIDS, Tuberculosis and Malaria.
(7) Yes. The Australian Government will contribute $25 million to the Global Fund over the next three years.
(8) A decision will be made by June 2004 regarding attendance.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Employment Services, upon notice, on 2 December 2003:

question.para: (1) How many people participated in work-for-the-dole during (a) 1996, (b) 1997, (c) 1998, (d) 1999, (e) 2000, (f) 2001, (g) 2002, and (h) 2003 in the postcode area (i) 3020, (ii) 3021, (iii) 3022, (iv) 3023, (v) 3029, (vi) 3030, (vii) 3036, (viii) 3037, (ix) 3038, and (x) 3335.

(2) What was the average length of time that participants were in receipt of benefits after participating in work-for-the-dole during (a) 1996, (b) 1997, (c) 1998, (d) 1999, (e) 2000, (f) 2001, (g) 2002, and (h) 2003 in the postcode area (i) 3020, (ii) 3021, (iii) 3022, (iv) 3023, (v) 3029, (vi) 3030, (vii) 3036, (viii) 3037, (ix) 3038, and (x) 3335.

talker.name: Brough, Mal, MP
Mr Brough
talker.role: Minister for Employment Services and Minister Assisting the Minister for Defence

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) Work for the Dole projects and participants are not allocated by postcode but rather, by Employment Service Area (ESA). The specific location of projects, job seekers and sponsors may not all be the same. On this occasion we have grouped your requested areas as closely as possible and the information is provided below.
Job seekers who have participated in Work for the Dole since the programme commenced in November 1997 in these postcodes are:
Total of job seekers who participated in Work for the Dole in the majority of the requested postcodes is 2335.

(2) Work for the Dole is a Mutual Obligation and work experience programme. Employment is not a stated objective of the programme. It is acknowledged however, that work experience is valuable and that continued engagement of a job seeker is vital in attaining an employment outcome.
The Department of Employment and Workplace Relations (DEWR) undertakes surveys of former employment assistance participants three months after exiting programmes.
The Post Programme Monitoring survey measures outcomes achieved by job seekers three months after they exit the Work for the Dole programme.
Around 32% of Work for the Dole participants are in employment or training three months after leaving the programme. This rises to 46% at the 12 month point.
Meaningful data for average length of time that participants were in receipt of benefits after participating in Work for the Dole are not available at this level.
